DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN ACQUISITIONS AND TAKEOVERS AMENDMENT (REGISTRATION OF INTERESTS) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Jenkins) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, relating to the registration of certain foreign interests in Australian property.
Motion (by Senator Jenkins) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.
SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

In a speech on an urgency motion in the Senate on 23 May 1990, I set out the general arguments for a register of foreign ownership of Australian land, property, businesses and resources. I do not intend to rehearse all those arguments again. Honourable senators will find them in the Hansard at pages 883-887.

I also drew the Senate's attention to the deep concern of the public with regard to the question of foreign investment and foreign ownership. During the last two years I have sent out some thousands of questionnaires to newly enrolled voters in Western Australia. Each questionnaire sought to ascertain whether these voters agreed with, or disagreed with, or had no opinion about twenty matters. One of the questions was about the long-standing proposal of the Democrats to establish a register of foreign ownership.

Many hundreds of these questionnaires were returned. The question with regard to which there was the highest agreement with the position of the Australian Democrats was the question of a foreign ownership register. Although we did not keep a precise count, I would estimate that not less than eighty per cent, and probably ninety per cent, of respondents expressed agreement with the proposition for the establishment of such a register.

Foreign ownership of Australian assets is a burning issue out there in the electorate and as senators we are morally bound to pay attention to the concerns of the people who have sent us here to represent them.

In response to concerns in the United States about the level of foreign ownership in 1988 the United States House of Representatives passed the Foreign Ownership Disclosure Act. The speech by Representative Frost of Texas describes the purposes of the legislation which is similarly applicable to the Australian environment, and I quote:

`Mr Speaker, H.R. 5410 provides for the registration of foreign interests in US business or real estate in order that our Government might know the extent to which foreign investors have significant or controlling interest in US business and real estate. Since 1982, foreign investment has more than doubled exceeding $1.2 trillion, yet our Government, unlike many other governments who impose strict and detailed reporting requirements on foreign investors, does not have a complete and accurate accounting of the extent to which foreigners own or control American businesses and real estate. H.R. 5410 seeks to make that information available to the US Government to ensure that national security is not endangered by concentrated foreign interests in various industries in our Nation'.

As Representative Frost correctly pointed out, other countries exert very firm control over foreign investment-particularly those former colonial countries which have in the past experienced at first hand the disadvantages of being slaves to foreign economic control and domination. We should heed the harsh lessons of their bitter experience.

There is a growing chasm between the level of foreign investment which the present Government considers acceptable and the level that the Australian public considers appropriate. The government appears to be confident that virtually all foreign investment is benign and that it is to be encouraged and welcomed. The Australian people are not so naive. They understand that a family which progressively sells off its assets in order to sustain a lifestyle which is beyond its means is doomed to bankruptcy, poverty and powerlessness.

The entry of foreign banks into Australia has led to major problems which could have been avoided had a register existed. A register would have enabled a more cautious approach to competition between new entrants and established Australian banks. Instead of the massive and expensive advertising campaigns which the banks were locked into and which the ordinary bank account holders paid for, banks could have spent more of their resources in providing a better service to their customers. Rather we have seen banks forced to take more risks in their loans policies in their attempts to win business. Thus the Westpac group has suffered a major slump in profit because of bad debts as a result of injudicious lending to entrepreneurs and high fliers. That Group has been forced to make provision for a much increased rate of bad debts in future months.

In summary, if the banking industry is a test case of the advantages supposed to accrue to the Australian people from deregulation and foreign investment, then all the signs are that those advantages are illusory.

The lack of control over the influx of foreign players into key sectors of the business world is most strikingly demonstrated in the proposed sell off of television licences and the proposed entry of foreign ownership into the print media in Western Australia. The ability of foreign owners to manipulate the press should be an anathema not only to the Australian Democrats but to all members of the Senate and I cannot but believe that both the Government and the opposition would unite to prevent it.
The Minister for Communications, Mr Beazley, has the support of the Democrats when he states that:

``The Government believes it is vital that Australia's radio and television stations are owned and controlled by Australians because they are major outlets for political debate and the exploration of cultural identity.'' and

``Like other democracies around the world, we believe that it is of national importance that there is stringent limits on foreign ownership of the electronic media. There is strong public support for this policy, which acts to reinforce the requirements for certain levels of Australian programming content.''
Moves by the Government to restrict foreign ownership of radio and television stations in Australia to an absolute maximum of 20 per cent are therefore very welcome.
The establishment of the Foreign Register will be an effective method of monitoring the changes which will undoubtedly take place in ownership of the industry in the next few years.

The increase in foreign ownership of the Australian tourism industry, while not posing the same problems as foreign control of the media, is causing widespread concern and in terms of the sell off of real estate is widely regarded as contrary to the national interest.
For example, on Queensland's Gold Coast foreign investors were clearing development sites and leaving them idle wasteland in expectation that they would appreciate in value.

Other foreign investors in tourism are seeking full vertical integration. Overseas nationals can buy package tours to Australia in their own country, fly to Australia in aircraft belonging to their national airline, stay at resorts owned by corporations based in their own country, spending mainly in those resorts in shops owned by those same foreign corporations. Most of the profits of the overall enterprise are either generated in the home country at the point of original purchase of the package tour or repatriated to it from the resort in Australia. Australia gains little from this form of exploitation of our country as a tourism destination. A Register of Foreign Corporations will assist in identifying the extent of such integration.
The dilemma caused by not knowing who owns what in Australia and the consequences of this ignorance are well demonstrated in the mining and petroleum industry in Australia.

In Western Australia the level of foreign ownership of the mineral sands industry is not widely or accurately known. However, it is possible that all the major operators are partially foreign owned, and some no doubt foreign controlled. If the level of foreign ownership were known, the implications could be addressed. This is one industry in which the mechanism of transfer pricing is probably used to ensure that profits on Australian resources are mainly generated on the high seas, after those resources have left Australia-thus depriving Australia of taxation income.

The lack of a Register of Foreign Corporations allows foreign control to occur without Australians having an opportunity to understand the ramifications. I draw to the attention of the Senate the alarming situation which could result from the takeover of Carr Boyd Minerals by Ashton Mining Ltd. I alluded to this in a Notice of Motion to this place on 23 May 1990. Carr Boyd Minerals Mount Weld rare earth deposit is reported to be among the richest rare earth deposits in the world. Yet without a Foreign Corporations Register such a resource can quietly pass into foreign control without the opportunity for public debate about the ramifications.

The sale of Cable Sands' existing and proposed sand mines to foreign owners also has major ramifications not only for Western Australians but for Australia as a nation. In addition to the loss of economic benefits to Australia, a foreign owner has been granted rights to operate in very fragile and ecologically important coastal regions of Western Australia, including land designated as national park. The foreign ownership of mines is backed by very powerful mining legislation which puts the owner in a very strong negotiating position when dealing with the State and Federal Governments. The likely losers in the sell-off are the people of Australia. History demonstrates this only too well.

I point out to the Senate the enormous environmental damage being done in countries such as Burma, Papua New Guinea, Sarawak and the Philippines by foreign timber companies which are annihilating tropical rainforests to feed the developed world's insatiable appetite for sawn timber. Foreign companies operating in environments to which they have no long term commitment maximise their dollar profits, rip out the resource as rapidly as they can, seek to generate as much of the profit as possible in their own countries and leave the developing countries they exploit to attempt to deal with the resultant massive environmental degradation.

There is a clear and undeniable link between foreign ownership and environmental irresponsibility. The more we encourage foreign ownership, the more we hand over control of our environment to people who do not care about it, who do not understand its fragility and who will not have to live with the consequences of their actions. But our children and grandchildren will have to live with those consequences.

The tentacles of foreign ownership by giant corporations already affect significantly the Australian way of life. The people of Australia need to be informed and have the right to know the extent of this influence. A Register of Foreign Corporations is a simple and effective method of achieving this.

Despite statements to the contrary the gathering of data to compile and maintain a Register would not be costly as most of the information is already available from a variety of State government departments.
Queensland leads the way with the establishment of a State Register. If Queensland can do it I doubt that it is beyond the resources of this Government to at least match what has been achieved there.
We can hardly become the clever country which the Prime Minister aspires to, if we do not ensure that Australia's rich resources benefit our nation rather than being sold for short term gain.

This Bill's provisions will not curb foreign ownership but its passage will establish a Register of Foreign Corporations which will enable us to find out how much of our country and of our economy is already under foreign control. It will also effectively monitor the extent of foreign ownership in key industries and the rate of increase (or decrease). As always, knowledge is power. Once we know what the true situation is, we will be in a position to ascertain where the dangers lie and then by appropriate further legislation or controls we will be able to do something about them. This Bill in respect of foreign corporations may be regarded as a first step towards a full register of foreign ownership.
I urge the Senate to support the need to establish a Register of Foreign Corporations for Australian land, business, property and resources. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL (PRINTING, PUBLISHING AND DISTRIBUTION OF ELECTORAL MATTERS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 with respect to the printing, publication and distribution of electoral matters, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
My purpose in introducing this Bill today is to draw attention to what I see as a most unsatisfactory situation with regard to the use of political advertising during the period of an election.

The Senate will recall that this is not the first occasion on which I have raised this matter. I have tried on previous occasions to convince both the Government and the Opposition of the importance of the provisions contained in this Bill. By permitting this situation to continue we are, in fact, allowing politicians a licence to lie.

It concerns me that while we, as politicians, are happy to impose requirements on the business community by obliging commercial operators to tell the truth about the products they are offering to consumers, we permit ourselves the freedom to make untrue and misleading statements about what we or our political opponents are offering to the community in terms of policies for government. I find this situation unacceptable and highly immoral. I believe it implies a degree of contempt, on our part, for the electorate.

A provision similar to the one I am proposing today with regard to the prohibition of false and misleading advertising was included in the Commonwealth Electoral Act in 1983 and was one of many reforms to the Act that were adopted following the tabling of the first report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in September 1983. The Committee's second report, which was tabled in August 1984 canvassed a number of matters relating to political advertising, including the definitional problems associated with political truths, of what is opinion and what is fact; what is untrue and what is misleading or deceptive; the potential problems arising from the placing of criminal liability on the publishers of election material; and the potential dangers associated with the injunction process.

A simple and satisfactory solution to the problems raised by the Committee would have been first, to amend s.329 (2) to remove the onus of guilt from the publishers and printers of material and to confine liability under the Act to the person or political party who authorised that material, which was the recommendation to the Committee of the Advertising Federation and the Media Council. Second, to amend s.383 by restricting the injunction process with regard to s.329 (2) to the Commonwealth Electoral Commission. Instead, the Government took the quite unnecessary step of removing all of sub-section 329 (2) from the Act.

In taking that action, the Government has said, ably supported by the Opposition, that while we agree truth in political advertising is a desirable objective, we believe that such a law will be too difficult to enforce. So let's put it in the too hard basket and hope it will go away (and in the meantime, we can use the situation to our advantage!).

The provisions contained in this Bill are modelled on Section 52 of the Trade Practices Act which has been in operation since 1974. Sub-section 52 (1) states: `A corporation shall not, in trade or commerce, engage in conduct that is misleading or deceptive or is likely to mislead or deceive'. On advertisements, the Act states that corporations shall not make untrue, false or misleading statements or publish advertisements that are false or misleading.

This Bill will make it an offence under the Commonwealth Electoral Act for any person to authorise the printing, publishing or distribution of electoral matter containing a statement that is untrue and that is, or is likely to be, misleading or deceptive during the period of an election campaign.
The Bill also makes provision for the Electoral Commission to institute injunction proceedings should it be of the opinion that subsection 329 (2) of the Act has been contravened.

There have been numerous objections in the past from both the Government and the Opposition with regard to the measures I am proposing and we have modified our proposal over the years to comply with most of those objections.

It has been argued that this provision will be limited in the type of advertisement of statement that it will prohibit. I have always acknowledged that that is the case. The only statements which will be caught under this section are things like: `X Party's official policy document states that it will introduce a consumption tax'. If X Party's policy does not contain such an item then that statement is clearly untrue.

An example of a statement that would not be caught under the Act is: `When X Party wins office it will introduce a consumption tax' or `A vote for so and so is a vote for consumption tax'. Under the definition contained in this Bill, such statements do not have a truth value in that very strict sense. They are statements about a future activity, a prediction, and therefore could be either true or false.

Because this provision is so limited in its application, the Government and the Opposition have argued that it isn't worth the bother. My response has been, and continues to be, if we cannot reform the entire world, there is still a legitimate argument for reforming the little bit that we can get hold of, and this Bill will be at least one step down that path. It will catch a limited range of statements that have truth value in their own right.

In 1984 Senator Ray, on behalf of the Government, raised the likelihood of the democratic process being disrupted and placed at risk by minority groups, desperate for publicity, who would manipulate the injunction process. I agreed that there was a danger of that occurring. This Bill, as I have already mentioned, consequently amends s.383 of the Act by limiting the power of injunction, with regard to s.329 (2), to the Commonwealth Electoral Commission.

In the past (1987) Senator Ray has opposed the reliance on the Electoral Commission as the body with sole responsibility for initiating injunctions, claiming that such responsibility would create enormous problems, put inordinate pressure on the Commission, and leave it open to claims of bias from all sides. I reject those assertions.

As I have pointed out before during debate on this matter, under the Act, the Electoral Commission has been given not simply the power to prosecute if something is brought to its notice. It has an obligation to take legal action to enforce the provisions of the Electoral Act in their entirety. It has been set up as the independent arbitrator in our electoral process to ensure that that process is fair and above board. As such, it must necessarily be involved in the political fray. As no attempt has been made to change this situation, I assume the independent power of the Commission to enforce the Act is accepted by the majority as necessary and desirable. Why, therefore, has the case of untrue and misleading advertising been singled out as a special exemption from this general proposition?
What we are saying is this: The only power, the only area we will exclude from the Electoral Commission, is that relating to electoral advertisements.

The Courts have been making decisions with regard to Section 52 of the Trade Practices Act since 1974. During debate on this issue in 1984 I stated, and I quote: `Anyone can look, as I have done, at the laws that have flowed from the operation of the Trade Practices Act. There is now a clearly worked out basis in law on how those particular obligations operate, are to be imposed, what will occur, how it will occur and the types of defences available to people resulting from those obligations not to mislead the community about services or products'. It is not difficult to define the sorts of statements that would be prohibited under s.329 (2) of the Electoral Act. It is very clear because we are looking at a very narrow range of statements.

The former Australian Electoral Office, in its submission to the first Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform (p.181), suggested a provision be included in the Act regarding the right of candidates to seek an injunction to restrain misleading advertising. The Committee, in its first report, subsequently recommended that the Commission be obliged to seek injunctive relief in respect of issues such as misleading electoral matter (clause 11.7, p.181). So this is not something the Australian Democrats have dreamt up as being a good idea . . .

I made the comment when this issue was first debated in this place that `A democracy relies on two things: The first is the ability of people to have a free vote and express their free determined will as to who shall govern them in the next parliament, and the second, which is equally important, and on which democracy stands, is information. Without information a democracy is dead'.

Electors have the right to true and accurate information about policies and issues that concern them during an election in order to make an informed choice. At the moment they are, in some instances, being denied that right.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTENNIAL NATIONAL RAIL TRANSPORT DEVELOPMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bell) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to establish a Trust fund for the purpose of the grant of financial assistance for development and maintenance of a national standard gauge rail transport system, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Bell) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill proposes an Australian Centennial National Rail Transport Development Program to assist in the development of a national standard guage rail network comprising mainline interstate and mainline export links capable of moving heavy freight tonnages efficiently and without undue delay. This will require substantial upgrading of parts of mainline track in New South Wales and Victoria. Whilst the Bill provides for encouragement of parts of State systems to be merged with the Federal system, Australian National, such mergers are not compelled. There is also provision for retirement of debt for earlier gauge standardisation works, notably in Western Australia, and evaluation of the economic and environment costs and benefits of rail upgrading.
It should also be noted that the Bill represents an affirmation of this country's intention to rid itself of the limiting trappings of colonialism.

The Australian Centennial National Rail Development Program is motivated by the clear need to reduce the total costs of land freight transport in Australia. This need to reduce transport costs is widely acknowledged and has been the subject of several major privately and Government funded studies. What is not so clearly recognised in all of these studies is the need to reduce the external costs of transport, including the tragic costs of road accidents involving semitrailers on our highways.

The point was well made by the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Rail: Five Systems-One Solution. In his foreword to their report released November 1989, the then Chairman Mr John Saunderson said:

``The plain fact is that a greatly increased amount of freight could be carried across the continent by rail more efficiently and with greater safety than it ever could be by road. Road has been preferred because it is seen as providing reliable transit times. If rail were more efficient and carried the amount of freight it should, lives would be saved, less non-renewable resources would be used and less pollution would be generated. For rail to become more efficient, money has to be spent upgrading such things as the permanent way, communications and terminal facilities and providing more and purpose-designed rolling stock.''

``The case for one national rail system for freight and passenger services is obvious. All that stands in the way of such a system are the vested interests and parochialism of the existing authorities.''

Although a commitment has been made by the Federal Government for ``major changes to Australia's transport infrastructure'' including the allocation of some $4000 million for National Highway and National Arterial road development over the next five years, this commitment is yet to extend to rail upgrading. Here, a major need is the improvement of the track alignment in South East Australia's mainline interstate rail network along with Adelaide Melbourne gauge standardisation. The Australian Centennial National Rail Transport Development Program meets this challenge, and the need to get a national rail network that is capable of efficiently moving interstate and export freight by the end of this decade.

Since Federation, the Commonwealth has assisted the development of strategic parts of a national rail system. During the First World War, a transcontinental rail link was built between Port Augusta and Kalgoorlie. Between the wars, this link was extended to Port Pirie, and a standard gauge link from the north coast of New South Wales to Brisbane was constructed with Commonwealth assistance.

After World War Two, standard gauge was extended to Melbourne in 1962, then from Kalgoorlie to Perth and from Port Pirie to Broken Hill in the late sixties and then to Alice Springs and Adelaide in the early eighties. A further stage in national rail development was the formation of Australian National by the Whitlam Government in the seventies. The result of these investments by the Commonwealth has been upgraded track west of Adelaide and Parkes so that standard gauge links all mainland capital cities and intermodal trains can now operate profitability between Adelaide and Perth, plus Alice Springs.

These intermodal operations involve road trailers being moved on rail wagons in trains 1800 metre long. Such trains, with a trailing load of about 5000 tonnes, require well constructed track with gentle grades, easy curves and good clearances.

It is worth recalling the progress made by Australian National since taking full control of the Tasmanian and South Australian non metropolitan railways in 1978. At that stage, Australian National was given a direction to operate mainland freight operations on a commercial basis within ten years. With bipartisan support from the Federal Parliament, hard work by the Australian National board including its former Chairman Mr. Lou Marks, and the support of staff and unions, this goal was achieved in 1988.

As well as reflecting good management and union support, this shows strategic mainline investment for rail freight can pay dividends. Assisted with the road trailer `piggybacking' on rail wagons and more recently double stacking of containers, rail now takes about 70 per cent of all land freight in and out of Perth.
By way of contrast, rails share of land freight on the important Sydney Melbourne rail corridor is less than 30 per cent. The vast majority is carried by heavy trucks on the Hume Highway.

Rail's share of Sydney Melbourne land freight was over one half in the mid sixties. The shift away from rail is for the most part due to levels of service. Here road transport has an advantage offering door to door deliveries. Other reasons for road transport increasing its modal share include improved truck technology and better roads. Today, one vehicle in three on the Hume Highway is a heavy truck.

Since the establishment of the National Highway System in 1974, the Federal Government has fully funded the Hume Highway. In 1974, it would take at least 15 hours to drive from Sydney to Melbourne; now a modern heavy truck can do it in 10 hours.

Although more than $730 million dollars have been spent in upgrading the Hume Highway by the present Government, it has not spent one dollar on upgrading the existing Sydney Melbourne railway. Even when a further $600 million has been spent on the Hume Highway over the next five years, there will still be problems with large numbers of heavy trucks on this highway unless the rail system is upgraded. Without rail taking a lot more Sydney Melbourne freight, large amounts of money will still be needed for maintaining and reconstructing the existing Hume Highway.

The Victorian Government in 1986 formally asked the Federal transport Minister to have the Bureau of Transport Economics conduct a evaluation for the costs and benefits upgrading the Melbourne Sydney railway. It is unfortunate, in my view, that this request was then declined. We have since seen considerable effort made by a private consortium in conducting studies to assess the viability of a Very Fast Train or VFT linking Sydney and Melbourne in 3 hours.

However, the VFT will be unsuitable for the transport of shipping containers or steel along with other bulk freight between Sydney and Melbourne. In October 1988, the Victorian Government proposed a Fast Freight Train or FFT concept. This involves upgrading of the existing Sydney-Melbourne train line to reduce the transit time of freight trains from about 13 hours to 9 hours.

How much longer will it take to upgrade the existing Sydney Melbourne railway? In 1980, the Fraser Government made an offer to NSW and Victoria to electrify the Sydney-Melbourne line. Although this offer was not taken up, and later withdrawn, it would be appropriate for the Federal Government to now reconsider the benefits of an upgraded Sydney Melbourne railway. The cost of such evaluations is provided for in the present Bill under `inquiry projects'.

The proposal of a standard gauge link between Adelaide and Melbourne was recently examined by Australian National, who find the break of gauge at Adelaide as a costly one affecting the east-west movement of some 800,000 tonnes a year of freight. Various estimates of the cost ranging up to $500 million have been given for this proposal along with the preferred option of a new route to the north of the Adelaide Hills.

In addition, consideration should be given to more effective mainline interstate rail access to Brisbane, and its port at Fisherman Islands. Whether this should include a rebuild of the present standard gauge line through Grafton, or reconstruction of lines to the West of the Great Divide is a matter for detailed evaluation.

The Bill also provides for upgrading of the railway between Burnie and Hobart. It is again a matter for detailed evaluation whether it is worth converting to this line to either standard gauge or dual gauge track, so as to allow standard gauge wagons to cross Bass Straight in ferries and move to Hobart the way narrow gauge rolling stock daily crosses Cook Straight in New Zealand to moves, say, between Auckland and Christchurch. There is also provision for upgrading the Brisbane to Cairns section of track, although much of this work has already been undertaken by Queensland Railways in their mainline upgrading and electrification projects.

Unlike the present Government's legislation, the Bill before the Senate provides scope for Federal investment for mainline export railways. One obvious candidate would be the 35 kilometre Maldon Dombarton rail link that would provide improved rail access for export coal to Port Kembla. Completion of this link, started in 1983 by the Wran Government and stopped in 1988 by the Greiner Government, would get coal trains out of inner city areas in Sydney and reduce the numbers of coal trucks on Wollongong City roads. At present, a massive five million tonnes a year of coal is moved by road for export through Port Kembla. This means during each working day, one coal truck a minute converging on the Port Kembla coal loader. Both Labor and Coalition Federal Governments have allocated millions of dollars for road used by coal trucks. It is time some Federal funds were made available for measures to get some of this export coal off public roads.

It should be of concern to the Government when a Canadian authority on transport, Professor Stevenson, who visited Australia in 1985, found in his recent book, Rail Transport and Australian Federalism (on page 94) that the present Government appears to have attached ``a lower priority to rail transport than any other Commonwealth government since the Second World War. It was apparently much more interested in highway freight transport.''

When one considers the millions of dollars paid by the Government rail systems in diesel fuel excise that have been diverted into road building, and the lack of Commonwealth funding of rail development or even the planning of selective infrastructure upgrading throughout the eighties, substance is given to this charge. The diversion of rail funds to road works has arisen through the provisions of the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act and the former Australian Land Transport Program that permit the States to divert potential mainline interstate rail funding to road works has already been noted by this Senate (by Australian Democrat Senators). The figures are telling: from 1 July 1985 to 31 December 1988, the Australian Land Transport Program collected some $60 million from the Government rail systems for fuel excises, and allowed a maximum of about $35 million to be diverted from roads to mainline interstate rail projects. Instead, only some $2.68 million was applied to rail projects.

This is at a time when the rail systems have been paying rail fuel excise to the Commonwealth that now amount to over $100 million a year, and Australian National's overall deficit has fallen to about $55 million a year. It is also at a time when the external costs of long distance trucking are increasing. As well as a conservatively estimated shortfall of some $140 million in fully distributed financial costs of road systems costs for interstate trucking in 1985-86 as noted by the Inter-State Commission in its 1987 report on cost recovery, we are probably looking at a community cost of similar order for road crashes involving the interstate movement of freight by heavy trucks plus other social and environmental costs.

This safety factor is highlighted by the tragic crash involving a semitrailer and a bus near Grafton that claimed no fewer than twenty lives in October 1989. This was followed in December 1989 by the collision of two buses on the Pacific Highway. We cannot wait for the years it will take to build a four lane Pacific Highway to reduce this tragic road toll. Instead, the Commonwealth has a responsibility to make a real effort to improve the efficiency of interstate rail freight and passenger operations. This is additional to its work with the Rail Industry Council which has just reported and its support of the National Freight Initiative Committee. This Committee also reported in May and found considerably improved intersystem operations could have considerable economic and social benefits including a positive impact on the nation's GDP with a boost of up to $1000 million.

A further incentive to get heavy long-distance freight back onto rail is provided by our decreasing self sufficiency in oil, and the need to reduce Greenhouse gas emissions. It is generally recognised that rail is about four times more fuel efficient when compared to road transport for moving reasonable tonnages of freight over some distance. In a paper given to the CSIRO Greenhouse and Energy Conference in December 1989, Dr Philip Laird of the University of Wollongong found that if the mainline interstate rail links in South East Australia were upgraded to Fast Freight Train (FFT) standards so as to give easier ruling grades and better track curvature, and, rail was to win 70 per cent of land transport on the 10 main interstate transport corridors linking the five mainland State capital cities, there would be savings of about 200 million litres of diesel each year. This is about 10 per cent of the some 2000 million litres of diesel used each year in the late eighties by trucks in Australia, a saving too large to be ignored.

Energy conservation was in vogue some 10 years ago. With declining self sufficiency in Australia's proven oil reserves, and oil industry projections of Australia's oil import bill reaching $5.5 billion by 1998, it is about time that it come into fashion again. The Australian Transport Advisory Council views stated in 1979 are still relevant; they include the observations that: Transport is almost wholly reliant on petroleum fuels and there are no widely available fuel substitutes at this time. Nevertheless, rail is relatively energy efficient compared to road for long distance freight . . . (and) . . . does have fuel substitute options, such as coal-oil slurries or electrification . . .

In 1980, a Senate Standing Committee on National Resources found that the competitive position on railways on routes with high load factors should improve if equipment was modernised and tracks were improved as well as changed freight handling practices to meet users needs. The Committee's report noted ``. . . Ideally Australia's inter-state haulage should be by rail between city freight depots with local distribution by road vehicles.''

The Australian Centennial National Rail Transport Development Program will make this a reality for all but high value time sensitive interstate freight. In regards to funding, the program is to be funded from fuel excises paid to the Federal Government by State and Federal Rail Systems to 1 July, 2001 in stages. Firstly, there would be a transfer in funding from the Australian Centennial Road Development Program (ACRD) of the amount of fuel taxes paid by rail to the ACRD trust fund. This is about $30 million a year. Secondly, as recommended last year by the Standing Committee of Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, there would be backpayments from the ACRD to rail development to account for the diversion of former rail fuel taxes to road works. Thirdly, there is scope for a reduction of about $75 million paid to consolidated revenue from other fuel excises paid by the rail systems. However, the provisions in the ACRD Program for urban public transport will remain.

Federal fuel taxes have been imposed on rail operations since 1982. It may be argued, that they should be abolished, as they are soon to be abolished for coastal shipping. Some State Rail Commissioners, now with the support of the Inter-State Commission in most recent report Road Use Charges and Vehicle Registration : A National Scheme, have argued for the abolition of Federal rail fuel taxes. However, this is outweighed for the urgent need to properly develop a national railway network. Such development has a very good precedent the formation of the National Highways System in 1974. As the then Federal Transport Minister observed in effect, if we left it up to the States alone to build a national highway, their own priorities would not allow it. So also with a national rail system. This is why the bill also allows for the cost of absorbing, with the agreement of the relevant State Government, any suitable part of a State Rail system into Australian National. This could usefully include Broken Hill to Parkes, or Adelaide Melbourne, or indeed the entire V/Line rail system.

The bill also allows for the retirement of debt to the Federal Government from earlier gauge standardisation projects. This will be of help to Western Australia and with the provision for upgrading mainlines in Queensland and Tasmania will help balance the likely expending of most funds in South Eastern Australia. Thus, there are potential benefits for each state and territory.

In conclusion, the proposed Australian Centennial National Rail Transport Development Act will help take parts of Australia's interstate mainlines out of the nineteenth century with their steam age alignment and broad gauge track. The Act will also provide funding and a basis for a true national railway system ready for the demands of the twenty first century. The funding is from rail systems themselves and returned for cost effective projects that will improve freight transport and reduce the demands on our road system and road users.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Devlin) agreed to:
(1) That, for the purpose of completing its inquiries into the question of animal welfare in Australia, the Select Committee on Animal Welfare shall confine its inquiries to the following:
(a) completion of its report on intensive livestock production;
(b) completion of its report on the racing industry;
(c) the implications for animal welfare of the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory;
(d) the implications for animal welfare of the transport of livestock within Australia; and
(e) the implications for equine welfare in competitive events other than racing.
(2) That the Committee report on the matters referred to in paragraph 1 (a) (intensive livestock production) on or before 29 June 1990.

(3) That the Committee report on the matters referred to in paragraph 1 (b) (the racing industry) in an interim report on or before 29 June 1990 and a final report on or before the last sitting day in October 1990.

(4) That the Committee may report on the matters referred to in paragraphs 1 (c), (d) and (e) at any time but must present its final report on or before the last sitting day of the Autumn sittings 1991.
