SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That General Business not be considered this day.

Without wishing to open up a large debate, I want to put one matter on record in relation to Senator Vanstone's notice of motion, which may have been the first item of general business on this day. The Government believes that it has not been given sufficient notice to make a decision in the party room, but I wish to put on record the commitment that the Government is quite happy that one day, namely 24 August, time for government business will be put aside to discuss this matter and to finalise it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support Senator Robert Ray's motion. I thank him for his comments about proceeding with Senator Vanstone's notice of motion today. It will allow the Opposition to consider this matter further today. As a result we will determine what action, if any, we wish to take on this matter. At this stage I wish to take note of Senator Ray's assurance about 24 August. Today or tomorrow morning the Opposition will consider further how to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion. I was not aware of any arrangement made between the Government and the Opposition on this matter. I had heard that the Government intended to move that government business take precedence over general business today. That was why I did not deny the Manager of Government Business (Senator Robert Ray) leave so to move.

SPEECH.PARA: I strenuously object to the motion, for two reasons. It is only proper and polite for individual senators to be consulted about whether government business should take precedence over general business. General business is one of the few times when individual senators can take the opportunity to express the views put to them by constituents about a whole range of issues. In this case there is a whole rack of Government papers which need to be considered at some stage. Those papers are generally considered on each day of sitting, but the time available on each sitting day is only 30 minutes. Generally there is an excess number of Government papers which cannot be dealt with in that time. Thus, we have that situation today. We have a range of Government papers which need to be further considered by the Senate. If this motion is carried, we will not be able to consider those papers until August.

The second reason I believe that this motion should not succeed is that for the Senate to exercise its proper control over executive government it is important for the Senate as a whole to safeguard general business time. I understand that this is the second last day of our sittings, but at the rate we are going it appears that we have plenty of time to deal with all the matters.

I know that there are about 16 speakers listed on the wool legislation, but my recollection of final sitting days is that once people hear the revving of the planes, the speakers on the list tend to disappear. We can get to that very important matter of wool earlier than expected. Thus, all the speakers on the list can have the opportunity of expressing the views conveyed to them by their constituents and their own views after they have given mature consideration to the matter. I know that it is a forlorn hope; nevertheless I hold to the hope that this motion will not succeed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 30 May.
Clause 2.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —We are on amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Durack to clause 2, which changes the commencement date of the Act. The question is that Senator Durack's amendment be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the amendment (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, subclause 3 (1), line 7, at end of subclause, add ``and commerce''.

Clause 3 outlines the objects of this Bill, about which we have had a great deal to say in the debate so far. One of the deficiencies we have exposed in this legislation is the difference between the general objectives of the Bill and the ways in which the Government seeks to give effect to them. The objects of the Bill are stated in clause 3 (1), which says:

The principal objects of this Act are to increase, and improve the quality of, the employment related skills of the Australian workforce so that it works more productively . . . thereby increasing the efficiency and international competitiveness of Australian industry.

One of the major criticisms that we have made of this Bill is that it seeks to cover the whole range of employment. For example, the definitions of `employer' are extremely wide. As I said, it covers the whole range of economic activity and not just industry. The object of this amendment is to make this clause consistent with the legislation's objectives. This may seem to be just a tidying up measure, and if that is so I am sure that the Government and the Australian Democrats will not object to it. We basically see the amendment as doing that and making the objectives consistent with the operation of the Bill. Nevertheless, the addition of the words `and commerce' does serve to emphasise the point that we have been making that the ambit of the legislation, which covers a whole range of economic activity and employment in the community, raises basic difficulties with a number of other clauses in the Bill which need further consideration.

I think this has been emphasised in a letter which I received only yesterday from the Secretary-General of the Law Council of Australia. It also raises a matter which I wish to discuss later in relation to clause 27. The letter includes a statement which sums up very well what the Opposition has been trying to say during this debate. It reads:

. . . the Law Council would have preferred to have seen the legislation expressly recognise the differences in the training requirements of manufacturing, retail and service industries and the professions. If this had been done there would have been no need to deal with such matters in the proposed guidelines.
They are matters which we have been complaining about.

I am very pleased to find that a peak professional body in Australia has made the point again, and it is still being made by the Opposition. That is interesting, in the light of the Minister's reply to the Opposition's criticism of this legislation that all these bodies had been thoroughly consulted and were all satisfied with the way the Government had brought in this Bill; that there was no need to give it further consideration; and that the Opposition had been wasting everybody's time. So much for that.

It is perfectly clear that this legislation has been drawn up with regard to the needs of one segment of industry and has not had regard, in its present structure, to the needs of commerce and more particularly professions. It may well be that the guidelines, when we finally see them, will overcome the problem. We would certainly like to find out more about them before we pass the Bill but presumably that is not going to be possible. Nevertheless, the Minister may be able to help by answering some questions that arise, particularly under clause 27. Clearly the structure of the Bill will be an impediment in applying these basic notions of what is eligible training, even with the help of guidelines. The basic problem is that the thinking behind the Bill is restricted in the way in which this objective has been restricted, namely, the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian industry.

If the words `and commerce' were added it would be helpful for the Government and the Minister in drawing up guidelines. It would serve to give further support to guidelines which, hopefully, will recognise these distinctions, whereas clause 27 does not do so. It may be that there could be difficulties in developing guidelines sufficiently flexible in the light of clause 27. I think there could well be legal argument as to whether the guidelines, if they have the necessary flexibility, will be consistent with clause 27. It would help to give force to those guidelines if they have that flexibility, and it would help to give further legal force to them if the Opposition's amendment were accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the Opposition's amendment. It does so for a very clear reason. The objective of the legislation is to increase and improve employment related skills of workers in all branches and sectors of Australian industry, and that includes commerce. Training programs, training expenditure and programs which will be considered eligible include those targeted at workers in the commerce sector. It should be recognised that the term `industry' as referred to in the Bill is one which is both widely and generally used to include all branches of industry whether it be the agricultural, mining, manufacturing, retail service or commercial sectors. This is the meaning intended in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also consistent with the usual dictionary definition of the word `industry', that is, a branch of industry or trade. The addition of the word `commerce' would add absolutely nothing to the meaning or the intent of the legislation. In stressing that last point, I indicate that there have been extensive discussions in the preparation of the legislation with associations representing most of the service sectors as well as manufacturing, professional and commercial associations. It is widely understood that the legislation covers commerce, as intended by the Opposition. There is no need for the amendment and the Government opposes it.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 6, clause 4, definition of `skill', line 30, after `includes', insert `expertise,'.

Clause 4, page 6, refers to the definition of skill and is a sort of hybrid exercise. `Skill' is not really defined. It simply states that it includes competence and knowledge. Page 27 of the explanatory memorandum, in dealing with the definition of `skill', says:
. . . has the standard dictionary meaning, namely, practised ability, expertness and facility and it includes competence and knowledge.

It is intended that the term have a wide meaning. It seems very extraordinary to me that, when one tries to give it that widest meaning, the Bill only says it includes competence and knowledge. Clearly, what the Government is seeking to achieve in this whole exercise is to improve the meaning of the word. It is obvious and we have already dealt with that. The explanatory memorandum uses the word `expertness' and I think the word `expertise' is a better and a better understood word. It is used much more than expertness. Although that is a word, it is not a commonly used word. To give this definition its full force we believe that the word `expertise' should be included in the definition of `skill'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the definition of a particular word. This always seems to me to be somewhat fruitless. With regard to this amendment, the word `expertise', in all of its accepted definitions, means expert knowledge. Expert knowledge, of course, is a subsection of knowledge which is included in the Bill. I think the notion of having `skill' defined as competence and knowledge refers both to the residual understanding and its application in practice. I fail to see why we need to extend it. In saying that, I am not fussed either way. It does not seem a matter of great moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —For essentially the reasons that Senator Macklin states, the Government opposes this amendment. We see the point that Senator Durack raises as being covered by the definition already in the Bill. Amendments to include `expertise' would be purely cosmetic and would add nothing to the substance of the definition. As Senator Macklin, I think, explained, `expertise' comes within the Oxford Dictionary definition of the word `skill'. So we see the Opposition amendment as adding nothing and oppose it accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 5 to 25-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to clause 6, I ask the Minister how $1,000 was calculated as being an adequate amount in any one year to allow for the cost of an apprentice.
—I am in the process of getting advice on this matter so Senator Reid may like to elaborate her point.

—I do not think there is much to elaborate. The cost of an apprentice is considerably more than $1,000 if one takes into account the amount of time, for example, that a hairdressing apprentice spends at school and the actual cost to the employer. Why the figure of $1,000? How was it calculated?

—I am informed that $1,000 is an option. The other option is to claim the costs that are actually incurred for that apprentice. So it is not limited to $1,000. It is an option that is there for convenience. Otherwise the employer or industry group can claim, I am informed, the actual amount incurred.

—In regard to clause 8, why is the threshold figure $200,000, when for payroll tax, I think, in every other State it is at least $400,000? Why was the figure of $200,000 chosen and how was it calculated?

—The purpose of that mechanism is that, whilst about 75 per cent of the work force will be covered, about 85 per cent of employers will be excluded. One per cent of $200,000 is $2,000, so we are talking about small amounts being recouped thereunder. A lower threshold would have involved a large increase in the number of employers required to comply, a relatively small increase in the number of employees covered and compliance checking for trifling amounts of expenditure. Whilst average training expenditure is lower amongst small firms, almost 60 per cent of firms with payrolls above the threshold spend nothing on formal training. The training guarantee aims to directly improve the level and quality of industry training of firms above that threshold. That is essentially why that figure was seized upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also in regard to clause 8, I raised at the second reading stage the discrepancy in the treatment of payroll tax between the States. There are two questions involved. Firstly, how will it be done? As I understand it, in New South Wales, for example, the end user incurs the payroll tax for the employee, while in Victoria the agency does. That is with regard to those agencies we were discussing at the second reading stage, employment agencies. There seems to me to be some confusion. How does the Commonwealth intend to deal with the matter?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, are there any difficulties in terms of across border operations with regard to payroll tax, for example, where a company is situated in one State and its employees are situated in another State? How are they treated if there are differences in the way individual States treat payroll tax?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Macklin says, a discrepancy currently exists between States in the treatment of payroll tax legislation. I think it relates particularly to employment agencies. In some States or Territories, the Australian Capital Territory for example, employment agencies are explicitly deemed within the legislation to be the employer in every situation. That is not necessarily the case in all States.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the training guarantee legislation there is no presumption that either the employment agency or the client is the employer in every case. The decision on who is the employer depends on the type of relationship that exists between the worker, the employment agency and the host of expertise.

I could probably go on without specifically addressing Senator Macklin's point but I will not do that. I will seek further information. I am informed that there have been no problems with firms crossing State borders and also national payroll and training expenditure count. I think that may satisfy the two points Senator Macklin has raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 9 seeks to bind the Crown in subclause (1) but then goes on in subclause (2) to say-astonishingly:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in this Act permits the Crown to be prosecuted for an offence.
Can the Minister explain why that is there?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crown is covered by clause 9, as Senator Reid indicates. She asks why clause 9 goes on to indicate that the Crown cannot be prosecuted in a court of law. Senator Reid and I would both understand-if not everyone else-that it is quite inconceivable for the Crown to prosecute itself in a court of law. That goes back to some fairly essential principles of constitutional law.

—Does this cover all employees of the Crown and those others hiding behind it, you might say? Why is the Crown bound in clause 9 (1) if it is then excluded in clause (2)? What, in effect, is the purpose of saying that the Crown is bound? It clearly is not if there is no way in which it or its officers can be held responsible.

—The point that we both agree on is that the Crown is bound and is obligated under clause 9 (1) to fulfil commitments under the legislation. But there is indeed some essential and basic constitutional question as to whether the Crown can prosecute itself in a court of law. Senator Reid went on to ask whether the Crown can actually prosecute an employee of the Crown. That raises other, diverse, questions as to whether that person was working inside or outside his terms of employment and so on. But as a general principle, the Crown prosecuting the Crown is something that is not allowable.

—I ask this generally: Up until now we have completed part one. Have there been any amendments in part one or anything that we have dealt with so far that have been brought about from the original draft to this stage as a consequence of the consultation that the Minister has talked about so much?

—I am sure that this will be a running question with other parts of the Bill. Perhaps we can take Senator Reid's question on notice for this part of the Bill, take advance notice of it for further parts of the Bill and come back to her.

—This also relates to clause 9 and the Crown. During the second reading stage I raised the matter of departments of State. It is clear that each Commonwealth department-I presume this extends even to the parliamentary departments-will be treated as a separate entity for the purpose of the calculation of the levy. What discussions have been had with State governments? Is there an agreement relating to corresponding State departments and instrumentalities?

—State governments are regarded as single employers covering all State Public Service departments. However State statutory authorities are employers in their own right. The Commonwealth is setting higher standards for the Australian Public Service. Each Commonwealth department will be required to meet its obligations as an employer under the training guarantee. Mr Dawkins has written to State and Territory Ministers suggesting that the States consider requiring each of their departments to publish information on their training programs and their expenditure in their annual reports.
-I move to clause 17, which relates to exemptions. Could the Minister for Administrative Services indicate what constitutes a public benevolent institution, other than public hospitals?

—Senator Walters rightly raises the matter of public benevolent institutions. The term is narrower than charitable organisations. Examples of public benevolent institutions are the St Vincent de Paul Society, Sydney City Mission, the Smith Family, legal aid offices and community management teams of, for example, the Skillshare program.

-As the Minister may well be aware, there are concerns in a number of welfare services. One example is the Care at Home agency in Canberra. The Care at Home agency employs trained nursing staff, who are sent into homes to assist with the health care of the Canberra population. Indeed, sometimes they are sent just as companions. It claims-and it has now been going for 11 years; it employs 70 people so its payroll is over the $200,000 mark-that it operates as a service to the Canberra people. I would be very interested to hear the Public Service answer as to what additional training these trained nursing staff would have to undergo to be able to go into a home and give this service that they are already trained so well to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could possibly be obliged to undergo training such as skills upgrading and the like.
—Skills upgrading?

—There is always a need to upgrade skills. I will go through the four objectives required before an institution is classed as a public benevolent institution. This may assist us to work out whether the organisation we are talking about comes under that umbrella. As a guide, a public benevolent institution needs to satisfy these four tests: its object has to be the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, destitution or helplessness; it has to be carried on without the purpose of private gain for particular persons; it has to be established for the benefit of a section or class of the public; and the relief has to be available without discrimination to every member of that section of the public which the organisation aims to benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: These are pretty substantive provisions that assist in defining a public benevolent institution. The institution Senator Walters mentions would have to look at those four objective tests to see whether it came within that definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the Public Service officers know about Care at Home, seeing as it has been operating in Canberra for such a long time. I am sure that they already have taken such organisations into consideration. They would not be in Canberra and not be aware of such a service that has been in operation for 11 years, so I ask: Does the Care at Home agency come within that particular definition?

—It is really not my role to answer the question directly, but the other benchmark is that at the moment public benevolent institutions are exempt from taxes such as income tax, fringe benefits tax and payroll tax. If one is looking at an institution which is exempt from those--
—That is not the question I asked.

—I will not directly answer Senator Walters's question but I will give her some assistance as to how organisations in the community can assess whether they are covered. Those tests are also quite indicative in making that assessment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -Very briefly, the Public Service officers obviously do not have a clue about Care at Home, otherwise they would be able to answer my question. That seems extraordinary to me. I do not know whether this particular agency covers all those criteria. It seems incredible to me that the officers beside the Minister for Administrative Services are not aware of it. For the Minister to say that people employing trained nursing staff need to spend one per cent of their payroll on upgrading the training of that trained nursing staff is unbelievable. Is that the advice the Public Service officers are giving the Minister? It is absolutely ridiculous for them even to suggest that one per cent of the payroll tax should be spent on upgrading nursing skills when the nurses are already fully qualified and fully trained and are going into homes not to do highly technical work that is done in hospitals but to give home nursing care.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume that the Government is saying, `If this particular group does not need to train its staff, then it can pay the tax as a payroll tax to assist others'. It seems that this is what this Bill is all about. There are a number of groups, industries and agencies that do not need to spend such a large amount of money on upgrading training because they are using trained staff of such quality that this is not a requirement. But the Government will still enforce the payment of that amount. I might be wrong. Could the Minister advise whether he is willing to make anyone employing fully trained staff who do not require upgrading exempt from that payroll tax?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite unfair for honourable senators to draw inferences from answers given to them and to blame the public servants for the inferences that they have drawn from those answers. I am trying to be calm about this, and I will be. It is unfair to draw that particular inference especially when one is talking about only one organisation in a nationwide scheme. We are in the business of providing the criterion-that has been provided to Senator Walters-and in the business of assisting further. I gave Senator Walters further assistance in terms of how that organisation can be assessed. The other thing we can do is check the whole nature of the organisation and come back to Senator Walters on that. I think it is quite unreasonable to expect that if at the drop of a hat people across the country raise the name of an organisation, we can come up with a very quick yes or no answer. We will find out and let Senator Walters know in due course.
—Minister--

—I have not finished, Senator Walters; you had a bit more to say, and so have I. The Government acknowledges, and I think industry acknowledges, most of the facets. Senator Walters mentioned, for instance, fully trained nurses. Fully trained they may be, and they are a great profession, but they live in a changing environment. Changing research means that new products are on the market and new needs have to be met in terms of sicknesses. Senator Walters can sit there and shake her head, and sometimes I wish she were back in nursing, but I am glad she is here now to keep us going all morning. The reality of nursing, as with a whole list of other professions, is that nurses do not live in a static world. Because of different research developments, different medicinal developments and different sicknesses, we can argue quite strongly that training in techniques for those in the health profession-from doctors to nurses-can be augmented. We could go on all morning discussing this but I do not think I can add much more.

-This is certainly my last point because obviously the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) does not understand what he is talking about. He does not understand the nursing profession. It is not accurate for the Minister to say that I have picked one agency or one organisation out of the whole of Australia. I chose an organisation that is on our doorstep here in Canberra. It has been going 11 years and employs 70 people, and the public servants do not know whether it is exempt or otherwise. I can only assume that that is the case because I am quite sure that if it were otherwise, they would have given the Minister the answer `Yes, they are exempt' or `No, they are not'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the greatest respect to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), his last answer to Senator Walters was quite extraordinary. During the debate so far the Minister has said a number of times-and it was advanced as a reason for the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990-that employers go poaching from each other and that it is necessary to have training to make sure that this does not occur. What he is talking about in the particular instance of the program that Senator Walters raised is training nurses beyond what is required for their purpose, which, for certain, means that, having been trained by that organisation if it were required to do so, they would then have to move on to get jobs commensurate with their new skills. That seems to me to be quite pointless.

SPEECH.PARA: I was going to mention a number of organisations under this clause. If I did that, we could probably stay here all day. That would probably be not of great point, but I cannot help but mention the emergency housekeeper service. It has a huge payroll, administered by two or three people. To suggest that something like that should then have to try to scrounge from the community or Government more money to put into a training program for this purpose defies belief.

I just want to try to get to the philosophy of this. Is the Government merely trying to raise money or is it genuinely trying to train people for jobs? The emergency housekeeper service cannot be a surprise to anyone; it exists everywhere, and has for a very long time. Is its payroll exempt from the operation of this act?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will bypass the earlier points made by Senator Reid. I have said this to Senator Walters and I will say it to whatever organisation is listed: people cannot come in here with a name and expect me to respond. I have gone through the criteria that apply. I have gone through the existence of another indicator, whether the institutions are exempt from other taxes such as income tax, fringe benefits tax and payroll tax. Public benevolent institutions are those that rely on public donations and government funding for their operation, and are often staffed by volunteers. Requiring them to meet the requirements of the training guarantee could force them to cut back services to the poor, sick and needy, which we acknowledge as being an undesirable result. The Government acknowledges the need to ensure that those sorts of organisations are exempt, but we will have a look at the actual structure, details and funding of the particular organisation Senator Reid mentioned and come back to her. If she wants to mention any others, by intervention now or by correspondence, we will assist her.

—I think that just highlights the need for the guidelines which we do not have. It would have been helpful if they had been here. I shall not pursue others at the present time. But under clause 17 (b) I simply want to ask whether the Catholic systemic school teaching staff are exempt or not.
—I am told that schools and hospitals of registered religious bodies are included.
—So the Catholic systemic school system is exempt from the operation of this tax?
—No, it is not exempt.
—The Catholic systemic schools, already strained for funds, will have to find the funds to pay this tax?

—As I said, they are not exempt, but I am informed that our discussions already indicate that most schools that we are talking about pay more than one per cent in terms of training, so they would meet their requirements under the legislation.

—If they do not, any church-based school which in a particular year is short of funds or, having its staff trained to the level that it needs them, is not doing staff training during that year, will have to find the funds to pay this tax?

—I think we are going over the same question in different ways. The answer I gave at the start is that they would be covered by the legislation and would have obligations under it. Obviously the Government's intention is that we raise the level of skills training rather than collect levels of taxation. In those circumstances we would anticipate and hope that the level of skill training would be raised to meet their obligations under the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister just elaborate on what clause 18 means? It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Training guarantee charge is not payable by an employer for a year unless the employer is a resident of Australia during the whole or a part of the year.
That seems to me like a fair old loophole that might be of great benefit to certain larger organisations; but maybe I misunderstand it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we need to go back to the definitions in the explanatory memorandum, for a start. Clause 18 provides exemption from having to spend the minimum amount, as Senator Reid indicates, for non-resident employers. The memorandum says:

SPEECH.PARA: An employer is a non-resident employer during a financial year if during any part of that year he or she was not a resident of Australia.

It should be noted that, as explained in the notes on clause 7, a company which operates in Australia for part of a year will be a resident employer for the purposes of this Bill even if it is incorporated elsewhere. Hence it is required to meet the requirements of the Bill-
even if it operates as a corporation within Australia for a part of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that, which is what prompted me to ask the question. Why is the clause in there?

—I think it is a catch-all answer. The best thing we can do there is to give the first part of the answer which is that to try to cover this in any other way would make it quite difficult to administer. I would like to get some further advice on that particular clause for Senator Reid during the course of the next half hour or so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue it. It just seems like a huge loophole and if the Government had left it out altogether it might have been better off.

SPEECH.PARA: We could probably stay here for the rest of the day trying to sort out what sorts of people are included in clause 25. Given the Minister's answers to the questions raised by Senator Walters and me under clause 17 I really wonder whether there is any point in pursuing it at any length. I am wondering about seminars, the difference between the sorts of courses that are generally appropriate to unskilled and professional people, and the matter I raised in the debate that came to me from the Real Estate Institute of Australia about the sorts of magazines that people subscribe to, which are their means of learning and skilling themselves in new areas. Would subscriptions to certain types of magazines for the benefit of employees in the way of self-education, perhaps, be exempted?

I raise the question of articled clerks in a law firm. Is the Minister suggesting that they are apprentices and that they can get the deduction that applied under the apprentice clause? A number of things occurred to me under clauses 25 and 26, which could keep us here a long time. What a pity it is that we do not have the guidelines. If the guidelines under clause 30 were available perhaps none of these questions would even occur to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will first answer the previous question, that being the question about clause 18. I am informed that the reason we have that exemption is essentially that the cost of administration outweighs the very small number of people who would be exempt under clause 18 of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid asked questions about a number of aspects which may or may not be covered by the legislation. I am informed that most seminars and conferences will not be structured as defined in the legislation and they will not be counted as eligible training as a consequence. However, the cost of attending employment-related seminars will count if the seminar is part of a broader structured training program which has been designed by any employer for an employee or a group of employees. For example, a partner of a law firm could design a training program for one of his or her junior colleagues. The program, for instance, might cover a year and have the objective of improving knowledge of tax law and practice to a certain level. The means of so achieving that objective may include attending specified courses, undertaking supervised reading programs, attending appropriate seminars organised, for instance, by the Australian Taxation Office or a consultant. In those cases the cost of attending the seminar would count.

I think the subsequent question was whether subscriptions paid to industry associations would be eligible expenditure. Where, for instance, an industry association undertakes eligible training activities using funds derived from those subscriptions, then that portion of the subscription which is used for training activities will count as eligible training expenditure claimable by the employer who is a member of the association.

The types of eligible activities which an association may undertake are covered in subclause 25 (2). I think one example is the development of training programs which include the development of training materials for programs and books as well, so we would be there covering the question of books being allowable as part of the expenditure. Where an association also charges a specific fee for eligible training activities, that fee will, of course, count as eligible expenditure for the employer.

I note that Senator Reid made the point at the start-it is one which is quite accurate-that we could spend probably the week rather than just the day going through item after item across the country, but she mentioned also the questions of articled clerks and whether their wages would count as eligible training expenditure.

The Government has held discussions with the Law Council of Australia on this particular issue and clause 30 of the legislation was included following these consultations. This clause allows the Minister to make guidelines which will simplify the record keeping for designated entry-level training arrangements. The Law Council has said it would be interested in working with officials to develop these guidelines and such guidelines will allow employers to claim a minimum amount of expenditure for each articled clerk without keeping training records.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 26.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 14, after paragraph 26 (1) (k), add the following new paragraph:

; and `(m) expenditure incurred by the employer in engaging replacement staff (including all hiring and salaries expenditure) to undertake the duties of an employee during the period that the employee was solely or principally engaged in participating in an eligible training program'.

The amendment is to add an additional limb to subclause 26 (1). Subclause 26 (1) sets out in very considerable detail the types of expenditures that can become eligible to set against the levy. We commend the detail that appears in the subclause despite a lot of other criticism we make of the legislation. Also, this particular clause does seem to have had regard to some of the comments that had been made in relation to capital expenditure. One of the weaknesses under the original proposals has been rectified by the Government. Expenditure within a corporate group is to be claimable against the group and not just in relation to each particular member of it, the related company. Certainly, on capital expenditure the amendment has been made by the Government to take the matter up.

But when one looks at the various items of expenditure, one sees that the expenditure incurred by an employer in engaging replacement staff, including all hiring and salaries expenditure, to undertake the duties of an employee during the period that the employee was solely or principally engaged in participating in an eligible training program is not included. The Minister may be able to show us where that type of expenditure would be included, but it does not appear to be in the provision. It is clearly the sort of expenditure that will be, or is already being, incurred by employers who provide training that the Government would desire.

After this legislation comes in, an employer is induced to engage in the desired training and will incur all sorts of expenditure as a result of it-the variety of which, as I have said, is already set out pretty clearly in subclause 26 (1). There are difficulties in doing it that way, even though the subclause makes clear that it provides only examples of such expenditure. Nevertheless, it might be helpful, again, if we had guidelines.

We certainly believe firmly that another example-and a very obvious example-is the one we are addressing in this amendment. I commend it to the Government. If, as I said, the Government can point to some other basis for it-how it can be claimed, without any doubts about it-then this amendment will not be necessary. In the absence of that, we believe that it is a very important addition to the examples that are set out in clause 26 (1). It should be agreed to by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support the amendment. We see it as a classic case of double counting, in fact. There are obviously obligations on industry to fulfil; the priority being, of course, to increase levels of training. If that is not done, then obviously industry has to meet obligations in terms of the one per cent. As part of the mechanism of the outcome of this particular Bill, where an employee undertakes a training program there will be short-term costs to the employer, represented by the wage of the employee. Employers can count the wage of the employee while he or she attends a training program as eligible expenditure. The mechanism of the legislation is such that if one were able to include the cost of replacement staff, then there would be a classic case of double counting. The outcome of this would be that no cost would be incurred by industry and the Government in fact would be paying the whole cost of the particular training programs, either by way of the guarantee or other tax mechanisms so we oppose the amendment.

—All I can say to the response of the Minister for Administrative Services is that it is just as well that he and his advisers are not in business. If one does not do some double counting when one is facing costs, one would be bankrupt pretty quickly. That is in fact what employers are faced with. When employees go on a program like this-or for whatever reason because there are many other reasons why they may not be able to be working at the task which they were employed to do-the employer has to keep paying them their salary for a period of time; he does that, clearly, when they are training. At the same time, replacement staff have to be obtained. In many cases replacement staff have to be employed to do the work, if the work is there. That is an additional cost. That is why, of course, the oncosts of employment in Australia are so high. That is one of the most obvious problems facing Australian business. To say that that is something which cannot be counted because it is double counting is ridiculous when the reality is that there are double costs that are incurred. It is ridiculous to say that because it is double counting that is a reason for being against it. Of course our amendment is proposed because of double costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition amendment is based on a notion which I do not think is correct. Senator Durack just argued that there was a cost in terms of replacement staff. That is perfectly true. In fact, the taxation system treats the situation that way. But we are not talking about the taxation system. What we are talking about is training costs. Presumably, replacement staff are fully productive. If they are not, any additional training may be counted with that replacement staff. In as far as members of such staff are fully productive, it is not a training cost. The cost there is towards productivity and hence is dealt with under the normal methods of taxation. It is dealt with in terms of the costs of a company dealing in whatever it is that the company is doing. What we are talking about here in this legislation is training costs. It is not a training cost, except in so far as training of any of those replacements is a cost to the company, and it will be able to be counted under the one per cent exercise. Anything outside of that is a cost to the production operation of the company.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one question I want to ask on clause 26 (1) (d) (i) (b). How much money does the Government estimate it will forgo as a consequence of including this clause in the Bill?
—Could you explain the question a little further?
—Clause 26 (1) (d) (i) (b) describes examples of eligible training expenditure in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: contributions payable or paid under Chapter 4 of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that no loss of revenue is anticipated under this provision in that revenue will still be collected either from the employer or the individual involved.

—If one is, let us say, an engineering graduate who acquires a liability to pay a graduate tax and if one's employer pays it as part of his training tax, that graduate does not have to pay it as his graduate tax, the employer pays it. So the Government gets only one lot of money instead of two. How much money does the Government anticipate forgoing as a consequence of this provision?

—I can quite well understand the purport of Senator Reid's question. I indicated to her just now that the payment will be covered as eligible training expenditure. There is need for further clarification for the assistance of my advisers. I wonder whether Senator Reid could go through the question again.

—If one acquires a liability as a graduate to pay a graduate tax and if one is smart enough to get oneself employed by an employer who is liable to pay training tax, one can shift one's liability for paying the graduate tax to the employer. He pays the graduate tax and debits it from his training tax. Therefore the Government gets one lot of money and not two.

—I think any answer to that question would have to be a figure plucked out of the air. It depends, as Senator Reid has just said, on the individual determination of the person. Secondly, under this legislation a person would not necessarily be paying anything. That would also have to be a consideration. Hopefully, if that employer were so interested in this exercise he would be doing it to go over the one per cent, in which case he would not be paying a penny. So the Government, at the end of the day, would not lose anything. But surely it would depend on the individual determinations, how the person was employed and what the employer did. It seems to me that, at the end of the day, the figure would not actually mean anything because any figure could do.
—It seems to me that this might be a matter that we could pursue in an Estimates committee in the future. We could find out what in fact has occurred.

—What Senator Macklin has said is precisely right. The revenue under the higher education contribution scheme (HECS) would be the same. As to the revenue under the training guarantee scheme, it would depend upon the individual involved, the individual employer and the level of training that that employer has already committed himself or herself to. As Senator Reid rightly said, the application of the provision is something that could be scrutinised in an Estimates committee further down the track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also ask a question with regard to HECS and clause 26. At the second reading stage I raised the possibility of distortions between private and public institutions. If one looks at the example which Senator Reid has just given, a private institution would be treated differently from a public institution. According to calculations that I have done, taking into account that the institutions would be paying fringe benefits tax, in terms of the Taxation Commissioner's recent ruling, on almost every occasion there is a distortion against public education.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, if one looked at a course in Japanese at a private institution and one at a university or technical and further education college, there would be a marginal gain in choosing the private institution over the public one. I am quite sure that the Government is not intending that. We could not do anything in this legislation to fix that up, but I wonder whether the Government has any intention of trying to regularise that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin raises a problem which we recognise as one we will have to monitor. We accept that it is essentially a problem if public and private trainers offer comparable courses at comparable prices. However, it should be taken into account that HECS applies only to courses with a high public subsidy and that these conditions may not be met all that often. However, we are prepared to look at the tax treatment of employer payments to HECS to ensure that public institutions are not put at a disadvantage. I give this commitment now: we will consider the need for any amendment to the HECS legislation pending that monitoring.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question with regard to clause 27. Where an employer provides a training course for a person that significantly upgrades his skills, which is what is intended, is there any possibility-the employee having been put in a category whereby his salary might go up, say, $10,000 a year, or he would be worth that much more-that the employer would have to pay a fringe benefits tax as well for the benefit that has been conferred on the employee? I think that needs to be clarified beyond doubt.

—I think that it is fair for Senator Reid to ask for clarification. Essentially the question of whether the fringe benefits tax is payable where an employer incurs the cost of training an employee very much depends on the circumstances of the case. But generally it should be recognised that so long as the training has work related to it, that work would not be subject to fringe benefits tax although classified as a fringe benefit. This is because the employee would have been entitled to an income tax deduction if the training cost had been paid by the employee personally. This is generally known as the `otherwise' deduction rule. In this case the employer would also be entitled to an income tax deduction. This contrasts with the situation where an employer reimburses a higher education contribution scheme debt. Although this is also a taxable fringe benefit, its value is reduced to nil because the employer is precluded from obtaining an income tax deduction.

—Is the Government planning to amend the fringe benefits tax legislation in any way to make certain that the Commissioner does not get his fringe benefits tax hat mixed up with his graduate tax hat, or be in the position where one hand does not know what the other is doing? Will the Minister seek to ensure that that is clear?
—We do not see it necessary at this stage to do that.
—As I see it, if the item is to be subject to fringe benefits tax, it is hardly likely to be liable as an eligible training expense, because the two are incompatible.
—I think that is right, Senator Watson.
—I wish to ask the Minister a question on clause 29 relating to articled clerks. Under that provision will an articled clerk be included or excluded? It is an interesting category of people.
—It is very much an interesting category of people; I was one myself at one stage.
—The Minister gave that answer a little while ago.

—In fact, I did give the answer earlier. The answer then was, and still is, that there have been discussions with the Law Council of Australia and a mechanism will be worked out under proposed section 30 to ensure that an appropriate level of expenditure in employing articled clerks can be included as part of the training guarantee commitment in a very simplified way.

—I thank the Minister. I have two more questions on clauses 39 and 43 as to confidentiality. It is fairly obvious that from time to time, although not as often with this Bill as under the previous one, that details of specific training courses will have to be provided to the national training body, whatever that may be, or to an industry training body when that comes into being on 1 January. What protection do firms have if they are required to provide this material either to their industry training agent or to the national training body?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under clause 39 of the Bill, the secrecy clause, there is a requirement that the Commissioner of Taxation, the training advisory body, and their officers and employees, not make a record or divulge any protected information to another person, unless this is necessary for the administration of the Act. This provision is similar to that under the income tax legislation and the same penalties prevail for both.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, as part of the guidelines for the registration of industry training agents, the Minister will also state the conditions to be observed by those agents in the conduct of their business. These will be discussed with industry in the coming months. Consideration will be given to the requirement that information provided by employers to industry training agents must not be passed on to other employers. Industry training agents who fail to observe these conditions will risk deregistration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any point in talking again about how unsatisfactory not having the guidelines is. In clause 30 and clause 27 (4) (c) one sees the phrase `cannot include any generally supervised practice or work experience'. What would be the position of a housemaid or cleaner, the nature of whose training really is supervised practice or work experience? That is the nature of training given to people to upgrade skills and to teach them. If one takes somebody who is totally unskilled in those areas, say in cleaning an office, it has to be supervised practice. Will the guidelines make that plain? If the Minister intends not to do anything under this legislation to enable an unskilled person perhaps to acquire the skills of a housemaid or a cleaner, what is he trying to do? Why is it that that sort of very valuable training for some people seems to be excluded?

—We did get on to the subject of cleaners when we discussed the Bill yesterday. I think Senator Reid will find that one has to look at people not purely in the actual job they perform at the time, but at other courses which may assist them in their overall skill levels. I refer, for instance, to small cleaning firms-and one must remember that we are talking about firms above the benchmark-which undertake management training for some of their managers, which is obviously essential in all businesses; supervisor training, including training to design and provide supervisors on the job; training workers in, for instance, the use of chemicals and equipment in which they may need to have training and guidance; and occupational health and safety training is another area. As we are talking about the cleaning industry, I imagine that English language training may also be encompassed by skills and training in that area and would be quite useful for the industry to commit itself to.

—I am almost tempted to accuse the Minister of unnecessarily prolonging this debate. Most of the matters the Minister has mentioned of course are as appropriate to a larger cleaning firm as they are to a smaller one. I suggest that even training in the use of certain chemicals would be on site on-the-job training and not something that necessarily a person would go off somewhere else to do. The example I gave the Minister involved a cleaning firm that was large enough to do so electing to take on a person who is totally unskilled. Where would the firm send such people to be trained? It is on-the-job training by the firm's own supervisors and managers that gives that person his or her start in life. Why is that sort of training specifically excluded? The Minister seems to be assuming that everybody is already trained, and he is talking about extra training.
—The basis of the question is that on-the-job training is not included, but it is.

—In that case what do the words `cannot include any generally supervised practice or work experience' mean? I am referring to page 15, clause 27 (4) (c). Paragraphs (a) and (b) make sense, but paragraph (c) does not.
—If Senator Reid looks at the clause as a whole--
—I have.

—The first part of it refers to an eligible training program `that consists of or includes on-the-job training'. The premise underlying that part is the obvious one, that on-the-job training is included. One can have on-the-job structured training. Such training must include periods of instruction and may include related periods of closely supervised practice. In those circumstances, the wage and salary costs of both the supervisor and the person undertaking the training count during those periods, along with other directly related expenses provided for in the legislation.
—What about subclause (c)? What does that mean?

—The point of subclause (c) is to pick up the need for on-the-job training to include not just generally supervised practice of work experience, but also some training on the job which involves periods of instruction and closely supervised practice over and above the normal course of a person working and getting assistance and guidance from a supervisor.

—That makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. For example, if one is in a cleaning firm and has a brand new floor polisher, does the training program associated with teaching someone how to use it safely come under subclause (b) or is it excluded under subclause (c)? If it is excluded under subclause (c), why is it excluded and what does that mean?

—I think that clause 4 makes that pretty obvious to those who read it. If it is closely supervised practice and the training is part of that, then it is covered. But if it is all rather general with no actual program and no training, but just a matter of someone saying, `Here is the cleaner; here are the instructions; go and read them', then that cannot be included as a commitment under the training guarantee. There has to be closely supervised practice. As I pointed out a couple of answers ago, structured instruction is one sort of supervised practice that would be covered, but it is not the only one.

—I shall not press this matter but there is no way that the Minister has explained properly why it makes sense that an eligible training program that consists of or includes on-the-job training cannot include generalised supervised practice or work experience. The whole debate so far has highlighted the fact that the Minister is not able to answer so many of these questions in quite simple detail and that the Bill should have gone to a committee for detailed examination in order to clear up the problems that will occur once the legislation comes into operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that there is no problem about the distinction between closely supervised and generally supervised practice. Anyone who has ever been involved in training people knows that distinction. With regard to Senator Reid's particular example about the cleaning firm, it seems to me relatively clear that if instruction is given on the operation of the new cleaner-that is, if a person is shown how to use it, the pitfalls and dangers of it, and how to get the best out of it-that is closely supervised practice. If, however, the cleaner is in some back room under a pile of rubbish and the person says to an employee `There it is, go to it', that is not closely supervised training; it is just work experience.

SPEECH.PARA: The distinction between the two has been drawn often in professional areas. In fact, almost every profession has a distinction between those two and has employed it for a long time. I have discussed this matter with a number of industries, and the industries know the difference. I think that the structure will be very easy to operate in practice in the industries themselves. I wish to ask a question which arises from clause 43 and deals with the ability under that clause for there to be a shopping exercise in relation to one's structured training course. If one nips off to a particular registered industry agent and finds that that agent does not think too highly about one's structured course, one can go to someone else and then someone else again. In fact, one will be able to make a tour until one finds someone who is willing to agree to that particular structured course. That seems to me to be a very undesirable practice. Has the Government looked at this item and will it be covered in the guidelines?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very much aware of the problem and this will be one of the issues that will be considered in developing the guidelines which operate for industry training agents. For instance, if an agent rejects a training program but fails to provide adequate advice to the employer on how to structure the program in order to make it eligible, then the employer should be able to seek advice from another agent. However, we would not want an employer who had his training program rejected by one industry training agent to take that rejected program to another agent rather than appealing the decision to the training advisory body. The training advisory body will monitor the performance of industry training agents, so it should be difficult for them to provide certificates incorrectly over a long period. These two responses indicate that this is a issue on which the Government will keep an eye.

-One of the great difficulties that the Opposition faces in the committee stage of this Bill is that we do not have the guidelines before us. There are many anticipatory questions which arise because we do not have those guidelines. I suggest-and this is meant as a helpful note-that it will be necessary early in the New Year for the Government to bring in amendments to at least one of the Bills that we have before us today because the framework on which the legislation is based is one of structured courses. During the comments that have been made across the chamber, it has become fairly clear that recognition will be given to `closely supervised practice'. That important concept will have to be incorporated in amendments that will need to follow the introduction of the guidelines early in the New Year, otherwise a lot of ambiguities and disputation will arise as to what is eligible expenditure.

—I have a question on clause 101. Is it envisaged that forms will have to be filled in in order to meet these requirements? There is a fairly hefty penalty for contravention of this clause-a $3,000 fine. Will the Australian Taxation Office outline the actual forms to be filled in?-because there is a fair amount of scope for argument as to whether the records are being kept properly. There certainly needs to be an education program so that people understand what they have to do. It is implied in the body of the clause that this is not the case, but I think the Minister should make this matter quite clear.

—I am advised that guidelines will be issued to provide industry with assistance in terms of the sort of information that needs to be kept for the Australian Taxation Office to be in a position to ensure the application of the Act.

—I wish to raise a point on clause 85, which is the same point as I made earlier. Why should false statements be okay in one situation and not in another? That is a strange way of doing things. If the Minister reads that clause and then looks back at his answer that he gave in relation to clause 9, he will see what I mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also refer to the answer that I gave on clause 9. As we are coming to the end of the committee stage, I refer to the fact that Senator Reid asked for information on the amendments that have been made as a consequence of consultation. I have here about 1 3/4 pages of amendments which basically indicate the main changes to the draft legislation. I have checked with Senator Reid and I seek leave to incorporate these in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CHANGES TO DRAFT LEGISLATION
Background

Draft legislation was prepared and released for comment on 19 February. As a result of comments received from industry and useful suggestions from the Australian Democrats, a number of changes have been made to the legislation.
Main Changes

(i) introduction of industry training agents, to be registered by the training advisory body, who will be able to give advice to employers and issue certificates (binding on the Commissioner of Taxation) stating that certain training activities and expenditures are eligible. Industry training agents will be industry-based, provide a point of contact for employers and reduce the Tax Office's role in the interpretation of what is eligible training
Clause:
Part 10, Sections 88-92-Registration of Industry Training Agents
(ii) providing for corporate members of a business group to be able to treat themselves a single employer if they so wish, so as to reduce the burden of record keeping on related companies
Clause:
Section 12-Election by members of business groups.

(iii) replacing the requirement that structured training programs have an assessment process included, by a requirement that programs formulate expected outcomes or the means for identifying productivity improvements. This maintains the requirement that employers identify the expected impact of the training before the program begins, but they are not required to assess participants.
Clause:
Section 27 (2) (d)-Structured training program
(iv) extending the definition of who can design a structured training program to include persons with appropriate experience, as well as qualifications
Clause:
Section 27 (2) (a)-Structured training program
(v) allowing employers to claim either the equivalent of the depreciation allowance on equipment or the total capital expenditure at the time it is incurred
Clause:
Section 26 (2)-Examples of eligible training expenditure
(vi) broadening the definition of what buildings and equipment count as eligible expenditure from ``solely for training purposes'' to ``solely or principally for training purposes''.
Clause:
Section 26 (1) (h)-Examples of eligible training expenditure
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill agreed to.

Bill agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Bolkus) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately three Bills, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1990, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1990. Each of these Bills could well do with a separate debate, but because of the time schedule the Government has brought these together and we are, in effect, debating three entirely unrelated Bills. However, I thank Senator McMullan for at least separating one Bill, which was debated earlier, because in the other House they had to face the prospect of debating four unrelated Bills in a very restricted time. Fortunately, we have slightly more time.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1989 failed to pass through the Parliament before the March election and was introduced earlier this year to give effect to the Budget announcement relating to the timing of remittances of pay as you earn (PAYE) deductions and to adjust the operation of the quarterly instalment system of paying provisional tax. This Bill repeats the earlier remitter provisions but omits the provisional tax proposals of that earlier Bill. The Government's failure to organise its program adequately to serve passage of a Bill before the election necessitated the Australian Taxation Office revising most provisional tax assessments. Since there was no legislation for several of the components in the original assessments, such as the uplift factor amongst others, I believe that the Australian Taxation Office handled the situation very professionally. However, there needs to be a mechanism to overcome a future situation of this kind. In fact, most taxpayers received reduced assessments but some had increased demands over what they expected to pay in situations, particularly where their taxable incomes tended to fall as compared with the previous year.

Under the earlier remitter measures, group employers who have total PAYE remittances exceeding $5m for a financial year will be required to pay group tax twice per month in lieu of the current practice of once per month. This stage is the first step towards PAYE remittance arrangements aimed at moving, according to the Government, larger group employers to a bi-monthly system, and small employers, comprising the majority of the remitters, to a less frequent payment system than at present and possibly with the discontinuation of the tax stamp system. We have had a lot of criticism of alleged pressure to move some of these people off the tax stamp system. I endorse the move to less frequent remittances from the small employers. That is one of the reasons why we are not proceeding with some of the amendments that we had proposed earlier.

In respect of the 1989 Bill the Government claimed that the estimate of the one-off revenue gain would be $550m in 1989-90. This claim, strangely, is repeated in respect of the current Bill, notwithstanding, that it is not intended to operate until June 1990, whereas the other Bill operated from 1989. Given the procedures necessary to be undertaken by the Australian Taxation Office once this legislation is passed to put these measures into place, I think it is doubtful that the full amount could be realised. However, I am not prepared to estimate what the figure should be.

When we look at the consideration of the issues, this Bill is one of last year's Budget Bills. The changes to PAYE remittances will have the effect of bringing forward revenue from 1989-90 to 1990-91. We have described that as an example of the innovative accounting of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) designed to magnify the size of the Budget surplus in this financial year. Essentially, the major component of the $550m is a timing difference. It will dress up the surplus for the current year. In effect, the interest gain will be quite small. In part, one must dispute the financial impact of the $550m since this is an exact repeat of the figure when the Bill was introduced last year, and yet this time around it will not operate until the month of June. It is now going to have an operation of only one month.

The 1989 Bill was blocked by the Senate on three occasions. A Senate amendment sought to exempt public benevolent institutions from the earlier remitters provisions for the following reasons. We believed, as an Opposition, that at the time there was a lack of recognition by the Commonwealth of the shortfall, which this measure would introduce, to these sorts of institutions so far as their revenue was concerned and it would cause them a loss of working capital. However, in the intervening period we have had over six months, and almost a new financial year, in which governments, both State and Federal, have had time to rectify this Budget position. At the time we acknowledged the unique position of these institutions utilising public funds for community purposes. Honourable senators must recall that we pressed the Government on three occasions in regard to this matter. The Government was quite heartless and failed to recognise this important position faced by these community organisations which included public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and community purposes. It was really a question of just how far can an opposition press a government on humanitarian grounds to recognise an urgent need within the community.

We believe that the new arrangements virtually amount to unannounced tax on these institutions, which have limited power to recover the extra charges, because the finance for these organisations have been established in the previous year. Yet after 1 July we had a further impost which they would not normally have been able to cover and there would have been a shortfall of funds which we detailed at some length last year. The fact that these institutions are already exempted from a wide range of both Federal and State taxes I believe, highlighted an obvious anomaly.

I acknowledge that in the intervening time the Opposition has had lots of representations from other non-profit organisations seeking to be covered in our exemptions. We were very cognisant of the fact that, once one starts introducing particular items for exemption, there will always be difficulties for those who are left out. We are in favour of making a tax system fair to everybody of all classes across the board. We believe that six months has given these organisations time to reorganise their accounting routines. Because of the proximity to the start of the new financial year to get the additional revenue that they need, we will not be proceeding with the original amendment.

At the same time we still recognise that the Government has failed to give proper regard to the negative cash flow that this Bill will have on public funded bodies such as hospitals, universities and public benevolent institutions. On the other hand, we have to recognise that there is a quid pro quo in that the Government says that as part of this deal it is offering small employers a strategy of paying group tax much less frequently.

The Opposition's decision not to pursue the amendments was taken recognising that the institutions concerned have now had over six months to reorganise their payroll systems and that the Government has had a similar time to adjust for extra finance to compensate for the loss of working capital. It is not our responsibility to back-door finance to these sorts of organisations. It is the Government's responsibility to provide finance through the normal financing patterns. So the only period where there should be a genuine shortfall is probably less than one month.

To pursue the amendment further, we believe, would be both technical and difficult to justify, given that it is a Budget measure and that the Government deems this money to be absolutely necessary. The Government raised the fallacious argument that it would impact on the Government's decision as to whether interest rates could be lowered at that time, but I suppose any argument is better than none in a storm or when one is in an embattled position.

I believe that the amendments we posed at the time should never have been seen as a replacement for funding from both Commonwealth and State governments. Government assistance to public benevolent institutions, hospitals and universities is provided for by means of outlay measures which are subject to review each 1 July. Seeing that these will be reviewed to operate from 1 July, these institutions as a result of our delaying tactics will now only have to suffer a penalty for less than one month.

Further consideration had to be given to the Government's response that it was the first step in small employers paying group tax less frequently, a decision which the coalition welcomes and which we did not want to jeopardise.

It has never been the coalition's intention to play politics with government-I used this word in the sales tax debate the other day-in regard to what I call genuine, non-political revenue-raising legislation.

A flaw which we raised in regard to the earlier Bill still remains, that is, the inconsistency in the time period in which remittances must be made. A group employer paying its employees on the fourteenth of the month gets only seven days to make the remittance, as it must be paid by the twenty-first of the month. However, a group employer paying its employees on the fifteenth of the month has 22 days to make the payment, which is not due until the seventh of the following month. So in its present form the amendment Bill will serve only to encourage businesses to pay their employees once a month, preferably on the fifteenth, with their pay as you earn remittances due on the seventh of the next month. Thus the revenue gain will be minimal. A far more equitable and cleaner arrangement would have been for payment to fall due either seven or 14 days after payday for those group employers affected by the Bill.

The fact that this Bill was drafted rather hastily has resulted in a possible loophole for large employers in that there are no grouping arrangements. I find this rather strange. What large employers can do is split off into company A and company B for the purposes of group remittances and avoid the twice monthly provisions. So a certain weakness exists in the drafting of the Bill. There should have been provision for consolidation to stop the artificial demarcation of companies into separate companies simply for the purpose of overcoming the early remittances provisions. The loophole will be exploited by certain companies. It was an issue that we raised earlier.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1990 addresses at least 10 principal areas. Two of these areas, quarterly provisional tax and provisional tax instalments for 1990-91, replace similar measures previously contained in Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, which lapsed due to the election, and which have been omitted from the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1990, which I have just discussed.

The section on quarterly provisional tax gives effect to two Budget proposals adjusting the operation of the instalments system for the paying of provisional tax. Effective for assessments on or after 4 December 1989, the threshold for general provisional tax exemption will be increased from $5,000 to $8,000-I note that date because if we did not have that date included there would be further complications such as the necessity to have a further revision of provisional tax arrangements-and this exemption is applicable to provisional tax payable in the current year and subsequent years. In addition, any excess provisional tax credit no longer will be offset against a quarterly instalment of provisional tax for the succeeding year which has been notified but is not yet due for payment. This is a matter that we have been pressing on the Government and the Tax Commissioner for quite some time because it is a matter of some concern to provisional taxpayers. So we welcome that.

With regard to provisional tax instalments for 1990-91, where the amount of a taxpayer's instalment of provisional tax for 1990-91 would ordinarily be calculated by reference to his total liability for provisional tax for 1989-90, those amounts are instead to be determined by reference to a notional income. These are the sorts of problems that the Government got itself into by its failure to properly organise its legislative program before the March election.
