The amount of that total notional liability will be the amount that would have been determined in accordance with the method proposed by the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 had that Bill become law. I believe that this is further reason why we do need, in similar circumstances in the future, a mechanism to overcome these sorts of impasses.

I mentioned previously that we need this sort of mechanism. As one can see from the legislation, the Government has made the changes to the tax law apply even though they were not passed at the appropriate time. I trust that no penalties will apply to those who may have done their tax calculations according to the previous rules in this instance due to a lack of ruling. To do otherwise, in the absence of such a mechanism, I believe would be unfair.

The changes to the various laws as a result of amendments to Commonwealth and State companies codes, allowing companies to buy back shares in themselves, are also included in this amendment Bill. The arrangements whereby the amount paid to a shareholder for a share will be taken to be a dividend to the extent that the amount is drawn from the company's distributable profits, except where the buy back is made on the stock exchange, is agreeable to the coalition. For Australian-owned, non-resident companies the exemption which excluded them from the definition of foreign controller, and hence from the scope of the thin capitalisation control system, is removed effectively from 1 July 1990. This term `thin capitalisation' is used to describe the funding of foreign investment in Australia that is excessively geared with in-house loans instead of equity.

There is a distinct tax advantage in maximising the amount of in-house debt, which allows profits to be lifted to the foreign owner in the form of tax deductable interest payments, rather than in the form of non-deductable dividends. So the thin capitalisation rules control profit shifting by imposing maximum permissible debt-equity ratios on foreign controlled Australian enterprises where the prescribed ratio is exceeded. Interest deductions are derived on excess debt owing to the foreign controller and other non-resident associates. Thus the lifting of the exemption for Australian-owned non-resident companies to thin capitalisation rules would imply that they are now subject to them.

The coalition notes that the gift provisions for gifts of $2 to the National Foundation for Australian Women Limited, Landcare Australian Limited and the Foundation for Development Cooperation Ltd will be tax deductable under this Bill. The inclusion of Landcare Australia is particularly pleasing to the Opposition, as we believe there is a large amount of work to be done on combating soil erosion, which this group undertakes. We also note an extension, which is part of the Government's shipping reform strategy, of the current fiscal regime for new ships for a further period of five years from 30 June 1992.

The coalition also concurs with the fringe benefits tax amendments included with this amendment, which will extend the period of amortising the taxable value of certain fringe benefits provided under remote area home ownership schemes from seven to 15 years, subject, of course, to certain conditions of ownership being met.

On the matter of quoting the tax file numbers for investment purposes, certain investors are to be exempt from these requirements. The Bill will widen the manner in which pensioners may claim an exemption from quoting a tax file number other than in writing and including by phone.

The removal of the need for superannuation funds to obtain actuarial certification when claiming deductions for the cost of death and disability cover for members of the fund will ease the burden of people in these strenuous situations. I think this was a matter that I referred to in earlier legislation about two years ago. It is pleasing to see it introduced now but I regret that it has taken two years. Having just passed other superannuation Bills this week, which will no doubt create more work for the superannuation funds, I trust that this amendment will work towards easing their administrative load. In discussing those Bills I did put to the Government further measures aimed at easing the administrative load and increasing the efficiency of those funds. I trust the Government will proceed in that direction but I hope it will not take two years to effect it. In summary, the coalition does not object to the Bill and will not propose any amendments, nor oppose its passage. However, I will raise certain matters in the committee stage. Because of the time constraints in this second reading stage of this Bill, I will raise other matters during the committee stage of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3).

I turn now to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). This addresses a significant number of measures, most of which arose as a result of the 1989 Budget. The first measure is in regard to beneficiary rebates. Currently a rebate is granted for social security beneficiaries, which includes sickness, unemployment and job search allowance, so that where these payments are the person's sole or predominant source of income no tax is payable. This is a fair and reasonable amendment. We have no problems. It is proposed to vary the rebate on an age related basis because the various social security benefits are now paid on this basis. For example, those in receipt of the single, under 18 years and living at home benefit will have a separate rebate for tax from those on single, under 18 and living away from home benefit.

Regarding the Medicare levy measure, the coalition welcomes the addressing of the anomaly where an exempt person has a dependant who pays the full levy and then when the exempt person must pay half the Medicare levy that his or her income would otherwise require. This covers, basically, people in the Defence Force. In other words, they were no longer exempt. This amendment, we believe, rectifies the situation, which will be particularly pleasing to people associated with the Defence Force.

The third measure relates to losses. I will debate this in a little more detail at the committee stage; but currently taxpayers are allowed to carry forward losses incurred for income tax purposes for seven years. If they have not been recouped by that time they lapse. For primary production losses and capital losses, an unlimited carry forward is allowed. This Bill proposes allowing unlimited carry forward for income losses incurred in 1989-90 and subsequent years. Some criticism has been levelled at this move in terms of not allowing income tax losses only and not all losses to be carried forward indefinitely. However, the coalition does not propose to amend this legislation. That is a decision of government; it has to carry it.

The fourth measure relates to quarrying operations. Again we have some concern here because there is a number of inconsistencies. Special deductions have been available for decades for capital expenditure in connection with mining and petroleum operations. These provisions have not applied to quarrying operations because of a High Court decision to that effect in 1969. However, just prior to the Budget the Federal Court ruled that open cut extraction of limestone to produce cement was mining. Thus, the extension to formally include quarrying operations in all except two instances can be viewed as affirming the Federal Court decision and a modifying of the rules accordingly.

Whilst mine development expenditure is allowed as a deduction over the life of the mine or for 10 years, whichever is the shorter, because of the generally longer life of quarries, development expenditure is proposed to be allowed as a deduction over the life of the quarry or for 20 years, whichever is the shorter.

On the other hand, capital expenditure on housing and welfare to employees is deductable for mining purposes. Because of the proximity of quarries to urban areas, the value of the land and the buildings provided to employees would be expected to maintain or increase in value and hence no tax benefit would be appropriate in these circumstances. I would like to put to the Government that a fairer concept would have been to exclude housing welfare except where the quarry is located in an isolated rural area, rather than having a total exemption. Had it followed this course I believe it would not have got itself so confused over some of these provisions. As I will explain in the committee stage of this debate, a number of the provisions are superfluous and redundant or unnecessary.

The fifth measure extends the current income tax exemption for non-profit clubs which are engaged in athletic sports or games in which human beings are the sole participants to all non-profit bodies established for the promotion of or encouragement of any game or sport or community purposes. Again, in the committee stage I will be referring specifically to a problem that arises in relation to clause 6. The coalition applauds this move by the Government in encouraging sporting and community service based bodies who, we believe, make a very important contribution to our society.

The sixth area covered is the removal of the income tax exemption for the Australian Wool Testing Authority. This company, which was formed in 1982, has had a tax exemption applicable since then. In order that it operate as a competitive player in the market place, as was originally intended, again we support the move to remove this tax exemption.

The seventh and eighth amendments deal with dividend streaming of imputation and securities lending arrangements. I have several comments that I would like to make in relation to this. Problems associated with recent chemical contamination of land have placed farmers in a difficult position where they voluntarily dispose of livestock. The new provisions provide relief by extending concessions to voluntary disposal of livestock, similar to those available for certain specified forced sales of animals. Owners who voluntarily dispose of stock arising from contamination of land may either use the profit to reduce the cost of the replacement stock or spread the profits forward by equal instalments over five years. Following these amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act, we now provide a concessional taxation basis in circumstances of profits now arising from voluntary disposals resulting from contamination of land, death or compulsory destruction of livestock for control or eradication of disease, and finally fire, drought and flood.

The tenth item covered by the legislation is the increase in the pensioner rebate. This will ensure that a single pensioner may earn non-pensionable income up to the income test free limit of $40 per week and married pensioners up to $70 per week combined and still not pay tax. In the case of married pensioners, the transferring of the rebate excess from one spouse to another I believe will be a move appreciated by the pensioners. The date on which this ruling is to have effect has been causing some concern. The change was proposed in April 1989, almost 12 months ago. As I understand it, it is to apply to the financial year 1989-90. However, as recently as last week I had a constituent contact me to say that social security was not acknowledging the new ruling and thus she was being penalised by having her pension benefits cut despite her husband's excess rebate. I trust this matter will be cleared up by the passage of this Bill and that she will receive entitlements to the announced date. I would like a clarification on that, if I may, during the response.

The eleventh item refers to allowable tax deductions for gifts of $2 or more to a number of worthwhile organisations. I am particularly pleased to see deductability allowed for the life education centres. The work being done through these centres for today's youth will be invaluable in future years when we have a generation coming through who refuse to become involved with drugs and alcohol to the detriment of their bodies as a result of the learning they have received through these life education centres.

The twelfth item refers to a change in relation to Australian films. It covers division 10ba which provides generous tax concessions for tax investment in Australian films. This is a technical change. Tax concessions for the funds invested have to be deposited in the Australian Film Industry Trust Fund. The amendment before the Senate today removes this requirement and will, I believe, simplify the administration of this concession.

The thirteenth measure exempts from sales tax imported uncut precious and semi-precious gemstones and imported coins. Since sales tax is not levied on Australian produced uncut diamonds or Australian coins, it was deemed appropriate to also exempt imported equivalents.
Finally, because of the shortage of time, perhaps I may refer to the tax file number and the scrip lending during the committee stage of the debate.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have been advised that a number of attendants have withdrawn their labour until midday tomorrow. The industrial action results from a dispute between the attendants and the Department of the Senate and the House of Representatives in relation to current award restructuring negotiations under the structural efficiency principle. Because of the industrial action there will be no messenger services until further notice. Copies of committee reports and other documents will be available from the Table Office and Sub-Tables Office.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank Senator Watson for his broad support for the three Bills that are before us and, as usual, for the constructive nature of his comments. Can I respond to some of the points which need response at this stage; others, more appropriately, will be dealt with, as he has indicated, in that committee stage. Senator Watson queried in two ways the question of the $550m. I suppose none of us can be absolutely certain, until after the event, whether that is the precise amount. His other question was: how could it be a $550m bring forward if we passed it in December and still be a $550m bring forward if we pass it in May?

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that there will be one fortnightly payment brought forward that would not otherwise have been made in this financial year, whenever the Bill is passed. All the other fortnightly payments which would have been made have been caught up in the monthly payments. There may be some slight effect but it will be substantially the same.

As for the public benevolent institution point that Senator Watson made, I do not accept the original reasons that he put forward, and the Government never did. I will not reiterate the debate about that. One of the problems with the Senate is that we have that debate too often. We certainly do not want to have it again now. I do acknowledge that even if those arguments had been valid at the time, the six months that have passed since the matter was first debated would satisfactorily have obviated them.

Senator Watson also raised a concern about grouping provisions. At the moment we think that the question of people entering into artificial arrangements to avoid liability is adequately addressed through two parts of the Bill. The new section 221ed in clause 4 groups wholly owned companies for the purpose of applying the threshold. Also, the new subsection 221ec (5) allows the Commissioner to determine that an employer remit twice monthly. We think that those two proposals overcome the perceived drafting weakness. We are confident that that will prove to be the case.

I do not want, at this stage, to go into any of the matters raised in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Anything that needs to be dealt with can be dealt with in the committee stage. I do note Senator Watson's claim that we are two years behind him in regard to one matter. Without necessarily conceding it, I think it is an indication of the role that debate in the Senate can sometimes play.

With regard to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill No. 2, there are two matters that Senator Watson raised that I think need to be looked at: the question of deductability for housing for quarries in isolated rural areas and the definition of community welfare groups. I am not sure that the suggestions he is raising for possible future consideration are ones that will necessarily improve the situation, particularly the one concerning the definition of community groups. I understand the point he is trying to achieve. I think the change might, in fact, narrow rather than broaden the matter, but we will deal with that in the committee stage. On the question on which he sought clarification, that is essentially a Department of Social Security matter on which we will try to get some advice to him as soon as possible. I do not have any information to provide at the moment. I thank honourable senators for their support and urge the passage of the Bills.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the Committee stages of the Bills be an order of the day for a later hour this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, this Bill is not opposed by the Opposition but, in saying that, we recognise that there are some aspects of it which may cause concern for the future. Given the number of present and former Commonwealth public servants that live in my electorate, it is not surprising that it is a matter in which I take an interest. No doubt the Minister on duty at this time will do so also. It is a Bill which will result, perhaps, in hardship to some public servants.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not surprising that the Superannuated Commonwealth Officers Association is very concerned about the way the Bill may be implemented and operated and the impact that it will have on its members. I think it is totally reasonable to think that a person who has been off work for a long period, while he might seem to be medically fit and able to earn, is not able to obtain any form of employment. He may even have lost some of the skills that he had previously and thus not have any skills which would enable him to re-enter the work force.

I think the concern of the Superannuated Commonwealth Officers' Association is that the able to earn provision should not be implemented harshly and its implementation should take into account the fact that some people may have been off work for quite a long time. Implementation should take into account the social consequences of that being the case. Sudden withdrawal can be quite traumatic indeed.

The Opposition takes the view that the scheme should be administered sympathetically. We ask the Government to give an undertaking that it will be administered sympathetically and take into account hardship. We give an undertaking that we will be monitoring the operation of this Bill very closely indeed. I certainly will. I shall bring to the Senate any cases where I believe there is hardship and where sufficient sympathy has not been exercised in its operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid would know that she and I have a special interest in this legislation. I can assure the Senate and the Opposition that Comcare as an organisation, the Government collectively and I individually will also be monitoring the implementation of what looks like a sensible reform but I am aware that there is some potential concern. I thank her for her support and we look forward to the prompt passage of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1990
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 4, after proposed subsection 221EC(9), add the following new subsection:
``(10) This section does not apply to:
(a) a public hospital;
(b) a public benevolent institution;
(c) a public university.''

This particular matter is one of long-standing in terms of the Senate. This particular Bill was first introduced on 26 October last year and it was passed in November. In the committee stage Senator Watson moved an amendment that the Australian Democrats supported. That went down to the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives disagreed to the amendment on 27 November and sent it back up to us. The Senate insisted on its amendment on 30 November and sent it back down to the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives disagreed with the Senate's amendment and sent it back to us on 30 November. The Senate continued to insist on it on 11 December and sent it back down to the House of Representatives. The Bill has now come back to us today. Unfortunately, at this stage the Opposition has indicated that it will go to water on the exercise and allow the Government to pass this particular piece of legislation.
On 1 November, Senator McLean, speaking for the Australian Democrats, said this with regard to the amendment then proposed by Senator Watson:

We identify with the amendment proposed by Senator Watson, which simply reverts to an exemption which has been granted under previous tax policies to hospitals, benevolent organisations and universities in not imposing upon them an unnecessary requirement to meet twice monthly group tax payments. We cite that exemption as having been appropriate in the past. We have not had a reasonable explanation from the Treasury as to why that exemption should be removed.
On 2 November, speaking to his amendment, Senator Watson moved that amendment and then said this:

In opposing the amendment, the legislation will go down to the other House and will then come back again. It is not a taxing measure. We are not taking money away because, as I mentioned, it is a machinery Bill; it is just rearranging the collection of tax. It has an indirect effect. If the Government is using this measure as a taxing Bill, then it is a disgrace. It is morally wrong and outrageous to use the back-door methods that it will be attempting to apply to get extra revenue from public hospitals and public universities which, according to its logic, the Government should not be doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It now being 12.45, under sessional order I shall report progress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Multiple Sclerosis Society of the Australian Capital Territory was incorporated in Canberra on 29 November 1978. Its aim was to serve people in this area with multiple sclerosis and similar disorders and to help their families. For five years it operated as a self-help organisation relying on the voluntary efforts of members and their families and friends. After it received a community development fund grant of about $5,000 in 1984, it employed a part time welfare worker, which enabled it to expand its operations.

SPEECH.PARA: In the following year it received a large and very generous donation from Miss Gloria McKerrow which permitted it to proceed with some of the things it had been talking about and to meet the needs of the community in a different way. At that time it employed a part time executive director and set about raising funds to build a facility in Canberra. There had been extensive consultations under the leadership of the then President, Sir John Overall, to ascertain what members of the Society and their families believed would benefit them and were needed. A firm of architects was engaged, a block of land was obtained at Deakin, and a building was built. The Society recognised at the time that there were to be three stages in the construction: initially, a day care centre and some office accommodation; subsequently, a very much needed respite care house; and, eventually-and this has not yet happened-a separate office block.

The suitability of this site included that it is near the centre of Canberra; it provides reasonable access from all suburbs; it is on the ACTION bus route; it is only about a kilometre from shops; it is opposite a swimming complex with facilities for people with disabilities; it is close to the John James Hospital, which has doctors and other specialists relevant to people with multiple sclerosis; it is near the rehabilitation services of the Woden Valley Hospital; and is near two schools, both of which indicated that they would welcome interaction between students and the Society's members. So the proposal proceeded. A public fund to raise money was successful and stage one was built. Miss McKerrow gave a subsequent large donation which enabled the second stage to go ahead.

The then Minister for Community Services and Health, the Honourable Neal Blewett, MP, opened the first stage on 10 November 1987. It was a day care centre. People suffering from multiple sclerosis and similar problems could go to the centre and engage in activities and discussions. It removed them from being socially isolated, as many were, and gave them the opportunity to meet other people.

The second stage involves a four-bedroom respite care house. Respite care is something that is desperately needed in Canberra at all levels. It is something that is very scarce. This house was built at a cost of just over $200,000 and was opened on 20 February 1989. The reason I am raising this matter today is that it has scarcely been able to be used since that time because the Government, for the most extraordinary reason, has refused to consider appropriate funding for it that would be available in any other situation.

The day care centre which I referred to has operated most successfully over the last 18 months. Over 100 people attend each month and participate in a range of activities. The respite care house can be used only by those who can afford to care for themselves totally or who have a carer that they can bring with them. Of course, not all people can afford to do this. All others are excluded.

Applications have been submitted to the Department of Community Services and Health under the Disability Services Act, and to the Australian Capital Territory Government. Some money came from the Australian Capital Territory Government but all avenues have been rejected by the Department of Community Services and Health and the Federal Government.

The reasons why funding has been rejected make interesting reading. The Society has been told that the respite care house is not in a residential area. It has been built in Deakin on land provided by the Government. At the time, it was the Federal Government which approved construction on that site. But another part of the same Federal Government, the Department of Community Services and Health, rejected funding for people going there for respite care because it is not in a residential area. It is right next to the day care centre. Any person who goes there for respite care is able then to go across the path to the day care centre and mix with other people without any travel and transport hassles. It is, I would say, less than two kilometres from a street with residential houses. If it happened to be located two kilometres away, it would get funding. It is not isolated; it is not out in the middle of the Brindabella Ranges on it own; but it is said that it is not located in a residential area. Yet it has been approved by the proper authorities to be what it is-a respite care house-in that particular area.

The other reason given-and in some ways from the correspondence one might think that this is the more significant reason-is that it is on the same site as the day care centre. I defy anybody to give an explanation that makes sense of that. The day care centre is the place to which people with disabilities go for companionship; to indulge in activities that they are able to partake in together; a place where they can talk and have meetings with doctors, physiotherapists or others and generally share some social interaction of which they are otherwise deprived. But it is on the same site as the day care centre. If it were not on the same site as the day care centre it could receive the appropriate funding that the Department of Community Services and Health would otherwise make available for those who were eligible to use it.

The Society says that it is there for short term respite purposes with a maximum occupation of three weeks. It is not a permanent residence. There is no intention for it to be that; it would not be suitable for that. It is for respite care. Very significantly, it gives people staying there for a time an opportunity, while they are away from their home indulging in respite care, to be near other people and not to be isolated, as might otherwise be the case, had they stayed in their normal home and were merely visited by someone to provide services from time to time. It means that they have interaction with a variety of people and that is of benefit to them. It provides easy access to both the paid staff of the Multiple Sclerosis Society and to the volunteers.

The present location was determined after extensive consultation with all of the people concerned. It is on an absolutely lovely site which has an absolutely splendid view of the Brindabella Ranges. It could not be a more appropriate location. I could say that the decision is mindless; I could say that it is unbelievable. The building was opened, I remind the Senate, in February 1989. The Society has been more than patient in attempting to deal with government to work its way around these unbelievable barriers which have been placed in front of it-that it is not in a residential area and that it is on the same site as the day care centre. I cannot believe its patience. It has worked hard to continue to raise funds to enable the building to be used as best it can. I invite honourable senators to go and look at it to see how lovely it is.

The Senate will scarcely believe this: the Society has been told that funds could be provided on an interim basis while it finds a permanent site in another location. One really cannot credit that anybody could have said such a thing. Of course, there would be an additional capital cost to acquire another place. Let us remember that it is on the same site as the day care centre, so it cannot be sold as it is of no use to anybody else for any other purpose. The concept of placing it elsewhere does not meet with the users' wishes. The members of the Society do not want that to happen because they recognise the isolation that would flow from it and the additional costs of transport to bring people staying in the respite care house to the day care centre each day so they could have some companionship.

We are talking about the recurrent costs which would enable those who cannot afford to use the respite care house from their own resources to have access to the sort of government funding which is available and which other people get. Others are not deprived of it because their buildings are not located on the same site as a day care centre and they are located in a residential area.

I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is present, knows of this story. I hope that he will not just regard this as a Thursday lunchtime chatter during which time senators get things off their chests. I hope he and I between us can see that the mindless bureaucracy that somehow interprets rules to allow a thing like this to happen can be changed and that this Society can get on with the work towards which the community here has so generously donated. It is not as though government has been asked for the capital costs. The buildings have been built with donations from Miss McKerrow and public subscriptions. It just seems unbelievable, and that is why I bring the matter to the attention of the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday next week it will be one year since the massacre by the Chinese military of peaceful demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. I think it is timely to reflect on this tragic anniversary, to look at what has happened since to the People's Republic of China and at what implications there are for Australia's relations with one of the major regional powers.

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty International, as honourable senators are aware, issued a comprehensive report in mid-May this year which put to rest any lingering doubts about the scale of the Chinese military crackdown on the peaceful student and worker pro-democracy demonstrations. Amnesty's figures contrast sharply with those of the Chinese leadership in their revisionist assessment of how the peaceful demonstrators were crushed. Sadly, some of the same misinformation has been given credence in Australia. This is most certainly to be regretted.

Amnesty International says that over 1,000 citizens were killed in Beijing alone, and at least 6,000 have been detained, tried or executed throughout the country since the June crackdown. The real number of those who have been detained, it is believed, runs into the tens of thousands. In its report Amnesty lists more than 650 prisoners that it has been able to identify. Given the forthcoming sad anniversary, I think it is appropriate for the Australian Government to call on the Chinese Government to reveal what has happened to these many thousands of unidentified prisoners.

Amnesty also noted in its report that secret executions had been extensive. Although only a few dozen executions have been publicly reported, some sources say several hundred people were secretly killed in Beijing alone between June and August last year. Of course, following the massacre there was widespread international condemnation of the killings and the People's Republic of China was subjected to wide diplomatic isolation. Many Western nations undertook some form of protest to express their disapproval over China's actions. Although there have been some attempts at normalising relations-notably by the United States, Japan and the United Kingdom-this process has not gone far. Indeed, the limited sanctions that have been applied, notably on military weapons, have had an effect on the People's Republic of China.

One interesting aspect of the international condemnation of the regime's activities is that China's current international isolation has been compounded by the massive political changes in the Soviet Union and in eastern Europe. At a time when eastern Europe is opening to the winds of democratic change, seemingly, the People's Republic of China is heading in the opposite direction towards greater repression and state control over the daily lives of its people.

In the aftermath of June 1989 there have been some dramatic changes within the People's Republic, both at the political and at the economic levels. There has been widespread police action, including arrests and executions. This suggests that overt political repression has become a routine instrument of control of the leadership of the People's Republic of China. While the regime admitted in October 1989 to a total of 2,500 detainees as of late June, according to informed Western observers nationwide arrests are probably somewhere between 10,000 and 30,000. Of great concern to Australia should be the comments by the President of the Supreme People's Court which discounted the notion of the presumption of innocence of the accused.

The repression is aimed, of course, both at the intellectuals, the students, and at the ordinary working people. It has been assisted by a compliant judiciary and a renewed propaganda campaign against the so-called `bourgeois liberalisation'. Despite the lifting of martial law on 11 January this year, indications are that the campaign of repression is continuing.

China's leadership has recognised the importance of political stability, both for its own personal reasons and for the sake of ensuring continued Communist Party leadership. To this end there has been a deliberate policy of political stabilisation. Amongst other things, this has involved a re-emphasis on orthodox ideology and a move to strengthen the organisational and ideological leadership of the party. The current leadership has stressed the need for ideological indoctrination through the inculcation of the basic theories of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong thought. This is currently being juxtaposed against that bourgeois liberalism which I have just mentioned.

At the national level, the current leadership is inherently unstable. This is, of course, as a result of the current policy of political repression, the continuing problem of political succession, given the age of many of the current leaders, and as a result of the growing role of the military in political affairs, as is witnessed by the substantial increase in the defence budget. Of course, that could be seen as both a cause and a function of the instability.

The fact that the elderly Deng Xiaoping, who has resigned from all official party posts and government leadership positions, seemingly retains a supreme control position, is obviously indicative of the very delicate and unstable nature of the leadership issue, which is unlikely to be resolved until Deng Xiaoping dies and then, of course, only by a clash between the conservative and progressive elements of the leadership factions.

Together with the importance of political stability, the People's Republic regime has also recognised the importance of economic stability. This is spelt out in the decision of the Fifth Plenum, which states:
Economic stability is the foundation of political stability. If the economy is in trouble for prolonged periods, it will be difficult to have political stability and maintain social order.

Hence the emphasis of the current regime on a policy of political stabilisation to try to control what was in fact a rapidly overheating economy. The regime's emphasis has been on a return to the 1950s style of planned economy, with priority being given to state-owned large and medium enterprises. The factory manager responsibility system, introduced under the previous party secretary, Zhao Ziyang, is now obviously under threat. So, too, are the advances in production and efficiency which were made under that free enterprise system.

The prospects for stabilisation of China's economy are not good. The inflation rate last year was in excess of 20 per cent and industrial output increased only marginally. Most commentators believe that in the first quarter of this year China had nil economic growth; it may even have been negative. One result of the new economic policy restrictions post-June 1989 was the increase in unemployment, which went from 2 per cent to 4 per cent of the work force-that is, four million people. The real prospect of increasing unemployment tends also to enhance social and political instability, thereby ensuring continuing economic instability.

Throughout all of this turmoil, my Party has been supportive of the Government's policy with regard to our bilateral relations with China. We supported the full review of our relations, encompassing diplomatic, cultural, economic, development assistance, and political relations. We supported the broad thrust of what the Government was doing in cutting off party and political visits. Of course, there are now signs that the Government is relaxing this stance. There was a visit recently by the Chinese metallurgical Minister to Western Australia, to attend the opening of a joint venture. Similarly, the Australian Government has altered its earlier policy of suspending all ministerial visits. We now have a policy of reviewing each visit on a case by case basis.

Fairly obviously, a fine line must be drawn with regard to the question of our relations with the People's Republic. On the one hand we have to recognise China as a major regional and, indeed, world power. The nations of the region have a direct interest in ensuring that China remains an important pillar of regional stability. From Australia's point of view, it is obviously important that some lines of communication be nurtured so that our interests and concerns can be made known to the People's Republic.

On the other hand, the Democrats believe strongly that Australia should continue to speak out on human rights abuses in the People's Republic, and that this be a continuing factor in our bilateral relations. The recent report by the United States based human rights group, Asia Watch, which concluded that the Chinese authorities have increased the use of torture and political repression to suppress Tibetans is, of course, of great concern in this regard. We should reject outright Chinese criticism of so-called `interference in its internal affairs' and maintain the international push for the basic recognition and acceptance of fundamental human rights throughout the world.

From the Australian Democrats' point of view we urge the Government not to take the road that the United States Administration has taken with regard to the Chinese leadership. The United States has, to quote a media headline, `dropped human rights for ruthless pragmatism'. While there are some important economic arguments for continuing preferential trade relations with China for the United States, the Bush Administration's rhetoric on human rights concerns has not been matched by its actions. We have seen the same thing happen with regard to United States relations with the Soviet Union on the issue of the Baltic states. We will be better able to judge Australia's position with regard to these matters when we have seen the results of the current review of the position of Chinese students in Australia, which the Government is currently undertaking. It is our hope that the Australian Government will not wash its hands of its responsibilities as a good international citizen and that it will continue to highlight human rights abuses wherever they may occur, regardless of the attitude taken by those countries. Many people in China still doubtlessly thirst for democracy. I think it is very important that, whatever Australia does, we not be seen to be supporting, in any shape or form, the repression which occurred and that any subsequent movements with regard to our relations with the People's Republic of China be based very firmly on the basis that we want it to understand our total abhorrence of the human rights abuses that occurred at that time.

It is my hope that the transition in leadership in China will be peaceful, and that that transition will lead to a freeing up of the political regime within China. I hope that, in time, we will see China follow the route that so many other Communist countries have followed: that it will recognise that the repression, abuse, torture and killing of its own citizens is not the path to stability and that, indeed, the only way is to trust its own people and truly to become a People's Republic of China.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all the conservation issues that I have raised while I have been in this chamber I would have to say that the south-east forests of New South Wales would take first place, for a number of reasons. The first reason is that I have had a long professional association with those forests in acting as a scientific editor on studies conducted on the effect of woodchipping on wildlife in those forests. I have such a real appreciation of these particular native forests in south-east New South Wales that I was prepared to be arrested twice. This was not a light decision that I took because I am what is known as a cleanskin; I had never been arrested before and certainly had no convictions. I was certainly not the only one. More than 700 people were arrested in the south-east forests of New South Wales last year, including many prominent figures and many, many more ordinary citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: In raising the issue of the south-east forests so many times last year and, indeed, devoting to it the only matter of public importance that I was allocated in my term in parliament, I felt that I was representing the concerns of conservationists and locals living in the area and whose campaign led to the National Estate of the south-east forests becoming an issue of national concern. As a result of the concern expressed by so many people and my own concern, last year I introduced a Bill, the Australian Heritage Commission (National Estate Protection) Amendment Bill, in an attempt to provide the Government with a piece of legislation that it could usefully adopt, not to prohibit logging and other activities in the National Estate areas, but merely to regulate activities by foreign and domestic corporations which might adversely affect National Estate areas. In other words, it was not a piece of ambit legislation but a moderate and very realistic piece of legislation that I thought the Government could very usefully have adopted.

Significantly, both the former environment Minister, Senator Richardson, and the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, threatened to use the corporations power of the Constitution-perhaps I should not say threatened but promised-in relation to the south-east forests of New South Wales. Not long after I commenced the drafting process for this Bill, the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF), Director, Phillip Toyne, sent a letter to Prime Minister Hawke in May last year in which he specifically requested that the Government use its corporations power under the Constitution to protect the National Estate in the south-east forests of New South Wales.

In the latter part of the year the other major conservation group in this country, the Wilderness Society, launched, with much fanfare, a National Estate campaign at which Senator Richardson was the guest and major speaker. After the request by ACF Director Phillip Toyne and the launch of the Wilderness Society campaign, it was a great disappointment to myself and the many thousands of people concerned about the protection of the National Estate forests in New South Wales and elsewhere that the two main conservation groups in this country did not make this an issue during the election campaign. The much heralded Wilderness Society campaign sank without a trace during the election campaign and Phillip Toyne's letter was put on the back-burner by the Australian Conservation Foundation-much to the relief, I suppose, of the Government. I think the lack of judgment by those two groups and their inability or unwillingness to negotiate forcefully with the Government in the lead-up to the election led to the loss of a major opportunity to protect those forests and led also to the disappointment of many thousands of conservationists around the country who had been concerned about them.

Very recently, in fact just this month, there was the release of a report by two museum scientists. The report is called Wildlife Conservation in the South East Forests of New South Wales and it was prepared by Graham Pyke and Paul O'Connor. It is a very thorough review of the existing information on wildlife conservation within the south-east forest region of New South Wales and on the effects of logging and associated practices on the conservation values of these forests. The New South Wales Forestry Commission, in what has become fairly typical fashion, has criticised the report because the scientists who prepared it did not carry out any original research. This in my view was an irrelevant and actually quite a mischievous piece of criticism and unfortunately reflects the siege mentality of an institution which is desperately in need of reform in all its echelons, but particularly at the top.

The museum report was never intended as a piece of original work-it is a review of the work of dozens of scientists who carried out original work in the area. The value of the museum study is in its collation and assessment of the many scientific studies that have been carried out and in the sound recommendations it puts forward on the basis of examining those studies. To save the time of the Senate I seek leave to incorporate the recommendations in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUMMARY

The aim of this paper is to review existing information on wildlife conservation within the S.E. Forests Region of N.S.W. and on the effects of logging and associated practices on conservation values of these forests, and to then make recommendations based on this review. We consider Land Systems, Forest Types, Plant Communities, Plant Associations and individual animal species. We do not, however, consider individual plant species.
Our conclusion and recommendations are as follows:

1. Logging of forests brings about essentially permanent changes in the distributions and abundances of their plants and animals and destroys any wilderness value of the forests. There should therefore be reservation of some areas essentially free from the effects of logging and associated practices.

2. Present National Parks and other Reserves are essentially unlogged or ``oldgrowth'' and have generally low timber value because of their rugged topography. These existing reserves should therefore form the basis of a reserve system in the S.E. Forests Region. Additions to the Reserve system should come from the region's state forests as they contain almost all remaining old growth forest.

3. Five of the Region's ten Land systems, as defined by Keith and Sanders (1988), are inadequately conserved (i.e. Rainshadow Valley, Western Flat Country, Tableland, Granitic Hinterland, Escarpment). The same should be true for the Forest types (sensu Forestry Commission of N.S.W. 1989a), Plant Communities (sensu Keith and Sanders, 1988) and Plant Associations (sensu N.S.W. National Parks and Wildlife Service, 1986a) associated with these Land Systems.

4. A number of animal species are rare or endangered within the Region and are therefore of concern. These include 15 mammal, 2 bird and 1 fish species. Also of concern are the Region's 17 Microchiropteran bat species as their distributions are very poorly known and they are likely to be adversely affected by logging. The Region has been inadequately surveyed for all animal groups.
5. The reasonably large Coolangubra Wilderness area is not totally included in the present reserve system.

6. The conservation values of each of the Region's State Forests were assessed in terms of extent of old-growth forest, presence of areas of poorly conserved Land systems, wilderness area, records of animal species of concern, potential to join with or link other reserve areas, and presence of areas of high predicted arboreal marsupial density. Based on these criteria, the Coolangubra Wilderness Area and adjoining parts of Coolangubra State Forest have the highest conservation value.

7. We recommend that the Coolangubra Wilderness and State Forest be added to the Reserve System. This would result in the reservation of the last remaining unreserved old growth area of poorly conserved Western Flat Country, significant areas of Escarpment and Granitic Hinterland, which are also inadequately conserved, and an area containing many animal species of concern and high densities of arboreal mammals.
8. We also recommend reservation of:
a) The last remaining unreserved old growth areas of the poorly conserved Tableland land system within Tantawangalo and Glenbog State Forest;
b) Additional old growth areas of the Escarpment Land system from within Murrabrine, Glenbog, Bemboka and Tantawangalo State Forests.
c) All unreserved old growth areas of the Rainshadow Valley land system and any areas of this very poorly conserved and largely cleared land system that could be rehabilitated.
Recommendations 8 b) and c) will require further survey before appropriate areas can be identified.
9. The existing forestry practices in the Region will in many respects, help to conserve wildlife. We have, however, identified the following deficiencies:

a. The existing filter strips (20m wide on either side of gullies with catchments exceeding 50 ha) and, to a lesser extent, the wild life corridors (100 m or more wide along watercourses or gullies and connecting neighbouring catchments) will be inadequate for the long-term survival of species which require large home ranges such as the Yellow-bellied Glider and Powerful Owl. We recommend that these areas be expanded and/or extended in areas where such species occur.

b. Results of the logging research program in the Waratah Greek Flora Reserve are not yet available even though the initial logging was carried out in 1984. We recommend that high priority be given to the presentation and publication of results so far.

c. The present burning regime in the Region's State Forests is overly simplistic in design and will result in fires that are too frequent, at too low an intensity and at the wrong season for some wildlife. We recommend that the burning regime be modified to ensure a reasonably high diversity of fire histories across forest areas, that many areas experience fire at 10 to 25 year intervals rather than 4 to 7 years, and that many areas experience hot, summer fires (or their equivalent, if this can be established). We also recommend that controlled burning be used as a management tool to promote the long-term survival of rare or endangered species.
10. There is a great need for more research in the Region and in comparable areas. We have identified the following subjects as being in particular need of study.

a. Relationships between written forestry practices and what actually happens in terms of retention of trees and other vegetation in logged forest and in terms of timing, intensity and extent of fires.
b. Effects of logging and burning on plants and animals, especially those that require tree hollows (e.g. arboreal marsupials, owls, Microchiropteran bats) and those that are rare or endangered.
c. Population biologies of rare and endangered species.
d. Distributions and abundances of species throughout the Region.

11. Current estimates of future timber yields from the Region's State forests are based on assumptions that are overly simplistic and not well substantiated. In order to ensure that approximately constant timber yields will be available in perpetuity, it is essential that a comprehensive and accurate computer model of forest growth and harvest be developed. Such a model would also assist in the consideration of alternative short and medium term strategies for timber harvest.

12. Most of the remaining old-growth forest in the Region's state forest is of high conservation value. Alternatives to logging these areas should therefore be fully explored and any increases in availability of timber should be used to enable additional old-growth forest areas to be added to the Reserve System. Any logging of the remaining old-growth should be postponed as long as possible and start in the areas of lowest conservation value.

13. Alternative strategies to logging the remaining old-growth forest, such as those proposed by the South East Forest Alliance, have not been adequately considered. We recommend a comprehensive and detailed evaluation of the range of alternatives along the lines of the current Resource Assessment Commission's Inquiry into Australia's Forest and Timber Resources.

14. Documentation of past land-use decisions (e.g. State Forest vs. National Park) and their justifications is poor while that for land-management decisions (e.g. control burning regime) is reasonable. There is also little opportunity for interested parties to comment on land-use and land-management proposals. We therefore recommend the establishment of procedures for the preparation of supporting documentation in association with proposals for National parks, Flora Reserves and National Estate Listing, for soliciting and evaluating comments from interested parties on these proposals, and for comparison and combination of competing proposals. Advisory Councils, with appropriate expertise and representatives from a variety of interests, could make well-considered recommendations to the State and Federal Governments concerning the operations of the Forestry Commission, Heritage Commission and other Government Bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having incorporated that document in Hansard, I would like to read one section from the body of the report which I consider to be a really significant comment on and, indeed, criticism of, the Forestry Commission practices, particularly in relation to logging and burning in those forests. On page 11 the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is ample evidence that forestry practices affect wildlife. Shortly after burning and/or logging some species are more abundant than before while for other species the reverse occurs . . . With time these effects may disappear . . . but some effects such as those on animal species that require tree hollows will persist for two hundred or more years. Since S.E. forest areas that are utilized for timber supply will be heavily logged after at most 150 years after the initial bout of integrated logging . . . these forest areas will never return to a state approximating in all respects, their unlogged condition.

The New South Wales Government asked a scientist called Pryor to comment on the alternative strategies proposed by the South East Forest Alliance (SEFA). He was very critical of its proposals. However, in this report by the museum scientists, their comment on Mr Pryor's report indicates the very slim basis on which Mr Pryor criticised the South East Forest Alliance strategies. I read from page 31 of the museum report:

Pryor, in reviewing the SEFA proposal, focuses largely on eucalypt plantations and does so inadequately. He asserts, without presenting supporting evidence, that the minimum annual rainfall for eucalypt plantations is 850 mm rather than 800 mm as assumed by SEFA. He states, without describing his methods of calculation or presenting his data, that the total area within the S.E. Forest Region that is suitable for eucalypt plantations is 12,000 ha as compared with the SEFA estimate of 14,000 ha. He presents some data on growth rates in eucalypt plantations and deduces that timber yields from these plantations would average about 15 m3 per hectare per year using present plant stock and technology but could possibly be about 30% higher with improved stock and technology. The figure of 20 m3 per hectare per year assumed by SEFA may therefore be slightly optimistic but is within the realms of possibility. Pryor's basic conclusion is that the claims by SEPA are overly optimistic. He might be correct but he has not so demonstrated.

The Pryor report is also inadequate in terms of assessing the consequences of pursuing the SEFA suggestions. Pryor asserts that timber mills will be closed and jobs will be lost. However he presents no supporting evidence or calculations. The extent to which the SEFA suggestions would reduce or eliminate job losses is therefore unclear. Pryor does not evaluate the consequences of earlier than planned logging of the regrowth forest.

There is also a very significant comment on environmental impact statements (EIS). I have long been concerned, as have many resource managers and ecologists, about the failure of environmental impact statements to take into account the alternatives to those proposed within the EIS. In this respect it is significant that the museum scientists have this to say about the procedure of the EIS:
The procedures associated with these EIS's-
namely, in relation to the south-east forests-

are reasonably well known and will not be described here. However, it should be mentioned that, by its nature, an EIS does not deal evenly with all land-areas within a Region nor with all alternative land-use and land-management options. In other words, it is an inherently biased document. The EIS's prepared in connection with logging in the S.E. Forest Region are no exception to this generalisation.
SEFA has put out a press release in relation to this museum report. I have to agree with its comment on the report, as follows:

The independent scientific report highlights the growing body of evidence questioning the validity of the basis for the Commonwealth/NSW agreement which allows logging to continue in these high conservation value areas. The joint Commonwealth/NSW Biological Resources Survey (BRS)-due to be released at the end of June-has been held up by the NSW Forestry Commission and the previous Federal Minister for Resources Senator Cook as providing the answer to the dispute. Yet, as the Museum Report shows, this forms only a small part of the information base, and its outcome is already compromised by the proforestry stance of 5 of its 6 members, 3 of whom are employed by the NSW Forestry Commission. The BRS interim report has been severely criticised for its bias toward timber production over ecological protection.

I regret that these recommendations and comments from SEFA, whose team includes people from the Wilderness Society and the ACF, have come too late to achieve any significant commitment from the Federal Government. Nevertheless, I would have to lend my support to the specific SEFA proposals; that is, an end to logging in National Estate areas, including a condition of future export permits that timber must not be taken from the National Estate; a full investigation of conservation values of potential high conservation areas, including old growth forests, adequacy of existing reserves and linkages between high conservation areas, and migration corridors; a moratorium on logging in these areas until a comprehensive biological study is completed, and the full range of high conservation value forests are protected as national parks; and Commonwealth assistance for industry restructuring and plantation establishment.

Decisive Commonwealth action is certainly well overdue. Certainly, despite the repeated posturing of the Federal Government before the election, nothing has been done and I fear that nothing will be done at this point. However, I do add as a last note that the adoption of the Australian Heritage Commission (National Estate Protection) Amendment Bill would go a long way towards satisfying claims by conservationists and all Australians concerned with the preservation of a vital part of our national heritage and would place the responsibility for the preservation of our National Estate and our national heritage squarely where it belongs, that is, with the national Government of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of this matter of public interest debate today to comment on the parlous state of the Northern Territory's economy and the direct relationship of that economy to the actions of the Hawke Labor Government or, rather, the inaction in so many areas. During the Estimates committees hearings, and recently here in the Senate, I have pursued a number of questions that would affect the personal finances of many Territories, particularly with regard to the tax zone rebate scheme that has been unaltered by this Government since 1984. That has meant, in effect, that the taxation arrangements of Northern Territorians, or taxpayers in northern Australia and many parts of Central Australia, have been very adversely affected because there have been no adjustments to this very important scheme which takes into account the additional expenses required to live in either northern Australia or remote parts of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Hawke Government in 1988 established the Prime Minister's country task force, which made recommendations for movement in this area, and the fact that the Government has subsequently chosen to ignore any action in either the 1988 or 1989 Budgets, is very serious. I will be looking very carefully at the 1990 Budget for an adjustment that is substantial and which recognises that it is now six years since there has been any adjustment to assist personal taxpayers.

Another area that impacts very seriously on Territorians is, of course, housing. The availability of housing and the finance for it, particularly through the government sector, are of major importance. Honourable senators will be aware that recently the Commonwealth has negotiated and arranged for a new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. This Agreement is going to have very dire consequences for the Northern Territory because substantial cuts which will flow through to the capital works program of the Northern Territory and subsequently into the housing programs will be very harshly felt by many Territorians.

I recall that during the Federal election campaign Senator Collins, who is now the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, commented on this matter in the Northern Territory media. I quote from the transcript of a radio program in which Senator Collins said, on 22 February 1990:
The housing agreement between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory is an eminently fair one.
Further on he said:
There will be a reduction. There's no question about that. It won't be in the order of $100m.

History has proven that Senator Collins was very wrong in that assertion because, contrary to his earlier assurances, the signing of the new Agreement has meant that consequently there will be a loss of $100m in housing funds up to 1992-93 and $370m over the next 10 years. That is going to have extreme consequences for all Territorians, particularly for that group in the community who rely on Housing Commission funds for the provision of adequate and proper housing.

The business sector of the Northern Territory has suffered a number of very harsh consequences because of decisions by the Hawke Government in recent years. The Government's lack of resolve and lack of action in being able to solve the pilots dispute last year cost the Northern Territory economy well in excess of $100m. The consequences are still being felt. It will take years to restore confidence among the travelling public and tourists who come to the Northern Territory. Whilst it is pleasing to note that the marketing plans put in place by the Northern Territory Government for the tourist industry this year are working, the consequences will still flow on.

Treasurer Keating recently announced very significant cuts to defence allocations. Defence has an important effect in northern Australia. Those cuts-they were in the order of $214m-will mean that programs will either be deferred or very important commitments in northern Australia will not happen in the appropriate timetable. The commitment from government will not be there. In many areas of the capital works program over the past few years the Government has continually deferred or delayed the commencement of projects. Again, that affects the very important building and construction sector of the economy and we see major changes in that area. So the business community is also reeling from these very direct economic areas.

Another area that I comment on is one on which I throw a challenge to both Senator Collins and to the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon. They need to be very vigilant and very aggressive in arguing for funds for the coming financial year, 1990-91, relating to the Government's ongoing commitment to the recurrent funding for the Northern Territory. We are well aware that the Commonwealth injects in the order of $1 billion in to that recurrent funding. But it is very important to note that the provision of services is aggravated by the special conditions of remoteness and the very high proportion of Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal people living in the Northern Territory. That does impact very substantially on funding.

Just as Commonwealth funding to the States has been cut back substantially over the past few years, there has been a very disproportionate cut in similar funding, whether it be of a capital nature or of a recurrent nature, to the Northern Territory-far in excess of cuts suffered by the States. I believe that the figure is in the order of a 16 per cent cut in the last few years to the States, whereas funding to the Northern Territory has been slashed by 27 per cent. No government can continue to provide the level of services which are required when it is faced with that sort of considerable and continual butchery by the Department of Finance and the Treasury.

The options, of course, for meeting shortfalls in future years represent a great challenge. I believe that the resources of the Northern Territory Government and its agencies have been stretched to the limit by the action of the Federal Government in the last few years. They have done everything possible and responsible in order to meet their fair share of contributions in the required areas. But as we are aware, there has always been the need for top-up funds for the Northern Territory, and they will certainly be required again this year.

I am well aware that the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Marshall Perron, has recently made submissions to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) explaining the seriousness of the problem and outlining that, because of the serious cuts and the shortfalls in so many areas, the Northern Territory Government will face a gap as high as $70m in the coming financial year. There will have to be some pretty creative types of political work to make up this gap. As I said earlier, I challenge Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon to make sure that the Commonwealth increases funding in an appropriate way, to look carefully at the reports of the Grants Commission, particularly with regard to the relativities, and to ensure that those relativities are argued in such a way that they properly reflect Northern Territory needs and priorities.

Of course, many issues, projects and ideas are on the table that will have to be met. The Commonwealth will have to accept its responsibilities. For example, the innovative Northern Territory university was created by the Northern Territory Government and it is still not being funded by the Commonwealth in an appropriate manner which treats that university in a similar manner to universities in other States. It should look at and review the funding arrangements for tertiary education.

With regard to the capacity to fund roads, repairs, maintenance and public works supervision, the Commonwealth has a very direct responsibility that it must exercise. The research undertaken by the Menzies School of Health Research, located in Darwin, has a very wide and important application across the whole of northern Australia. Research is being undertaken into the prevention of trachoma, otitis media, AIDS, hepatitis and other infectious diseases; the prevention of alcohol, Kava and other drug related problems; and improvements in nutrition to prevent diabetes, heart disease and other problems. It has, of course, particular relevance to Aboriginal health and public health in the countries to the near north of Australia. The Commonwealth should accept further responsibility for funding in this area.

The Northern Territory, as I mentioned, has been adjudicated by the Grants Commission in recent years and because of the action of the Federal Government is treating it as a State. But long-term debts have accrued since self-government and there are special arguments and special reasons why many of these debts should, in fact, be written off by the Commonwealth at this time to alleviate the special budgetary problems of the Northern Territory. There are special arguments for the needs of northern Australia and, in particular, the Northern Territory. It is an important, resource-filled area of Australia that contributes phenomenally to our export earnings and, of course, will play a very significant role in the future. It is important that the Hawke Labor Government meets its commitments in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 June last year I was holidaying with friends in the United Kingdom. I awoke on that Sunday morning to be told that there had been a massacre in Beijing. At first I was incredulous. I could not believe that a government would kill its citizens in cold blood; that it would walk into a square and shoot them because they asked for democracy. But as news report after news report after news report flooded in, the sad truth dawned, not only upon myself, but upon millions and millions of people around the world that what had happened in Tiananmen Square was a massacre of the innocent.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that very, very purposefully: it was a massacre of the innocent. These people were not-I hasten to advise-dangerous saboteurs. They were not setting about trying to destroy the country. They were there for two reasons, and two reasons only. They had two grievances that they wished to take to their Government. Those grievances were, firstly, that corruption be rooted out of the Government; and, secondly, that democracy be allowed in China. The massacre that occurred in Beijing on that morning, the subsequent slaughter of people throughout the country, the subsequent persecution of people who held those beliefs, are very difficult for us to understand. But for that Government it was nothing but a callous and ruthless attempt to hold on to power for a little bit longer. It is very difficult for us to understand because we take principles like accountable government and democracy for granted, and we are lucky in that we are able to do so. But the people in China are not so lucky. They certainly were not so lucky then.

What these people in Beijing did was fundamental in their country's history. They had never had democracy; they had never had accountable government. They had never experienced these things. But they knew what they were, they knew that they wanted them, and they knew that they were willing to lay down their lives to win them. And lay down their lives they did. Sadly, the forces of the old men in the walled city prevailed, and I will tell honourable senators how they prevailed. They prevailed because innocent people were shot in the streets. People lying in hospitals were bayoneted to death. Old men, women and children were crushed by tanks, by armoured personnel carriers. People who dared to oppose the Government were rounded up, tortured, tried without fair judicial process, and many of them were executed ruthlessly, without feeling and without compassion, so that their blood would purchase a few more pitiful years for these evil men in the walled city.

This Sunday, throughout the country, many Chinese and many other ordinary Australians will be gathering to remember that sacrifice. We will be remembering the sacrifice of well in excess of 4,000 people in China who died trying to win freedom for their country. It may seem that that sacrifice has nothing to do with us, but it has everything to do with us because it should remind us that our freedom and our democracy in this country are precious and that they are worth standing up for. They are so precious that people in other countries who do not have them are willing to lay down their lives to win these principles.

I am sure that in the course of history the men who were responsible for that massacre, the men who were responsible and who are still responsible for the persecution of those people in China, those evil old men, Deng Xiaoping and Li Peng, will be judged as the butchers of Beijing. They will be judged as the people who chose to bleed the life out of the young people of that country to maintain their cynical, twisted and bitter grasp on power. I urge honourable senators, as I urge everyone in this country who is interested in democracy, freedom and truth, to support those rallies against the Chinese Government. I shall certainly be supporting those rallies. I shall be attending the rally in Brisbane and I shall be addressing that rally to remind the people of Australia that our freedoms are precious; that they are very, very fragile; that we should be grateful that we have our Constitution; and that we should not give up in the fight to support the people of China who cry for freedom, to support the people around the world who cry for freedom.

I am sure that the sun will one day dawn upon a world in which everybody may take freedom, liberty and truth for granted. But between now and then this Senate can rest assured that I shall not give up the fight to win those things. I urge, beg and plead with people to support freedom and democracy in China; to support freedom and democracy wherever it is needed; and to support these rallies so that those evil old men, those butchers of Beijing, will not be allowed to escape the condemnation of history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The State Coroners Acts have been criticised by former Commissioner Muirhead in his interim report on Aboriginal deaths in custody. Coroners, he states, have insufficient powers and resources. In Western Australia, for example, witnesses are not obliged to give evidence or to come under cross-questioning during coroners' inquiries. I have referred before in this place to the example of the death of Stephen Wardle on 4 February 1988. During the inquiry into his death the 17 policemen and women who were present in the police station when he died were not asked to present evidence at the inquiry. The coroner is attached to a section of the police department and must rely on police evidence. This poses obvious concerns when a death occurs in police custody. Had our State Coroners Acts been stronger, there probably would have been no need for a royal commission into Aboriginal deaths in custody.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to make just a few brief remarks on the death in custody of Daniel John Morris. He was found dead in police custody at 4.05 a.m. on 18 August 1988. The findings of the Coroners Court at Westmead were brought down on 29 August 1989. In his findings, Mr Hiatt, the Coroner, stated:

The determination of the court is, that Daniel John Morris died on 18 August 1988 within cell one, Mount Druitt Police Station, Mount Druitt, from hanging wilfully self inflicted with intention of taking his own life. With recommendations made by the Court to the Minister of Police.

There appear to be many irregularities that are not conclusive or consistent with Mr Hiatt's findings. The forensic pathologist witness and Government Medical Officer, Dr P. S. J. Ellis of Westmead Hospital, indicated that cause of death was inconclusive. Part of his evidence included reference to major bruising to part of the deceased's neck which was not consistent with hanging, but with strangling. That evidence is clearly in the transcript.

Also, evidence given by Detective Sergeant R. L. Wyse which, again, may be seen in the court transcripts, reveals that there were no fingerprints of the deceased in the area.
