So it is alleged that Mr Morris managed to climb approximately 10 feet, secure one leg of his jeans to a crossbar, secure the other leg by means of a knot tied around his neck, then proceed to jump in order deliberately to hang himself. During the questioning at the inquest, this question was asked:
So there are in fact prints that are identifiable but not capable of being compared to any known prints, is that the situation?
Sergeant Wyse responded:
Yes, the prints are identifiable but we can't find out who owns them.
Later he stated that the prints found had been compared with palm prints on file of Mr Morris, and then compared again with prints taken at the morgue, both with a negative result; both with a `no'.

There are many other questionable irregularities. For example, there are time discrepancies between the police car diaries and the police radio log. There are other discrepancies. Daniel John Morris's blood alcohol reading when he was picked up by the police the previous night at 11.30 p.m. was 0.231. He was last spoken to about 20 to 25 minutes before he was found dead. When he was spoken to at that time he was told that he would soon be released on unconditional bail. Yet despite this, a press account in the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 August 1989 was headlined; `Danny, a typical case of cell death'. I quote from that article:

His case was typical. He had a blood alcohol reading of 0.231 when he was picked up. Police figures show that 27 of those who have died were intoxicated, and at least 13 had a blood alcohol level of more than 0.2.

It is implied, therefore, that his death in custody was typical in all other aspects. He was not processed, as I said before, for unconditional bail until 3.40 a.m. yet he was picked up at 11.30 p.m. When he was picked up he was in the company of his young son, Timothy, aged 3 years old at the time, and he was arrested on a charge of offensive language. He was taken to the police station where he was left handcuffed to a metal rail of the dock until he was formally charged at 1.00 a.m. I quote again from the same article in the Sydney Morning Herald:
At 1.30 a.m. he was moved to Cell One, the only cell in Mt Druitt station where he could effectively hang himself. He was moved ``because he was noisy'', said one officer.

The coroner did make certain recommendations as it was responsible for him to do. He recommended that written records should be kept, countersigned by a supervisory officer, showing the times that cells are checked, and that the record should be made immediately after the cells are checked. He recommended putting video cameras in the cells of the Mount Druitt police station and for these cameras to be monitored at all times when the cells are occupied. He recommended that if a cell death does occur, the radio room immediately start to record on cassette all information relating to the event. Finally, he recommended the removal of all horizontal bars in the cells.

The family of the deceased is calling for a full and open inquiry into the death of Daniel John Morris. They have asked for my support in this. I give them that support wholeheartedly, and it is for that reason that I have made these remarks in the chamber today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some remarks about the forthcoming commemorations of the Tiananmen Square massacre. I will not go over the points that have already been made, nor will I elaborate to the Senate on the points that I have made about the deals continuing to be done by big business with the Chinese. On a previous occasion I detailed to the Senate the advertisements by one of our biggest companies-if not our biggest company-that had appeared, saying that whilst the West was concerned about the activities of the regime in China, this particular company was keeping business going. That was, admittedly, before the Tiananmen Square massacre. My concern, however, is that nothing much has changed. I will, if it is appropriate, detail to the Senate on another occasion material relating to that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: What I wish to focus on now is an aspect of gross and continuing violation of human rights in China supported by Australian taxpayers' money provided under the Foreign Affairs vote by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA), which gives financial and moral support to the China population program.

Does the Senate know that on 7 June 1989, just three days after the Tiananmen Square massacre, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities allocated $US57m to the world's most inhuman population control program, that in China? Does the Senate know that Australia doubled its grant to UNFPA in the 1989-90 Budget and that, therefore, we share in legitimising the gross violations of human rights that occur in China? The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has stated that he had a particular interest in increasing the amount of money to UNFPA. I quote from the Senate Hansard of 18 August 1989, at page 416:

The population control program that is conducted in China . . . has never been one about which I have seen evidence to justify the allegations that are being made about coercive abortion, involuntary sterilisation and so on.
A very large number of people throughout Australia saw the 60 Minutes program of 8 April 1990. They heard the presenter say a number of things, including that-and I quote:

The Chinese say they only want a better way of life for their children and the world looks the other way as China wields the one child policy like an axe. The communist master plan is killing millions.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I knew that. I asked at Estimates committee hearings for the Government to examine the evidence that was before it. There is so much evidence that I cannot present it to the chamber in the time available to me. Let me refer to an up-to-date quote from Shen Guoxiang, the Director of Publicity at the State Family Planning Commission, reported by the Reuters correspondent in Beijing on 14 April 1990:
This year's campaign'-
that is 1990-

aims to instil zeal into local officials to enforce the punishments and rewards, educate couples on the benefits of small families and persuade women to abort unauthorised babies. He said local authorities have much autonomy in deciding punishments for couples who have too many children.

``Normally the women are willing to abort,'' said Shen, ``But if they are not then the local cadres come round to persuade them a little . . . the time limit for abortions was normally three months into the pregnancy but some `stubborn' women resisted persuasion at first and had to have the foetus removed in the fourth month or later . . .
These gross violations of human rights have been understood and responded to by the United States. I quote from a statement by the United States Agency for International Development:
UNFPA participates in the management of a program of coercive abortion and involuntary sterilisation in the People's Republic of China within the meaning of the Kemp/Kaston Amendment.
UNFPA praises the China program. I quote Manfred Kulessa, China representative of UNFPA, of 11 July 1987, who said:

It is significant that here in China . . . the government has shown its full commitment to a family planning program that has been internationally acknowledged as one of the most successful efforts in the world today.

Success is considered in many ways. I do not think that those millions of Chinese citizens who have been subject to gross violations of human rights because of the China population program supported by UNFPA think that it is a success. It is not only a gross violation of human rights, it is also a gross violation of workers' rights. The Country Reports on Human Rights for 1989, US State Department, Washington, which was issued only a couple of weeks ago, says:
Couples are not allowed free choice about whether to practice family planning, how many children they may have, or when they may have them . . .
When national targets are not met, officials call for stricter implementation, and some have advocated more coercive methods than central government policy currently authorizes . . .

Disciplinary measures against couples who violate the policy include stiff fines (often as high as a year's salary), withholding of social services, demotion, and other administrative punishments. If a unit-
that is a work unit-
exceeds its allocation, punishment may be meted out to the offending couples, to unit officials, and to the unit as a whole.

That is a gross violation and subjugation of workers' rights. Yet we, by our taxpayers' money, are supporting that subjugation of workers' rights. Three days after the events at Tiananmen Square the United Nations allocated $US57m. What did our delegate do? The tears were not dry in this Parliament when our delegate got up, three days after Tiananmen Square, and supported that allocation to assist the most inhuman population control program in the world. It was opposed vigorously by the United States, which had done some homework about the violations of human rights and workers' rights.

I appeal to the Government, I appeal to the Senate, I appeal to the whole of Australia to recognise that there are violations in this area and that, in the words of that 60 Minutes program, `the world unfortunately looks the other way as China wields the one child policy like an axe; the Communist master plan is killing millions'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Acting Treasurer's statement yesterday that the national accounts do not indicate any change in the Government's policy on interest rates. Can the Minister confirm that the national accounts data, together with the increase in the foreign debt announced today, mean that interest rates will remain high in the foreseeable future? Can the Minister inform the Senate when the Prime Minister's election promise that `because we've followed the right policies, interest rates are going down' will be fulfilled?

—The fact is that since the election monetary policy has been relaxed and interest rates have gone down. They are certainly not at the level they were before the election. As to the first part of the question, I have nothing to add to what the Acting Treasurer said yesterday.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the Myanmar national elections, the main opposition party, the National League for Democracy (NLD), appears to have won an overwhelming victory. Will the Minister report on progress by the military regime in handing over power to a democratically elected government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Blewett, in a statement of 29 May, said that the Australian Government strongly supported democratic reform in Myanmar and welcomed the holding of national elections on 27 May-the first in 30 years. Although counting is still continuing, there is little doubt that the NLD has scored a major success. As of yesterday, the NLD had 67 officially declared seats and has claimed unofficially that it has won 366 out of a total of 485. This result would give the NLD at least 75 per cent of the seats in the National Assembly. The strong support shown for the NLD is a testament to the courage of the people of Myanmar and is a further condemnation of the attempt by the military regime to intimidate and harass its political opponents through widespread arrests and detentions.

ANSWER.PARA: However, to the regime's credit, the elections appear to have been conducted in an open and orderly manner. The Australian Government calls on the military regime to recognise and respect the result of the elections and to move quickly to hand over political power to a new democratically elected government. The high level of popular support for the NLD adds increasing urgency to the need for the regime to release immediately Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the NLD, who has been under house arrest since July 1989, with the NLD Chairman U Tin U and other political detainees.

The Australian Government believes that the elections provide a real opportunity to achieve political and economic reform and national reconciliation in Myanmar. The clear question must now be the transfer of power to a democratic government. As yet, the military regime has given no firm indication as to how it will adhere to its public undertakings to hand over power. We understand that the NLD may soon be entering into negotiations with the military regime on the formation of an interim administration on the drafting of a new Constitution.

The indisputable result of the elections underlines the need for a quick transfer of authority in accordance with the expressed wishes of the people of Myanmar. At a time of a worldwide trend towards democracy the establishment of a free representative and open government will assist Myanmar to take its place again in the family of nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I note that, in the Minister's announcement of a Defence Force structure review, he refers to government guidance on force structure provided in a paper on further strategic planning for the 1990s endorsed by Cabinet in November last year. In the terms of reference of this review it is referred to as ASP90-typical Defence language. How has this document in any way refined the White Paper of 1987? In view of the tantalising references to this document in the terms of reference, will the Government now make public this additional guidance to the 1987 White Paper, if necessary in a sanitised form?

—This document, of course, was done under the auspices of my predecessor. I was not aware of his views, and I may even check them, as to whether it was ever supposed to be a publicly available document. If there is no problem with that either in the document's original form or its amended form, I will give some consideration to making it public. It should not be seen as a document, however, that contradicts the White Paper, but one which merely develops themes within it. I must express to Senator Durack-not that I am saying that he espouses this attitude-that I am surprised how many people regard the White Paper as set in concrete, almost tablets handed down from on high. I do not think that was ever the intention. The White Paper was to set the main themes. Of course, the variations on those themes are just as important. Several of those will emerge, and, no doubt, the new force structure review will point in some other directions in which to extend the White Paper and may even occasionally contradict some minor elements of the White Paper. I will have the thrust of Senator Durack's question examined. If it can be made available, I will certainly make it available. If it cannot be made available, I will give some consideration to making it available to Senator Durack.

—Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs tell the Senate whether a banking ombudsman has been appointed yet? If one has been appointed, what will this mean for consumers who have a dispute with their bank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Jones will be aware, the Government has long recognised the need for independent, free and accessible dispute-handling mechanisms for consumers having difficulties with banks. In October last year, after 18 months of quite arduous negotiations between the Australian Bankers Association (ABA) and the Government, my predecessor, Senator Bolkus, announced the establishment of the banking ombudsman scheme. I wish to pay a tribute to Senator Bolkus for his sterling work in this area. It is an initiative which I very much welcome as it will provide Australians with a quick, free, efficient and effective way of resolving disputes with banks.

ANSWER.PARA: As part of the scheme, a council comprising three consumer representatives and three industry representatives has been established. Sir Ninian Stephen was appointed to chair the council, an appointment which illustrates the commitment which the scheme has to independence and fairness. The council was charged with the task of selecting the first banking ombudsman. It has now completed that selection task. Earlier today Sir Ninian announced the council's choice for Australia's first banking ombudsman. He will be Mr Graham McDonald, who is a presidential member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and has had a distinguished legal career in Western Australia. He exhibits a strong commitment to public service. The many highlights of his career include being the inaugural solicitor with the Western Australian Aboriginal Legal Service between 1973 and 1975 and a member of the Western Australian Aboriginal Police Relations Cabinet Subcommittee, being a founding partner in two legal firms, and the Western Australian Commissioner for Corporate Affairs between 1987 and 1988.

In the past the high costs associated with the legal system and the small amounts often involved in disputes have prevented many consumers from pursuing disputes with banks. With Mr McDonald's appointment consumers will now have an independent, free and accessible dispute-handling mechanism which will enable them to pursue such complaints. Under the scheme a bank will in the first instance attempt to resolve the dispute with the consumer concerned. Should the dispute not be resolved at this level, the consumer will have access to the ombudsman, who will investigate and adjudicate on the dispute.

The Ombudsman's jurisdiction will cover disputes between individuals and banks involving claims of $100,000 or less relating to transactions on or after 10 May 1989. He will have no jurisdiction over bank policy issues, including the setting of interest rates. The guiding principle for the Ombudsman will be what is fair and reasonable in all the circumstances, having regard to legal principle and to what constitutes good banking practice. The Ombudsman will set his own procedures for determining disputes but will attempt in the first instance to try to settle them by conciliation between the bank and the customer. Although the Ombudsman's decision will be binding on the banks, customers will still be able to take legal action should they not be satisfied with the decision.

The four major banks and most members of the ABA have agreed to be covered by the banking Ombudsman scheme. State banks are not at present participating members as they are covered by State ombudsmen. The only major consumer lending bank that has so far refused to join the scheme is Citibank and the Government very much hopes that in due course it too will agree to participate in the scheme.

The Ombudsman is currently seeking office premises in Melbourne, which will be operating by early July. In the meantime the ABA has established a secretariat in Melbourne to handle public inquiries regarding the scheme. In conclusion, I would like to congratulate Mr McDonald on his appointment, thank the Australian Bankers Association for its part in setting up this scheme, and, as I say, I look forward very much to Mr McDonald taking up his duties on behalf of customers in their relations with banks throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I draw his attention to an article on page three of the Australian on 29 May which reports that three senior officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs have hurriedly been sent to North America for high level briefings on growing and significant evidence concerning the detrimental effects of agent orange on the health of Vietnam veterans. First, is the Department therefore seriously reviewing its stance in relation to the efficacy of the findings of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam? Secondly, will the Minister and the Department undertake to make public its views and conclusions coming from these North American briefings? Thirdly, when can the Senate and the Vietnam veterans expect such an announcement to be made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Repatriation Commission is aware of various reports coming from the United States on a wide range of issues and decided that it needed to have first-hand reports to consider. The Department of Veterans' Affairs made three of its senior officers available to meet with Veterans' Administration authorities in the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the first question about seriously reviewing the stance of the Department in relation to the findings of the royal commission, it is not the object of the officers' visit to collect material to review the findings of the Evatt Royal Commission. Those findings are not being reviewed. Investigation by the Repatriation Commission is to examine and gain first-hand a full understanding of the policy and scientific environment surrounding recent decisions by the Government of the United States. The officers will also discuss possible future developments with the United States Veterans' Administration. Once the officers have returned with this information I expect the Repatriation Commission will give further consideration to the material and views gathered by the team.

As to Senator McLean's second question, as I have indicated, the departmental officers are visiting at the request of the Repatriation Commission. When the Commission has an appreciation of the situation it will report to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The Minister will inform the Parliament of conclusions reached by the Commission and of any decisions which might subsequently be made by the Government. Any announcement will be made as soon as it is reasonable and responsible to do so, but, of course, overall the Government will maintain its stance of being absolutely committed to meeting veterans' needs and is monitoring the matters of concern very closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I seek the Minister's guidance. Does he not see a contradiction in the fact that the Government says that it is standing by and not reviewing the findings of the Evatt Royal Commission, which were that agent orange was innocent? So presumably these people have gone to North America with an open mind and, if they find otherwise, surely the Government must review its attitude towards the findings of the Evatt Royal Commission. Can the Minister not see that contradiction?

—The officers who are being sent to the United States are not being sent with the object of reviewing the findings of the royal commission. They are being sent with the object of collecting evidence and material of significance which has emerged in the United States in recent times. When they inform the Commission of the facts and the opinions and the material that they have been able to consider, no doubt the Commission, in making its report to the Minister, will consider what impacts it might have in relation to previous conclusions in this area.

—How does the Minister for Social Security respond to a statement by the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory that Aboriginal people should be paid social security benefits only at their home community address?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fairly well established-or at least I hope it is-that in Australia we do not seek to introduce a system of A grade and B grade citizenship: we have only one kind. The Government rejects the suggestion, absolutely, that benefits should be paid to Aboriginal people only in their home community. In the Senate we have been debating, in the last few days, policies of restricting benefits to those who have moved to areas where their prospects for employment are lower. Yet, we have Mr Perron suggesting that when people go to areas where employment prospects are higher, we should, indeed, cut out their benefits. That is an extraordinary suggestion and one that I find totally and utterly abhorrent.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think we ought to go back to the bad old days of locking black fellows away, pretending that they are not there, and starving them or taking their children. I thought we had got past all of that. I thought Australia had advanced just a bit down the road from there. So, I say to Senator Zakharov that the Government will not be taking up Mr Perron's suggestion. We have, however, had officers in Alice Springs in recent times discussing with the council some of the problems that are occurring there. We look forward to working with Mr Perron and finding solutions to the many problems which beset people in isolated communities. Let it not be thought for a moment that in the Northern Territory alcohol problems reside entirely with the black population. They, of course, do not. The per capita consumption of alcohol by whites more than matches that of the blacks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Given the Minister's statement that the multifunction polis (MFP) is now likely to have a core in one capital city and have other components shared within the States, can he explain who will bear the infrastructure costs-estimated by Arthur Andersen and Co. to be $8 billion-from State to State, and in what proportions; that is, Japanese, Federal and State governments? Is it true that the infrastructure costs for the core city, to be located in Adelaide, will be considerably less than in other cities, and that an Australian national opinion poll has identified that South Australians are more tolerant of foreigners, particularly Asians, than other States? Is it anticipated that the Indenture Act will need to be introduced into the relevant State parliaments in order to fast-track the proposal to bypass normal planning and environmental laws?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The joint steering committee which has been managing this program will report to the Government at the beginning of July. It will make recommendations about a number of issues. As far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned, we either act on the recommendations of the joint steering committee or we do not. Of course, as the honourable senator is aware, in the last few weeks State governments have been putting forward proposals to the joint steering committee about possible sites for the MFP and, of course, South Australia is one of those States.

ANSWER.PARA: I think rather than add anything more to the answer, I will just deal with what I regard as some of the difficulties in the honourable senator's question, which may be based on misconceptions. As I understand it, the Arthur Andersen report figure of $8 billion, to which the honourable senator referred, was based on a city of a particular size and, of course, the investment will take place over years, if not decades. It is not as though a lump sum has to be found for that sort of level of investment. I suppose it is true that if Adelaide were chosen as the site for a MFP, on the recommendation of the joint steering committee, the infrastructure costs there would be less. Some of the building costs might be less, depending on the nature of the site and on what contribution was made by various parts of the Adelaide community, whether it be government or private sector.

The only other part of Senator Olsen's question with which I think I can deal is that concerning the hub and spoke concept-that is, a central point with various other points connected by sophisticated communication systems to the core. That is an option which has been canvassed widely by the private sector and with which I think I have some agreement, but the joint steering committee will make a recommendation about that. The reason why I have some agreement with it is that our research capacities around this country are rather scattered because of the very nature of Australia, with six States on the mainland and six population centres. In my view, there are very good medical research facilities in Melbourne and in electronics there are better facilities in Adelaide, for example. The connection of those centres to a core, as I said earlier, would be in the best interests of the national research effort. I think that view has something going for it. But in so far as the rest of the question is concerned, these matters have to await recommendation by the joint steering committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Following the Minister's response, I ask: in the preliminary planning stage, which the Minister indicated is currently the phase of the MFP, have there been discussions as to the need for indenture Acts to be introduced in the respective State parliaments, wherever the core and the various shared components of an MFP might be located, for the purposes of fast tracking such a proposal to overcome the current or normal planning laws applying in each State?

—Not that I am aware of, but certainly, in terms of my awareness, it has always been considered that, if the joint steering committee makes positive recommendations about the MFP and the governments adopt them, there will have to be a close collaborative legislative arrangement between the Commonwealth and the State government where the core site is at least. I do not have any further detail about what has been discussed or recommended by consultants to the joint steering committee at this stage.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to comments made in the Senate on 24 May by Senator Chapman concerning my constituent, Mr Stephen Whitlam. Has the Minister received any subsequent information from Mr Whitlam concerning the matters raised in the Senate and does this information throw a new light on the allegations made with regard to my constituent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen correspondence from Mr Stephen Whit- lam relating to the allegations raised by Senator Chapman in the Senate last week. The allegations made by Senator Chapman came from a document circulated by an officer in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade known as the Officers Revolutionary Council. In the case of Stephen Whitlam, the document alleged that he had improperly received some $30,000 for the boarding expenses of his son at Canberra Grammar. Stephen Whitlam wrote to the Secretary to the Department to answer those allegations. Let me quote from his response in part:

ANSWER.PARA: To my knowledge I have not received any benefit to which I was not entitled nor have I sought to receive any such . . . benefit. The Department paid the board but not the tuition.
It paid this for a period of 2 1/3 years. As Stephen Whitlam then indicates:
The total cost to the Department was probably about one quarter of the figure concocted by the ORC.
The Secretary to the Department in his reply said:

I want you to know that you have my full confidence as an able and honest officer of the department. The Department has examined the allegations which have been made about the way in which your situation was handled. This investigation concluded that the decision made at the time was appropriate and that it was also appropriate for you to receive whatever entitlements flowed from that decision.

In conclusion, I would point out to the Senate that these allegations were made without any effort by Senator Chapman to verify the facts. They were selectively chosen because of the association with the former Prime Minister, and they provided no opportunity for the persons involved to respond to the offensive and inaccurate allegations. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter received from Mr Stephen Whitlam.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator the Honourable Kerry W. Sibraa,
President of the Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra
Dear Mr President,

On 24 May Senator Chapman asked Senator Evans a question without notice in the Senate. That question referred to me and to a person who once worked for my father, the former Prime Minister. The reference to me was offensive and inaccurate and a gross invasion of my privacy. I write to you now to seek to incorporate an appropriate correction in the Hansard. Moreover I believe that the Senator who posed the question made absolutely no effort to contact me to ascertain whether what he said about me was correct. One is entitled to expect more of the elected representatives of the people.
The facts of the matter are as follows.

On 18 May a document was circulated in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade by the `Officers Revolutionary Council' (ORC). There were no names or signatures at the end of the document but only one person has ever been known to be associated with the `Council' and that person was also seen distributing the document. The document named five people (including me) who allegedly benefited financially from improper decisions by the senior management of the Department. In my case, the document alleged, inter alia, that I had improperly received some $30,000 for the boarding expenses of my son at Canberra Grammar.
On 21 May I wrote to the Secretary of my Department answering all of the accusations made by the ORC. I am happy to provide you with the full text of that letter but the key portions are as follows:
-``To my knowledge I have not received any benefit to which I was not entitled nor have I sought to receive any such undue benefit''

-``My son (born 1971) attended Canberra Grammar from 1983 to 1986. He boarded from third term in 1984, i.e. for two and one third years. The Dept. paid the board but not the tuition. . . .The total cost to the Dept. was probably about one quarter of the figure concocted by the ORC.''
The Secretary replied to me on 24 May. The key portion of his message is as follows:

-``I want you to know that you have my full confidence as an able and honest officer of the Department. The Department has examined the allegations which have been made about the way in which your situation was handled. This investigation concluded that the decision made at the time was appropriate and that it was also appropriate for you to receive whatever entitlements flowed from that decision.''

Against this background you can imagine how appalled I was to see the Parliament of the Commonwealth used as a platform for achieving further dissemination of the malicious, misleading and inaccurate accusations made against me. It was curious that when Senator Chapman referred to the ORC document he quoted only two names, the names associated with the former Prime Minister. Yet other names in the document were alleged to have received much more money than I received. Why this selective use? Was it a desire to expose a possible abuse?-in which case there was no justification for naming names unless the accusations had been verified. or was it to achieve a gratuitous attack on a newsworthy name regardless of the damage done to any innocent person?-in which case it was most reprehensible.

A great wrong has been done to the reputation for integrity of me and my family and the Parliament has been used to exacerbate that. I ask that the Parliament, through you, now do what it can to put matters right-by publishing a correction in the Hansard and by reprimanding the Senator who chose to be the channel for spreading the unfounded accusations.
Yours sincerely,
(STEPHEN WHITLAM)
Australian Embassy,
Riyadh
(Postal address-Dept. of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Canberra, 2600)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Minister will be aware that he, as the previous Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, refused the National Trust of Australia's request for him to intervene with the Victorian State Government to save the Bow Truss Woolstore building in Geelong from being demolished on the grounds that `any nomination for the World Heritage listing should be supported by the relevant State or Territory Government'. As this is in direct conflict with the Hawke Government's past practice of dictating to and bullying State governments on these matters, do these grounds for non-intervention reflect a change in the Government's heritage policy, or do they apply only to States and Territories that have Labor governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not too many States that do not have Labor governments these days, as the people of Australia have accepted who can best govern this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume asks me two questions and I shall try to take them in order. First, it was said that I would not intervene in the case of the Bow Truss building in Geelong. As I think Senator Baume is aware, I wrote to the Victorian Minister at the time, Mr Roper, indicating my concern at the Victorian Government's proposal to allow demolition of the building to continue. I did so on the basis of advice I had received from the Australian Heritage Commission and I conveyed my feelings to Mr Roper. However, if I was attempting to stop demolition of that site on the basis of World Heritage listing, I would have been battling in any event. The reality is that we cannot list anything for the cultural heritage list of World Heritage until we have put in an indicative list to the World Heritage organisation. We have not done that yet and it will take quite some time to prepare. A number of States have shown interest in having nominations put on the list, including the Greiner Government in New South Wales. An indicative list of that kind will probably take at least another 12 months, perhaps longer, to prepare. Therefore, I would not have been able even to attempt to prevent the demolition of the building using that as a basis.

The second part of the question relates to whether this indicates a change of Government attitude to World Heritage nomination. I have lost count of the times that I have stood in this place and said that the Government seeks the agreement of States on every single occasion when it comes to World Heritage nominations.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they do not do so, what will happen?

—I will get to Senator Boswell, if he waits a moment. When it comes to Shark Bay in Western Australia, I spent a couple of years talking to the Western Australian Government, and that included a visit to the area. I talked to local people, and the Western Australian Government continued to talk to local people, before we got to any kind of agreement. Even though we have not got to the specifics of it yet, nonetheless we came to an in-principle agreement. That is what I have sought to do on each and every occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: There were occasions, such as with the notorious government we finally got rid of last year in Queensland, when no amount of talking could ever do any good. As we got nowhere with talking-and talking to Bjelke-Petersen and his successors was always a forlorn hope-we acted. It is a Commonwealth power, a Commonwealth right, and we do not intend to abdicate Commonwealth rights when it comes to recalcitrant State governments, let alone stupid ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's response that there are occasions when no amount of talking does any good. I draw his attention to the fact that whatever the amount of talking that has proceeded with regard to the Bow Truss building, it obviously has not done any good. Does he intend to do anything further to try to save the last two historic trusses still standing?

—I thought I indicated earlier that there is no way that I can intervene at present. Because we do not have an indicative list before the World Heritage Organisation and because this will not occur for some time, I cannot act. I told the Victorian Government some time ago that I did not like the situation. I am sure that Mrs Kelly has conveyed similar thoughts on that matter. But having said that, I point out that the Victorian Government has chosen to disregard our views. Beyond feeling pretty sad about what it is doing, there is not much else that I can do.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 29 May concerning the need for Australian companies to improve management techniques. Is the Minister aware that in that article an opinion was expressed that Australian industries could reduce work force layoffs and subsequent skills wastage, as well as greatly improve productivity, if they adopted new policies which encouraged the commitment and trust of their employees?

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister confirm that the article referred to a pay system, known as the independent cooperative system, which has been developed by a British brewery, reporting that 100 per cent productivity improvement had been achieved within four years of introducing that pay system, which provided for payment to employees of a fixed number of overtime hours irrespective of whether those hours were actually worked. Can the Minister indicate whether the introduction by Australian companies of such a pay system would be acceptable within the framework of Australia's present wage system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The focus of the current wage system is to encourage multi- skilling and flexibility at the level of the enterprise, but within an overall framework which ensures that genuine restrucuturing takes place and that individual outcomes are consistent with broader objectives and requirements. Senator Colston has identified a practice employed at the Ind Coope brewery at Burton in Britain which led to significant productivity gains through cashing out the overtime payments. In effect that removed any incentive to prolong the time to undertake a particular task, as the rate of pay remained fixed regardless of hours worked. The principle underlying such a system is that which underpins the structural efficiency principle in the current wage fixing system-that is, the company negotiated the removal of particular work practices which were constraining productivity and efficiency and apparently the results were substantial and provided benefits to both employer and worker.

ANSWER.PARA: Whether such a system would be appropriate for Australian businesses would depend on the work practices of a particular enterprise. Indeed, there are examples where such arrangements have been implemented. For example, a recent certified agreement at ICI Botany cashes out a range of long-established employment conditions, including overtime penalty rates, with the cost of these entitlements being included in the base salary, which is now related to the levels of skill. I understand that, with the introduction of these new arrangements last year, there has been a significant reduction in absenteeism and overtime.

I note that the agreement also addressed training, which was considerably upgraded, and supervisory layers with greater responsibility and autonomy given to the workers. That agreement demonstrates that there are avenues for enterprises wishing to tailor arrangements to their particular circumstances. The particular avenue of certified agreements was opened up by this Government through its amendments to the Industrial Relations Act.

However, this is only one example of the substantial change that is currently under way in Australian industry. Significant changes are also being achieved within mainstream award structures. I can conclude the answer by saying that obviously it is up to management in particular cases to take advantage of the opportunities that are now available through the Act and to engage their work forces, through their unions, in the creative use of the opportunities that are now there to make the types of gains that ICI Botany has made and those referred to in Senator Colston's question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: PREPAYMENT OF TELEPHONE CHARGES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to the latest report of the Auditor-General on departmental finances and, in particular, the condemnation of the agreement entered into by the Department of Social Security (DSS) with Telecom Australia on the last day of the 1988-89 financial year for the prepayment of $12.7m for future telephone charges. Does the Minister share the view that this transaction has all the hallmarks of a deliberate attempt to prematurely expend the Department's budgetary allocation, to the clear detriment of the overall state of Commonwealth finances? Was prime ministerial approval of the prepayment sought by either the Department or Telecom? Was ministerial approval sought for the additional appropriation in March 1989 of $11.5m, when the Department must have known that it already had a sufficient surplus to cover this figure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston put out a news release which covered two matters in addition to this one, and he had them all wrong. Given that he has chosen to ask a question about one of them, I am happy to refer to it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Attorney-General's Department advised that the prepayment was in accordance with Appropriation Act and Finance Direction 8d. It concluded that the prepayment was a valid agreement which achieved substantial savings for the Commonwealth. In addition to this discount, which, by the way, was worth approximately a million dollars, the Department was able to make significant administrative savings by rationalising its billing arrangements. The prepayment arrangements removed the need for the Department to issue to Telecom about 800 cheques every month.

The prepayment arrangements were a product of several months of negotiation between the Department and Telecom to secure a satisfactory billing arrangement. The funds expended on the prepayments were not spare funds but were diverted from other expenditures and plans on the basis that, given the level of discount that was offered, the best value for money was to be obtained by maximising the prepayment.

Senator Alston would no doubt be aware that departments have the capacity under existing financial arrangements to carry up to 2 per cent of funds from one financial year to the next. The Department of Social Security did not use that capacity fully in 1988-89 and therefore the prepayment, clearly, was not a device for avoiding the lapsing of the appropriation.

If Senator Alston had studied the Department's explanatory notes for its additional estimates for 1988-89 he would have seen that the funds sought at that time were not comparable to those out of which the prepayments were made; $11.07m of the $11.5m he referred to was for salary to offset the costs of national wage case increases. Finance Direction 8d, if read in full, includes supporting statements, and Senator Alston would have seen if he had taken a look that provision is made in it for prepayments. In particular the supporting statements note the need for flexibility in the interpretation of the restrictions on prepayment.

Prepayments are permitted where they represent a better deal to the Commonwealth than that which it would achieve if payments were made after receipt of accounts. When DSS concluded its prepayments with Telecom, the arrangements were within the existing Finance directions. The Department operated on the policy that prepayments must achieve a discount which is greater than the long term bond rate. At the time the arrangement was made with Telecom the discount was almost 2 per cent above that rate. I would be happy to organise for Senator Alston a briefing with the Department on this matter so that he can fully understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was the legal advice to which the Minister refers obtained from the Attorney-General's Department only after the inquiries initiated by the Auditor-General and at his request? Secondly, as the Minister was attempting to suggest this was all above board and not a device, can the Minister explain why Finance Direction 8d has subsequently been rewritten in order to ensure that this practice cannot occur again? Thirdly, is it not a fact that the existing Direction prohibited prepayments unless required by contract, and the arrangement between Telecom and the Department of Social Security was incorporated in a contract for that purpose?

—I do not think it was rewritten to take account of this circumstance, no. I have pointed out that the Attorney-General's Department advice was that prepayment was in accordance with the Appropriation Act and Finance Direction 8d. I do not know the date that that advice was received, but I shall inquire and let Senator Alston know as soon as I find out.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware that in the minutes of the last meeting of the National Health and Medical Research Council working party on acupuncture-held at Prince Henry's Hospital in Melbourne on 26 May last year-which have been obtained under freedom of information, show that members expressed `their particular concerns' about the safety of acupuncturists who were not accredited by the Acupuncture Ethics and Standards Organisation Inc., the principal national standards setting body for traditional non-medical acupuncturists, and also expressed their support for the principle of registration for traditional acupuncturists, but that in the final published report of the working party published late last year these conclusions did not appear? Having regard to this discrepancy between the minutes of the last meeting of the working party and that report, does the Minister believe that: firstly, by withholding its concerns about safe versus unsafe acupuncture the working party has offered encouragement to untrained and potentially dangerous acupuncturists to set up practice; secondly, by refusing to publicly recommend the registration of well trained and safe acupuncturists the working party has made it more difficult for members of the Australian public to make an informed choice of safe acupuncture practitioners; and, thirdly, that the withholding of information that reflects positively on traditional acupuncturists accredited by the organisation exclusively and unfairly promotes the interests of medical acupuncturists?

—Senator Powell raises matters of very serious concern. To ensure that she, the Senate and, indeed, the whole community get the best possible answer I will refer her question to the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe, for his consideration and obtain a full answer.

—Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General confirm that the Attorney-General's Department is holding a three-day meeting of Senior Executive Service (SES) officers in Melbourne this week? Can the Minister confirm that the Commonwealth is paying for approximately 100 Senior Executive Service officers from his Department to fly first class to Melbourne to stay at the Windsor Hotel for the duration of the conference and indeed will check in at about 8.30 this evening? Given that the great majority of the officers attending the meeting are from Canberra, can the Minister inform the Senate of the reason that the meeting is being held in Melbourne as opposed to Canberra? Will the Minister inform the Senate of the cost of holding this meeting in Melbourne, including air fares, accommodation, travel allowances, meals, et cetera, and who approved of the conference?

—I do not have any detailed knowledge of this meeting. I understand that there is a meeting of Senior Executive Service officers of the Attorney-General's Department to be held over some three days. I do not believe that all of those officers by any means come from Canberra. Melbourne was obviously thought to be a most convenient location for those members of the SES all around Australia to gather for this very important management conference. As to the detailed questions, obviously they require an answer which probably cannot be given until after the event.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the report of the Attorney-General's Department shows that 58 of those officers are employed in Canberra, can the Minister inform the Senate as to which senior officers will be available in Canberra to serve the Attorney-General and him if required during tomorrow's sitting both of this House and the other House of this Parliament?

—I am very confident that what arrangements have been put in place to provide the fullest possible service to the Attorney-General and me will be adequate to deal with such questions as Senator Bishop may wish to ask tomorrow.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to the announcement made yesterday by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Gordon Bilney, that access to combat related positions in the defence forces will now be open to both sexes. I note that women will still not be allowed into front line Army units or to fly Royal Australian Air Force combat aircraft. Can the Minister explain the reasons why women are to be excluded from direct combat? Does the Minister believe that the pledge of full equal employment opportunity by the year 2000 can be met for women in the defence forces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that yesterday Mr Bilney announced that all three Services would open combat related roles to women; that is, those duties requiring a person to work in support of and in proximity to a person performing combat duties, and work that is performed in circumstances that involve the risk of being killed or injured by an enemy. People doing that work may be inadvertently drawn into combat but their primary role is not to close with and destroy the enemy. That is the distinction in the Australian Defence Force wide policy decision which Mr Bilney has taken on the recommendations of the Chiefs of the Defence Force and the Chiefs of Staff. It was taken with the primary objective of giving women a broader range of quality career opportunities in the Australian defence forces. This will have a major influence on the range of trade and professional skills they may develop and on future promotion possibilities.

ANSWER.PARA: This policy has required each of the Services to consider the particular operational circumstances it will face. The Royal Australian Navy has decided that women can serve on all Navy ships with the exception of submarines. The Australian Army has decided to provide progressively further opportunities for women where this can be achieved without detriment to operational effectiveness. Women will be excluded from armour, artillery, infantry and combat engineers. The Royal Australian Air Force has decided that women will be excluded only from operating combat aircraft which have offensive capabilities and from being airfield defence guards. The Royal Australian Navy has a situation where persons performing combat related duties are-and I cannot avoid the expression-in the same boat as persons performing combat duties. Navy had the choice of continuing to exclude women from warships or, excepting that, if making combat related duties available to women in the Navy were to mean anything they would have to be posted to warships, and there is no practical reason why any restriction should be placed on the types of duties available to women at sea. That means that they may take primary combat roles. I am glad to see that the Navy took the second course of action.

The Chiefs of Staff will review implementation of the new arrangements annually and review the policy in June 1993. That policy review will certainly include further considerations to the general exemption under the Sex Discrimination Act for combat roles.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the continuing Australian and Allied defence interests currently facilitated by United States access to Subic Bay and Clark Field. What steps has the Australian Government taken to secure United States commitment to retaining naval and air facilities in the Asia-Pacific region so that there is minimal possibility of developments which may lead to any destabilising power vacuum in our region?

—Mr President, this is one of those matters that involve not only defence but also foreign affairs, but fortunately I have both hats on today. The Australian Government would like to see the United States remain involved at both Clark and Subic Bay. Certainly in any discussions with any US officials that are visiting here, and I am sure this has been relayed by our Embassy staff in Washington, our aim is to pursue that goal. It is our view that their involvement there leads to a far more stable region, one in which this region will be much more likely to be at peace than otherwise. But when it comes to the specific negotiations between the US and the Philippines, we really regard that as their own business and we do not interfere in that process other than within the alliance to encourage the United States to stay involved in the region. For the long term, we hope that that will occur and we will see what transpires.

—My question is directed to Senator Collins representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of reports from the spinal injury expert Dr John Yeo calling for seat belts to be installed on all buses following the bus tragedies of the past year? Does the Minister have any plans to introduce the compulsory wearing of seat belts in buses nationwide? Could the Government move to have one law for seat belts introduced, or would separate legislation have to be introduced to each State Parliament? How quickly could such legislation be introduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this is in fact an extremely important issue involving the protection of lives and, indeed, the prevention of personal injury to a great many travellers in Australia. The issue was debated extensively at the Australian Transport Advisory Council meeting in Perth last Friday. One of the emerging problems in the analysis of the injuries, horrendous injuries in some cases, inflicted on victims of these crashes is not simply the injuries inflicted when passengers have been thrown off seats but unfortunately the very serious injuries caused by people being thrown against the seat supports after the seats themselves shear off the supports and the jagged edges of the supports are left exposed, with the seat support still screwed to the floor.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of this, investigations in which Australia is taking part are going into not simply the question of seat belts but the provision of strengthened supports for the seats themselves. The Minister for Land Transport, Mr Bob Brown, has provided me with the following information as to the Commonwealth's position on this. Following the tragic events at Grafton and Kempsey last year priority was given to expediting mandatory requirements for stronger seats and energy-absorbing padding to provide protection for occupants of seats behind other seats. These requirements are based on the latest international standards and incorporate additional requirements for armrests and other seat fittings.

I am pleased to say that in Perth last Friday, following excellent cooperation from the industry and State and Territory governments, the new national standards were endorsed at the Australian Transport Advisory Council meeting that I referred to. In addition, a national standard to limit the road speed of heavy trucks and buses to 100 kilometres per hour was endorsed.

I expect that Mr Brown, the Minister for Land Transport, will formally sign the order promulgating the new standards shortly. The new seat standard will become effective from 1 July 1992 and the new speed limiting standard from 1 January 1991. I am also pleased to advise the Senate that the Minister for Land Transport has directed that the merits of even stronger seats and seat belts for all coach seats be examined as a matter of urgency. Work is well under way to develop better emergency exit arrangements for coaches.

The Federal Government has reacted quickly to give priority to the development of the new standards and has worked closely with industry and State and Territory governments. Australian coaches will be built to standards equal to or better than those applying anywhere in the world. Under the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 the Federal Government has sole power to determine safety standards of new vehicles. The Minister for Land Transport is committed to maintaining the broad-based consultative processes that have served Australia well in the past, and work well, in developing the new heavy vehicle standards. State and Territory governments will retain responsibility for regulation of areas such as registration and seat belt use. The Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 provides for national standards to be determined by orders approved by the Minister and tabled in the Federal Parliament. The process of developing new standards requires consultation with relevant parties, governments, industry, unions and users, and often requires testing and performance analysis to determine the best solution.

I can assure the Senate that the work in relation to coach safety will be given the highest priority. A test program is already under way to determine the performance of existing seats and provide a basis for further developments. We must be sure that our safety standards are based on facts and careful analysis and design, not immediate reaction to unfortunate events.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Acting Prime Minister, to the wool floor price. Will he now acknowledge that the enormous damage caused to the industry by recent speculation over the future of the floor price was the direct responsibility of the Government, accept that it is totally because of the inept handling of the matter by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that he has now had to determine the 1990-91 season floor price when there is still a month of the current season to go, and acknowledge that, as a result, the Australian Wool Corporation has a highly legitimate claim when, as it stated in its press release today, it says that it will seek some $600m for the losses forced upon it? Does the Minister feel responsibility at all for this shocking situation and these acts of economic treason? What will the Government do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is more dangerous to Senator Boswell than to me. As time passes and the farming community, the wool growing community, increasingly realise both the enormity of the problem and the solutions which this Government has taken to try to solve that problem, rather than look at the short term issues-`I want my lolly now', as Senator Boswell might put it-which have bedevilled the National Party of Australia throughout its existence, when the wool growing community understands these issues better than Senator Boswell does-and they will-then his question will be bounced back at him by me and others, because it just shows how shortsighted and silly he has been about the whole issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Will I admit that the floor price has been affected by actions by the Minister? No. Will I respond to a press release from the Wool Corporation today seeking $600m, as Senator Boswell suggested? No, I will not respond on an ad hoc basis with a knee-jerk reaction; nor will the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In terms of acknowledging responsibility, I really think I have answered that part of the question, because Senator Boswell will have to acknowledge responsibility in due course for giving succour, if I can use that expression, to people who really have very short-sighted views.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. It is in regard to the report Toward a Forest Accord in Western Australia which the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has had for two weeks. Given that WA Chip and Pulp Co. Pty Ltd (WACAP) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Bunnings Ltd, which has 90 per cent of the hardwood market in Western Australia; given that Bunnings Ltd takes 90 per cent of first grade karri sawlogs, but gets only 40 per cent sawn timber recovery, while small sawmillers can get up to 70 per cent recovery; and given that the need to fill WACAP's woodchip quota results in the logging of forest which with higher sawn timber recovery would not need to be logged because the State's sawn timber requirements could be met from two-thirds to one half of the area now being logged, would the Minister immediately reduce by half the WACAP's export quota in order to stop the current inefficient and wasteful use of old grade karri logs and thereby extend the time before the mature forest resource is completely exhausted? Would the Minister also tell us the current target royalties for chiplogs from State forests in Western Australia and when this target will be achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The environmental group called Coalition for Denmark's Environment has put forward a proposal entitled Toward a Forest Accord in Western Australia. Whilst all contributions to the forest debate are welcomed by the Government, I believe that this report contains several basic misconceptions. The first point I would make in response to Senator Vallentine's question is that the report proposes a strategy to reduce the area of Western Australia forest havested through restructuring the Western Australian timber industry. The report is based on achieving improved resource utilisation standards extrapolated from milling studies of only seven first grade logs. This is an extremely small and, might I say, a questionably small example compared to an annual sawlog cut of between 200,000 cubic metres of karri and 500,000 cubic metres of jarrah. That is, the sample size cited in the report is less than 0.01 per cent of the total annual cut of karri sawlogs. This in itself casts some doubt on the accuracy of the claim that the higher recovery is sustainable across all qualities of karri logs currently harvested in Western Australia. I believe the Western Australian government would need more reliable data than that offered in the report before it could consider altering its existing contractual obligations to licensed sawmilling companies which have geared up their operations on the basis of the current allowable cut of karri sawlogs that have been determined under the sustainable yield strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I would make is that larger sawmills can bring to the forest industry a number of advantages which the smaller sawmills cannot. These include the injection of capital to develop sophisticated technology and equipment in drying and value-added processing systems, better industrial safety and welfare programs and greater investment in research and development. While each situation needs to be looked at on its merits I do not consider it desirable as a general rule for large sawmillers to be replaced by a plethora of smaller ones.

The third point that I would make is that the mature karri forest in Western Australia will never be exhausted because the State Department of Conservation and Land Management has adopted a management regime under which some 30 per cent of the forest is reserved permanently from logging. A further 15 per cent is excluded as a result of specific proscriptions such as the allowance for river and stream side reserves. In addition, the area available for harvesting for logs is managed and regenerated on a 100-year rotation cycle. Concerning the final part of Senator Vallentine's question about target royalties for chiplogs, the question of the royalty rates paid by Western Australian companies is a State government matter. I am advised that the West Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management pricing system is set to maximise returns from these resources and their utilisation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: PREPAYMENT OF TELEPHONE CHARGES

TALK.START.PARA: —During Ques- tion Time today, Senator Alston asked me again about the Auditor-General's report, and when Attorney-General's advice was received on matters raised in that report. The advice from the Attorney-General was provided on 22 September 1989, some eight months before the Auditor-General's report. Finance direction 8d has since been changed to clarify the circumstances under which prepayments can occur. I might say that it now very definitely sanctions the practice which Senator Alston seems to be querying.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now in a position to provide the final piece of information for Senator Boswell to his question about the ship being built in Fiji. The answer is as follows: I have further information concerning possible Fijian Government assistance for the construction of the cruise ship Reef Endeavour for the Qantas Airways Ltd-Captain Cook Cruises Pty Ltd joint venture. The building of the cruise ship is being undertaken by the Suva shipyard of the Marine Department, which falls under the Fijian Government Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Utilities. However, the Suva shipyard has been operating on commercial principles since 1986 and publishes its results accordingly. The shipyard has been successful and anticipated profit for 1989 is around Fijian $1m. Corporatisation of the Suva shipyard is under active consideration but is yet to be finalised.

ANSWER.PARA: It may be of some significance that the shipyard has several commercial rivals in Fiji. But following inquiries I have made with respect to the Qantas-Captain Cook Cruises project, it is my information that no Fijian Government subsidy has been paid to the shipyard. It is also of interest that Australia has derived benefit from the Qantas-Captain Cook Cruises shipbuilding project. Virtually all of the raw materials have been, and will be, sourced from Australia. One thousand tonnes of steel for the project have already been purchased from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. In turn, this steel has been pro- cessed by the Brisbane-based company Steelmark; which has also been contracted to cut the steel. I also understand that the shipping to Fiji of all materials has been on Australian vessels.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT AND DETERMINATION OF THE REMUNERATION TRIBUNAL ON THE REMUNERATION OF MINISTERS OF STATE, PARLIAMENTARY OFFICE-HOLDERS, SENATORS AND MEMBERS, THE JUDICIARY AND SECRETARIES OF DEPARTMENTS AND SENIOR PUBLIC OFFICE-HOLDERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report by the Remuneration Tribunal was an attempt by an independent body to establish what would be a fair and reasonable rate of pay and allowances to parliamentarians. It is a subject about which this Government and previous governments, whenever an independent inquiry has been established, have continually known better. They have continually overridden the recommendations contained in this report. Today, for example, we understand that the Australian Labor Party Caucus had a long, heated and, in fact, adjourned meeting on this matter which resulted in its having to meet again at lunchtime. As I understand it, the Labor Caucus bowed once again to the dictates, for political reasons, of its leaders. There will be interference with the independent determination of a tribunal set up to establish what is the right, proper and justifiable remuneration of members of parliament and what their allowances should be. The fact that the Labor Party in government has done this simply reflects what happened when the coalition was in government. A Prime Minister in those days who, I believe, had inadequate concern for the terms and conditions under which members of parliament worked, decided that he knew better than the independent tribunal which had been set up. I do not know of any other instance in Australia where a group of people having been awarded by an independent tribunal a set of wages and conditions which involve an improvement have refused to accept them. There is no other group in Australia which has done so.

Yet-and I stress this-every time the Government interferes with this independent Tribunal, the highly intellectual members of the media take that as an indication that members of parliament somehow establish their own salaries and vote themselves pay rises. For the benefit of the press gallery, I say once again that the only possible thing that members of parliament can do in respect of their own salaries is reduce them. That is what we have done again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am interested to hear the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support say, `Hear, hear'. I wonder whether he says `hear' hear' because his salary is not going up or because he believes that it is good that the press gallery at last recognise that no longer should we have the politics of envy every time there is a pay rise. It might be relevant if in this chamber every now and again, in view of the enormous amount of public money, taxpayers' money, paying the most extraordinarily highly paid people I have struck in the media-those working for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-their salaries should be subject to the same sort of scrutiny, the same sort of debate, the same sort of sneering remarks that we get from the media whenever the question of our salaries is raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I find what the Government has done in this instance to be absurd and damaging. This Tribunal should be treated with the respect it deserves. Its determination should be dealt with with respect. It should be recognised as independent and proper. Every time a government interferes with such an independent determination for crass political reasons-the Prime Minister has interfered this time because he was dictated to by his mates in the Australian Council of Trade Unions-it creates the false impression in the public mind that politicians set their own pay and award themselves pay rises. It is false; it is disgraceful.

The response, in general, of the media has been appalling and, I believe, is aimed at holding politicians up to ridicule and contempt. By the way, I except from that Milton Cockburn of the Sydney Morning Herald, who wrote a reasonable and fair piece on this the other day. But I imagine that today's report will be greeted with the usual sneering ratbaggery of a great number of my former colleagues in the media.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
