DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the report of the review of the national capital plan and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a tabling statement relating to the report which was prepared by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows:

The report that I have just tabled on behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory was prepared by the Committee in the previous Parliament. The new Committee recently appointed in this Parliament resolved to adopt the report and to table it without amendment.

The report deals with the Draft National Capital Plan prepared by the National Capital Planning Authority. In July last year the authority released volume one of the draft plan and this was followed in October by volume two. The report that I have just tabled is the result of the previous committee's inquiry into those first two volumes of the Draft Plan.
The Committee completed its report and had intended to table it last February but was unable to do so because of the dissolution of the Parliament for the election.

Matters have progressed substantially since the report was prepared and the National Capital Planning Authority has extensively revised its draft. It appears that the authority has now considered the comments and criticisms made during the extensive public consultation process. The authority has also considered many of the concerns expressed by the Committee in the public hearings that were part of the committee's inquiry and in the private briefing sessions the Committee had with the authority. The authority has also taken account of matters that I raised with them on behalf of the Committee.

The report I have just tabled was prepared before the authority published its revised plan. However, I think it is important for the Parliament and the public to be able to weigh-up the new draft in the light of previous concerns and criticisms. I believe that this report needed to be tabled without amendment because it will help establish whether or not the National Capital Planning Authority has taken the right track.
The Committee itself now intends to proceed to a review of the revised draft and I hope to be able to report back to the Parliament in August.

The previous Committee examined all the submissions received by the National Capital Planning Authority in response to its public consultation process and held a series of public hearings and briefings. It found both support and opposition, and also considerable misunderstanding of the plan. Expressions of concern about the role of the National Capital Planning Authority, the legislation dealing with planning in the A.C.T. and the adequacy of A.C.T. self-government arrangements were also confused with comments on the provisions of the plan itself.

The committee considered that the National Capital Planning Authority had produced a draft plan that, if adopted, would comply with the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act in so far as the Act relates to the National Capital Plan. The Committee concluded that the draft plan contained proposals which would provide a sound basis for the continuing planning and development of Canberra in a way that would preserve the character of the city as the national capital. The Committee rejected criticisms that the National Capital Planning Authority had exceeded its authority or had usurped the role of the A.C.T. Government.

There were some short comings in the plan and the Committee found that it failed to anticipate or deal with many of the issues that subsequently became important. This led the Committee to recommend a series of significant changes to be incorporated before the plan is finalised and brought into the parliament. For example the Committee recommended that the plan be revised to stress and clarify its role in relation to the proposed territory plan. The Committee also suggested that the proposal to adopt and incorporate gazetted former National Capital Development Commission policies be made more explicit and prominent.

The Committee was concerned that the draft plan contained neither an adequate, full or explicit vision of Canberra's future nor analysis of alternative outcomes. It therefore recommended that the plan present more substantial economic and demographic data. The discussion about the future composition of the territory's economy, population and work force and how the trends in these factors would affect the development of the territory in its role of the national capital was found to be inadequate. The Committee also found that there was a need to discuss the implications of the plan for Commonwealth-Territory financial relations.

In some cases the Committee found that the proposals in the plan were quite acceptable but that many of the people who had responded to the draft plan were unaware of these proposals. In some cases they were aware of proposals but did not understand them. The Committee therefore recommended, for example, that the plan make it clear how the principles, policies, standards and special requirements it sets down are linked to the old NCDC policies.

The future role of the plan itself needed clarification and the Committee recommended that the National Capital Planning Authority's intention to review gazetted policies be made explicit and that a timetable for the review be included in the plan.

The recommendations that I have referred to so far dealt with the plan in a general way. The Committee also made a number of recommendations about specific proposals for areas of land to be identified as designated areas or areas where special requirements will apply. The approach adopted by the Committee, when reviewing these proposals, was generally that leased land should not be made designated land nor should land where a significant Commonwealth involvement does not exist. It was felt that these areas should only be designated where it is necessary for the integrity of the character of the national capital. There were instances where the Committee thought that for some areas a better balance of Commonwealth, Territory and private interest would be better achieved if special requirements were applied rather than designation. In each case the Committee believed that such an approach would not jeopardise the national capital role of the A.C.T.

The National Capital Planning Authority's revised draft was recently tabled in the Parliament as the certified draft national capital plan. The Committee has not yet had the opportunity to look at the certified draft in any detail. It appears that, in taking previous comments and criticisms into account, the National Capital Planning Authority has rectified many of the problems identifed by the Committee. However the adequacy of the certified draft is a matter for the further review that I referred to when I began my comments and I do not want to pre-empt that review.
I commend the report to the Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: report No. 34 of 1989-90, Royal Australian Mint, coin production.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —This audit report deals with the Royal Australian Mint's coin production. It deals with a matter of some concern which has been costing taxpayers multimillions of dollars a year. The Auditor-General has recommended that some action be taken to stop this unnecessary drain on public funds. It has emerged from a gross miscalculation some years ago about the demand for coinage. The Auditor-General found that stocks above the recommended levels had been accumulated in the early 1980s, with a production cost of over $20m, and had been on hand from 1983 to 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General said:
Using a long term bond rate of 13% it calculated that the carrying cost of the capital tied up in this excess was about $3m per year.

It was said that the excess stocks had been difficult to dissipate `largely because of a fall in demand for circulating coins'. I understand that the Treasury's estimate now of the need for coins in the next few years is nil. In fact the Treasury's comment, as I recall it, was that it envisages that demand estimates for each coin-20c, 50c and $1-over the next three years will approach zero. I am not necessarily blaming anyone for that miscalculation, but it is evident that the structural change in the demand for coinage seemed to emerge in part from the introduction particularly of the $2 coins and to some extent of the $1 coin.

The Reserve Bank repurchases coins which are surplus to the community's re quirements. It told the Auditor-General that during the 1980s it accumulated stocks of 20c, 50c and $1 coins in excess of its normal trading requirements and that the Mint's excess stocks have been increased by its repurchase of $100m face value of 20c, 50c and $1 coins from the Reserve Bank in 1987-88 and 1988-89. The cost of production of these coins was about $13m. The Audit Office, using the current long-term bond rate, calculates the carrying cost of excess stocks at the cost of production is now about $3 3/4m a year.

The question is, how are we to resolve this problem? The facts are that from 1985-86 the Mint virtually ceased new production of 20c, 50c and $1 coins, so there is no new production coming on, although the Mint seems to want to keep lots of blanks. I am not quite certain why that is the case, but it seems to want to maintain a large stock of blanks just in case demand changes. As I have said, apart from the issue of bicentennial coins in 1988, the Mint virtually ceased new production of 20c, 50c and $1 coins, and a trial meltdown was conducted in July 1989 after the Treasurer's approval had been obtained for the conversion of surplus stocks into metal cake. In late 1989 the Mint decided to melt down progressively $55m face value of its stock of 20c and 50c coins and the Mint will use this metal to produce 5c and 10c blanks. The meltdown will be undertaken on an as-needed basis, and the Mint expects that this will provide the metal for the production of 5c and 10c blanks for about five years. At present, though, the excess $1 coins are to be stored to meet demand, and consideration is to be given to the feasibility of their meltdown.

The Audit Office is critical of the delay in addressing the problem of the excess stocks of 20c coins which became apparent as early as 1982-83. It recommends that the meltdown should begin as quickly as possible to realise offsetting savings in the cost of 5c and 10c blanks and eventual savings in storage costs. As I have said, the only criticism is in the delay in resolving this problem, although the Auditor-General makes the point:
There are a number of inefficiencies inherent in the present system of distribution which lacks sufficient mechanisms to encourage the efficient management of stocks of coins.

I hope, as I am sure do other senators, that the Auditor-General's recommendations are carried out with speed by the Royal Australian Mint, which clearly will not be in great need of great volumes of funds, I hope, in future estimates, as it will not be producing a large number of coins for quite some time. I look forward to seeing some reduction in future estimates requirements at the next Estimates committee meeting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Eighty-sixth report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This is the Eighty-sixth report of the Committee which deals with its operations from July 1988 to June 1989. The report describes in detail the scrutiny by the Committee of the 1,352 instruments which came before it in the course of the year, to ensure that the Executive and other law-makers comply with its principles of parliamentary propriety and personal rights and liberties. It sets out statistics of the types of instruments examined and the ministerial undertakings obtained in respect of concerns raised by the Committee. It also lists undertakings implemented during the year.

The report sets out in one convenient document the whole of the operations of the Committee. The Chairman makes a statement to the Senate at the end of each group of sittings on the Committee's work during those sittings. It is also usual to incorporate in Hansard correspondence with Ministers and a short statement in respect of each instrument where the Committee feels obliged to give a protective notice of motion of disallowance. The report draws together these threads into a single source of reference.

The delegated legislation considered by the Committee is, of course, made under the authority of Acts of Parliament, and imposes duties and grants rights which are in no way less than those derived from Acts. The Committee believes that it has a trust from the Senate in its non-partisan scrutiny of delegated legislation for breaches of its principles which relate to compliance with the enabling statute, observance of personal rights, provision of review of administrative decisions and avoidance of provisions more appropriate for enactment by the Parliament. These are principles with which I know the Senate is closely associated.

The report should also be of benefit to officers of departments and statutory authorities who are involved in the making of delegated legislation. Ministers should take this opportunity to direct their departmental officers to meet the requirements noted in the report when preparing delegated legislation to place before the Minister or the Executive Council. It is a test and a yardstick of efficient administration in departments that the standards of the Committee are known and applied.

I believe the report demonstrates that the Committee has carried out its high duties in a manner which justifies the continued confidence of the Senate. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the statement of the work of the Committee during the Autumn sittings of 1990.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
STATEMENT OF WORK OF COMMITTEE
DURING AUTUMN SITTINGS 1990

The work of the Committee during these sittings has been unusual in that the number of sitting weeks has been much less due to the elections on 24 March 1990. The scrutiny which normally takes place over the whole of a normal sittings has been compressed into four weeks.

The considerable volume of delegated legislation which came before the Committee in that short time illustrates its position in Australian public administration. Although the Parliament did not meet for more than four months, the parent Acts which authorise the Executive and others to make laws remained in operation, and delegated legislation was added to Commonwealth law at a rate scarcely less than during a normal sittings. It may be that the Executive could not function without delegated legislation, especially where flexibility and technical detail are elements of a particular scheme or a continuing program. Such law making by the Executive does not occur in a vacuum. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee acts as a surrogate of Parliament to scrutinise in minute detail every instrument of delegated legislation to ensure compliance with parliamentary propriety and personal rights.

This scrutiny is procedurally possible because of the legislative requirement that all delegated legislation be tabled in both Houses and be liable to disallowance. In practice, however, it is only in the Senate where disallowance occurs. Such extreme action is rarely necessary, however, as a Minister will usually undertake to amend an offending instrument to meet the concerns of the Committee or will explain the provisions of the instrument to its satisfaction. The Senate has never failed to act on a recommendation of the Committee. This confidence of the Senate in its longest serving committee, with the exception of certain domestic committees; is due not to any procedural formalities. It is because the Committee has earned this respect due to the most notable characteristic of its operations. That is, that it operates in a non-partisan fashion, with no consideration to party loyalties or to the broad policy merits of individual instruments.

This trust of the Senate is, in turn, reflected in the dealings of the Committee with Ministers. A communication from the Committee is recognised by Ministers and administrators as dealing with only technical legislative scrutiny which could not affect the efficiency of any properly conceived administrative scheme.

The following Table lists the different instruments of delegated legislation which have been considered by the Committee during these four weeks of sittings. The list is noteworthy for its length and variety. A number of entries in the list have themselves been telescoped for ease of reference. The Education Determinations, for example, are made under various provisions of a number of parent Acts. It is not possible conveniently to list these in any other form due to deficiencies in numbering and citation. The same applies to the Health Determinations. The legislation in the list was made under parent Acts administered by Ministers through every Department of State and important statutory authorities. Even the Statutory Rules series alone is made on the advice of almost all Ministers and in some cases directly by judges of Commonwealth courts. The Parliamentary Presiding Officers' Determinations are made by officers of the Parliament.

Each instrument which comes before the Committee is scrutinised under the four principles which may be called its terms of reference. When a defect comes to its notice a letter is sent to the Minister responsible for making or administering the legislation in question, with a request to amend the offending provision or parent Act, to take administrative action or to provide further background explanation.

In these sittings the Committee detected what appeared to be defects in 107 of the 550 instruments which it considered. These defects are set out below under each of the four principles. These principles are not mutually exclusive. For example, failure to provide proper review of an adverse exercise of a discretion is also a breach of personal rights.
(a) Is the delegated legislation in accordance with the statute?

This principle includes the general reference of parliamentary propriety. This is not interpreted narrowly to mean only that an instrument is within the authority granted by Parliament to the Executive to make laws. Like all the principles of the Committee it is broad and evolutionary. The Committee was concerned at the following aspects of various instruments.

It is a fundamental principle of parliamentary propriety that if delegated legislation authorises instruments of a legislative nature then provision should be made for parliamentary tabling and disallowance of those instruments. Such provisions may grant power to exempt from provisions or fees or to otherwise affect the operation of the principal instrument. If such power only applies to individual cases then a right of review of the merits of decisions may be appropriate. If, however, a group or class is affected then the resulting instrument may be legislative and should be subject to control by Parliament in the same way as the principal instrument. The Committee questioned a provision for Departmental by-laws with no tabling and disallowance requirements. Another case required a certificate of exemption from review procedures to be tabled but did not provide for disallowance. In another a definition of ``drugs'', which was an important element in the entire scheme effected by the delegated legislation, could be varied by a declaration in the Gazette with no tabling or disallowance. The power to exempt or vary may be a power equal to that of the original law maker.

Parliamentary propriety is also affected if an instrument on its face is unusual to the extent that its provisions may have been unintended. In such cases the Explanatory Statement should fully describe the background. For example, one instrument which determined the remuneration of important office holders was followed a few days later by another, next in the series, which duplicated the same remuneration for the same office holders. In another case, one instrument made in 1990 was expressed to come into operation on the date of the coming into operation of a provision of a 1980 Act. One instrument determined allowances for every State of the United States in one part and in another omitted one State. In one instrument the Chairpersons of various Committees set up by regulation could appoint an acting member, whereas in most similar cases the Minister had this power. On a lighter note, the Committee was intrigued by a breakfast allowance for New York which was double that for lunch. This was made up for, however, by a dinner allowance which was six times that of lunch.

The Committee always checks that particular procedural requirements for the making of delegated legislation have been met. In suitable cases this should be actually advised in a recital in the enacting words. In other cases it may be sufficient to include the advice in the Explanatory Statement. In one case the Minister was required to approve a project before determining an amount of money to be spent in respect of the project. The instrument itself, however, did not refer to an approval or even a project, but merely determined a sum of money.

Following instructions from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, Acts of Parliament now provide in effect for commencement at least within six months of Assent. This beneficial development has not been followed by all delegated legislation. The Committee questioned two instruments which provided for commencement on a date to be fixed by the Minister by notice in the Gazette, which could be any time in the future, or even not at all.

The Committee is concerned that delegated legislation should be drafted and made to the same high standards as Acts of Parliament. The Committee questions instruments where these high standards are not met. One instrument was headed with a particular citation but referred to another citation in its body, a citation which was also used for a later instrument in the series. Some copies have been defective, with pages missing or with printing so poor that it could not be read. Others contained drafting and typographical errors serious enough to confuse users. One contained more than 100 handwritten alterations with no initials or other evidence of authentication. One instrument was described on its face as having been made on the advice of a Minister whose title was evidently transposed.

In some cases Explanatory Statements were still not provided and in others there was no system of numbering or citation to assist the Parliament, the Committee and the public. Citation was poor or lacking completely even for instruments which in one case authorised the release of private information and in others authorised the payment of Commonwealth money. As discussed later in more detail, a number of Explanatory Statements did not explain reasons for increases in taxes and fees.

One recent development has been a tendency to make different Statutory Rules with the same title, on the advice of the same Minister, amending the same principal Regulations made under the same parent Act, on the same day and with consecutive numbers in the series. There have been many such examples of this in the last six months. In the most extreme example of this trend, eight separate such Statutory Rules, all with the same title and other features described above, were made on the same day. The Committee has questioned the legislative policy which results in this apparent duplication of time and resources.

Another characteristic of the sittings has been the number of Statutory Rules issued with a pink slip attached advising that the copy is to be substituted for an earlier, presumably defective, copy. Two such Statutory Rules were issued with a pink slip advising that the copies were to be substituted for two earlier, separate, defective, copies. This is a level of presentation which falls below that expected by the Committee. In almost every case the Explanatory Statement is silent on the reasons for the substitution, even where the different copies have different dates of making by the Governor-General. In other cases there is no apparent difference at all between the two, or three copies, with even typographical errors reproduced in the later versions. The Committee was particularly concerned that some of these defective copies may have been distributed to the public or other users. Again, there was no assurance on this point in the later Explanatory Statements.

The substituted copies raise problems of invalidity. Several of the sets of Statutory Rules were expressly advised as having been made in reliance on amendments of the parent Act which received assent after the putative date of making of the first copy. There may also be invalidity questions under s.48A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, which provides that regulations are not to be remade while they are required to be tabled.
(b) Does the delegated legislation trespass unduly upon personal rights and liberties?
The Committee is always particularly vigilant where personal rights are concerned. During the reporting period the Committee was concerned about the following matters.

One area where the Committee always raises questions is where provision is made for the issue of search warrants without including the highest possible safeguards. The right of entry of public officials onto private premises, in many cases by force if necessary, requires close scrutiny. One instrument provided for the Secretary of a Department to issue a warrant. This was a breach of the important safeguard that warrants should only be issued by a judicial officer. In addition, the Secretary could delegate this power to any person at all. Another instrument empowered the Minister or a delegate to issue warrants, although delegation was restricted to senior officers of the Department. Again, this was a breach of the principle and safeguard that in these matters a person should not be a judge in their own cause. Such issue was a serious matter, as the warrant in this case authorised the destruction of certain buildings and property found on the premises. The Committee questioned another case where a warrant could be issued by a magistrate, who is a judicial officer, or a Justice of the Peace, who is not, and where the prescribed form of the warrant was not mandatory. In another case the Committee was concerned at the lack of provision for a mandatory form of warrant even where issue was required by a judge.

The Committee is always concerned at provisions creating strict liability offences, that is, where there may be no intention by a person to commit an offence, or even no knowledge that an offence exists. Such provisions have potential for breaches of personal liberties and the Committee accepts strict liability only in exceptional circumstances and after full explanation from the Minister. Strict liability provisions included a failure to provide information to a public official and a prohibition on discharging more than 20 persons from a tourist boat in certain areas, even apparently if the boat caught fire or was sinking. Another instance involved a prohibition on keeping certain hazardous objects on land or interfering with authorised public officials who entered upon that land. The Committee was especially concerned that in this latter case there was not even a provision requiring such authorised public officials to carry and produce proper photographic identity and evidence of their authority. In this context, the Committee normally insists that any public official with the power to enter private premises, whether by warrant or otherwise, carry the fullest identification.

Another aspect of offence provisions that draws an immediate response from the Committee is any reversal of the normal onus of proof which, of course, lies with the prosecution. It is a principle of personal liberty that a person is innocent until proven guilty. The Committee will accept the reversal of this presumption only in special circumstances. This is the position even where, as in the one case considered during these sittings, there were a number of elements in the offence of which only one reversed the onus of proof.

The Committee questions any provision which gives the executive unusual powers which affect personal rights. One instrument made extensive provision for a number of committees to advise the Minister on important policy issues. The Minister was empowered to appoint Committee members, who were required to be highly qualified and eminent. Although the maximum period of appointment was only three years the Minister could remove members for no reason and with no explanation. The usual provision in such cases restricts removal to proven misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.

Wherever an instrument imposes, or provides for a change in the rate of taxes, charges or fees, the Committee requires the Explanatory Statement to set out the basis for the calculation of the rate, the change from the previous rate and the period during which the previous rate was in force. The level and calculation of taxes and charges directly affects personal liberties and any unusual or unexplained increase may breach those liberties. One instrument advised that an increase in charges from $860 to $2000 in little more than 12 months was ``to meet costs''. Other increases from 2.5 cents to 13.5 cents and an increase of 50% were not explained at all. On the other hand, a reduction of 40% in a levy was also unexplained.

On a related issue the parent Act of one instrument provided that fees charged by the regulations must not amount to taxation. There was no such assurance in the Explanatory Statement. In addition, the Explanatory Statement stated that the fees had been set following advice from an Industry-Government Consultative Committee. The Committee asked whether such advice had actually been accepted.

Delegated legislation may deprive people of their property in the course of provision for a scheme or program. In such cases the committee is vigilant to ensure that the compensation process is as fair as possible. In one case personal service of a notice for compensation purposes could be substituted by a notice in the Gazette and in a local newspaper. Failure by an affected person to take action then generally resulted in loss of a right to compensation. In addition, compensation was not payable where another person had been compensated in good faith in respect of the same matter. Such a provision prevented payment where the government may have acted in good faith, but negligently.

Procedural requirements, as with the substituted service just mentioned, have the potential to affect personal rights. In one instrument, involving appeal rights, persons had to be `told' of the result of a hearing. In another, the Reserve Bank had to `tell' banks of an accounting day. It appeared that telling for these important matters could be merely oral. This contrasted with another instrument which required `telling in writing'.

Expressions in delegated legislation should be precise and certain. Subjective and vague provisions could breach personal rights. Some such words and phrases questioned by the Committee include `adequately supervised', `keeps up to date', `successful business record', `distinguished talent', `has a national reputation' and `regional and global priorities of the Commonwealth'. Failure to comply with such provisions could result in prosecution or the exclusion from personal and economic benefits. In such cases, of course, the Committee believes review of adverse decisions should be provided.

(c) Does the delegated legislation unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal?

This principle complements the Committee's vigilance with respect to personal rights and liberties. Any discretion granted to a Minister or administrator to make a decision which could adversely affect an individual is scrutinised for appropriate external review of the merits of that decision.

The Committee prefers independent external review of the merits of administrative decisions rather than internal review, even if such review is conducted by an independent specialist tribunal constituted expressly to consider such reviews. The Committee generally refuses to accept that final review should be conducted by a public official or a delegate of the Minister. In this context the Committee questioned provisions under which a specialist internal review tribunal could not make a final, binding decision but could only recommend in respect of an earlier decision, following a procedure where only the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police was entitled to be represented. Review by the Minister personally is more acceptable as the Minister is, of course, liable to be examined in parliament on his or her actions. The Committee's preference is for review of executive discretions to be conducted by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), which is an independent body of legal and technical experts able to place itself in the position of the original decision maker and to substitute its decision for the original decision made. The case for review is more pressing where a statutory decision maker is given authority to delegate that power.

In some instruments external review was provided for some discretions but not for others. In these cases the Committee believes that if review is appropriate for some discretions which are part of a general scheme, then in the absence of compelling reasons to the contrary, review should be provided for all such discretions. In some situations it appears that absence of universal review rights in a particular scheme was a mere oversight, corrected as soon as the Committee drew attention to the defect. In other cases the Minister explained to the satisfaction of the Committee why external review was inappropriate. Such reasons included decisions to be made in emergencies.

The Committee always looks carefully at discretions involving the rights of individuals to carry on a business or to practise a trade or profession. Such considerations are also part of the Committee's brief to safeguard personal liberties. Decisions affecting important commercial rights, such as the power to withdraw or cancel export entitlements, were raised, as was the failure to provide review of a decision not to waive or reduce fees, where such fees could amount to tens of thousands of dollars.

In some cases the Minister may advise the Committee that a discretion relates to the allocation of a finite resource, where the overturn of an existing decision and its substitution by another will result in a chain of alterations to other decisions, to the detriment and confusion of those affected. The Administrative Review Council, the peak Commonwealth advisory body on all aspects of administrative review, has accepted that in such cases independent external review of the merits by a body such as the AAT with all the rights of the original decision maker, may not be appropriate. The Committee may accept such advice although where this is the case it will look with particular care to ensure safeguards exist with respect to the original decision, such as detailed and precise criteria to guide and control the decision maker.

Such criteria should be provided wherever possible in all delegated legislation. In several cases, however, the effect of detailed criteria was diluted by the addition of an additional criterion such as `any other factors that are relevant' or `any other factors that the Commissioner considers relevant'.

The Committee is particularly concerned where discretions are provided but there is no mention of review rights either in the instrument itself or in the Explanatory Statement. Such rights may, of course, be provided by the parent Act, by the parent regulations in the case of certain Orders, by the principal regulations or by other instrument. Review rights should in such cases be set out in the Explanatory Statement.

In one such case a statutory authority could determine payments out of a fund to holders of equity in the fund with no apparent review of any adverse decision in respect of classes of equity or even between individuals in a class. This was even though the Explanatory Statement advised that there was no automatic right of payment.
The Committee questioned a reference to `reasonable costs' with no indication of a right of review of an adverse decision, as it did with a discretion to determine whether costs were `excessive'.

Similarly, the Committee asked for further advice where, although AAT review was provided, the Minister could exclude this right by giving a certificate on public interest grounds, with provision only for tabling but not disallowance of the certificate. In this instance the Explanatory Statement advised that the right of review was included on the recommendation of the Administrative Review Council. There was no corresponding advice on whether the exclusion certificate had been recommended by the ARC.

Discretions may affect individual employees of the Commonwealth as well as commercial enterprises. The Committee asked for clarification of review rights of a discretion to reimburse interest where a public servant is transferred and subsequently takes out an unregulated mortgage in place of a regulated. Similar discretions in respect of a disability and other allowances were questioned.
In one set of regulations there were 11 separate decision makers expressly mentioned, including State and Territory Ministers and officials and, in two cases, non-government bodies.
(d) Does the delegated legislation contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment?

No instrument was questioned under this principle during the sittings. The Committee awaits, however, resolution of a matter which it first raised several years ago and which it has continued to press. The Sex Discrimination (Operation of Legislation) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1989 No. 200, continued in operation for a further 12 month period, to 31 July 1990, certain legislation which would otherwise be in breach of the parent Sex Discrimination Act 1984. This was the sixth year in a row that these discriminatory laws had been prolonged by regulation. The Committee indicated to the Minister that amendment of the Act would be appropriate rather than further regulation.

An analysis of the legislation which has come before the Committee this sittings emphasises a trend noticed before in these statements. This is that the Statutory Rules series, which is the best drafted and produced of all of the scores of series of delegated legislation, is a clear minority of the instruments which come before the Committee. As noted earlier during the survey on the principles of the Committee, the Statutory Rules series may have defects. It is, nevertheless, markedly superior to all other series, due largely to the safeguards imposed by the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903. Much of the other delegated legislation lacks this protection and, although subject to tabling and possible disallowance, is not acceptable in quality of drafting or presentation.

Another aspect of the legislation is encouraging. The considerable numbers of Civil Aviation Orders, Defence Determinations and Public Service Determinations all deal with matters which are particularly suited to executive law making. The Civil Aviation Orders deal with technical engineering requirements and the other Determinations largely with the minutae of financial aspects of personnel administration. Other series of instruments, which are not equal in presentation to these series or, of course, to the Statutory Rules, sometimes address issues which are less obviously appropriate to delegated legislation.

Despite the generally good response that the Committee receives from Ministers and departmental officials there are still areas of concern. When the Committee reconvened after a break of more than four months it found that some replies to correspondence were still outstanding. It is essential that officers address such queries with a priority that reflects the importance of the subject matter and the gravity of a communication from a Committee of the Parliament. On behalf of the Committee I have written reminders in respect of this correspondence, indicating that if necessary the Committee would repeat its initiative of last year and invite senior departmental officials to appear before it to explain long delays. Such an option is also available to the Committee in respect of undertakings to amend legislation which remain outstanding.

The members of the Committee are grateful to their colleagues in the Senate for their commitment to its non-partisan parliamentary ideals of protection of personal liberties and parliamentary proprieties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I wish to support the remarks of the Chairman, Senator Colston, on the operations of the Committee. In particular, I confirm the non-partisan nature of its technical legislative scrutiny. The reputation and prestige of the Committee has always been based on the strict avoidance of both party-political controversy and the policy merits of delegated legislation. Naturally differences of opinion may arise in the course of the detailed scrutiny of each one of the more than 1,000 instruments which come before the Committee each year, but these are never based on party-political grounds. Members seek to protect the rights of Parliament and the rights of individuals in a way which excludes party-political disputation.

This is the first report by the Committee under the new procedures for review of annual reports by standing committees. The report is self-explanatory in its assessment of the 35 annual reports referred to the Committee in the second half of 1989. All of the 34 reports for 1988-89 were judged to be `apparently satisfactory'. One 1987-88 report was tabled extremely late and the Committee has commented on this unsatisfactory aspect, the inadequacy of the explanation and the failure to comply with the requirements of the Act. This report was the only one amongst the six listed by the President as apparently tabled late which was in fact late.

The unusual sitting pattern in the current session made necessary by the timing of the election restricted the scope of the Committee's survey. As the report makes clear, the Committee envisages in the Budget Session a review process which will include short public hearings and a focus on particular areas of concern. Among issues highlighted in this report is the failure of most reports to meet the Government's requirement that reports should specify `results achieved and progress towards the achievement of objectives and targets'. The Committee will give particular attention to this issue in its current inquiry into Estimates committee procedures. The Committee intends to hold hearings in this inquiry and to report during the coming Budget period of sittings. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1990

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1990 and the amendment moved by Senator Macklin to clause 4. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were discussing this matter earlier today I was going through the reasons put forward by Senator Watson when he moved this amendment on 2 November. I wish to quote from the Hansard again where Senator Watson emphatically points out that this is not a taxing measure; it is a machinery Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government is using this measure as a taxing Bill, then it is a disgrace. It is morally wrong and outrageous to use the back-door methods that it will be attempting to apply to get extra revenue from public hospitals and public universities which, according to its logic, the Government should not be doing.

At that time the amendment moved by Senator Watson was carried 32:24. We next debated this matter on 30 November when we had a message from the House of Representatives saying that the House of Representatives had disagreed with the Senate's amendment. Senator Watson said this:

The Opposition is not impressed with the reasons given by the House of Representatives in transmitting its message No. 577 . . . In response to that, I remind the Senate that the reduction in revenue has been estimated by the Government at $50m. While this is a deemed loss to the Government, it is an imposition of $50m on public hospitals, benevolent institutions-perhaps only one would qualify; the Australian Red Cross-and public universities . . . Can the Minister . . . convince us that that $50m has been given back by virtue of payments to the States and others, to public hospitals, benevolent institutions and universities?
We have not been convinced of that in this debate and yet we are told that we should not proceed with this amendment. Senator Watson continues:
If so, we would be quite happy to allow this amendment to lapse. But he cannot. The Government is trying to claw back, by a backdoor method, revenue to these vital institutions.
Further on in his speech he says this:
We are not asking for something that is unreasonable; rather, we are asking that the Government fund these bodies adequately and that it does not claw the funds back through the back door.

These bodies, particularly public hospitals, operate on deficit finance or overdraft arrangements; they are nearly always in the red, with their funding from the public purse in arrears rather than in advance. Therefore, most are faced with making interest payments on their overdraft; so the Government's interest gained is their interest lost and that is what we must recognise. Those interest payments are currently at rates of between 20 and 25 per cent. Should they now be expected to make twice-monthly remittances of pay as you earn tax, this will disrupt their planned cash flows and place them further in debt.

That is still the case. That has not changed. They will still be further in debt. If that was a reason given on 30 November to support this amendment I believe that it is a reason now. Senator Watson then goes on to point out the consequences of these actions:

These bodies-the public hospitals, public universities and benevolent institutions-also rely very heavily on donations and bequests from individuals, particularly for capital works and equipment purchase projects. So, what will happen? People donate money to the Melbourne Royal Children's Hospital for beds and redecorating children's wards but, in the future, as a result of this legislation some of that money will be used to pay the debt interest.

That is still the case. Nothing has changed. The losers, Senator Watson summarises, will be the kids and the facilities the donors provide. That is still the case. Nothing has changed. The kids and the facilities will be affected. `This type of legislation is not the humanitarian sort of thing which governments should be involved in', Senator Watson says. He goes on:
I believe it is disgraceful. It will not be possible to transfer debt to the public funding body.

Now we have the Opposition, however, being willing to do that-being willing, in fact, to hit those kids in the public institutions, being willing to load benevolent institutions with further debt and in fact not holding the line on this. Opposition members know that if they had held the line the Government would have accepted it this time round. But they went to water. They went to water and are quite happy to allow this to roll over now, having done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never gave us that guarantee.
—Why does Senator Watson not actually listen? In that particular debate, Senator Haines, speaking for the Democrats at that time, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: To require those sorts of institutions to come up with tens of millions of dollars, just because the Government wants this one-off boost to revenue, is bizarre, to put it mildly. They will have to acquire this money from somewhere, and that means either cutting their expenditure in some area . . .
and Senator Watson agrees with that: that is what they will have to-
or borrowing the money-
and Senator Watson agrees with that-
which will impose additional stresses on their finances for repayment, to say nothing of the additional pressures that it will apply to lending institutions.

Senator Stone also at that stage supported this particular proposition. I think honourable senators in here remember him for his very dry approach to economics. He said something which I think was very interesting. In referring to what the Minister had done by way of reply when he said that the interest payments would minuscule, Senator Stone said this:
. . . he has described the interest cost to these bodies as minuscule . . . 22 per cent of $50m is $11m, as far as I know.

I think that is worth repeating. If that in fact is the case-and it used to be when I was at school; I do not think it has changed since-and we have had an admittance from the Government that is the amount of money we are talking about, then that is not a pittance for public institutions that are in debt.

The type of response that the Government made, of course, was that at some stage they will start to look at this issue somewhere down the track to decide whether or not they should readjust the exercise with regard to public hospitals, tertiary institutions and benevolent organisations. We are now further down the track and nothing has happened. This particular amendment is not in fact asking anything different from what currently happens.

I would just like to go through what is the situation with regard to the tax treatment of these particular bodies. Are we suggesting something out of the ordinary with regard to them? Let us have a look at what the current situation is. Public benevolent institutions, including public hospitals, are exempt from the fringe benefits tax. Religious, scientific, charitable and public education institutions, are exempt from income tax and hence capital gains tax. Public benevolent institutions, public or non-profit hospitals, universities and public or non-profit schools are exempt from the bank account debit tax. Similar institutions under State imposts are exempt from financial institutions duties.

Public hospitals, public universities and public benevolent institutions qualify for exemptions from State stamp duties. Public hospitals, public education institutions and non-profit bodies are exempt from State land taxes. Public hospitals, public education institutions and benevolent organisations are exempt from State payroll taxes. Public hospitals, public education institutions and benevolent organisations are exempt from local government rates. Public hospitals, public education institutions and benevolent organisations are exempt from sales tax. They are also exempt from diesel excise, and from alcohol excise where it is used for sterilisation and not for consumption.

So what we have is a vast range of exceptions made for these particular bodies. What this amendment is suggesting is in fact not to establish a regime that makes them different; this amendment in fact is to establish a regime in keeping with the way that they have always been treated.

I believe that this was worth supporting last year. We supported Senator Watson last year when he moved this on behalf of the Opposition, and we supported him when it came back the first time. We supported him when it came back the second time. I really do believe that if the arguments were valid then-and, as Senator Watson must acknowledge, nothing has changed-those arguments are valid now. Under those circumstances I believe, since we are not talking about a tax Bill but a machinery Bill, the Opposition cannot say that this is a matter of taxation unless Senator Watson wishes also to renege on that explanation to the Senate last year. So I think we quite properly ought to continue with our support of this amendment and send the Bill back to the House of Representatives in the amended form so that those particular institutions that are named in the amendment-those public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities-are not further imposed on with regard to costs and charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position of the Opposition was fully outlined during my second reading address, and I refer Senator Macklin to those comments. But I would like to add that governments and the three affected bodies have had now almost six months to adjust their accounting provisions, to adjust their finance. We are approaching a new financial period-1 July-and these bodies will be affected for approximately 14 days.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Senate that essentially, overall, as a maximum we are looking towards $50m but it is not really $50m because it is only a timing extra cost on that $50m-that is, $15m, which is interest for about 14 days applicable to the $50m. That is the real cost that these people will incur and we believe that governments will finance these bodies appropriately in the coming financial year commencing 1 July. These provisions do not apply until June this year and I believe that we were right in putting forward those amendments. We put the pressure on the Government. I believe it will respond adequately with the financial arrangements for the year commencing 1 July.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel almost irrelevant to this debate. I almost left it to Senator Macklin and Senator Watson but I thought I should briefly reiterate the Government's position. Obviously we oppose the amendment. We, as I said in the second reading debate, did not accept the arguments that were put in November when the legislation was deferred. We do not think they were correct then and we have not changed that view, but we certainly endorse the view now adopted by the Opposition that had it been true then, the changed circumstances have certainly overcome such problems as there might have been, Senator Macklin referred to the changed circumstances, and Senator Watson said I think in November that it would disrupt the planned cash flows of the institutions. It certainly will not disrupt the planned cash flows of the institutions now. They have had six months to cope with two weeks of disruption before the next financial year and six months to cope through their governments and other bodies with subsequent funding.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go into all the arguments that we put in seemingly never-ending debates last year. I will simply say that what we are talking about is the transfer of taxpayers' money to the Government through an institution which is merely the conduit for that transfer, and that is the role which ideally it ought to play. Administratively it is necessary for some accumulation. We are trying to minimise that accumulation because it is not the institution's money; it is the taxpayers' money en route to the Government and it ought to get there as quickly as possible. It is part of a broader strategy that will in the end lead to a beneficial variation for small employers who will be able to remit on a less frequent basis than at present as the system develops, and therefore we oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not disagree with the proposition put forward by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan)-that is, that if the Government wishes to rearrange the way in which these taxes are collected, then it is entitled to do so. In fact, when the Government made this announcement, we expressed support. The Opposition at that stage expressed opposition. The reason the Bill went through is that we supported it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not that particular matter with which we disagree. We disagree with the imposition of the tax on these particular bodies. We think that the item that Senator Watson raised last year was an important one. Earlier today Senator Watson, in response, said that he is now confident that the Government is going to do something. I am very happy to see this newfound confidence of the Opposition in the fact that the Government is going to do something, and I welcome that. I am not confident that it is going to do anything with regard to these matters. I am not confident that it is going to find the additional amount of money that it is going to cost those institutions or put that in its Budget in August for those institutions.

If Senator Watson has that firm, undying, unswerving faith in the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that I must admit is missing from my breast, then let him have that. I would say, `Grab this now and, if the Government comes up with it, we can do something about it then'. The politics of the matter are that one does not trust the Government; one makes sure that these institutions are protected first, and then if the Government comes up with the money, one says `Fine'. What Senator Watson is doing is selling them out now in the hope that we can rely implicitly on the word of the Treasurer-a person I have never heard Senator Watson express a great deal of trust in previously but who is now a new-found friend and buddy-to help these institutions out. It is nice for him; it is not nice for us. We persist with the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — The incorrect assertions from the Australian Democrats demand some comment. In terms of timing charges the cost to the Government in lost revenue might be $50m. The cost to these institutions in respect of the one month is only the financing cost on that $50m, and that is for basically a full year. So it is quite incorrect to say it is going to cost hospitals, et cetera, $50m. It is a timing charge because it is slipped into the current year vis-a-vis the next year, so it is only a financing cost of the $50m. I think that correction deserves to be made. Certainly it is a cost to the Government in terms of the extra revenue it will give, but that is only a transfer cost, a timing difference. Senator Macklin has confused the difference between a timing cost and a financing cost.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No 2) 1990
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Committee to clause 6 which covers exemptions for community service organisations. I believe that there is a need for a definition of a community service and community service organisations. I refer to page 10 of the explanatory memorandum. I believe that it would be preferable for the legislation to stand on its own. Therefore, the definition of community service and/or community service organisations should be included in clause 6 of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) because I think in future years people will refer to that Bill and I do not believe they should have to refer to an explanatory memorandum to get the full interpretation of what a community service organisation is all about. I think the definition in the explanatory memorandum is quite adequate. We do not have an amendment, but I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to consider making an appropriate amendment to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill.

—I will respond briefly to that question. The objective is a shared objective of making the definition as clear as possible. I should say firstly that a lot of time was put in trying to get as specific a definition as possible and to get something comprehensive and precise beyond that which we have proved extremely difficult. While giving an undertaking that I will look at it again, for future reference I have to say my first reaction is that an attempt to be more specific is more likely to narrow than broaden the definition because, in the attempt to be specific, by being inclusive one tends to exclude the things not specifically referred to and it may cause a problem. I am not antagonistic to the thrust of the suggestion and I am happy to give an assurance that we will look at that matter, but I do not want to generate great optimism about the outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move on to clause 7, which proposes to insert new section 26bc, securities lending arrangements. Scrip lending involves, for example, a seller of shares who has not yet received scrip from an earlier purchase on the Stock Exchange borrowing comparable scrip purchases, usually through a major institution to effect the transfer arising from the sale. The borrower of the scrip subsequently returns to the lender the scrip received from the earlier purchase to complete the borrowing transaction.

SPEECH.PARA: Such arrangements have existed on Australian stock exchanges and most overseas stock exchanges for many years and are important in assisting the proper functioning of the Stock Exchange. However, capital gains tax questions have arisen as to whether the lending-borrowing of scrip constitutes sales-purchases of the shares. The legislation before us seeks to overcome these perceived difficulties, but anti-avoidance measures, for example, the prescribing of disqualifying events such as dividends or rights issues occurring during a borrowing period or lending scrip for more than three months, make scrip lending impossible.

In addition, a capital gains tax arises when the loan is returned after the books close for dividend rights entitlements, despite the amendments. Thus, on the advice that has been obtained by the Opposition, it appears that the Government's intention to facilitate the practice of scrip lending is prevented by the previous two mentioned anti-avoidance measures. However, scrip lending from offshore, I remind the chamber, can still occur.

I remind the Committee that shortly after the Budget announcement of the change, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia wrote to the Treasury seeking clarification as to the treatment of the dividend distributions during the period of lending and a Mr G. R. Potts replied as follows:

The relevant legislation is to be framed such that dividends and associated franking credits paid during the term of a scrip lending arrangement that are received indirectly by the lender of the underlying scrip will be treated as though they had been received directly by the lender.

I remind the chamber that it would seem that this undertaking was overlooked in the drafting of the Bill and cuts across effectively the whole practice of scrip lending. I seek an assurance from the Parliamentary Secretary that meaningful discussions between the Stock Exchange and the Treasury will proceed immediately to overcome the impracticalities to enable Australia, once again, to have a proper settlement process.

The intention of the Government was always to have a proper settlement process. It frames its anti-avoidance measures so widely that it has created this impasse. So the amendments do have imperfections; this is widely acknowledged. They also impede the efficacy of scrip lending. Unfortunately, the provisions are having very serious consequences for Australian stock exchanges and the need to receive serious consideration is important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rather than delaying the Committee with a detailed backwards and forwards discussion about whether the problems to which Senator Watson refers are as serious as he outlines, I am happy to respond to his specific request. Certainly there will be prompt consultations. They have already begun and there will be continuing consultations between the Government and the Stock Exchange and other interested parties to ensure that we can assist in the process of introducing improved settlement procedures in the securities industry. Those negotiations will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now refer to clause 11, proposed changes to section 79, which involves proposed subsections 79e (8), (9) and (10). I recommend a reading of page 14 of the provision. Proposed subsection 79e (8) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of any other provision of this section, if, before a year of income, a taxpayer: (a) has become a bankrupt; or (b) not having become a bankrupt, has been released from any debts by the operation of an Act relating to bankruptcy; then no loss incurred by the taxpayer before the day on which the taxpayer became a bankrupt or was so released is an allowable deduction.

Clauses 8 and 9 follow a similar theme. I wish to remind the Committee that these provisions have been drafted almost in an identical way to similar subsections of section 80 of the current Income Tax Assessment Act. I also remind the Committee that these specific provisions of section 80 were actually criticised by Mr Roach of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in case X1090 ATC149. There is a strong view now that there should be further amendments. Again, statute law revision seems to be the appropriate place to recognise the comments that have been made by Mr Roach in relation to section 80 to ensure that those comments now relate to the new provisions that have been drawn in.

We are disappointed that, Mr Roach having made these comments in relation to section 80, the Government did not pick them up when drafting proposed new subsection 79e, (8), (9) and (10). A consequence of Mr Roach's suggestion would be that the amendments would allow a deduction in respect of losses actually incurred and paid prior to the bankruptcy and also in respect of losses that have been paid in the course of the administration of the bankruptcy. In fact, the view that is expressed under proposed new subsection 79e (9) would also allow a deduction for debts paid in the year of the bankruptcy, but subsequent to the bankruptcy, where the debt was incurred prior to the bankruptcy. I believe it is unfortunate that we are now continuing to draft laws contrary to the intention and statements as emanated from, say, Mr Roach of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a long contribution to make in response to Senator Watson's comments. I appreciate the nature of concerns raised by Senator Watson. Only recently the Taxation Institute of Australia wrote to the Government about this matter. The provisions relating to losses in the Bill are identical to those in the draft, which was released in February. We did not get any such comments at that time. It made reaction difficult. It is the first time that these matters have come before us. We will look at them. I cannot give any current indication of what the likely reaction will be, other than to say that the representations are from reputable organisations and they will be examined accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 22, particularly quarrying operations. Again, perhaps through a statute law revision Bill, or a miscellaneous provisions Bill, the Government could look at this. I would like the Government to consider a different approach in the treatment of housing and welfare in relation to quarrying operations. It is the belief that it would have been better to exclude housing and welfare from the Bill, except where the quarry is located in an isolated rural area, rather than having a total exclusion of such housing and welfare expenditure. I believe that because of the difficulties that the Government ran into in relation to its treatment of housing and welfare, the proposed new subsection 122jc is now actually not required as it does not, unlike its equivalent in section 122a, contain any reference to expenditure on plant.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I believe there is an unnecessary complication and inclusion when we refer to proposed new paragraph 122jc (4) because it is unnecessary for subparagraph (b) to refer to plant as expenditure in relation to plant is already excluded by the proposed new paragraph 122jc (2). In any case, it was referred to above all references to expenditure on plant in section 122a (1) and it has not been reproduced in proposed new subsection 122jc. As a consequence, I think the Government has run into some problems in relation to how it differentiated the housing and welfare by trying to make them as comparable as possible with general mining operations. I believe that those are purely tidying up provisions that should be considered at a later date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have a very big statutes law or miscellaneous provisions Bill at this rate. Senator Watson did me the courtesy of raising the matter of quarrying with me prior to the committee stage. I thank him for that. There are significant concerns expressed by the officers advising about each of the proposals raised but it does not exclude consideration of them. The question of housing and welfare in isolated rural areas, as far as we know, does not arise, but there is nothing inherent in the nature of quarrying that makes it impossible-though it makes it unlikely-when we think about the economics of the operation. We can have a look if there are any examples of where there might be a problem caused by that. It is worth considering, though, that comparable circumstances to those arising in mining towns are not likely. Nevertheless, it is worth looking at and if there are circumstances we will consider that.

SPEECH.PARA: We are fairly concerned that the definitions should not be left open. We try to make them as only putting those things which are necessary as a safeguarding provision. But we are never averse to looking at positive suggestions about change. At this stage, we think, with the exception of housing and welfare, none of them need changing. Only if examples could be shown where an adverse consequence would flow would we be prepared to look at housing and welfare. We certainly have no intention of dealing with quarrying and mining differently in that regard. It is simple. On our best information the circumstances do not apply. But we are prepared to have a look at that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to drawn the Committee's attention to clauses 42 to 45. This covers the insertion of a proposed new subsection which covers the insertion of proposed new section 160aqcb. It is a general anti-avoidance measure which will take effect from 1 July 1990. It concerns dividends streaming arrangements which are schemes to provide franked dividends; that is, those with imputation credits to those taxpayers who can use them-for example, taxable Australian residents who perhaps have a higher income. Also it relates to unfranked larger dividends for those who cannot derive benefits from imputation tax credits such as overseas people, charities and people on low incomes, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments, for the most practical purposes, will discourage the practice of companies giving shareholders a choice of accepting a streamed or selected dividend. I have received substantial representations stating that the amendments have unintended consequences of detrimental effect as they relate to arrangements between Australian companies and non-resident parent companies. The Government might like to consider the quarantining of these provisions just to Australian resident companies and allow the streaming operations to continue to extend to a parent company overseas. The Australian provisions that are to be inserted into the Act are very much more stringent, for example, than those operating in New Zealand which has similar provisions but they are far less onerous. In New Zealand, for example, they allow the dividend streaming to operate between New Zealand and Australia.

The provision before us will not even allow reciprocity between Australia and New Zealand. Perhaps an easy amendment could well be the insertion of the word `resident' on line 14 of page 47 of the Bill, between the words `another' and `company'. By that simple technique we would quarantine the anti-avoidance provisions purely to Australian operations and allow the full force of the law in existence prior to these amendments to flow to the parent company overseas. The application of withholding tax tends to minimise the impact of tax-avoiding proposals. The big anti-avoidance losses that are likely to occur and that these amendments seek to overcome occur in relation to deals done within Australia rather than with relationships between Australian companies and overseas parent companies. We believe that the legislation has unintended consequences which will create detrimental effects between Australian resident companies and their non-resident parent companies.

We are also concerned about retrospective application. Good law would demand the application of proposed section 160AQCB(4) to limit the application of this section to dividends arising out of dividends streaming arrangements entered into after 15 August 1989, which would effectively stop them, or shares acquired after 15 August 1989. Accordingly, as existing shareholders who may be perceived to benefit from existing dividend selection arrangements dispose of their shares, the perceived loss to revenue reduces and ultimately disappears. I put two alternatives to the Senate: either quarantine the arrangements just to Australian resident operations or, preferably, eliminate the certainty of retrospective application by limiting the application of proposed new section 160AQCB(4)-that is, the new provision we are inserting into this Bill-to ensure that these arrangements do not apply after 15 August 1989.

I will attempt to explain the detriment that can occur as a result of the provisions before us today, particularly in relation to an Australian company and its overseas parent. There is no significant loss to Australian revenue because the arrangements are not directed at the erosion of Australian revenue collections. The arrangements do not result in any significant erosion of such collections. There is a retrospective effect which we on this side of the Parliament believe is reprehensible because there will be a substantial and continuing detrimental impact on employees, foreign corporations and Australian investors, all of whom have acted and made substantial business decisions in good faith, based on the law and practice at the time. There will also be a detrimental loss to the Australian economy because of a substantial leakage of Australian-sourced profits to foreign jurisdictions. There will be a lower ability to attract Australian finance for the Australian operations of foreign corporations.

Apart from everything else, there will be a reduced capacity to buy back the farm. Ultimately, when our problems have been overcome, surely we should be interested in not putting forward tax laws that are going to inhibit Australian investors from buying back the farm because, effectively, this will dilute the overseas shareholding, particularly if those shares are issued on the Australian stock exchange. This will have quite detrimental effects.

For the purpose of clarification, I seek leave to table a document that supports the comments I have made. I believe that by tabling this comment the Australian Taxation Office, the Government, et cetera, will be able to recognise fully in detail the summary that I have given to the Committee today.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are further difficulties in relation to the dividend streaming arrangements. If our objective is simplification, I believe that the way we have gone about it is not necessarily right. I seek leave of the Committee to incorporate in Hansard a simplification of section 160aqcb.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
In keeping with the objective of simplification, it is suggested that proposed ss.160aqcb (1) and (3) be combined as follows:
``160aqcb (1) where:

(a) on a particular day after 30 June 1990, a company pays an unfranked dividend or a partly franked dividend (which unfranked dividend or partly franked dividend is in this subsection called the `scheme dividend') to a shareholder in the company; and
(b) the scheme dividend was paid under a dividend streaming arrangement:
(i) in relation to the company (in this subsection called the `debit company') or
(ii) in relation to another company (in this subsection called the `debit company'):

there arises on that day a franking debit of the debit company equal to the amount calculated using the following formula, as reduced by the amount (if any) of the franking debit of the company arising under s.160aqb in respect of the payment of the scheme dividend:
Scheme dividend x Substituted franking percentage where:
`Scheme dividend' means the amount of the scheme dividend;

`Substituted franking percentage' means the actual proposed franking percentage, or the greatest actual or proposed franking percentage, of the frank dividend(s) for which the scheme dividends were substituted''.
It is further suggested, again in keeping with the simplification objective, that the following subsection be inserted in lieu of subsections (2) and (4) of proposed s.160aqcb: ``(2) Where:

(a) on a particular day after 30 June 1990, a company (in this subsection called the `debit company') pays one or more franked dividends or issues tax exempt bonus shares (in this subsection called the `scheme dividend' or `scheme bonus shares' respectively) to a shareholder in the debit company; and
(b) the scheme dividends or scheme bonus shares were paid under a dividend streaming arrangement in relation to the debit company;
there arises on that day a franking debit of the debit company equal to:

(c) Where scheme bonus shares were issued, the actual proposed franked amount, or the sum of the actual proposed franked amounts, of the franked dividend(s) for which the scheme dividends were substituted: or
