(d) Where scheme dividends were paid, the actual or proposed amount, or the sum of the actual or proposed amounts, of the unfranked dividend(s) for which the scheme dividends were substituted.''

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that for simplicity and clarity we could well bring together two subsections. The purpose of the incorporation is to assist the Government to seek ways of simplifying income tax legislation. We understand that the Tax Office currently has a number of people examining proposals for a simplification of tax law. We understand that it is going to be a long term project, but we hope that they do not lose sight of the immediate need to simplify the existing law to overcome the complexities and unintended consequences and to make the law more certain, particularly as we move to self-assessment and substantiation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously I cannot comment on the simplification proposals which Senator Watson has just had incorporated. I simply indicate that I will refer that document to the people involved in the simplification process. Although in the other areas that Senator Watson mentioned I have indicated a preparedness to examine the proposals and, if the circumstances are as he outlined them, I express some sympathy for the objectives, when it comes to the dividend streaming matters he raised we do not have much room for compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe that there is any retrospectivity or any unreasonable pressure on arrangements established by Australian corporations. One of the reasons for deferring the commencement of the measure to dividends paid under arrangements after 1 July 1990 was to allow companies time to adjust their arrangements. They have had some 11 months in which to do that. So we are not persuaded by that argument.

Isolating the application of this to resident corporations seems to us to be not much more than an incentive to Australiana companies to move their operations offshore, which is not, I am sure, what Senator Watson intended and not what we wish to achieve or would approve of. We are not therefore persuaded that these sorts of changes ought to be approved at this time, and I do not want to indicate at this stage that we are likely to be moving in that direction. We believe that, on the evidence available to us at the moment, the proposals outlined are those which are most likely to achieve our objectives. As with everything else, we will monitor their operation to ensure that their outcome is that which we anticipate and seek, but at this stage we do not intend to consider amendments of the sort outlined by Senator Watson.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Parliamentary Secretary might not wish to follow the generality of what I put forward, in relation to either quarantining or limiting the retrospective effect of the legislation, perhaps he might at least move in the direction of granting similar reciprocity to that which New Zealand offers us in similar legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be in New Zealand next week. If they twist my arm very hard, I might consider it.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1990
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to clause 15 of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which covers the insertion of new division 16k, ``Effect of Buy-back of Shares''. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate a document by the Australian Institute of Taxation which expresses concern about this provision and seeks to demonstrate that a court may not interpret the provisions as the Government anticipates.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL
Clause 15-Insertion of new Division 16k (``Effect of Buy-back of Shares'') into Part III of the Act

The Institute notes proposed s.159gzzzt which is intended to operate to incorporate proposed ss.159gzzzn and 159gzzzq and 159gzzzs into Part IIIa of the Act. Specifically, the proposed section provides that, for the purposes of the application of Part IIIa to a taxpayer, where the expression ``provision of this Part'' or ``provisions of this Part'' is used in Part IIIa, the expression is taken to include a reference to ss.159gzzzn, 159gzzzq and 159gzzzs.

However, the Institute notes that, although s.160zd (1) of the Act is expressed to be ``subject to this Part'', neither the expression ``provision of this Part'' nor ``provisions of this Part'' is used in s.160zd (1) of the Act. That is, a literal reading of the provision may render it inapplicable to s.160zd (1) of the Act, and, accordingly, both the specific provisions of the buy-back provisions relating to the consideration in respect of the disposal of a share and s.160zd of the Act would prime facie apply to buy-back transactions. In the Institute's view, a Court would be unlikely to construe proposed s.159gzzzt so narrowly, with the consequence that such a Court would be unlikely to hold that s.160zd of the Act has application in respect of a transaction involving the buy-back of shares. However, it is suggested that proposed s.159gzzzt should refer to the term ``this Part'', rather than the expressions ``provision of this Part'' and ``provisions of this Part'', in order to more precisely bring within its scope the words ``subject to this Part'' contained in s.160zd (1) of the Act.
Bill agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 21 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not opposing the Australian Securities Commission Amendment Bill, which we recognise the Government has had to introduce to provide for interim arrangements in the transition of corporate regulatory functions from the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) after 1 July this year. The NCSC will continue to exist until the changeover to the national scheme, whenever that might be, and new members will need to be appointed on or about 1 July. This Bill will enable full time members of the ASC to hold appointments as full time members of the NCSC as well; that is, the new members of the NCSC will be able to carry on as members of the ASC. The Opposition is not opposing this Bill because we recognise that it would be difficult to attract suitably qualified applicants to be members of the NCSC when it is likely to operate for only a few months. Overlapping appointments will avoid this problem and ensure a smooth transition.

SPEECH.PARA: The original intention was that the national scheme would commence operation on 1 July. The cooperative scheme arrangements must stay in place after that date because the Commonwealth and the States are still in the process of negotiating on major aspects of the national scheme, particularly the funding and staffing arrangements. It is now about a year since the package of corporation legislation was passed. The Australian Securities Commission was established on 1 July 1989, although that part of the Act which establishes the watchdog parliamentary committee has not yet been proclaimed. We believe that this is quite extraordinary in view of the emphasis given when the package of legislation was introduced to having the ASC and corporate regulation subject to the scrutiny of one parliament.

The ASC's major problem is, however, that although it has a wide range of powers and functions which relate to the regulation of bodies corporate, it unfortunately has no Act to administer. The Corporations Act was passed a year ago, but has not yet been proclaimed. We now have the interesting situation where we have one commission, the NCSC, which has plenty of legislation to administer, but a rapidly diminishing number of staff to administer it; and another commission, the ASC, which has plenty of staff, but no legislation to administer.

The reason that the Government's Corporations Act has not been proclaimed is that several States launched a constitutional challenge to the legislation in the High Court of Australia. We warned the Government that what it was trying to do in attempting to take over the States' powers in relation to the incorporation of companies was simply not constitutional. The High Court, unfortunately for the Government, was of the same view. Therefore, the judges' decision vindicates what the Opposition had been saying all along-that the Commonwealth corporations power does not extend to making laws about the incorporation of companies. Now the Commonwealth, as the loser, must pay not only its own costs in relation to the High Court challenge but also the States' costs. Added to this is the cost of running two commissions since 1 July last year.

One wonders why the Government embarked on this disastrous plan in the first place. It has been ruinously expensive and a constitutional and administrative nightmare. If the Government's objective was to simplify and facilitate corporate regulation, so far it has achieved exactly the opposite. The real problem with the cooperative scheme was not that the legislation was wrong but that it was not being properly enforced-at least I suggest that that was the principal problem. The regulatory authority that was supposed to enforce it was under-resourced, as we demonstrated on so many occasions in Estimates committees and in this chamber.

It is also important that it is the courts and the proper investigatory bodies which do the enforcing of the legislation. There has recently been a worrying tendency, I suggest, towards prosecution by the media in the area of corporate regulation. The Opposition believes that the guiding principle in corporate regulation ought to be agreement between the Commonwealth and the States on uniform legislation. That is the only way to achieve a legislative scheme which is both uniform and constitutional. The Opposition welcomes the recent moves in this direction.

The Opposition also urges the Government to take account of the dangers inherent in a uniform scheme, particularly the tendency for the administration to become too centralised. It is vital that everybody-not just those who happen to be near head office-has direct access to those who have power to make decisions, a point I have made before in this chamber and a point particularly stressed by practitioners in my State of South Australia. This means that staff in regional offices will have to have real power to make decisions. The Opposition wants the mess which the Government has created of corporate regulation in Australia to be cleared up as quickly as possible, and that is why we support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Hill in this debate on the Australian Securities Commission Amendment Bill. It is clear that it is because of the ham-fisted handling of this matter by the former Attorney-General and the current Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that this transition legislation is essential. As Senator Hill pointed out, it is now necessary for the staff of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to take over the jobs of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). There is no doubt that attempts to recruit staff to continue with the functions and role of the NCSC would be impossible in the current climate. Indeed, the uncertainty that has existed since the original announcement in 1987 about the new national scheme has created an incredible decrease in morale at both the NCSC and the various corporate affairs commissions around Australia. Staff members have a lower morale because, as Senator Hill said, they have no idea when the new legislation will come into effect. The original legislation was enacted over a year ago now and is still a long way from being proclaimed.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to what was said by Mr Ray Schoer, formerly of the NCSC and now of the Australian Stock Exchange, about staff problems within the NCSC. On 22 October 1989, on the Business Sunday program, Michael Gill interviewed him and asked him:
Given the sorts of doubts that exist obviously, is there any doubt that the NCSC will be effective, in the meantime?
Mr Schoer replied:
They have some very good staff, very dedicated staff. Certainly it's true that unless job offers are made to them soon, then a lot of those staff are going to leave.
The interviewer then asked:
When you say. `very quickly', how long can it drift like this?
Mr Schoer replied:
Another couple of weeks in my judgement.

The Senate should understand that that interview occurred on 22 October. On 6 May, the head of the NCSC, Mr Bosch, appeared on the Business Sunday program, again discussing the matter of the ASC approaching the NCSC staff. He said:

I think it is extraordinary, indeed incredible, that the staff of the NCSC are being asked to work in very difficult circumstances within two months of the announced termination of the organisation with no offers being made to them, no assurances being given to them about the continuity of employment. It is something I would not really have believed possible.

On 22 October Mr Schoer claimed that it was necessary to act on this matter within a couple of weeks. Some eight or nine months later, in May, no action has been taken. Therefore, there is not doubt in my mind as to why morale in the corporate affairs commissions (CACs) and within the NSCS is quite low.

Again, since the initial announcement of the scheme and the uncertainty, particularly during the last 12 months, the cooperative scheme has continually been criticised, particularly by the Attorneys-General. I wish to quote from a letter from Mr Chris Sumner, the Attorney-General in South Australia, to the Federal Attorney-General, Mr Duffy. In the letter, dated 24 April, he said:
. . . criticisms of the Cooperation Scheme have been exaggerated to attempt to achieve the aim of a national takeover irrespective of constitutional uncertainties.

This sort of thing has been going on. The Attorney-General and the proponents of the national takeover of the companies and securities legislation blame a number of problems on the cooperative scheme. If there were problems, it is important to ask what the Commonwealth has done in the last 10 years to resolve them. It has not proposed any amendments in the past 10 years. In the past three years any of the amendments proposed by the States have been opposed by the Commonwealth-unless, of course, the States agreed to this national scheme. In other words, the Commonwealth used the proposed amendments from the States as bargaining chips in trying to get the States to agree to the national scheme.

The Attorney-General would also have us believe that corporate collapses can be visited upon the failures of the cooperative scheme. These collapses have been an unfortunate part of Australian corporate life since the October 1987 share crash. The Attorney-General would have us believe that the crashes of the Hooker Corporation, Qintex, Girvan, Spedley Securities and Rothwells can all be blamed on the cooperative scheme. I do not think that anyone out there in the real commercial world would even consider that the national companies and securities legislation and the cooperative scheme, as it has existed for the last 10 or so years, could be blamed for these collapses.

On the Business Sunday program on 6 May, Mr Duffy referred to $8 billion to $10 billion in corporate losses which will probably occur in Australia over the next year or so. Again he would have us believe that these corporate losses are the direct result of some failure of the cooperative scheme. I would remind the Senate again that although the Commonwealth is blaming this cooperative scheme for all these misadventures in Australian corporate life, the Government has done nothing to try to fix it during the seven years that it has been within its control.

The other problem the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, would have us believe is that the cooperative scheme has caused a lack of new foreign equity capital coming into Australia. Again I suggest that this is an absolute furphy. I suggest that the reason there may be a lack of foreign equity capital coming into productive Australian enterprises has more to do with this Commonwealth Government's other policies. If we want to attract foreign capital to Australia, we should start looking at the regulation regime, the industrial relations system and the environment, fiscal and monetary policies. Obviously there have been failures in all these areas under the present Government.

We must ask, then, what the Commonwealth Government's agenda is in relation to the corporations and securities regulation system in Australia. Is it really about trying to fix up the system and create a better environment? I do not think so. I think that this Government is really about getting more power for the Attorney-General, his Government and his Department. Of course, all of that is at the expense of the States.

Some of the problems which have been identified quite properly with the cooperative scheme-and these were referred to earlier by Senator Hill-are the funding and resourcing. I suggest to the Senate that this can be solved by upgrading and maintaining the current cooperative scheme. But is is a problem that we have to face and it is not one that will go away. I am not saying `She'll be right'; it must be fixed up, but it will not be fixed up by centralising everything in Canberra. If that were to happen, Sydney and Melbourne would be looked after while Perth, Brisbane and Hobart would be left to wither on the vine. Of course, the business people and those who have to run the branch offices will not have a lot of pressure or persuasive power to try to alter that funding situation. They will be so far away that they will not have any political clout to try to increase funding.

I think it is important to look at what Mr Bosch said about the resourcing of the National Companies and Securities Commission. Here we have this organisation trying to keep a tab on all the corporate players and at the same time become a reliable watchdog. In an article in the Age on 9 May Mr Bosch refers to this resourcing of the NCSC in an address to the Institute of Chartered Accountants. He said that the best news of all was that under the new scheme there was reasonable hope that adequate resources would be applied to the area of companies and securities regulations. He went on to say:

It seems to me quite extraordinary that at the present time the national body responsible for policy and administration in the entire area of companies securities law should have a budget equivalent to the subsidy of school buses in the ACT.

Obviously that is quite an abysmal set of circumstances. I guess if I were trying to ruin the cooperative scheme and create a new national scheme, I would start bleeding the cooperative scheme and the NCSC.

The other problems which needs to be addressed is accountability and responsibility. People who are against the cooperative scheme have claimed that there is no accountability and that the whole scheme is not accountable to any one Minister or any one parliament. I suggest that under any new scheme or an upgraded cooperative scheme there are a number of reforms that could be introduced to ensure that the ASC, as it will be once this Bill is passed and has been proclaimed, is accountable through the ministerial council to the Attorney- General. There is no doubt that that sort of accountability could be upgraded. There have always been doubts about this Parliament's ability to debate or discuss amendments to legislation proposed by the ministerial council. With a clear indication from this Parliament in new legislation, this accountability could be upgraded. Of course, the CACs are responsible to their State parliaments and this responsibility should stay where it is.

The other problem that is associated with the current proposed national scheme is that of the independence of the corporate watchdog. Again in that article in the Age on 9 May, Mr Bosch told the group from the Institute of Chartered Accountants that there would be a very great increase in the power of Canberra public servants and this could be bad news. He went on to say:

I think that the independence of the new commission is something that will have to be watched with considerable care because the system that has been set up will, in fact, pass policy control entirely to Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be a lot better than the State public servants who handle it!

—Senator Schacht's interjection about the role of the corporate affairs commission's in the States may have some relevance in some of the States, but I can assure him that in Western Australia the CAC is held in high regard by the business community, and it provides an excellent level of service. It is a level of service that the business people of Western Australia do not want to see diminished by passing responsibility across here to Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to look at what has happened since the High Court ruling, in a 6 to one majority, that the Federal Government did not have the power over the incorporations section of the ASC legislation. Since then the Attorney-General has blamed the States for creating all of this uncertainty. As we have restated a number of times today, this Bill has now passed through the Parliament and has been waiting for proclamation for 12 months. The Attorney-General has gone out and said, `What we will do is go ahead and proclaim this legislation and just leave the incorporation bits out, try to blunder through, roll over the powers of the States and just push on with it and see how we get on'. There have been various forms of negotiations since then, and the holding out of various sorts carrots. He has got the Victorians and the New South Welshmen to agree on some sort of compromise.

I assure honourable senators that the business people in Western Australia, and the Liberal Party in Western Australia, do not see the Victoria-New South Wales compromise as any sort of compromise. It is just a sell out and an easy way to hand power straight to Canberra. It is something that the Liberal Party in Western Australia will not be part of.

Victoria's part of the deal was to get the Deputy Chairman of the ASC based in Melbourne and the Chairman of the Corporation and Securities Panel based in Melbourne. Of course, the other big carrot that Victoria had handed to it was the LaTrobe Valley database. Victoria got what it wanted and said, `Okay, you can have it all up there'. New South Wales got the Chairman and the headquarters of the ASC based in Sydney. New South Wales is also trying to get the funding that it requires. The debate that is going on at the moment is about the funding level and how much the Commonwealth is going to have to use to buy off the States. As I said in my maiden speech, I implore all of the business people around Australia to ensure that their State governments cannot be bought off.

Who is supporting this scheme? Who is supporting the Attorney-General? He claims to have business people begging him to get this national scheme up and running. Of course, it is the Business Council of Australia. It is the top end of town. It is big business. It is the businesses that represent roughly 2 per cent of the 800,000 public companies in Australia. Those big companies do not mind because it is not much for executives from a BHP, or a company such as that, to jump on a plane and go to Melbourne. But persons in a small business in Western Australia, Hobart or Brisbane will have to pay quite a few thousand dollars to get to Canberra to lobby for a cause if they are not enamoured of or feel aggrieved by part of this legislation.

Who on the other side of this country is opposing this legislation? In Western Australia the following groups are vehemently opposed to the centralisation of power in Canberra: the Law Society of Western Australia, the Confederation of Western Australian Industry, the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Chamber of Mines, the Stock Exchange Members of Perth, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Institute of Directors, the Trustee Companies Association of Australia in Western Australia and, finally, the International Association of Finance Planning. That is a fairly significant and representative group of Western Australian business people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at all the shareholders who lost their money with crook companies in Western Australia. What do they think?

—Who from Senator Schacht's State is supporting the State Attorney-General Chris Sumner's stance on this issue? In a letter that he wrote to Mr Duffy on 24 April Mr Sumner claimed the support of the Law Society of South Australia, the South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Australian Society of Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the South Australian members of the Australian Stock Exchange. Perhaps Senator Schacht would like to make comments about the bona fides of those organisations.
—I will certainly make some comments about the South Australian Government's position when I speak shortly.

—I look forward to that. Some of the other issues that I wanted to address relate to the duplication and expense which are inherent in this national scheme. The national scheme would be propagated by the Attorney-General so that it does away with duplication and expense. One only needs to look at the establishment of the Information Processing Centre (IPC) to see the costs that we are already meeting this year and will be meeting next year, in what Senator Hill has already referred to as a duplication-that of having an ASC and a National Companies and Securities Commission. The South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission has done a study into the establishment of this national database, and the incredible level of duplication and additional expense I do not think has been publicly revealed. The facility to establish this national database will almost entirely duplicate existing facilities within the corporate affairs commissions in the State.
—They have not got them.

—I will refer to that later. The lease costs in the first year will be between $1.4 and $2m per annum. Furniture and standard office equipment, not relating to computer equipment, will be about $2.2m. Microfilm maintenance in the year 1990-91 will be $1m. The cost of entry of data of the 800,000 registration forms for the companies, and these are all ASC figures, will be $2m. The other costs, which we should be aware of, are the telephone and fax links to the central national data base, which will all be at local call rates and will involve a significant subsidy from Telecom. The national data scheme proposes imaging of documents which will cost $1m in 1989-90 and $4.45m in 1991. The electronic data interchange (EDI) and EFT development of hardware have a budget of $1.5m per annum. It is proposed that this new EDI system will, in full operation, totally obviate the need for imaging. In other words, $5m could be saved if they just went slowly and moved towards the system which the CAC is developing. Telecom line costs will be another $2.2m. The South Australian Consumer Affairs Corporation concluded that the IPC microfilm storage, and associated systems plans, fail to recognise that more than 95 per cent of business handled by the CACs is local. Public companies comprise only 2 per cent of Australia's 800,000 companies. Excluding wages and computer equipment, small business people and business people will be paying $13.55m for something that they have already.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, I would like to move on to the impact on businesses of all sizes in Western Australia. The important thing is that local businesses will feel that they are a long way from the corporate regulatory action. As I have said, it will be okay for big business people because they can fly here relatively easily and can lobby people in the Attorney-General's Department and the Government.

There will no doubt be long delays in registrations, and other services currently provided by the corporate affairs commissions in the States, due to the physical removal of lodgment documents to the LaTrobe Valley. Businesses will be faced with very little control, or political accountability, over the fees and duties which they will have to pay to Canberra instead of the State governments. The State governments and the business communities will lose control in developing and innovating small business at a State level. This will mean a lack of progress in this area because there will not be six or seven State governments moving forward to try to have a better environment for small business. The Commonwealth Government will control that sort of policy.

The other problem for a State such as Western Australia, because the corporate affairs powers has moved to Canberra, is that practitioners, lawyers, accountants and other tertiary sector employees will have to move from Western Australia and to Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra where the corporate affairs action will be taking place.

The other problem is that the handing over of this power will see some subsidiary powers moving to the Federal Government and its control over a number of non-commercial social policies. I note, for example, that the Federal Government would have control over board compositions, more control over industrial policy, consumer laws and privacy laws.

I believe that how we should move in negotiations now is not towards trying to buy off the States with big handouts of taxpayers' money. What we should be doing is moving towards upgrading the cooperative scheme and facing the problems which I have delineated, that is, accountability and funding. This can be achieved by having agreed minimum levels of funding for the ASC and the State CACs. It would not take much of an advance in funding over what Mr Bosch described as the subsidy to the Australian Capital Territory buses to create a slightly more powerful and active national corporate watchdog.

The CACs are already moving towards a national networking. This could proceed. There can be a national database but it does not need a national scheme to create it. We can have the independent CACs under the coordination of the Australian Securities Commission creating a national computer network which will create a far more effective and far more reactive information system across Australia.

The corporate affairs commissions must remain responsible to, and funded by, the States. Therefore, political accountability rests with the State governments. The Australian Securities Commission must become responsible through the ministerial council to the Attorney-General, as it is now, but this level of accountability can be upgraded with a number of small reforms within the existing cooperative scheme. The Federal Parliament must have the clear right to debate legislation approved by the ministerial council and to refer legislation back to the council.

In Western Australia the Liberal Party and the business community are totally opposed to the centralisation proposed under the national scheme. At the meeting held between shadow Attorneys-General, Attorneys-General and our shadow Attorney-General in Melbourne on Monday it became apparent that a number of State Liberal parties and upper Houses will be opposed to the national scheme. It is incumbent upon the Attorney-General to take into account the quite significant opposition to this national scheme in future negotiations. I hope that, as Senator Hill said earlier, the negotiations can proceed in a more open, more honest and more accountable way than they have in the past and that the very real problems which the business communities in a number of the outlying States are finding with this proposed national scheme can be taken into account and resolved as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear Senator Hill's remarks on behalf of the Opposition but I presumed that the Opposition is supporting the Australian Securities Commission Amendment Bill. If one were going on the remarks of Senator Campbell from Western Australia, one would suspect that the Opposition was vehemently opposed to this Bill and the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). I will come back to Senator Campbell's remarks shortly. It is extraordinary for a member of the national Parliament to make the remarks that he did. I think he is in the wrong House. At the very worst he should be in the upper House of Western Australia.
—Don't wish that on anyone.

—I know, but I wish it on Senator Campbell because it appears that the Western Australian upper House's eighteenth century views and his eighteenth century views are as one. He has not caught up with the fact that there is a Federation in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak in support of this Bill. I also want to use this opportunity to speak in support of the establishment of a strong Australian Securities Commission. It is extraordinary that there has to be any debate at all in this country today about the establishment of a strong ASC. I refer honourable senators-particularly Senator Campbell-to a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs tabled in April 1987 called The Role of Parliament in Relation to the National Companies Scheme. In its conclusion it makes it quite clear what that Committee's view was about the establishment of a more up to date and stronger securities commission in Australia.

I point out to Senator Campbell, in particular, that that Committee not only had Labor members on it-Senator Bolkus was chairperson-but when this report was tabled Senator Robert Hill was a member of it, the Deputy Chairman; Senator Richard Alston from Victoria was a member of it, both Liberal members; Senator Barney Cooney from Victoria was a member of it; Senator Christopher Puplick from New South Wales, another Liberal, was a member of it; Senator Margaret Reynolds was a member of it and, for part of the reference, Senator Tate was a member of the Committee before he went on to bigger and better things as a Minister.

When I heard Senator Campbell speak I thought I had better just check in case there was a minority report from the Opposition members at the back of the document saying that they disagreed. But no, there is no minority report. It is a unanimous report by the Labor and Liberal members on that Committee. They were the only members of the Committee. I want to quote a couple of paragraphs from the conclusion, particularly for Senator Campbell's information. Paragraph 6.2 states:
The Committee received evidence that, under the circumstances, the scheme performs remarkably well.
That is, the present scheme. It goes on:

However, the Committee believes that it has now outlived its usefulness. The Chairman of the Ministerial Council and Attorney-General of New South Wales described the scheme as a `hybrid institution' which `imposes severe limitations on developing necessary policies' . . .
Paragraph 6.4 states:
Many people and organisations regard the Commonwealth takeover of this area of the law as the next step in a natural progression . . .
It is pretty clear what the Committee believed should be happening. As I say, there was no dissent from Opposition members. Paragraph 6.6 states:

The Committee has taken into account the support for the retention of the cooperative scheme. Much of this support was accompanied by constructive criticism and suggestions for reforms, which were discussed in chapter 4. The Committee commends these suggestions to the various governments which are party to the scheme in the event of the rejection of the Committee's recommendation.
I suspect it anticipated that there were a few people like Senator Campbell around who would reject any progressive move. Finally, the recommendation of paragraph 6.7 states:
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Parliament should enact comprehensive legislation covering the field currently regulated by the cooperative scheme.

Simple, succinct and to the point. That was a unanimous report by Labor and Liberal party members. If it was good enough for April 1987, Senator Campbell and others cannot complain when the Federal Government proceeds on the basis of bipartisan support from a standing committee of the Senate to introduce the scheme. Senator Campbell has not been here that long and he will have a chance to read the report, but it is very clear what, after detailed examination, an all-party committee of the Senate wanted unanimously.

Senator Campbell mentioned business support. He talked of the Business Council of Australia being the only group of business organisations roughly supporting the Commonwealth's position. He is right in that. A press release of 28 March 1990 put out by Nobby Clark, the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank and Clive Speed, the Assistant Director of the Business Council of Australia, says in part:

In the absence of support by the States for the second option the Commonwealth should proceed as quickly as possible with its plans to establish the ASC with such amendments as are necessary to the Corporations Act 1989.

Senator Campbell may say that they represent only 2 per cent of businesses in Australia, but most people would recognise that although they may be the top end of town they are certainly the biggest companies in Australia, the ones that have the most decisive influence on business activity, the ones that are listened to most. Certainly I have heard plenty of members of the Opposition in many other debates in this place quoting from the Business Council when it suits their purpose. But in this case Senator Campbell just dumps the Business Council's support in the bin because it does not suit his purpose at this time.

Why do the major businesses of Australia want to support the Commonwealth's wish to have a strengthened ASC? It is because they know that unless we get a comprehensive national scheme we will still be treated as the cowboy country of the Western world as far as the regulation of companies and securities is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't hurt the United States of America.

—If Senator Campbell wants to align himself with eighteenth and nineteenth century colonialist views from the days when it took three to four weeks to travel from Perth to Sydney and vice versa that is fine, but that is not the modern Australia. That is not the modern international economy.
—What about modern America?

—Nothing in America equates with what Senator Campbell proposes. I only wish that we had the American system in this country. The Americans have gone far beyond anything that Senator Campbell is supporting. No upper House, even in the legislature of Louisiana, proposes what Senator Campbell proposes. They accept the fact that if we are to have a modern economy with decent regulation, we have to have a national scheme with national authorship and national responsibility. We do not rely on the upper House of Western Australia, of all places, to decide what the national aspirations of this country will be. It is an absurd, bizarre joke.

SPEECH.PARA: To my mind this is amazing. I was astonished to hear Senator Campbell, in his maiden speech, setting out his view about a commitment to federalism. He said:
Our commitment to federalism must be based on this principle and not on reactionary States rights dogma.

Senator Campbell has expressed in this debate one of the most bizarre nineteenth century States rights dogmas ever heard. He has aligned himself with the most antediluvian conservative and reactionary forces in Western Australia. Ask the company shareholders of Western Australia who have been taken down over the years by the cowboy entrepreneurs whether they want a system where they get protection or Senator Campbell's system of weak State responsibility and weak State regulation.

We want to overcome all of that to make sure that ordinary people in this country have the confidence to invest in the stock exchange without their money disappearing down black holes. That is what is happening and that is ruining our reputation around the world. That is why the Business Council of Australia, as it says in its press release, wanted this new system adopted. It is saying that it finds it difficult to borrow money overseas for investment in Australia because, quite rightly, someone sitting in New York or anywhere else says, `Invest in Australia with your system of regulation? How do we know we'll get our money back? How do we know it won't be spent in devices to enable company directors to enhance their position at the expense of shareholders?'. We have seen case after case of that occurring in the last three years. We need a strong Australian Securities Commission; not the view expressed by you, which is, `Leave it with the States'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht, would you please address your remarks through the Chair.

—Sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. With such provocative remarks being made earlier in this debate it is hard to contain oneself. But I certainly respect your comment. Senator Campbell said, `What about South Australia? What about the Attorney-General of South Australia?'. I have already made my view known to the Premier and the Attorney-General of South Australia. I think it is a disgrace that a State Labor Government went to the High Court of Australia to challenge this legislation, and that the Labor Government in my home State was in league, at one stage, with the New South Wales conservative government in trying to thwart the establishment of an Australian Securities Commission. I have pointed out to both the Premier and the Attorney-General of South Australia that they are in contravention of the national platform and the State platform adopted years ago by the Labor Party to establish the ASC. I have given fair warning to them both that at the next State Labor Party conference, at the end of June, in one month's time, there will be a debate in the South Australian Labor Party about whether we will have a national scheme with a national aspiration or whether we will have a States rights nineteenth century horse and buggy approach to company securities regulation. It will be a very important debate in the South Australian Labor Party, which I represent in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that I win the debate but even if I do not and if my view does not prevail I will not let up. In the end, if this country is to have any future in the area of developing a modern, competitive economy, it can be done only if the national will, expressed through this Parliament, prevails. There is no future for this country-economically, diplomatically or in any other way in our relations with the countries within our region-if we consistently say, `We don't worry about the national view; we worry about the individual, parochial State view', because three local Western Australian businessmen got hold of a junior senator from Western Australia and said, `This is terrible. This is centralism. This is evil'. No other Western country has ever taken that view about a similar matter; only in Australia do we have this view.

We hear bleatings from the Opposition-and it was mentioned in Senator Campbell's maiden speech-about the need for micro-economic reform. There is no more important micro-economic reform Bill on the agenda than this Bill. We will not get a decent, modern competitive economy unless we put regulation into the national sphere. We will go on crippling the economy; we will go on making people queasy about investing in Australia if we do not have a national securities commission. I am amazed that even to this day some people in this national Parliament are willing to express a view similar to that of Senator Campbell.

I hope that before this year is out we can get an agreement with the States. But it should not be an agreement on the basis of surrender. That would be the worst possible decision that the Federal Government could take. If it surrendered to get some unanimity, which would be the lowest possible common denominator, it would mean that the States would still run the show. We would have to get agreement with six State Attorneys-General and two Territory Attorneys-General.

I cannot think of a more bizarre approach to trying to get a national view than going to a ministerial council where only one person-only one under the States rights approach of Senator Campbell-would have the power to veto activity of the ASC. Does any businessman in Australia run his national business on the basis of one State manager being able to veto the decisions of the overall company? Of course not. We do not want that for the ASC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Wool Commission.
—It made a bad mistake and it will pay the penalty. We will have that debate later on tonight or tomorrow and I will express my views on that matter there and then.

SPEECH.PARA: Although this Bill is in one sense only a minor Bill for the process of establishing the Australian Securities Commission, it has to be supported because it is part of that process. Even if, in the end, the States do not agree to a reasonable package from the Federal Government on the establishment of an efficient ASC, then so be it. I advise the Federal Government not to give in. I would rather take my chances in the High Court on the rest of the provisions of the Bill and win it there than go off and give in and surrender to nineteenth century colonial views that are absolutely antipathetic to the interests of a modern Australia. It is about time that some people in this country thought about the twenty-first century and not the eighteenth century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak with any great fervour on the Australian Securities Commission Amendment Bill but I am provoked by earlier contributions, particularly that of Senator Campbell. I totally disagree with Senator Schacht's condemnation of the people in the 1800s. I am glad that we had far-sighted people in the 1890s who managed to get federation. I am sure that had we left it to the 1990s we would not have a hope if Senator Campbell had anything to do with it. I am so glad that those far-sighted people managed to get a nation in this continent. In getting a nation-though many people do not seem to have read the Constitution-they gave the corporations power to the Commonwealth. There is a very good reason for that. At the time the people saw where commerce was going. They knew that it would be central and crucial to the economic health of this country that we should have a single voice.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been a number of reports. Senator Schacht referred to one, which was a very early report. I recommend that Senator Campbell also read the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, which took exhaustive evidence with regard to this matter. I think he will find a lot of new information there because obviously in his speech he was riding on information which was so out of date and so wrong as to be embarrassing. One of the most embarrassing items was his whole discussion of funding. There has been a very good reason why the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) has not worked. It is because of funding-because it has been bled white by the States, which had the control of the funding. We needed to move the NCSC because we have not had that. Every company in this country knows that it has been bled white by the States.

The debate we are having at the moment is nothing to do with principle, State rights or the NCSC wanting to be in Perth or anywhere else; it is to do with the dollar. When one looks at the State budgets one sees how much money is coming from this. It is bled straight out of the companies. But they are not getting the service back; they never have had the service back, because that has been used as a milch cow and the States have taken every penny and run off with it.

Let us look at the Government of Senator Campbell's State. It has done the same whatever political persuasion has been in power-as has South Australia, my own State of Queensland, New South Wales and every other State. It is nothing to do with all this hand-on-the-heart `We have got to be in Perth' business; it is to do with the dollar.

The dollar must get back into the regulation. That is where the debate is at the moment and that is where it is stymied. It is not on any of the other matters. They were easily solved at the end of the day. If people just sit around a table and talk they can agree on those matters. After all, we have modern communication. Senator Campbell was even decrying the amount of money we were spending on telephones. I think it is a reasonable investment in today's world. I was forced to interject `Bring back Edison'. Senator Campbell would have been one who said `Let us stay in there with gas' when Edison invented electricity.

The reason for the national data centre is that the States did not do that, and every company that knows how this place operates wants it done. Senator Campbell was talking about the physical lodgment of incorporation material and carting it off to the LaTrobe Valley. The whole mechanism with regard to the data centre means that no piece of paper has to move anywhere. That is the beauty of the exercise. That is why we are having that exercise put in place and that is why we need it. In this country now we need an exercise which will enable any company to incorporate in Queensland or anywhere else. If that is going to stay, it is going to stay. With regard to that, fairly obviously the High Court has made a determination that allows the States to stay in that particular area. But it still wants to cover the situation where a company's investors are in Western Australia and it is incorporated in Queensland, or vice versa. We saw a magnificent account of the collapse in Senator Campbell's State of a company that in fact was incorporated in my State and had grown out of a clothing store. The exercise obviously means we have to move around. The State boundaries are no longer relevant with regard to business in Australia and they cannot be allowed to get in the way of a developed system of regulation for companies.

Senator Campbell said that it was a top of town exercise. If he had been on the joint committee exercise he would have known differently. The people who came before us represented the majority of business activity in this country. Whether he likes it or not, they happen to be, firstly, the Business Council of Australia, whose members conduct the majority of business activity, and, secondly, the group that represents the majority of actual companies, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, which came before us and supported the proposals. The small business associations wanted them. So both the majority of business and the majority of companies came before that Committee and gave evidence that they wanted this to pass. That has not been recognised in Senator Campbell's speech but that is what actually happened. It is in the evidence. It is in the Hansard transcript.

The exercise has been thought through; the debate has occurred. What we have to do now is get this in place, because Australia has to have a future in trade and business. It is absurdly difficult for a company anywhere else in the world to try to find out what is happening in Australia. What Senator Campbell was suggesting, if it came to pass, would leave our situation worse than the post-1992 European context. Only 50 years ago the countries there were fighting a war to the death, and they have been able to cooperate better than the States of a federation have in this continent.

I think that is an indictment of us in not being able to put aside our parochial feelings, say what is in the interests of the entire country and try to go down that path. Brisbane has the same problems other places have but the structure has been dealt with. The regional offices would be able to provide all of the exercise that is currently provided. Senator Campbell talks about people having to go somewhere and lobby somebody. I suppose if someone wants to nip around the back and lobby a State Minister with regard to something it will be more difficult. But we are taking this out of the control of State governments and giving it to the Commonwealth Government. The ministerial council which ran this thing was constituted from executives. The parliaments never got involved.

Senator Campbell never sat in this place when time and time again we had Bills coming through. We had the power to amend that; we had the constitutional power to amend everything that came into this chamber. We could not. We could not even take notice of our own Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The reason for that is that, if we finally got all of the States and the Commonwealth in this continent to agree on something, the last thing we would want to do is say no. It happens so rarely we almost fall over ourselves being glad they have actually agreed on something.

That is what happened. Time and again it came into this place. Read the Hansard debates. People from Senator Campbell's Party-not only from the Australian Labor Party or my Party, the Australian Democrats-time and time again stood up and said, `This cannot go on'. That is why Senator Campbell has got the report that Senator Hill, now Leader of the Opposition in this chamber, signed. That is why he has the report that his leader for business in this chamber signed. It was because we had the frustration of not being able to amend the types of things which obviously ought to be amended.

In terms of the operation we had incontrovertible evidence before us that the items that had been put before that ministerial council for reform were still sitting on its table. That was not anything to do with the Commonwealth; it was the fact that all of the groups would not agree. The Commonwealth did not even have the chair most of the time. At least the States have acknowledged it ought to have the permanent chair if the national companies and securities system continued. In fact, that was one of their compromise proposals.

So the Commonwealth government, whether the Fraser Government or the Hawke Government, cannot be blamed for those matters. The system is outmoded; it does not work any longer. I think it is now time that we put aside the outmoded concepts, look to the future and know that we have to have in place a streamlined, effective operational method of dealing with these matters. There is now an agreement in regard to the compromises that all of the States have agreed to on policy items at least, and that is welcome.

The hurdle we have to jump over is the money split-up. At the end of the day I think the Commonwealth will have to give way. It hurts me to say that, but it will. We can use the phrase `buying them off'. I would agree with that. That is what will happen-the inevitable Federal compromise. But I can tell honourable senators who will suffer. The States will get their pound of flesh and bolster up their own budgets but that money will not go into corporation regulation at all. We will still have inordinate delays in incorporation even if they are under the State governments which have all this money because those governments will not put another penny into the scheme but will use the money for subsidising their school bus runs. That is where the money will go. It will come out the pockets of business straight into the State coffers. There will not be any advance. I wish there were some other future for a lot of that money so that we could in fact do the types of things that Mr Bosch pointed to, not just in the article I mentioned but time and time again, when he asked for resources and was denied. We will have the Australian Securities Commission asking for resources and being denied them.

I think that is a pity because that money is paid by companies for their regulation. That is why they are paying those fees-not for somebody to go off and subsidise a bus exercise. But that is where it has always been spent. That is an unfortunate exercise, but I suppose that Federation being what it is that is where the compromise will end up. The Commonwealth will give way; we will come to some kind of guaranteed formula; the money will be passed over; and this system will be put into place. I hope it does not give way too easily. I hope it kicks and fights for every penny it can get, because every penny will be needed to make sure that the system works and works well. Money is paid by business not as a subsidy to Consolidated Revenue, but for the regulation of corporation legislation in this country. If business cannot get a good service, it has every right to complain. It has not been getting a good service; it has been getting it from a shoddy slipshod exercise that has been starved of funds.

We all know of the inordinate delays and the difficulty the NCSC has in taking legal action; it is not broadcast anywhere, but we know. We know that it has to ascertain whether it can go in and take a company to the cleaners. It has to add up its pennies, and sometimes it has to say that it cannot do it because it does not have enough money to do it. It has to say that it cannot face a whole barrage of Queen's Counsel again because it has run out of dollars. We cannot even enforce the law. Not that business has not paid for that because for every shoddy company that operates in this country other companies suffer. Those companies are happy for shoddy companies to be taken to the cleaners because it helps the properly regulated companies in their businesses. They do not want shoddy companies hanging around the business establishment. They want them out; they want them prosecuted. They want those crooks who are wandering around in business to be fined, to be out of business entirely. But we cannot afford to get them out. It is not because business has not paid up; it has paid up every year.

What has happened is that that money has been used for every other purpose other than the regulation of the corporations legislation as it was under the NCSC exercise. Unfortunately, I think that is the exercise that will go on in the future when the Commonwealth finally rolls over and agrees to the inordinate State demands. It is a pity, because I believe that the Joint Select Committee had a fair and reasonable look at the legislation; we went through every clause and invited submissions on every clause; and the vast bulk of the legislation stood up. There was one dissenting report with regard to the substance, not the principle. I am glad actually to have been on the side of the minority which ended up as the majority in the legislation on that particular one, because we had the right view. We were not in the majority at that stage, but we managed to convince the right people at the end of the day.

I inform Senator Campbell, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Joint Select Committee was made up of members of both Houses, members of all political parties. In terms of the substance, we have good legislation here to run with. We have a number of innovations. The close corporation exercise, for example, is an interesting innovation. I do not know whether it will work, but small businesses want it. It has not got a very good history around the world, but it is there. There is a lot of good stuff there and I hope it is given the chance to work. This transitional exercise is an important one, but I hope that it is not, as it were, the first of a further delay in what this country needs, and that is to get a truly national companies and securities scheme in place and operational.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with what Senator Schacht and Senator Macklin have said. May I say in respect of Senator Macklin that it is sad to think that his voice will soon not be heard in this chamber. I think he has contributed mightily to this Parliament and it is sad to see him go.

SPEECH.PARA: This Australian Securities Commission Amendment Bill, as has been said, is a short Bill. I suppose the real intent of it is to make sure that after 1 July there is a common chairperson for both the National Companies and Securities Commission and for the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). The purpose of that is so the proper regulation of companies will continue to take place.

Senator Campbell has come in for a fair bit of criticism from the previous two speakers. It seems to me that all he was doing was putting his position, which I think is a respectable position; it is the position of somebody who believes passionately in States rights and that they should have the ascendancy over a centralised system of government. He simply put his philosophy into operation and I thought he did it very well.

What should perhaps be more commented upon is the position of his colleague Mr Peter Costello, the shadow Minister for corporate regulation and consumer affairs, who apparently also wants a national scheme interdicted, if one can gather that from the reports in the Australian Financial Review and the Australian newspaper of 29 May. Mr Peter Costello acted as a convener for Liberal and National Ministers and shadow Ministers in Melbourne on Monday 28 May. He then apparently gave a press conference. He said that the meeting expressed great concern about the scheme that was being established and he called upon Mr Duffy, the Attorney-General, to deal with the representatives of the upper Houses of various States that opposed it. They were specifically Western Australia-Senator Campbell has pointed out its position-Victoria and South Australia.

Certainly an argument can be made for a proper servicing of smaller companies in States and I can understand a legitimate concern on their part that a national scheme will overlook them. That fear has been put to rest by what has been said about the proposed agreement that is sought between the States. That is the first thing: their concerns will be dealt with.

Secondly, I raise the point that has been made several times in this debate already: we need a national scheme if we are going to take part in an international economy. Mr Costello has been foremost in proclaiming the need for micro-economic reform, for the reform of unions-his great case was the Dollar Sweets case; he proclaimed the Mudginberri case, and so on. If there is one area in which politicians-as distinct from employers or employees, people who run manufacturing businesses, farming businesses and so on-can be most effectively engaged in micro-economic reform, it is in this area of company regulations. It is up to the politicians to prepare the proper legislation for micro-economic reform in company regulation so that companies can engage properly and sensibly in the international community. It is in this area that politicians can play an effective role.

I am simply saying that it is peculiarly within the power of politicians to carry out that micro-economic reform that they so loudly proclaim should be carried out by other sectors of the community, whether they be farmers, metal workers or any sort of blue-collar workers, clerks, doctors or whatever; this is one area where the politicians themselves can do it. Unfortunately, there is great danger that the politicians, when challenged with this opportunity of doing something about micro-economic reform, are failing.

It is clear that if Australia is to take part in an international economy-and we have heard speeches from all sides in this House again and again that that is what it ought to do-it must set up the proper legal structure, the regulatory structure, whereby the exchange of securities around the world, including Australia, can take place efficiently. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, entitled the Role of Parliament in Relation to the National Companies Scheme to which Senator Schacht has referred and which was chaired successively by the present Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who deserves to be congratulated on the report, and then by the present Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, was recommended by all parties. Senator Schacht has quoted that.
I refer to chapter 3 of that report. Paragraph 3.1 states:
On 1 April 1987, the six State stock exchanges-
and that included Western Australia-
amalgamated to form the Australian Stock Exchange Ltd-
that is the one stock exchange operating in Australia-
According to the Chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange Ltd, Mr Ian Roach:
There is only one market for securities in Australia and it is part of the global market . . . it is essential that we pool our resources as one united stock exchange . . .

There are then quotes from Mr Henry Bosch; from Mr Robert Gardini, who represented the Confederation of Australian Industry at the public hearings of the Committee; there is a reference to Mr Ray Schoer who, I think, Senator Campbell has also referred to; and there is a statement by Mr Leigh Masel, the inaugural Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission. All of these statements said that there ought to be a single scheme because Australia had developed to the point where it was needed and the international market required there to be one. That was in 1987. Here we are, three years later, still struggling to achieve a proper structure.

The High Court of Australia has said that the Commonwealth has not got full control over the regulation of companies, that it has not got control over the incorporation of companies and, therefore, the Commonwealth has to work with the States. But that decision was not an invitation to the States, may I say with respect, to cause frustration, to cause difficulties, to cause all sorts of harm to a national scheme simply because some people wanted to score political points-indeed, they should not do it for any reason, but especially not because they want to score a political point.

In the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 29 May there is an article headed `New company law runs into more meddling' which talks about the meeting that Mr Costello convened. Unfortunately, that is true-the problem that this legislation faces is meddling, which has the most dire consequences for the sort of economy that Australia wants to develop.

I return to the legislation. It has arisen out of a draft agreement, as I understand it, between the Attorneys-General about how the structure, operation and new regime for companies and securities in Australia will go. As I understand it, there are a number of issues still to be resolved. They have been touched on already. One is the staffing in each State of the Australian Securities Commission and, in that context, what will happen to the employees of the corporate affairs commissions that operate in those States? I put on the record now that proper attention should be paid to their situation and proper accommodation should be made for them. That is the sort of thing that I think we ought to be concerned about, rather than whether or not the States rights have been properly stroked. It seems to me that it is hardly a consideration when Australia is facing the dire economic problems that it presently is.

The other thing that has not been fully agreed upon yet, as I understand it, is the revenue which the States used to derive from their regulation of companies. I think that is a proper matter whether or not that money was going to be used for company regulation. If States have got a source of income available to them, and that is going to be taken from them, of course they will be concerned. In my view it is proper that the Commonwealth pay attention to that and make sure that their economies are not affected by taking away a source of revenue that they have had up until now.

There are two matters which, I think are properly calling for attention from the Commonwealth and, indeed, from the States. First, what will happen to the staff of the corporate affairs commissions, and will they be accommodated properly? Secondly, what will happen to replace the revenue that otherwise would have been earned by the States in their regulation of corporations?

I go on to the person who has been, in recent times, most active in this field and deserves to be mentioned; that is, the Victorian Attorney-General, Mr Jim Kennan. In this context, I quote to illustrate my point what was said in a media release on 4 May which is pertinent. Mr Kennan had this to say:
I am pleased that Australia will have certainty in its regulation of companies and securities and have its position in the international business community restored.
He was able to say on that day:
All the States have recognised the need for a truly national scheme and the further damage that could be done to the Australian economy had there not been co-operation and conciliation today.
All of the governments of the various States have agreed but unfortunately, apparently, the upper Houses of at least three States have taken a different view.

I think it was Mr Kennan who made the suggestion-that other excellent Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, who has already shown himself as one of the great Attorneys-General of this nation agreed with what he said-that there are four basic principles that ought to operate in this area. First, that there ought to be a single regulator; secondly, that that regulator should be accountable only to the Commonwealth Minister-that is, to the excellent Mr Duffy; thirdly, that the laws should be made and amended by the Commonwealth Parliament only; and fourthly, that the key national issues should be within Federal control. If those four principles were adopted, much would be done to recover the damage that has been done to the economy as a result of the uncertainty that has grown in the area of corporate regulation.

That damage, as has been said before, is real because people overseas and stock exchanges overseas want to know who is in control of securities in Australia. If they are going to buy and sell Australian securities, they want to know what laws govern that; they want to know whether, when a particular situation arises if it needs rapid legislation that that legislation can be enacted; they want to know the sort of body that will carry out the regulation of companies and the regulation of the exchange of securities; they want to know whether that can act quickly and decisively. At the moment, unfortunately, they are unable to do that. If the agreement which is presently afoot can be concluded satisfactorily, that matter would be attended to.

This Bill deals with the Australian Securities Commission and, hopefully, that aspect of company control can be quarantined from the other functions that the corporate affairs commissions presently perform. It is important that the ASC be established as the sole body that regulates securities in Australia. I think the Opposition, which I understand is going to support the Bill, has shown a very responsible attitude in doing that and I congratulate it. I hope that the draft agreement-perhaps I should say the suggested agreement because I understand that it has not been concluded-which is presently in the various offices of Attorneys-General around Australia and in the office of the Attorney-General here, will result in a finalised agreement and that that will be done very rapidly so that we can get about the business of company regulation.

Finally, once again I congratulate the State governments that have worked so hard with the Federal Government to come as far as we have already come, and I encourage them to continue down that line. In particular, I congratulate Mr Kennan and Mr Duffy, who have struggled nobly and, hopefully, successfully to bring about what is much needed-that is, a good system of company regulation in this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented during Senator Schacht's speech earlier this evening. He suggested that three businessmen had found themselves a junior senator to come here and oppose the national scheme. I think the statement of Senator Schacht conjures some unpleasant images of me being in the pockets of three business people. I inform the Senate that I certainly did not speak to three business people. Indeed, as I said in my speech, the position I am advocating here today is supported by a great number of organisations in Western Australia, including the Law Society of Western Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, stock exchange members in Perth, the Company Directors Association of Australia, the Trustee Companies Association and so forth.

SPEECH.PARA: The other unfortunate misrepresentation Senator Schacht made was in his referring to me as a junior senator, suggesting that these three imaginary business people in Perth could not find a senior senator to do their dirty work. The only apology I make to the Senate is that, although I am a junior senator, I have very little control over my age. I guess one of the unfortunate things about me is that I was born at a very young age. That is why I am so junior.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everyone is born at a very young age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the point. Senator Faulkner got it. I am glad to see that one senator on the other side was bright enough to actually get the message of Senator Campbell's last few words. This evening we are talking to the Australian Securities Commission Amendment Bill. Of course, this is only a minor piece of legislation in the saga of Labor's power grab for corporate regulation. It is not opposed by the coalition. In effect, all it does is continue interim arrangements and enable members of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to be appointed as members of the National Companies and Securities Commission (ASC).

SPEECH.PARA: However, I take this opportunity to state briefly that the coalition deplores the incompetence that two successive Attorneys-General of the Hawke Labor Government have displayed in the long history of this legislation. Equally, as a Liberal senator for Western Australia, once again I place on record my opposition to control and decision-making in the corporate field being transferred out of our State. In so doing, I speak for a great many business and professional people. At the risk of someone else having a cheap shot at me-that is S-H-O-T, not S-C-H-A-C-H-T-I can tell the Senate that I have not been lobbied by any businessmen, but I am very much aware of what the situation is in Western Australia.

Last year, in speaking to the original legislation, I warned that as the Commonwealth lacked constitutional power to legislate for corporations, according to the Law Council of Australia, implementation of the scheme would require complementary State legislation and could involve expensive High Court litigation. We in the coalition are now richly entitled to say, `I told you so'. That is rather sad because much time and money has been wasted on this quite unnecessarily.

However, I think it is pertinent to query the costs of running both the ASC and the NCSC, the former having no Act to administer and the latter having continued responsibly but with insufficient personnel. Indeed, it was made clear on Tuesday in the Australian Financial Review that it would be extremely difficult for the ASC to take over corporate regulation in the New Year, let alone on 1 July. It would be interesting to hear from the Minister how the Government plans to do that when it is already expressing concern about next year. This Government has failed to organise the appointments of key personnel to the ASC and is making no effort that is apparent to us-to fill vacancies looming in the NCSC. No agreement has been made as to the funding of the ASC; nor have Bills been redrafted for the States to copy, even assuming that they choose to do so.

I believe that this Government has been grossly incompetent in seeking to implement what it has the cheek to declare is part of its program for micro-economic reform. Among those parts of last year's legislation that it has not proclaimed is part 14 of the Australian Securities Commission Act, which would establish a parliamentary committee to scrutinise the legislation. Small wonder that it does not want its incompetence exposed, I guess would be the answer to that. This Labor Government has sought to make a virtue of its supposed pragmatism, but I ask: Where is the common sense in trying to pretend that Australia is not a federation, that we do not have a Constitution, and that we do not have a high court that can make judgments? Thank heavens it does. It is thanks to the High Court that governments are stopped from doing exactly as they please. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and his predecessor have tried to override the Federal system. Even those who support the concept of a more centralised scheme recognise that this approach will achieve nothing except the waste of public funds.

Above these considerations is the principle that the national interest will not be served by the further centralisation of economic power wherever it might be-whether in Canberra, Sydney or Melbourne. The coalition has maintained that the cooperative scheme of corporate regulation should be subject to any necessary change. We support the principles of uniformity and certainty in corporate administration. I do not really think there are too many businessmen in Australia who would oppose the concept of uniformity, but they certainly oppose the concept of its being centralised. I think we need to take that into consideration because, potentially, a number of people could be seriously affected. It is probably not so bad for national companies, but what happens to family companies, private practices, small businesses and so on as opposed to national companies?

This must not mean that decision-making should be centralised and the local expertise built up in State corporate affairs commissions abandoned. That is one of the real concerns about what is going on with this legislation. It must not mean delays for Western Australian firms, for example, in getting decisions made or their incurring extra costs in communicating with a distant centre of authority. Heaven only knows that we in the west have enough problems with isolation now, let alone if all this administration is to be centralised in Melbourne. It must not mean a consequent relocation of company offices away from outlying States, with the loss of professional careers. That is another major concern. People are worried that there will be a mass exodus from the outlying States because their services will not be required where they currently are.

Accordingly, I commend my Liberal colleagues in the Legislative Council of Western Australia, who, on 16 May, passed a successful motion that any complementary State legislation would not be passed if it transferred constitutional power and authority to the Commonwealth, or conceded the benefit of any undecided constitutional doubt in favour of the Commonwealth.
