Rightly, the Legislative Council, the only chamber that represents majority opinion as expressed at the last State election, insists that the State should retain the benefit of the High Court decision and retain real political and administrative powers.

I must emphasise also that Western Australia is not alone in its stance. As my colleague Senator Campbell pointed out earlier, the Opposition parties in South Australia and in Victoria-a State that can hardly be described as outlying-have adopted similar positions, foreshadowing rejection of enabling legislation in their respective upper Houses. The concern is not just shared among people in Western Australia; it is quite clear that there is concern in various States throughout the country. It is not unkind to point out that in each of these States a majority of voters gave support to the coalition parties when State elections were last held. This is a logical response to reports that civil and commercial aspects of corporate affairs be centralised in Sydney and criminal and compliance functions placed in Melbourne, with a centralised data processing centre in the Latrobe Valley.

Such a scenario is far more than a loss for any concept of States' rights for their own sake. It would represent a downgrading of the commercial life of Western Australia in a way that would not enhance our national economic performance, quite apart from its impact in Perth proper. Clearly that impact will be devastating. Centralisation of commercial activity is nothing to do with micro-economic reform, and by damaging alternative centres of economic power it will actually retard this objective. In limiting my remarks to this Bill, I give notice that I will have a great deal more to say if further legislation comes before the Senate seeking to advance Labor's centralist ideology in the face of administrative commonsense and the long-term economic interests of the Western Australian and national commercial sectors.

I conclude by restating people's concerns about the funding and revenue sharing issues that are still far from being clarified. I repeat that this is not just true of Western Australia; the Liberal and National Attorneys-General and shadow Ministers for the States, who have no conflict at all with the desirability of a uniform system of company law, are as concerned as I am about the centralised administration of company law in one national body. There are many examples and I do not wish to go into them again this evening, but I express concern about the future and where this trend will take us in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, and I have no doubt the independent senators, for their support of the Australian Securities Commission Bill, which I hope will have a speedy passage shortly. Although the Bill itself is rather technical and administrative, it is true, as honourable senators have said in this debate, that it is part of a movement towards giving Australia an effective administrative structure for the regulation of companies and securities as benefits a nation in a trading and commercial world. We are senators, albeit elected from our various States and Territories, who are here as members of an Australian Parliament. It was a Parliament that was set up by the people federating in a Commonwealth of Australia in order to achieve together national objectives which could not be achieved as colonies or States. The matters which properly might come within the province of the national Parliament change over time. Clearly the time has been reached, in the 1990s, where we need to have an Australia-wide administrative structure which is not bedevilled by State boundaries in a way which fragments the effort which must be at the heart of our future as a trading nation with a vibrant commercial life. We need effective regulation to ensure that the moneys which are given by Australians and overseas investors to certain entrepreneurs and business people are used in a way which is honest, in the first place, and effective in creating a sound economic future for all of us so that the wealth is then shared in the community for generations to come.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why people like Sir James Balderstone, the chief of the Australian Mutual Provident Society, said only a few days ago that the establishment of a national corporate regulatory body to tackle the speedy prosecution of errant directors was an absolutely vital part of restoring the confidence of investors both within Australia and from overseas in the Australian economy in so far as that is represented by the trading and commercial activities undertaken by companies throughout this nation. I believe that we need to listen to that voice, not because it is from the top end of the market but because it indicates one of the reasons we have reached a situation where we have become fragmented, territorially circumscribed. Parochial is not a word I like to use, because I am a Tasmanian, but there are always tendencies within our Federation which emphasise and give undue weight to local concerns as opposed to the needs of the whole nation. It is a tendency which must be overcome in the regulation of companies and securities.

Two main arguments came from Opposition senators relating to their concern that the proposed scheme should not go ahead and that somehow the national companies and securities scheme should be enhanced or reinstated. One was to do with funding and the other with the way in which the new scheme will relate to local business communities. As for funding, it has to be firmly said-I say this particularly to Senator Campbell, but also to Senator Knowles, as the junior and senior senators from Western Australia who are now sitting together-that the States were very amply supplied by the corporate sector with funds to carry out regulation.

It is also a fact that the States diverted those funds into other purposes, into their Consolidated Revenues. I would like to illustrate that point because Senator Campbell was not in the chamber at the time last year when the following happened: In the autumn of last year the Ministerial Council on the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) met and decided precisely to remedy the disability which Senator Campbell, Senator Knowles and others have pointed to-namely, that it was under-resourced; that it did not have the funds to carry out the regulation of Australia's corporate and securities sector that it ought to have had. The Ministerial Council met in the autumn and devised a scheme whereby more money would be derived from the corporate sector, but this required legislation.

Within two months, in June of last year, the Commonwealth Parliament-and I give credit to the Opposition for supporting the measure-passed the necessary legislation to enable greater funding to be given to the NCSC. It was there in our appropriations; we discussed it at the Estimates committees. Only one State, New South Wales, has passed the necessary legislation to achieve that greater funding for the National Companies and Securities Commission.

The fact is that the States have not been interested in securing greater funding to enable their corporate offices to regulate companies and securities activity within their own borders. That is a great shame, but I think after 12 months' experience of that particular effort to provide sufficient resources and funding one can see why exasperation is felt. Quite clearly completely different funding of a much more national regulatory body is now undoubtedly required. The national companies and securities scheme was not supported by the funding political will of the State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you stop the Western Australia Government from funding WA Inc.?

—I am glad that you mentioned WA Inc., Senator, because in today's Australian Financial Review there is a very interesting editorial entitled `Company law debate federalism at its worst'. It points to a particular paradox which Senator Campbell and Senator Knowles might like to ponder. The Western Australian Opposition is simultaneously lobbying for a major inquiry into the deals surrounding WA Inc., while opposing the creation of a well funded national administration and enforcement operation that would go a long way towards remedying the deficiencies that have been highlighted in Western Australia. The fact is that the NCSC was always underfunded. I admit this in relation to Western Australia, and Senator Schacht has pointed to the same dangers in South Australia-that there is a danger of the local political power brokers becoming too closely involved with their local business community and its companies and securities activities. That is a real danger and I think the Western Australian experience has pointed to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Knowles will agree that for the past 18 months I have been subjected to question after question, particularly from Senator Durack, in relation to WA Inc., precisely because he understood that what was happening in Western Australia was having a national impact. Time after time I was unable to give him the answers that I wanted to give because, not being a responsible Minister in the sense that the NCSC was not answerable to me or to the Commonwealth Attorney-General, I had to await a fax from the NCSC, which might be four or five days late in coming, in order to reply to Senator Durack's queries. The fact is-and this is why the Senate Committee came into its unanimous conclusions-that we need to have not only a single administrative body but also proper parliamentary responsibility for the regulation of companies and securities throughout this nation.

That is what really lay at the beginning of this process within this chamber. As Senator Macklin pointed out, there was very clear evidence that there was no real line of political responsibility for the regulation of companies and securities in Australia. This was so diffused through the Ministerial Council that in no parliament could one Attorney-General or Minister for companies regulation, or whatever you like to call him, be held accountable for the laws or the administration which were supposed to regulate the companies and securities sector. In that situation, those who committed misdeeds, such as in the case of WA Inc., were able, because of that diffusion of political responsibility, to get away with a lot more for a lot longer than they should have done.

What we need now is either meetings of the Ministerial Council or a telexed consensus reached in relation to, for example, how to set up an inquiry or who should do what in relation to a particular malfeasance by some person involved in companies and securities in the jurisdiction concerned. Therefore, what we are proposing is something that is absolutely consistent with parliamentary accountability and that is something which should appeal to senators, because this chamber, of all chambers, tries to insist that the Parliament take the Executive and hold it responsible for, in this case, the regulation of companies and securities.

Another very valid point was raised by Senator Campbell to which some weight must be given, and that is that despite the fact that we are talking about a national administrative structure with all the advantages of uniformity that are involved, there must be an ability to relate to, and be sensitive to, local business communities, and particularly smaller businesses. Mr Hartnell has indicated that there will be separate business centres in the various regions. This does not just mean in cities such as the Sydney-Melbourne-Canberra nexus, but also in places such as Geelong and Townsville. These regional offices will be staffed at a high enough level to provide the sort of interaction with leaders in the local business community that Senator Campbell quite rightly sees as an important part of the operation of the Australian Securities Commission.

I think that one has to realise that the legislation that we passed last year also provided particular consideration for smaller businesses. As senators will know, the Close Corporations Act, which is part of the package of laws implementing a national scheme, provides a new, simpler and more flexible form of incorporation for small business. Many of the current detailed rules applying to companies that are appropriate for larger companies admittedly impose inflexible and unnecessary rules and costly burdens on small businesses. The close corporation will enable the small business to obtain the benefits of incorporation, such as limited liability, simply and cheaply. There is also a reduction of the regulatory burden on proprietary companies. Right through this operation there has been a consciousness of the need to differentiate between the large companies and the small companies which operate to the great benefit of our economy and community. This sector creates the wealth which is then used for other purposes and is distributed in all sorts of ways, including taxation and charges on business, in a way that helps the whole community. Small businesses have to be nurtured and they are being nurtured under this very scheme. I believe that the indication that the regional offices will work in a way which is sensitive to the local business community, will sufficiently enable that interaction that is so important to occur without allowing the local business community to capture the regulatory and political agents within that local community.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not believe you.

—Well Senator, they may not believe me, but we must ask what is the alternative. Mr Peter Costello, who is, I believe, playing a reasonably constructive role in these matters, had something to say about this. I do not know what they will say about that in my office downstairs when they read the Hansard! The shadow Minister for corporate law reform and consumer affairs put out a press release on 28 May after his meeting with Liberal shadow Ministers and political leaders throughout Australia. In that release he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If legislation is rejected in any of the States, Australia risks ending up with a system much worse than its predecessor with different laws and different administrative bodies between the States.

That is what Peter Costello said and I absolutely adopt every word of that. His concerns, like those of some senators, are about funding and the local business community relating to the national body. Those are concerns which must be addressed and I believe that they can be successfully addressed. One must also consider that the Hon. Nick Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales-the only Liberal politician in power, as opposed to being in opposition or a controller of an upper House-has also played a very constructive role in the past few weeks in relation to this matter. When one looks at his experience of the exercise of power and his knowledge of what is needed in Australia, one gets a very different picture. I am sure that Mr Greiner is motivated by the same fear expressed in Mr Peter Costello's remarks in his press release, which I will now repeat. He said:
If legislation is rejected in any of the States, Australia risks ending up with a system much worse that its predecessor with different laws and different administrative bodies between the States.

That would be an absolute disaster. After all, the Attorneys-General have sat around the table, thrashed this out, and agreed that one has to keep within the constitutional limits. The High Court has set down certain boundaries. I understand that references of powers is not now the way it will go. The States will pass an application of laws Act which will pass through their own parliaments, and adopt the substantive laws that are passed by this Parliament in relation to companies and securities. That keeps the constitutional division of powers between the State Parliaments and this Parliament very clear. I believe that is a neater way to go and certainly does not involve any dubious claims for a constitutional bridge on the part of the Commonwealth which might be brought undone in the High Court. I think this has been acknowledged before, about this proposal as a whole, but it sets this particular piece of legislation in some sort of context.

I would plead with Senator Campbell, and Senator Knowles, to speak with the Hon. Nick Greiner, and with Mr Peter Costello, to see the dangers that might unfold if the upper Houses do not pass the legislation, which may be presented by those governments to their Houses of Assembly, and realise the great danger that that puts Australia in. This is not my opinion alone; it is shared by many in the community. Many editorial writers and many people in the business community have been saying over the last several weeks that unless Australia can present to the world a regulation of its companies and securities sector which will be seen to be efficient and sound and capable of controlling situations such as WA Inc.-none of us wants to see that situation emerge ever again-and if that terrible situation is to be averted the national Parliament, and senators as part of the national Parliament, must take political responsibility for keeping a Federal Minister responsible for the regulation of companies and securities throughout Australia, through one administrative structure, namely; the National Companies and Securities Commission.
I thank those senators who have indicated their support for the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia present its report on or before 31 July 1990.

(2) That, if the Senate is not sitting when the Committee completes its report, the Committee may send the report to the President or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, or if the Deputy-President is unavailable, to any one of the Temporary Chairmen of Committees, and, in that event-
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this resolution;
(c) the President, the Deputy-President or the Temporary Chairman of Committees, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report; and
(d) the President shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(3) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, insofar as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Vanstone moving a motion relating to the order of business of the Senate.

Senator Vanstone's notice of motion is the one that concerns the televising of this chamber during the Budget Session of parliament this year. The reason that we are seeking to have it dealt with on this occasion, rather than when we come back in the Budget Session, is for the obvious reason that televising will start from the commencement of the Budget Session.

I recognise that it would have been better if there had been more time for consideration of this matter by the chamber between the giving of the notice and the time that we are seeking to have it debated, that is, today. But, unfortunately, the details of the notice-that is, the terms and conditions which we put forward as having been agreed with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)-were not concluded until, literally, a few minutes before the notice was given yesterday.

It is not as if it is a new issue. Some might say that it has been an issue that has been around for 25 years. Of more relevance to the debate today is the fact that the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings of this Parliament recommended in October last year that a trial period be commenced for the televising of parliament. That was adopted by the Opposition parties in their party room, but it seems that at that time the Government was not prepared to enter such a trial. We think that is regret- table and therefore we have taken this action in order to let the Senate decide whether it might be broadcast in this way.

I understand that there is quite a bit of work that would need to be done during the break with regard to technical and management matters on the procedures that would have to be adopted by the ABC. Apart from the work that would have to be done by the ABC in relation to educating its audience to program changing-all of those matters might seem mechanical to us, but no doubt to the professionals they are time consuming and have to be done in an orderly manner-it is necessary, in our view, that this matter be disposed of now rather than when we come back so that those who will be concerned with implementing the resolution, if Senator Vanstone's motion is adopted, have an opportunity to do so. It is for that reason that we say that it is urgent that the order of business be changed so that her motion be debated.

We undertake that it be a short debate and that if this motion is carried we would have one speaker who has agreed to speak for approximately 10 minutes. We do that because we recognise the weight of business still to be dealt with by the Senate in this session. We do not wish in any way to interfere with the orderly management of that business program. I urge the Senate to accept the urgency on this occasion and let the Senate express its view on whether it should be in a position to be televised commencing on Budget day this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the suspension of Standing Orders today. One wonders if this is such an important issue why it is dragged in now. It was not even introduced at the normal time of notices of motion yesterday but by leave yesterday afternoon. One wonders why, when the Manager of Opposition Business indicates that there will be a response tomorrow morning on this, on the public record, it is dragged in at this particular time. The normal procedures when something of this nature affecting the chamber is brought in are that we give notice and then have a consultation period and each party can made up its mind. There is no doubt that this issue has been canvassed. Let me not be hypocritical on that.

SPEECH.PARA: But when it came to moving the changes to the Estimates committee procedures, or the committee system, several times I moved an adjournment in this place until everyone was happy and made up his mind. When it came to Senator Coates's motion, on continuing orders, did we proceed with it and try to push it along until others were ready? No, we did not. What we have today is people moving helter skelter on this particular issue. What is the motive? So one senator can get up some Brownie points with the Fourth Estate.

Rushing into this for such opportunistic reasons worries me in that sense. The sorts of procedures and understanding that are essential to make this very anarchistic chamber work are being breached on this occasion. Everyone knows that no-one has the numbers in this chamber. Everyone knows that debate cannot be artificially restricted by the gag in general. Therefore, one has to have a certain degree of understanding and cooperation. This has been blatantly breached on this occasion. I have not had an opportunity or sufficient notice to have this matter finalised in my party room. If it had been moved even a week ago, I would have had the opportunity to say, `Look, this is going to be decided on the Thursday'.

I also made, I thought, the reasonable offer to have this matter debated and, I said, finalised on 24 August. One wonders what the motive is for rushing into it now. I can only divine one motive-opportunism, wanting to ingratiate oneself with certain elements of the media. Of course, they want Parliament televised and turned into a circus.

I am not going to go to the substantive issues. I will do that later in the debate. But there is no reason why it should be rushed in on the second last day of the session and determined by a few speakers when every other time we have been considering something that has a major consequence in this chamber, a decent amount of time for discussion, negotiation and internal decision-making is allowed. It is not allowed on this occasion.

I am very disappointed in members of the National Party that they would want to divert Government Business at this time when the whole wool debate is awaiting. Does it reflect very well on their priorities that they want to get into this sort of debate when important issues are going to be decided?

I admit that in the job of Manager of Government Business I have become a bit soft; I have become a bit too accommodating. Well, no more Mr nice guy any more on some of these matters. When the Opposition comes to us and asks for extra time we will probably give in because we do not have the numbers; but it will not be coming from the heart any more. We will not try to be so accommodating in future. We will do so only under the pressure of the vicious use of numbers in this chamber and not because we are trying to make the place operate and work properly.

The Opposition is coming in today trying to shanghai a decision. Senator Brownhill is sitting over there, not researching the wool question or anything else, but wasting his time on this proposition. The Government opposes the suspension of Standing Orders. We will divide on this issue. But when the substantive issue comes up, because we do not have a firm position we will not seek to divide. We will be moving what I hope will be a minor amendment to this substantive motion that we are no doubt going to discuss in a few minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders as moved by Senator Hill. While we may agree, when we get into the substantive debate, with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, that this might not be the most urgent issue ever to come before the Senate, if, as the Democrats believe, the people of Australia have a right to televised broadcasts of the Parliament as they have to radio broadcasts, then that must begin at some point.

SPEECH.PARA: We also agree that when that happens we will want to review what happened in the first instance and perhaps look at the way it has worked and maybe go into some other mode. This motion, which we believe ought to be debated today, gives us that opportunity. It is for a trial period.

The urgency of the matter now and why we support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is that, if we are going to do something, then obviously the Budget session is the period in which to do it. It is an informative and interesting session for the community. If we do not act now, today, then the work that is necessary to be done will not be able to be done in the winter recess period. Again we will be delayed further and further on a matter which, I might say in supporting the Opposition's motion, we have really only been delayed on because the Opposition has taken so long to come to a view about it. We have been clear for a very long time that this is something the Democrats have supported and we consider it as urgent as anything because now that Opposition members have come to agree with us and have taken this action we want to get it in place before they change their minds again. I think Senator Ray might have some sympathy with us on that.

I do not want to go to the substantive issues, nor do we want a long debate. When the substantive issue does come before us we, too, guarantee not to blow out this debate. But I have a feeling that Senator Ray might be able to get worked up and take his full 10 minutes if he is going to be party to this agreement. We support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders because we believe that this matter needs to be dealt with now. We need to get it out of the way and in place so that things can begin in the Budget session.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vanstone) agreed to:
That General Business, notice of motion No. 69, relating to the television broadcasting of Senate proceedings be called on forthwith and have precedence over all other business until determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate authorises the broadcasting by Australian Broadcasting Corporation television of Question Time in the Senate for a trial period from 21 August to 19 October 1990.

(2) That, if during the trial period the House of Representatives resolves to allow the broadcasting of Question Time in that House, the distribution of the broadcast between the two Houses shall be in accordance with the distribution of the radio broadcast, provided that the Senate is broadcast on not less than three days in any two-week sitting period.
(3) That the Senate authorises the broadcasting by television stations of excerpts of its proceedings in accordance with the following conditions:
Conditions governing the broadcasting of excerpts of proceedings by television stations
1. Access to the proceedings of the Senate for the recording and broadcasting of excerpts of proceedings is subject to an undertaking to observe, and to compliance with, the following conditions:
2. Recordings and broadcasts may be made only from channel 2 on the house monitoring system.
3. Broadcasts of excerpts shall be used only for the purposes of fair and accurate reports of proceedings, and shall not be used for:
(a) political party advertising or election campaigns;
(b) satire and ridicule; or
(c) commercial sponsorship or com- mercial advertising.
4. Reports of proceedings shall be such as to provide a balanced presentation of differing views.
5. Excerpts of proceedings which are subsequently withdrawn may be broadcast only if the withdrawal is also reported.
6. Debate on a motion for the adjournment of the Senate shall not be broadcast.
7. The instructions of the President of the Senate or his or her delegates in respect of the broadcasting of excerpts, which are not inconsistent with these conditions, shall be observed.

Tonight the Senate will have the opportunity to give Australians greater access to their Parliament. A parliament which deprives its people, the people it purports to serve, of access to its day-to-day operation is a parliament which has forgotten the fundamental premises underlying its own existence. The taxpayer is entitled to see what his elected representatives are doing, and how they are doing it. Taxpayers paid for the building, they pay for our salaries and they pay for all the associated costs. How could we possibly justify not letting them see how their money is spent?

This motion allows for a two-month trial period of televising Question Time. During that trial period it allows excerpts of proceedings-that is, all Senate proceedings-to be used by all the networks in their news broadcasts and current affairs programs. In that sense it is doing exactly what Senator Ray would like us to do; that is, giving us a first look at how such a thing would operate.

There is no risk in adopting this motion. We will be having a trial procedure. The Senate, of course, retains the power to ensure that the media do not misuse this opportunity. I believe that it is in everybody's interest to maximise the opportunities for Australians to see what is happening with their dollars in their Parliament.

Other parliaments televise their proceedings. The United States House of Representatives started doing so in 1979 and the Senate in 1986. In the United Kingdom the House of Lords commenced televising its proceedings in 1985, as did the Commons in 1988. In Canada the matter was raised in 1977. It may be instructive to look at some of the debates on the subject in the House of Commons and note some of the remarks that were made. A Mr Nelson said on 9 February 1988:
. . . we have come a long way in the past 400 years since the time when our proceedings were secret. The evolution of our democratic system has been one of gradual and increasing openness . . .
I believe and hope that we shall enhance the character and standing of this place in the world outside.
If the public live in ignorance because they are unable to see what happens here, that will ferment and breed suspicion and misunderstanding of our proceedings.

How true that is. Many members of the public have a misunderstanding of the proceedings in this place. There is not the time to detail all Mr Dobson's remarks but he made the point that most members of parliament are very keen to get on television. They will stand in the rain to get on television. They will go almost anywhere to get on television. Yet for some, when it comes to televising what they are doing in their own chamber-nicely airconditioned and away from the rain-there seems to be some reluctance. That reluctance is difficult to explain.

I want to make a number of points as to why the Senate should adopt this motion this evening. The first point relates to access, which I have partially mentioned it-people having the opportunity to see what happens in their Parliament. In this large country that is very important. The wealthy can travel here and see what happens. The print and radio media also have the opportunity to see what is happening. I am asking the Senate to adopt a motion tonight to let everyone else who cannot be here not only read about the Senate's proceedings in the newspapers and hear about them on the radio but also see them on television. That really is the limit of the change that is being suggested this evening.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I made the point that allowing the televising of Parliament, at least during Question Time, and providing excerpts to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and other broadcasters, would give all Australians greater and improved access to Parliament. Since it is such a large country that is a good thing, since it is only wealthy people who can come to sit in the chamber and watch.

SPEECH.PARA: I now make the point that this proposal is for a trial period only. It is not uncontrolled access; it is access in accordance with some conditions. I understand that Senator Robert Ray wants to move an amendment to allow the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure to look at those conditions and perhaps come back and make some recommendations for change. Nonetheless, this is not a suggestion for totally uncontrolled access by the media to excerpts of Senate proceedings. After all, the signal is controlled by our Parliamentary Sound and Vision Office.

I make the additional point that the taxpayer has already forked out about $50m for the sound and vision systems in this Parliament. I know that some of that is not related to the televising of proceedings, but the most substantial proportion of it is. Who now gets the benefit? We televise Parliament to our rooms and to the press gallery but, for some reason, not to the public. It seems absolutely ludicrous. The cost has already been incurred. This building has the biggest television production studio in the country. It should be put to good use. We can put that cost to a good use by a simple flick of a switch so that the ABC can take Question Time live and the other networks can take excerpts as they see fit.

Allowing the televising of Parliament will result in an improvement in standards-both in the substance of debates and most certainly in the standard of behaviour. I do not suggest for a minute that there is any problem with behaviour in this place, but should the Senate adopt this course of action my view is that the House of Representatives will very rapidly follow. That chamber could very well do with an improvement in its standards of behaviour.

I now canvass a couple of the arguments that have been put against this proposal. One is that if we televise Parliament it will in some ways stifle debate; that honourable members, knowing that they may well be on national television later that night, will somehow hesitate to take a tough stand or raise contentious issues. This is a ridiculous proposition to put, for a few reasons. First, they may be on national radio anyway. Secondly, whatever they say will probably be reported in the printed media. So there is no evading what one has said. There will be no greater scrutiny by this; it will simply allow movement on the television as opposed to a still picture. Thirdly, people who believe that they would modify their behaviour, to an extent where they would take a weaker position because of the televising of Parliament, really should not be here.

The main reason that the Government does not want to move this way now is basically a twofold reason. First, many members opposite do not approve of this chamber; they would like a unicameral system. They have never liked the Senate, and the further they can degrade the Senate the better. That is the first part. What flows from that is that they know that if the Senate does this, there is a full expectation that the House of Representatives will follow-as it should. That is where the rub comes.

If the House of Representatives follows, out comes the `Let's Protect Paul Society'. It is well known that Government members do not want the behaviour of their Ministers in the lower House televised live nationally, at Question Time. The only way to avoid that is to stop the Senate proceeding with this course of action. That is one of the fundamental reasons that the Government is against this; it does not want the people of Australia to see live the sort of behaviour indulged in in the House of Representatives, particularly by its Ministers.

The second matter that flows from the House of Representatives following the Senate is that the behaviour of Dr Hewson and his performance in the chamber will be able to be seen live. The Government does not want that either. One has only to have a quick look at the polls over the last couple of weeks to see why the Government would be apprehensive about televising Question Time in the House of Representatives. They are the real reasons that the Government does not want to proceed with this matter.

Earlier I mentioned the fact that Government members have always had the view that we should have a unicameral system; that the Senate should not be here. I remind honourable senators that this is the chamber that really makes legislation that affects the daily lives of Australians. This chamber stopped the infamous identity card legislation going through. This chamber's activities stopped the Bill of Rights. Very often it is this chamber that cleans up very messy legislation, and improves it no end. That is the case with whoever is in government. On that basis, it is quite appropriate for the Senate to take this first step into televising all proceedings at some later stage. But the Government, bent on degrading the Senate, is determined that this chamber will not make the move that brings the public coverage of the Parliament into this century.

The Minister said that this is an ambush and that there has not been time for people to think about it. Very briefly, I put an alternative view. This is not an ambush. The Minister talked about the new standing orders and matters relating to Estimates committees. We have had an opportunity to look at this again and again. All this motion is doing is giving us a chance to have a first look at the effect of televising the Parliament. We can then come back and have another debate about whether we think it has been effective.

In conclusion, the printed media have full access, radio has pretty good access, and I see no reason at all why television should continue to be unfairly and unwisely shut out of these proceedings. This motion will allow us to have a trial run of televising the Parliament and to make some assessments. A positive vote will result in a broadcast of the Senate, a Question Time in the Budget session, and excerpts by the other channels as they see fit.

If we get a positive vote tonight we will be at the go stage. The reason is that there have been negotiations with Harry Hall and Barbara Major of the ABC. I thank the Usher of the Black Rod for his contribution to those negotiations. We are now in a position to say that if this motion is passed tonight, the ABC will proceed exactly in accordance with its terms. That is a good thing. No further negotiation is required. We can simply say yes. We can give it a try; in the more colloquial terms, we can suck it and see. That is what we should do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I had been appraised of this motion some weeks ago and asked to guess who had moved it, I would have picked Senator Vanstone straight off. This is a Vanstone special. It relates to style in the chamber-the only thing that she has concentrated on since she has arrived in this place. First, we had sexist language, the language of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), or some other trivia--
—Fair enough.
—No. This fits the typical pattern of being absorbed with the trivia of this chamber and the Senate's chauvinism. I do not think that it adds much to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The first argument adduced in favour of this proposal is that it would continue the process of the proper use of taxpayers' money. I am not opposed to the televising of proceedings of this chamber. My only point, as I made earlier today, is that I would have liked to have had the position formalised at a Party meeting. I am sure that any such formalisation would have come down in favour of televising. But the hypocritical argument that this is an extension of the use of taxpayers' money rings pretty hollow to me. What television will do is show taxpayers how much money they waste by lavishing it on honourable senators in this chamber, given the quality of debate, the inanity of many of the Senate's procedures and the absolutely excruciatingly slow pace at which this chamber goes about its work. At least I will give Senator Vanstone credit for the fact that she did not adduce the argument that we are not doing it for the little kiddiewinks. I am very pleased that that did not come forward tonight.

I also welcome the televising of the Parliament because it will give exposure to the Opposition. That is a good thing. I will enjoy watching the camera pan across the back bench. Each time I will try to count up how many front benchers have been relegated there. It will be an interesting exercise. It is going to be an interesting exercise every time we do it. Or, just as likely, in one big sweep sometimes the coalition will be able to pick up five or six ex-members of the House of Representatives who threw the seats away for the Liberal Party in previous elections and were given the big promotion to the upper House as a reward for having lost coalition marginal seats.

Broadcasting will have some entertainment value as the camera sweeps across the Opposition area, in particular when the camera lingers on the now narrowing base of the National Party of Australia. Nothing could be more constrained in boosting the Government's stocks. There the cameras will linger on Senator Boswell and the rest of the old age pensioners in the National Party and their younger acolytes. Maybe this is really why Senator Vanstone wants it. Of course, the Liberal Party is always trying to wipe out the National Party. There is the leading culprit sitting over there in Senator Parer, who used to hate the former Premier of Queensland-to his credit. He is probably part of the plot, saying `Television of Senate proceedings will be the end of the poor old Nats; they will never adapt'.

But televising the proceedings of this chamber will involve some problems. The empty seat problem is always a problem but certain constraints that the House of Commons and House of Lords have used will generally overcome that. The general view of the public and anyone in the galleries is that politicians only work while they are in this chamber. I have to say publicly that the only time I ever get any rest is when I am in the chamber.

But some of the other conditions worry me. What about satire and ridicule? The producers cannot use an excerpt to satirise and ridicule anyone. Half the clowns who jump up here ridicule and satirise themselves. Does that mean half the senators are never going to get any television exposure? I wonder. A very strange qualification has been put in there. I do, however, support strongly Senator Vanstone's mention of commercial sponsorship and commercial advertising because I shall not wear a T-shirt advertising a local meat pie or anything else. I think that is excellent. While I am on the subject, I only want head shots in the coverage-nothing below the halfway mark for Senator Collins and myself. I will not be cruel enough to nominate anyone else in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing above the eyebrows for Senator McMullan.
—Nothing above the eyebrows for Senator McMullan.
—If it is Senator Vanstone, they will have to turn the sound off.

—No, no; we are trying to keep this at a high level, Senator Collins. There are problems. The big serious problem, the time bomb that is in here that we are all going to worry about, is item No. 4 `Reports of proceedings shall be such as to provide a balanced presentation of differing views'. Over the years a lot of great people, from historians to philosophers, have tried to interpret this. What is truth? What is balance? Who determines this?
—The Senate does.

—Oh, the Senate does. So we are going to have an extract on the news every night and next morning we will turn up and say, `Look, they took me from my wrong profile; they misquoted me; they cut it off at the wrong point. It was not a balanced presentation'. I can see someone lurking down the byway who always jumps up and says, `I have not been consulted'. How is Senator Harradine going to feel when he is not on the news every night? He really should only get one seventy-sixth of the program space. Yet he contributes to a whole range of issues in this chamber.
—He will get more than you.
—Yes, he will get more than me-because you hardly ever ask me a question, Senator Vanstone.
—On the basis of numbers we have more senators than you do and therefore the coalition will get more coverage if you want to do it on numbers.
—Yes, that is true, but I object to it. I think we should do it on intelligence quotient so that we can get a better coverage. But nevertheless, that particular question of balance is a serious one.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made a few facetious remarks tonight, that is true; but the question on balance is a serious one as to how it is determined and who is satisfied with it. Unless we take a very robust attitude to this-that is, take our wins and our losses-we really are going to get into nightmare territory. If someone's particular question is cut off halfway or a senator is taken from a bad angle or something else, they are going to have to ride the bumps. I do not want Senator Vanstone coming in here squealing that this new system that she has asked for is not giving her a fair run or running conspiracy theories around it. I do not think that would add very much.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone has said, `The Australian Labor Party has not progressed this'-first of all, because we believe in a unicameral system. If the conspiracy theory were true, we would televise this place straightaway. Nothing would destroy people's confidence in this place more than having it flashed into the dining rooms and kitchens of every house in the country. Come off the conspiracy theory. If those opposite want to destroy this place, they should show it as it is and not accuse us of that.

But the real coup de grace argument is, `Labor does not want televised proceedings because it does not want them televised in the House of Representatives' because we are afraid of Paul Keating every day at Question Time getting up and showing what a dope Peter Reith is! We are absolutely terrified that the Prime Minister is such a poor media performer that we are going to do badly out of this! The one thing I do agree with Senator Vanstone about, though, is that if we trigger it here, it will come to the House of Representatives very quickly. That is an incontrovertible fact, though not for the motives that Senator Vanstone ascribes.

What we have here is the argument that this chamber is just so important because it is men's legislation. I have gone back through the Hansards from 1975 to 1980 and I do not recall that point being made much. But, even more, the Australian Democrats actually achieved the balance of power from 1980 to 1983, and I have searched in vain for Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Withers or the others getting up and extolling the virtues of amending legislation and what a wonderful chamber this is. This is just Opposition mentality. The moment those opposite are in government they will be the first to complain when their legislation is amended by this chamber. The first day those opposite are in government all these lofty and high principles that have been enunciated tonight will go out the window. Senator Vanstone should recognise that. At least we on this side have the honesty to recognise that. Those principles will go straight out the window and those opposite will be complaining about Senate obstructionism and saying that this chamber is working against the people's House, et cetera.

I hope that when this motion is carried today it is carried on its merits and not on the basis of crude Senate chauvinism. I hope it is carried with the consciousness that the preconditions here may not yet be perfect, that it is very hard to find a judge of what is satiric and what is in fact balanced, and that these conditions may not work. But it is good to see that there are conditions there.

While I am on that point, I think seeing that we were given only a day's notice and that Senator Vanstone has written the conditions, in the meantime we should refer at least these conditions to a committee. But in no way should we stop them operating. I want to make that quite clear. The amendment I am about to move is not to send something off to a committee to stop and block an operation. What gets carried tonight is what comes into being. I move:
At the end of the motion, add the following paragraph:

(4) That the conditions contained in paragraph (3) be referred to the Procedure Committee for inquiry and report by 21 August 1990, and that these orders have effect until altered by a further order of the Senate in relation to the report of the Procedure Committee.

The effect of that amendment is that the Procedure Committee can review the conditions, see if they are adequate, add any or subtract any. It would have to then report to the Senate and its report be carried before any of the conditions that Senator Vanstone has put down are invalidated. I cannot see any real problem with that. At least we can all have a say in it and some of my complaints about the rushed nature of this can be obviated.

I just say in conclusion that the Government will not seek to divide on this. Indeed, we do not have any other view than a conscience vote on it because we have not made a collective decision on it. As we have not made a collective decision on it, members of the Labor Party can vote whichever way they like on this particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean you have not told them what they are going to do yet.
—Order! You are not in your right place, Senator.

—No, it is down at Sunbury but, leaving that aside, sometimes democratic centralism is the best course; sometimes listening to the rank and file is the best course. On this occasion allowing my colleagues to do as they see fit is the best course.
—You can take democracy too far.

—If Senator Crichton-Browne had actually insisted on democracy being taken a bit further in Western Australia, and agreed to one vote, one value, the Liberals would now be sitting in State government. But they vetoed a proper redistribution in Western Australia and forced us to win another election without 50 per cent of the vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Congratulations! It takes a particular genius to be able to do that to oneself and I have never heard one Liberal complain about the redistribution in Western Australia since the last State election when the Liberals buried themselves. But, then again, I know that Senator Crichton-Browne's faction is on the outer in Western Australia. It was probably the jellybacks from the Chaney faction that actually allowed that situation to happen. But do not divert me-

TALK.START.PARA: —You are actually three years out of date. I am surprised at you.

—Oh, Senator Crichton-Browne's faction has come back again, has it? I noticed a clone in his mould come in the other day. The honourable senator should not divert me. I recommend the amendment to the Senate. I really expect a call from Hollywood late in the spring session once we start on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be speaking for very long on this motion. However, I will probably speak for longer than the one-eighth of the time that we would have if everything was fair and averaged out in this chamber. I will not speak for long because, as I said earlier, it does not seem to the Australian Democrats that this is the most gripping issue ever raised in the Senate. I am absolutely staggered yet again to hear that Government senators will have a conscience vote on this. There always seems to be a conscience vote by the Government when we are dealing with procedures in this place, but not when we are dealing with the future of the East Timorese, just as one example.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Democrats have had a position for a long time on the question of the televising of parliament. We believe that the people of Australia have a right to see as well as to hear parliamentary proceedings. Since we moved into this new House of Parliament where all the facilities exist for that to be possible for the people of Australia, we have said that should happen. We are delighted that the Opposition has now a position on this. As I also said earlier, we are very happy to move this through today with some speed because we would not want the Opposition to change its mind.

I congratulate Senator Vanstone for the role that she has played in putting forward this motion. I am not absolutely sure why that position has been finally arrived at by the Opposition. Senator Vanstone seemed to allude to the fact that the Opposition seemed to believe first, as we all do, that this will soon move to the House of Representatives and that there the Opposition appears to believe that it can actually join the charisma stakes with its new leader, Dr Hewson. That, of course, remains to be seen.

I will not rehearse all of the substantive issues, but Senator Ray raised the question of how we might be seen and what the media often does about what goes on in this place. It seems to me that, in fact, the direct televising, albeit of excerpts and of Question Time, in some ways might lead to a better representation of what goes on in this place in the media generally. Sometimes one can go home late at night and switch on the television or radio and hear reports which do not seem to bear a great deal of resemblance to what actually went on here during the day. This may very well be an excellent exercise in that respect.

While we support Senator Vanstone's motion, we do have some fairly serious reservations. The first part of the proposal is that there be a direct broadcast of Question Time. We have not previously come out publicly on this matter. We believe that Question Time is not a direct, clear and honest representation of the daily and nightly work of this place. Indeed, Question Time in the Senate can sometimes be a deadly boring exercise. But it is seen in general parliamentary terms as a time for demonstrating all sorts of talents which do not necessarily go to the substantive work of the Parliament.

However, I have some hope that with the passage of this motion both the Opposition and the Government might lift their game here in this place. It has been a bit somnolent at Question Time these last couple of weeks. It will be a challenge to Opposition senators to do better than their counterparts in the House of Representatives in putting Ministers on the spot, something which I think has been lacking, particularly in this four weeks of sitting.

It is a trial period, so we are prepared to accept the first part of the motion, the direct broadcast of Question Time, particularly as, as Senator Vanstone has told us, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is keen to take it on. That goes very much to what we have said about the right of Australians to have at least a better look than they have had before at what goes on in parliament. In saying that we do not think Question Time represents the essence of what goes on here, we will be looking at the results of that trial period very much in terms of the balance of what is used to show what does go on in the parliament. We are particularly concerned that the committee stage of legislation, for instance, should be shown because that is a very significant part of the work that is done here. It is not the least of the work that is done by this chamber in contrast to the other, a point which Senator Robert Ray alluded to. In this chamber things do happen; legislation is changed; debate sometimes, although too rarely, affects the final vote.

I am disappointed that in his contribution Senator Ray seemed to feel it necessary to indulge in a bit of character assassination of Senator Vanstone. I would not for one minute imagine that she wanted me to get up here and stand up for her, but I think this is a much more important issue than that. So we will not engage in character assassination nor mention the fact that perhaps one of the reasons for supporting this motion and supporting television broadcast of parliament is that perhaps no longer will the gentlemen on the front bench put their feet on the seats-Oh, everybody's frowning at me! It is a very common practice for the Ministers and people on the other side to stand in the way that men do and put their feet up on the furniture. I find it appalling. The furniture belongs to the Australian people and the Australian people will see those feet put on the furniture, if parliament is televised. Perhaps honourable senators will then not do it any more. I do not want the seat ruined by the time I get on the front bench. It is a common practice; I invite Senator McMullan to watch for it. Maybe he does not do it, but the taller men among us do quite often.

I am just wondering about Senator McKiernan's ties and what will happen to them when we start televising parliament. His tie is very dull tonight. He might find it necessary to pick up some new ones to match the one he had on last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about my socks?

—If Senator McKiernan puts his feet on the seat we will see his socks. The Australian people will see a great deal revealed to them in this exercise. One of the things I look forward to is the Australian people seeing by means of television the fact that come 1 July on these Democrat benches half of the senators will be women. For us that will provide quite a positive part of the exercise. The Australian people I think will see the difference, as I have said, between the House of Representatives and the Senate if there is fair reporting. They will see that in the other place the gag is applied and the debate means nothing, but that in this chamber, as Senator Ray alluded to, since 1980 and the balance of power being held by the Australian Democrats, there has been a different chamber from the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, after that trial period we will be looking very much at what was produced, what was shown. In revising the trial period and deciding whether televising of proceedings goes on, we will put emphasis on the value of what was used. Now that the Senate is about to move into the twenty-first century we hope to make the way which will be followed by the House of Representatives, a system of operation that is right and proper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to wonder whether it is possible for the Senate to be given an indication as to what might be the cost to the Senate if the resolution is adopted. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, I think it would be desirable for us to be apprised of what the cost to the Senate would be. It may well be that there is no cost whatsoever, as Senator Vanstone seemed to indicate. If that is the case, there is not much point in my continuing.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention, though, my future fears about what might happen to broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, whether that be by radio or by television. We have seen what has happened to radio. The broadcasts have been isolated to unknown bands and very few people listen to parliamentary broadcasts. Maybe it was 3 or 4 per cent previously but that has probably dropped now to 0.5 per cent because people cannot find it. It is difficult to get the bands. People are not used to them. It seems to me that they are difficult to tune into. Am I correct in this? The other thing which is quite possibly coming down the track is the demand by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation that the parliamentary broadcasts stations should be paid for by the Parliament rather than by the ABC. Now one of the very important functions of the ABC was to broadcast proceedings of parliament. I think that has been its responsibility and it still remains its responsibility. I just make that indication here, during the discussions, so that honourable senators will think about that and not accept that the responsibility for paying for the broadcasting of parliament should be a matter for parliamentary appropriations.
Amendment (Senator Robert Ray's) agreed to.
Original motion (Senator Vanstone's), as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal-National Party coalition does not oppose the amendments currently before the Senate. The changed date-now 9 May-from the House of Representatives is the day the matter was introduced into Parliament and that fits the criteria outlined during the original Senate second reading debate on luxury cars. The Opposition's stand on this issue highlights its concern about the Government's tendency to legislate by press release-a concern which is clearly shared by the Australian Democrats and has been commented on by organisations such as the Australian Law Council. We believe that the coalition's stand has been vindicated by a recent report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills which welcomed our amendment. The changed date fits the criteria that we previously set down. We do not oppose the changed date.

—It is proper for me under the Standing Orders to ask a question of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer about the amendments which are before us. What does the Government expect to receive between now and 23 August 1990 by way of sales tax as a result of this measure? In other words, what I am trying to seek from the Parliamentary Secretary, now or later, is an indication of the amount of money that the Government will get as a result of sales tax on luxury cars. I want to assess whether it was in fact worth while financially to bring the House of Representatives back to consider this particular matter.
—It was not only for a Bill. It was a matter of four or five Bills.
—Well-just as a matter of interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

As Senator Harradine would know, the Government has assessed the full year revenue for the next financial year at $105m. We have not put out an estimate for 1 May or 9 May because it is almost impossible to work out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills have the effect of increasing the maximum rate of wool tax to 20 per cent. The coalition's decision to support the 20 per cent tax is based on a number of factors. I also draw to the Senate's attention that we have been alerted to the fact that tomorrow we will be considering further amendments with regard to the Wool Marketing Act which deal with guarantees relating to loans. This legislation will probably be brought in and made cognate with the debate on these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: This is so typical of the last minute haste with which the Hawke Labor Government deals with legislation on very important issues. Of course, there are administrative and commercial complications. I refer all honourable senators to the debate in the House of Representatives, where the Wool Tax Amendment Bills were debated on 17 May. They were guillotined through with very little debate. There was just no time allowed for any significant debate to take place. By comparison, I refer honourable senators to the speakers list that I have seen floating around which implies that there will be many speakers in this place taking an interest. It is a pity that this Government will not allow substantive, proper and good debate in the House of Representatives, where these matters should be under proper consideration.

Many important historical considerations should be taken into account. The wool industry extends back to the early part of the nineteenth century, and Australia has never had extremely high prices for wool for more than a season and a half. I refer particularly to the speeches of the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, the honourable member for Barker, Mr Ian McLachlan, and the honourable member for Parkes, Mr Michael Cobb, in the House of Representatives. They were three of about four or five Opposition spokesmen that were able to speak on this issue. Of course, they all have portfolio, electorate and personal interests that are very close to this matter.

I remind the honourable senator that the floor price was put in place for stability, for predictability, and for a smoothing of the price mechanisms which, it was hoped, would advantage buyers and flow on to growers. As Ian McLachlan said in the House of Representatives when he was referring to the 1970s:

Initially, provision was made in the early 1970s for only a flexible reserve-one that followed the market up and down on a daily or weekly basis. The early legislation did not make provision for what we now call the reserve price or the floor price until 1974. The basis of the floor price was a price below which we would not sell our commodity to the world . . . it was a price which was to give predictability to the growers . . .
It was also to provide predictability for the buyer from other nations. He then outlined a number of reasons for our current wool surplus:
. . . first, . . . we have never had a disappearance, as the term goes, of wool in any one year that is the equivalent of this year's wool clip . . .

Secondly, the age-old move from wheat to an alternative product has been around during the 1980s when the wheat industry found international prices totally unsatisfactory. Thirdly, we have had a run of extremely good seasons in Australia . . . Fourthly, . . . we have had a reserve price which, as it turns out . . . has been too high; it has been above the long term trend line.
He also pointed out that China, Russia and eastern Europe have been in a doubtful state in the commercial arena.

The wool industry is our greatest industry. It is our most efficient industry and our largest industry. On a net basis, wool is still our most significant export. As an industry, it is significant for Australia for research and promotion. Only a year or two ago it was bringing $500m a month into this country from sales. That has now fallen on average to less than $300m a month, impacting greatly on our balance of payments. Of course, the issue is complex and we often need to trace why and where things have happened in the legislative sense. The Wool Tax Acts are part of the greater wool legislation which was passed in 1987, of which the Wool Marketing Act was the major piece, setting the structure for the Bill. I quote from the second reading speech of the then Minister for Science, Mr Barry Jones, in the other House:

It is not appropriate in this regard for the Australian Wool Corporation to be hampered in its ability to operate commercially. It cannot be expected to seek frequently ministerial or government approvals for corporate financial decisions. It is also fundamentally wrong for major decisions on the finances and market operations of the Australian Wool Corporation, such as decisions on the minimum reserve price, to be taken in a political environment. If the Australian Wool Corporation is to act as an autonomous commercial body it must have financial arrangements established, as far as possible, on a commercial basis like any other business organisation. The Bill introduces a number of changes to ensure this. It also establishes a proper relationship on financial matters between the Australian Wool Corporation, the Government and the Wool Council of Australia.

With the progress of time, it is interesting to note how the Government's statements are now either inconsistent or rather hypocritical. In the reply by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, to the second reading debate in the House of Representatives on 17 May 1990, he said:
The Government too has to make sure that decisions we take guarantee this industry's viability.
He continued:
I believe that Cabinet Ministers have a prime responsibility to stand back from some of the industry politics in these issues and try to take a decision in the national interest.
When Mr Kerin went to the Wool Council of Australia conference in Roma on 23 May 1990, he said:

In 1987 I gave the power to set the MRP to the Australian Wool Corporation after consultation with the Australian Wool Council. I made a mistake in believing the Corporation was strong enough to take purely commercial decisions about fundamental commercial issues such as the level of the MRP. I did not forsee the industry political pressure put on grower members of the Board to push up the price.
He posed the question: Why will the Government not let the wool industry do what it wants? He said:
. . . the core of the government's concern is that without a full analysis of the facts and options, the industry may take a decision that sends it bankrupt and ends the MRP scheme.
He continued:

I am prepared to base my judgments about your future on wild optimism. From your perspective, the cost of servicing a debt of up to $4 billion along with declining equity in wool stocks, must be very worrying.
Let us remember Senator Button's second reading speech, which was incorporated in Hansard on 11 May 1990. It states:
The recommendations of the Wool Council of Australia are taken into account in setting the actual limits.
It continued:

In setting the maximum wool tax rate at 20 per cent, the Government is of the view that this rate is consistent with an appropriate mix of policy measures designed to ensure the continued viability of the wool industry and the reserve price system itself.

It is about time the Federal Government took responsibility for the difficulties facing the wool industry and accepted that its economic policies have caused the current difficult and complicated situation to arise.

The truth is that because of an inflated dollar Australian products are too expensive for overseas buyers. In the wool industry the situation is exacerbated by a high interest component in the cost of storage. The Wool Corporation claims that until the Government intervened, 70 per cent of wool on offer was sold. It also predicts that buyers will return once the rumours and uncertainty are taken out of our market-uncertainty created by the speculative comments of John Kerin and Paul Keating in the past month. If we had an affordable interest rate regime and if the Australian dollar reflected its own worth, Australia would have more overseas sales, fewer bales in store and less debt, and the floor price would not be an issue. While Minister Kerin has been claiming for days prior to this week's Cabinet decision that he had the power to intervene in setting the floor price, he would do better to turn his efforts to obtaining a more affordable interest rate and establishing a better dollar value.

The Labor Government has effectively created a situation where uncertainty and speculation prevails. If it were not for the Kerin intervention which has destabilised wool sales, sales of wool would still be proceeding normally. The speculation which has been associated with the recent debate on the floor price has resulted in extreme uncertainty and massive cost to the Corporation and to growers. It is the industry's right and responsibility to determine the floor price. The Wool Council recommended the lifting of the 10 per cent maximum to 25 per cent to give greater flexibility and greater grower equity in the fund. The Wool Corporation also recommended 25 per cent, but made the further point that it can borrow better with that level and that there may be a need to increase the promotion levy to move more of the coarser wools which are not selling as well. Both made the point about having a good safe buffer between the operating level and the maximum levy.

Yesterday's press releases of the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation are still trenchant with criticism of the Labor Government. The Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr Hugh Beggs, said:

I shall not endeavour to explain the Minister's rationale, that is his job, but I will say that the Board of the Corporation does take and always has taken very seriously its charter under the Wool Marketing Act.
The major parts of this are twofold:
(i) to increase the commercial returns to the Australian woolgrower; and
(ii) that the performance of its function and the exercise of its powers do not conflict with major Government policies.
I refuse to accept that in the Corporation's submission either of these factors was neglected. The result is that of the Minister's judgment overriding that of the AWC, and on his own head be it.
Mr Mac Drysdale of the Wool Council of Australia said:

General mismanagement of the Australian economy is obviously not enough for this Government. Its political intervention in the wool industry shows that it is unaware that it is destroying Australia's economy, industry by industry. Until today, the wool industry was one of the remaining few export industries this country could be truly proud of.

It seems that the Labor Government has become the destroyer of industries. Last year the Government destroyed the $5 billion tourism industry through its intervention in the pilots dispute. This year it is the wool industry's turn for the political and economic guillotine. We need to ask again why there is this legislative rush. I refer honourable senators to the debate in the House of Representatives on 17 May when debate was gagged. It became so very evident that it was this interventionist role that Ministers Keating and Kerin wished to pursue.

I have already stated the issues related to the interest rate policy, the overvalued dollar, the fact that the value of a bale of wool dissipated totally within four years at these interest rates. Ian McLachlan said in the debate in the other place:

When interest rates are held up, one is paying out much higher interest rates, than would otherwise be the case, because our dollar is higher, buyers from the other end of the world are not able to buy our wool at the same price.

It is important that we look at the costs associated with the stockpile. The current cost of storing a bale of wool is approximately $220. Interest payments amount to about $180, while storage costs $40. When it gets to the stage of stockpiling 2.8 billion bales by the end of this season, there is an unacceptable amount of dead interest going out to lenders. This consequently forces up prices and leads to higher costs of production.

The Federal Government should give woolgrowers a break and get on with the job of restructuring the labour market, cleaning up the waterfront, injecting competition into coastal shipping and obtaining substantial improvements in road and rail transport. Continued absence of progress in these areas will keep costs high, not only for woolgrowers but for all Australians. Substantial benefits are to be had from such reforms which the coalition has adopted as firm policies and accorded the highest priority. Unfortunately, the Government's past record indicates that it lacks the willpower to implement these urgently needed reforms.

There are many things that we could say about this issue, but I am mindful of the fact that there are many other speakers to be heard in this debate. Although the Opposition believes that as a general rule the wool industry should be allowed to set its own floor price, it accepts the Government's decision to reduce the floor price for wool to 700c so that confidence once again can return to the market. While the industry's floor price recommendation was not accepted by the Government, there will now be a firm floor price which will allow the industry and buyers to plan for the future with confidence. There are many buyers just waiting for a firm price to recommence their purchasing. The industry must move on to the positive task of marketing our wool and putting this industry back in shape. The Opposition has made a decision which I believe is strong and sensible, a decision to support the wool tax amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Panizza, I would indicate that although I did not interrupt the previous speaker, I would point out to him that when we are speaking of members of the other place we should use the proper mode of address rather than use a given name and a surname or just a surname only.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating, perhaps before I had expected, the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1990. I assure the Senate that I speak as an active and long-experienced woolgrower. I acknowledge the importance of the wool industry, and my colleague Senator Tambling has already pointed that out. The wool industry has been Australia's biggest income earner for most of the past 30-odd years, and probably beyond that.
