It is only in the past 18 months that coal has surpassed wool as an export earner. However, once the marketing system has been sorted out and more confidence is brought back into that system among world buyers, I believe that the industry will approach the $5 billion of export earnings mark again.

SPEECH.PARA: Wool is an industry that covers all of Australia. Whereas industries such as the gold industry or the iron ore industry are isolated mostly in Western Australia, the wool industry has its operations everywhere. It goes from the biggest station in the Kimberleys to the wheat belts of Western Australia and the wheat belts and traditional sheep areas of the eastern States, down to the small 10-acre lot owned by the weekend farmer; and indeed right down to the hobby farm. Therefore, what happens to the wool industry is felt throughout Australia. The wool industry is a great employer of people, and has potentially vast downstream benefits, provided that technology is introduced into Australia and there is the will in this country to provide such benefits.

I am a great believer in and defender of the reserve price scheme operated by the Australian Wool Commission, in the first instance in the early 1970s, and later under the Australian Wool Corporation. I can remember the disastrous prices that existed in the late 1960s and early 1970s. If one traces back the history of wool in Australia, since World War II when prices took off and when there was the old cry of `a pound for a pound' in about 1951, we see that the industry operated through a vast number of ups and downs for some 20 years. It was forced from the high prices of 1951 to virtually a bottom price during the Cold War period of 1954-55. There was a resurgency in the industry in 1956, which persisted until around the early 1960s. It was a total disaster in the early 1970s and credit must be given to those from our side of politics who brought in a reserve price scheme.

That reserve price scheme worked slightly differently from the way in which it works now, but at that stage it was the beginning of what I believe to be a pretty good scheme. In 1970 wool was around 30c a kilo on average. Within two years the price had gone up to 100c and then a year after that it was back to 28c on average. That was when the scheme came in-around 1972.

I am afraid to say that the management of the industry by the Corporation leaves a little to be desired. Let us look at the reasons for setting up the scheme in the first place. I have already mentioned the wild fluctuations. The reserve price scheme was meant to iron out the potholes; it was not intended to put up the price of wool to beyond the natural line, what the industry would pay on a long-term basis. Since the beginning of that reserve price scheme in 1972, it has worked very well except for a couple of worrying stockpiles on the way. However, the Corporation was able to clear them-and at a profit, I might add.

In 1986 there was a steep climb in wool prices due to world conditions. The zenith was reached in January 1988. Between 1986-87 and 1988-89, the reserve price increased from 508c a kilo to 870c a kilo. This was where the Corporation went wrong. The market had peaked in January 1988 at about 1300c a kilo on average. On 1 July 1988 the Corporation, with the advice of the Wool Commission, decided to increase the reserve price. As a woolgrower at the time, running my family corporation, I reckoned that that was not a very wise move. There was a great deal of contention around Australia as to whether that price should go up. Anyhow, the increase went ahead.

From the peak time of January 1988 to July of that year when the Corporation put the reserve price up to 870c, the indicator-that is the average floor price-had already dropped from 1300c to 1000c per kilo. Except for an upward trend in May 1988, the decline had been quite gradual and consistent. However, it remained consistent until the market indicator and the floor price actually met in November 1989. It has been nothing short of disaster ever since. The Corporation has been forced to buy too much wool. I have a chart here to illustrate what I said about the indicator peaking in January 1988 or thereabouts and then declining steeply. By October 1988 it had declined so much that it was almost meeting the reserve price. The reserve price and the indicator met in November 1989. I seek leave to have this chart incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The chart read as follows-
[CHART NOT INCLUDED ON DATABASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1639]

TALK.START.PARA: —When those two lines met, the Corporation had to start buying. The stockpile climbed quickly to 2.5 million bales and is now in the vicinity of three million bales and still rising.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point let me say without qualification that the only decision that this Senate has to make is to set the ceiling of the wool tax. The reserve price is definitely and entirely a matter for the Corporation to determine, except in certain circumstances relating to the powers vested in the Minister. We all know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) acted on those powers today. However, in arriving at the decision to set the maximum tax level, one must examine the reasons for doing so. In other words, in agreeing to the 20 per cent, the line that we have taken, we must look at how we came to that decision.

I have already said that the actions of the Corporation can be questioned. I have also pointed out that I support the reserve price scheme, even though I do not support every aspect of that scheme. The floor price of the scheme is inflexible at present, except in cases where there is an upward trend. The floor price, as set now within the present scheme, does not allow for certain things-mainly fluctuations in the value of the Australian dollar. Most importantly, it does not allow for consideration of the level of production. Production is mentioned very little in this debate. The floor price does not allow for political considerations or for production in other countries. We know that South Africa and New Zealand are good producers of wool. But now there are producers in Uruguay and Chile, and even some in China. Therefore, world wool production is rising. Also, the present floor price does not allow for overseas trends such as the use of synthetics and the fashions that predominated last year or will predominate this year and next year.

The greatest single factor is that the reserve price does not follow the value of the Australian dollar. When the present reserve price was set in 1988, the Australian dollar was worth US69.8c. I will come back to that later, but probably the fact that the Australian dollar was so low was the major factor is stimulating demand for wool overseas which caused the high prices. When the wool chaos set in earlier this year the Australian dollar was almost US80c. It is all very well for us in Australia to receive a fluctuating income but we have to look at the manufacturer's side of the story-the wool that they are buying to turn into garments. They will keep using any commodity that has a reasonably static price, with a certain built-in allowance for inflation and those sorts of things. However, when the price moves wildly, the manufacturers get into trouble.

When the Australian dollar reached almost US80c, in order to keep the price of wool stable at the factory door, the Australian reserve price should have been reduced to 746c a kilo. To keep the price stable that is what the base price should have gone down to. The yen, and my colleague Senator Archer gave me this figure today, has appreciated over that time by 14.7 per cent; my quick calculation on the American dollar, is around 14 per cent. There was a sudden rise that threw them and made their wool that much dearer. It then had to be reflected in their buying.

I suggest that this scheme will be around for a long time but it will have to be refined. The scheme started off reasonably well in 1971-72, and we have had a certain amount of refinement. In the last five or six years when wool prices have been pretty good we have not had enough refinement. Perhaps the scheme should be altered to set the reserve price in United States currency. I believe that the United States currency is the one to use, for various reasons. Firstly, it is a currency that is commonly used; and, secondly, because of America's low imports of wool from Australia, any change would not tend to distort the market as much. My suggestion is that it be linked to a currency that would keep the wool price reasonably static at the factory door. I know that at the time this would have meant a lower price to wool growers. I fully admit that. But a higher dollar can be reflected in the cost of other imports such as farm materials, for example, and machinery, and that would also make the figures decline. That is something for the Corporation to look at in the future.

I come now to the level of production. There were high prices in 1987, 1988 and 1989. In 1986 we had a glut of wheat and the price of wheat dropped away. We had a few problems then, and Senator Walsh kept reminding us that the minimum price was triggered and the Government paid out some $184m on it. That is a small figure compared with our problems in the wool industry now.
A lot of wheat growers, not all but a good majority, have turned to wool. Australia's wheat plantings have gone down by 22 per cent since 1986 so they have turned over to wool.

Let us look at the figures: in 1987-88 Australia had 157 million sheep. In 1988-89 we had 166 million. In 1989-90 it is projected that there will be 172 million, and the projection for 1990-91 is 174 million. I have a chart which shows that just after the War, in 1945-46, Australia had 89.4 million sheep. The figures show that we have had a gradual climb in sheep numbers. At this stage I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a chart which shows the number of sheep in Australia. I do so subject to the Minister giving the okay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister is more concerned about the source of the information that you wish to table.
—He can read it for himself.
—Is the source of this table the Commodity Statistical Bulletin?
—It says that down the bottom.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cook

TALK.START.PARA: —I will accept it on the basis that that is the source.

INTERJECT.PARA: TABLE 28: SUMMARY OF AUSTRALIAN STATISTICS FOR WOOL

a Sheep and lambs. b At 31 March. c In July-June year. d In farm bale equivalents Australian wool held by the Joint Organisation both in Australia and overseas from 1945-46 to 1950-51, by the Australian Wool Board in 1970-71 and 1971-72 and by the Australian Wool Corporation from 1972-73. No official stocks held between 1950-51 and 1970-71. pPreliminary. sEstimated.

Sources: ABS (1989), Livestock and Livestock Products, Australia: 1987-88, Cat. No. 7222 0. Canberra (and previous issues); ABS (1982), Livestock, Australia: 1980-81, Cat. No. 7203 0, Canberra (and previous issues); ABS (1989), Selected Agricultural Commodities, Australia: 1988-89, Cat. No. 7112.0, Canberra; Australian Wool Corporation (1989), Annual Report: 1988-89, Melbourne (and previous issues); National Council of Wool Selling Brokers of Australia (1989), Wool Review: 1988-89, Melbourne (and previous issues); Australian Wool Products Forecasting Committee; Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for not having shown it to the Minister, but I was told that this Bill would be debated tomorrow. I thank the Senate. We have had an increase in production per head of sheep of 10 per cent in the last five years. A fair amount of that rise since 1945 has been in the last seven or eight years. Production since 1950 has been up 30 per cent. In the last six years alone there has been an increase in the cut of 0.2 of a kilogram.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had no consideration of political circumstances. China has had its Tiananmen Square problem, and for reasons of its own stopped buying wool. Russia has had economical problems and it cut down on purchases. Eastern Europe has been going through a restructuring, and we welcome that restructuring. Those countries will prove to be good buyers of wool in the days to come. But at the present moment they have their own problems so they are not buying wool.

I have already canvassed the production of wool overseas. In Uruguay, Argentina, Chile, South Africa, Canada and New Zealand the production of wool is rising. One has to look at the overseas trend line. The pricing of overseas wool is below Australia's price and is biting into our markets. The demand of fashion for lighter and lighter materials has to be taken into consideration. In the past 18 months alone the use of wool has dropped from 500 grams per linear metre to 360 grams per linear metre in high quality woollen garments for men and women's wear. This has reduced demand by 24 per cent.

The climate in the Northern Hemisphere has also affected the industry. The last three winters in the Northern Hemisphere have been unusually warm. I will not go into any debate on this, as there are no Australian Democrats here to suggest why that might be. This could be a temporary phase and I certainly hope so, but it has cut down the use of wool. The climate in the Northern Hemisphere has resulted in a marked increase in the installation of internal heating in houses. This means lesser clothing for internal use. Electric blankets, believe it or not, have become popular in the Northern Hemisphere in the last four or five years. All of these things have had an effect on wool sales.

The use of synthetics during the high price period has dramatically increased. I will refer later to what the New South Wales farmers have had to say about that. Synthetic diameter sizes range between six and 15 microns so they are very handy to use in fine materials. They have a great advantage for the manufacturer. The best one can get out of wool is 15 microns. Hopefully there is a new chemical treatment around the corner which will reduce the micron in wool to reduce the diameter of the fibre. I hope that that will rescue wool.

Let us examine the options that the Corporation has, or had, available. It had three options. Option A was its own preferred option, to keep the levy at 870c per kilo and 25 per cent tax. With this option, at the end of five years, in 1994-95, we would have outside borrowings of $2.74 billion, maximum borrowings of $3.5 billion and a stockpile of 5.184 million bales. Option B was for 870c per kilo and a levy of 20 per cent. After five years the Corporation would have had outside borrowings of $3.292 billion, a stockpile of 5.4 million bales and maximum borrowings of $3.987 billion.

Option C involved a 700c per kilo floor price and a 20 per cent levy. In five years the Corporation would have no outside borrowings, a stockpile of 1.9 million bales and maximum borrowings of $2.103 billion. Let us ponder those maximum borrowings of $3.4 billion or $3.9 billion under option A or B. It is more than the entire Australian wheat crop. It equals the Australian beef production. It is twice the production of gold. It is two-thirds the export of coal. Nearly $1 billion alone would have to be sent overseas to pay for interest alone. At this rate, as Senator Tambling pointed out, a bale of wool would cost $220 per bale to store and so consume itself in four years. If demand drops any further the stockpile could blow out to seven million bales. If the Corporation goes bankrupt, who will pick up the bill? I understand that tonight a new Bill is coming through to underwrite $2.5 billion of corporate borrowing.

Let us consider the example of the International Tin Council and see what happened when it interfered with the world prices. If we look at this year's appropriations, which we dealt with not so long ago, we will see that the Government has allocated over $1m to cover the tin losses. One also has to look at the strain on our overseas debt, which under this Government is already crippling. Our overseas debt is approaching $150 billion. That is because of the way this Government has handled the economy.

I believe that the industry must take stock of itself, get the stockpile moving and do its share to turn the economy around. Otherwise, in 12 months time the problem will be greater or it will be too late and a total disaster. Growers, including me, must look beyond the farm gate.

The Corporation's performance in the last 12 months has been lacking. In the past 12 months it has bought 43 per cent of the clip and exhausted $1.8 billion of the money it had in the bank. It made a further mistake last year when it repaid two revolving fund payments to growers in high wool years that the growers did not really want. That sort of money would have been very handy at present.

It is interesting to hear what different people around Australia have to say. I spoke to one wool handling firm which was strictly in favour of the levy going to 25 per cent. I spoke to another firm equally as big and it was just as interested as we are in setting the levy at 20 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 10 per cent?
—I presume that the firm that said that it favoured a 25 per cent levy had a lot of money loaned out on wool in the store and a lot of money out on farms. I think the other firm had better foresight.

SPEECH.PARA: There have also been other distortions, such as transferred income from the fine wool growers-I am not a fine wool grower; we are medium woolgrowers-to the 21- to 24-micron growers. Income has also been transferred from Australian wool growers to overseas woolgrowers; those growers have been able to get a better price. Our price has been artificially too high.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are laughing all the way to the bank.
—Obviously they are. Let us look at a few of the Wool Corporation's statements over the last few months:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no evidence to show that the 870c per kilo has caused a fall in demand and a consequent build-up of stockpile.

I do not have to tell you what has happened, Mr President; you know. Another statement was `The floor price has been accepted by the textile trade'. So why then has the trade bought less than half of our clip and the balance of its requirements overseas? Then there was the story about losses on the stockpile held. I did not hear any wool buyer or the Corporation complaining when wool prices were rising and they had a stockpile. If one is prepared to accept the gains on the way up one should accept the losses on the way down.

I quote a question asked at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference held in February 1990. The question was directed by Neil Inall, the Conference Chairman, to Hugh Beggs, Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation. It reads as follows:
Is a 15 per cent tax to growers too tough a medicine?
The answer was:
No. 15 per cent is about right. It gives us the credibility to maintain the policy we have and it sends a solid message to growers. If it turns out to be too much we can return it to growers.
The following question was asked by a concerned woolgrower in the last week:

If the wool tax has jumped within three months from 15 per cent to 25 per cent due to a downturn in the market, in the event of a further downturn in the market, what will be the increase of tax to the woolgrower?

In other words, in January the Corporation was happy with 15 per cent and was going to return some money. But now it is looking for 25 per cent. The Government has taken the line that it will allow a maximum of 20 per cent. The coalition has decided to support that move. I believe that it is a good position to take. It is the only position that we can take so this great industry of ours can sort itself out and go forward. For the reasons I have outlined I believe that anything else would be a great disaster.

There were a couple of other things I would have liked to have mentioned. If honourable senators have a chance to read it, I direct their attention to an advertisement by the New South Wales Farmers Association which appeared in the Australian this week. I was going to discuss it in detail. It states:
Wool is not a necessity and comprises only four per cent of the textile market. If the government makes the wrong decision, wool processors will be financially burnt . . .
If wool comprises only 4 per cent of the textile market, let us find a way to increase that market share-not a way to drive ourselves out of business.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cook) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MR J. M. CAMPBELL, PRINCIPAL PARLIAMENTARY REPORTER: RETIREMENT

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to formally advise the Senate of the retirement on 14 March this year of Mr John Martin Campbell, the Principal Parliamentary Reporter since February 1985, and to extend to him publicly the deep appreciation of the Parliament for his service.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Campbell, who was born in Brisbane, began his reporting career with the Queensland State Reporting Bureau in 1953. In August 1960 he joined the Parliamentary Reporting Staff in Canberra as a reporter and was promoted to senior reporter in May 1971, supervisor in May 1974, Leader of Staff in January 1979 and Assistant Principal Parliamentary Reporter in May 1981. As I have mentioned, he became Principal Parliamentary Reporter, the head of the Hansard department, in February 1985.

Throughout his long career with the Commonwealth Parliament, Mr Campbell earned the friendship and respect of very many members and senators who served in both Houses over that period. Had the Parliament sat earlier this year prior to Mr Campbell's retirement, the only member of either House who was in the Parliament when John Campbell came to Canberra would have been Tom Uren, the honourable member for Reid.

Hansard reporters are frequently the chroniclers of history, and during his service with Hansard Mr Campbell reported many momentous events in the Parliament, both in this building and in the provisional House. He observed seven Prime Ministers-Menzies, Holt, Gorton, McMahon, Whitlam, Fraser and Hawke-and recorded the historic joint sittings of the Parliament following the 1974 double dissolution.

Mr Campbell also witnessed the growth in the number and scope of committees of this Parliament. Early in his career he travelled throughout northern Australia on an inquiry into Aboriginal matters and subsequently travelled throughout Australia and Papua New Guinea with a diverse range of committees.
As head of Hansard, Mr Campbell represented the Commonwealth Parliament at the annual conferences of the Australasian Hansard Association and the Commonwealth Hansard Editors Association.

Throughout his dedicated service to the Parliament Mr Campbell ensured that the other aspects of human endeavour were not neglected. He has always been active in his church and committed to his family. Not surprisingly, given his Queensland origins, he is a keen football follower, but `converted', so to speak, to Australian Rules football during his period in Canberra.
On behalf of all honourable senators I wish Mr Campbell a long, enjoyable and productive retirement and sincerely thank him for his untiring efforts for this Parliament.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As this Senate term of the Thirty-fifth Parliament draws to a close, I wish to make some brief remarks about what has been a momentus three years both for me and, I am sure, all honourable senators. I would also like to take this opportunity again to pay tribute to the honourable senators who will not be returning when the new Senate takes its place in August, and note the departure of some other well-known faces during this Parliament.

INTERJECT.PARA: There have been many highlights in the last three years that can never be duplicated. I include amongst those the opening of the New Parliament House on 9 May 1988 by the Queen, the emotional farewell to the provisional Parliament House on 2 June 1988, and the first sitting in the new building. The move up the hill was one fraught with difficulties as daily more and more problems emerged that had to be dealt with. The actual achievement of that move was a milestone in removalist history and the officers of the Senate responsible did a great job.

In September 1988, the facilities of the New Parliament House were tested to their limits when we hosted the annual Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) Conference, which was an unqualified success. There were 43 Commonwealth countries in attendance with 400 delegates. As President of the CPA, I was proud to be a part of such a memorable event, and of all the staff involved in making it possible.

Throughout the bicentennial year, Canberra and this building played host to a constant stream of royal visitors, heads of state and other foreign dignitaries representing many nations and parliaments. This continued throughout 1989 until today.

The building and its occupants are, I believe, feeling quite settled now, although it has been a time of great change for all of us. The administration throughout this period has not been easy as there is always a large amount of resistance to change. Yet change has been a recurring and dominant theme in the past three years, both in our small context and in the world at large. It has been a personal highlight for me that I have been in this position of President of the Senate in these times. Leading the parliamentary delegation to eastern Europe in 1989 at an historic time of social upheaval and representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in southern Africa earlier this year at the same time as historical change was occurring there were fascinating experiences for me.

In turning now to our honourable senators who are departing, it must be said that they too were part of history. Senators Hamer, Black, Devlin, Morris, Puplick, Sheil, McGauran, Macklin, Jenkins and Dunn will not be returning in August and they shall all be missed. Keeping in mind that there are different reasons for their departure, I think, and hope, there are some we will see back in the future.

In the past Senator Chris Puplick and I have played Senate musical chairs. Three times I was on the Senate ticket in what I call the death spot. Twice I won, once I lost. But I returned, as I am sure Chris Puplick will. I will miss your contributions in the Senate chamber, Chris. Your departure means that the Senate will be deprived of one of its most erudite speakers and spirited debaters. I also greatly appreciated your bipartisan support on the bicentennial visit to the United States.

I think Senators Black and Jenkins will be back also. Senator Dunn, your career as a senator began in unusual and colourful circumstances. In your relatively brief time here, you have been an industrious worker for your constituency. I know I will miss your interpreting skills when delegations from the Soviet Union arrive.

Senator Glen Sheil will be sorely missed, particularly by the Senate tennis team, and me-by the Senate tennis team, because without him they face the prospect of losing to the members of the House of Representatives, and by me, because as the Senate Presiding Officer it will be my shout if we lose again.
Senator McGauran, you will leave this place knowing you have a major claim to fame in your achievement of having had your private senator's Bill, the End of War List Bill, passed by the Senate.

Senator Ray Devlin has been a great friend to the workers in this building as a dedicated shop steward. His farewell presentation from the Senate staff yesterday was a touching one and a measure of the high esteem in which he is regarded.

Senator Macklin, I will miss your expertise on the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, particularly with regard to the Parliamentary Information Systems Office services. Such a weighty contribution will be hard to duplicate.

Finally, to Senator David Hamer, my Deputy President and Chairman of Committees for the past 3 3/4 years, you have been a tremendous source of support and assistance at all times to me. Your service with Senate committees over 12 years has been prodigious and in your own right you have been a great reformer within the Standing Committee on Standing Orders and its successor, the Standing Committee on Procedure. You will be sorely missed.
I wish all honourable senators the very best in whatever their respective futures hold.

During this Thirty-fifth Parliament, we have also farewelled a number of other distinguished honourable senators, in particular, a number of Senate leaders. Earlier on, we saw the departures of Senator Susan Ryan, a well-respected Minister of this Government and great friend, and Senator Arthur Gietzelt, who had served the Senate for 18 3/4 years. More recently, Senator Fred Chaney left us for the other House. Senator Janine Haines, Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator John Stone, Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, Senator Messner and Senator Sanders all retired.
I have been informed that 1990 is not remarkable historically for the turnover in senators. But the number of resignations at the time of the election was unprecedented.

A number of officers of the Senate and the Parliament were also farewelled during the life of this Parliament. The previous Clerk of the Senate, Alan Cumming Thom, retired in 1988 after 33 years in service for the Department. Tom Wharton, Clerk Assistant, Bert Cooper, the Principal Parliamentary Attendant, who joined the staff of the Parliament 40 years previously and was given the membership of the Order of Australia on Australia Day 1990, and John Campbell, the Principal Parliamentary Reporter, who retired in March this year, were also farewelled.

In conclusion, as is customary and deserved at the end of a session, I would like to express my appreciation and best wishes to all those who play a role, no matter how big or small, in the day-to-day functioning of this building and my office. In particular, I would like to thank all the senior Senate staff who have given me so much guidance and assistance over the last three years.

As President of this Senate, the past three years have been hectic, exciting, often frustrating but overall extremely rewarding ones. I have greatly appreciated all your support and look forward to seeing you back in August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to join you in paying the Government's respects and good wishes to John Campbell and Bert Cooper, whom you mentioned. Apart from that, I would like very briefly to say a few words about, generically, the 15 honourable senators who are retiring either voluntarily or involuntarily. I have the advantage of a reasonable education-if I am wrong, Senator Puplick can correct me for the last time-and there is a line in Tennyson which states:

SPEECH.PARA: And may there be no moaning of the bar.
When I put out to sea.
What about:
Break, break, break,
On thy cold grey stones, O sea!

These are called the valedictories. Valedictions mean bidding farewell. At other times we have condolences which express sympathy. Some of us have a different view of it altogether and think, `You who are leaving shall not grow old as we who are left grow old'. But it depends very much on one's subjective point of view whether this should be a valediction or a condolence. For some people, this provides the first opportunity for an interface between the public and the private sector. I do not think it is as bad out there as some people say at Question Time and at other times in Senate debates.

I suppose in the Senate there is a strange sort of fellowship. We have very different points of view. Sometimes I think that the Senate is one of those places where social and cultural life could only be improved by nuclear war or something of that kind. I think we all feel that from day to day. On the other hand, because we are sort of potential recipients of an isolation allowance or something because we are here in Canberra, we do, I think, develop some fellowship and respect for each other as time goes by.

I just want to say a few words in that light about some of the honourable senators who are retiring. First of all, I would like to mention Senator Hamer. He has been Deputy President and Chairman of Committees under this Government for the past eight years and I think he has carried out those tasks with fairness and distinction. He has helped greatly with the smooth running of the chamber and made many speeches about deficiencies in coastal shipping and the waterfront which I almost know by heart now but I am not sure that we all know the answers. Generally, in terms of his fairness and the distinction with which he has behaved here, he has introduced a note of what I might call wardroom mahogany into the Senate over a number of years, and I personally appreciate that.

Senator Messner, of course, is not here at the moment but I mention him second because he represented South Australia for 14 years, was a Minister in the Fraser Government and served for a long time on the Opposition front bench.

Senator Sheil represented Queensland from 1974 to 1981 and again from 1984 to 1990. If I am noted for being one of the shortest Ministers in the Hawke Government, I must say Senator Sheil was one of the shortest Ministers in the Fraser Government, having served a term of only a few days. I will miss him particularly because I think in recent times he has exerted a great deal of intellectual discipline on Senator Boswell, and I worry about the National Party of Australia without that guiding hand, which has had a lot of experience in this place. We will have to see what happens in the Budget session.

Senator Puplick, whom I mentioned at Question Time yesterday in appreciation of his understanding and use of the English language, has, if I can put it this way, always added colour to this chamber. It is sad in a sense-although the Australian Labor Party is not deeply distressed about the fact-to see somebody who has been a bright flower here cut down before the flower fully came to bloom. I hope he will be back-not at the expense of the Labor Party, of course, but at the expense of one of the people up the end of the chamber. Of course, if Senator Puplick does come back, I shall not be here so he will have the last say. I am reminded of a funeral a few years ago which I attended compulsorily, representing the Government. John Gorton was there and I said to him afterwards, `When you die I will come to your funeral because I want to, not because I was sent'. He was then 73. He said, `On the country, John, when you die I will come to your funeral because I want to'. Senator Puplick, in that sense, will probably have the last say. I hope it it is not in a condolence motion, however.

The President has referred to Senator McGauran and his distinction in having a private member's Bill passed. He has also been important in seeing that Ron Boswell does his job, and I hope he will not be missed too much either.

I would like to say a special word about Senator Macklin. I do not like using dirty words in the Senate but Senator Macklin, I suspect, is a genuine moderate. Over many years he has contributed sensible, genuinely moderate and informed views to debate in the Senate, and I think he has done that with integrity and in a very forthright way. Even though he is a Democrat, I think he has been been quite influential in the Senate, and I must say that I personally will miss him. I thought he was one of those who added discipline to an otherwise undisciplined group, and I think that is important in any party and any organisation such as the Senate.
Senator Sanders, I must say, I have always regarded as a sort of amiable boy scout who for a few years stirred the possum here on environmental matters and is now doing it elsewhere.
Senator Jenkins, who I have not had the privilege of knowing well personally, I think has been a diligent spokesperson for her Party.

You, Mr President, referred to Senator Irina Dunn's unusual entry into the Senate. I do not think she will be remembered for that so much as for the fact that while she has been here she has been the resident threat expert on all issues. There is some expression that if there is a mess-up or a conspiracy, it is sure to be a mess-up. Senator Dunn has always subscribed to both theories, I think: it is either a mess-up or a conspiracy.

I want to mention three of my own colleagues. Senator Black will be very much remembered for his chairing of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts and the recent drugs in sport inquiry. Senator Ray Devlin, who has already been referred to, I think has been a great committee man in the Senate, especially on the Select Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I think he performed the sorts of functions you, Mr President, referred to, in a very decent and sensible way, and will be missed. I have not had the opportunity of knowing Senator John Morris well-indeed, none of us have! He was elected in 1984 from the New South Wales Legislative Council and will be remembered, I suppose, for that.
Mr President, I want to refer to three others who left the Senate voluntarily to try to become members of the House of Representatives. These are the last three senators to whom I wish to refer.

Senator Haines was the first woman leader of a national political party. She began her career here in 1977, filling a casual vacancy, and was then elected to the Senate in 1980. I put her in the same bracket as Senator Macklin but in a different way. I think she gave some rigour to the Australian Democrats party. It was my great pleasure-also difficulty-to have to negotiate with her on numerous occasions about government legislation, and in all my dealings with her I found her a very sensible, reasonable and honourable person to deal with. I am glad she did not succeed in Kingston because I had a bet with her that she would not, but I wish her well in any career she is now following.

My colleague Senator Walsh has, I think, publicly praised Senator Stone. That is something I would not dare to do but Senator Walsh has always been more courageous than I have on those matters. Senator Stone is one of the few public servants who have had a career in politics. He brought with him a refreshing vigour in this chamber, and he took it with him when he contested the seat of Fairfax.

Last, but not least, I would like to pay tribute to Fred Chaney. I said of Margaret Guilfoyle when she left in 1987 that we had enjoyed a mild flirtation across the chamber over many years. I cannot say that about Fred. One of the greatest political enigmas of this period of politics will be the question why Fred left. He said it was because of me, that he just got bored being opposite me for seven years. But once again, although we both probably got bored, we developed some mutual respect and friendship. Of course, he is the only person to leave this place and succeed in winning a House of Representatives seat, and I personally wish him well in that career.

A distinguished or, depending on your point of view, undistinguished Prime Minister of Great Britain, Harold Wilson, once said that politics is like a game of musical daggers: it is disastrous to get caught holding the last dagger when the music stops. For some of our colleagues the music has stopped and I wish them well as I do others who will be continuing in politics. As I said at the beginning, I think in spite of all our differences and the perverse environment in which we live and work-I am not referring to the building, although I could be-there is an atmosphere of fellowship here which is seen on occasions like this. So on behalf of my colleagues I wish all those retiring the best future that is possible for them, whether it be in another career or in retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also briefly on behalf of those on this side of the chamber wish to use this opportunity in a formal way to say farewell and good luck to a number of colleagues who are leaving us at the end of this parliamentary session. Before doing so, I also wish to join with you, Mr President, and with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in thanking all of those who serve the Parliament and who serve us and who do their best to try to make our lives a little easier in this somewhat difficult and frustrating environment. I particular join with you in wishing well Mr Campbell and Mr Cooper after their very long service.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the Government said, some 15 senators are leaving us on this occasion. It was interesting to have heard tonight that it is not out of the ordinary. It seemed a great number to me. But on our side of the chamber there are some seven and they will be sorely missed. I also wish to take a few moments, if I may, just to make particular reference to a number of them.

I have not chosen any particular order, but I would also like to start with our good friend, Senator David Hamer, particularly for the enormous contribution that he has put in over a considerable period of time but particularly in recent times in his role as Deputy President and the reforms that he has brought upon us that some are looking forward to with enthusiasm and some with less enthusiasm, after our very recent experience. David Hamer, during his time in the Senate, has been committed to the institution and to improving it and enhancing it in the public eye. That is something for which I believe we should be grateful.

As a Liberal, I am also grateful for the contribution that he has made to politics on my side generally, both in this chamber and in the House of Representatives. His well-crafted speeches on coastal shipping have been referred to, but he has made a contribution in so many other areas; I think particularly of defence-as a former distinguished naval officer that is not surprising-foreign affairs generally, and a number of different areas. He has a right to be very proud of his contribution as an Australian parliamentarian. Certainly we on this side of the chamber, and I am sure all senators, are proud of the contribution that he has made.

Secondly, still in no particular order, I refer to my very good friend, Chris Puplick, who was twice elected to this chamber. David Hamer was once in another chamber and came back here. Like the Leader of the Government, I have little doubt that Chris will return. No-one doubts his skills as an orator. No-one doubts his contribution as a parliamentarian and certainly no-one on this side of the chamber doubts his contribution as a Liberal. We will miss you, Chris, as you are going to depart the Senate for a while, but we do thank you for your efforts.

Although we might have found the environment debate somewhat difficult in the last election campaign, when I think of Chris Puplick and the environment or the arts or any of the other areas to which he has been particularly devoted, I must say he has done his bit to enhance those particular areas of interest for the benefit of all Australians. That is something of which he can be proud and for which we should be grateful. So we wish you well, Chris, and look forward to your early return.

Glen Sheil has been mentioned. You may not know, Mr President, that Glen and I shared breakfast for a long time in this place. After his morning tennis Glen would order his breakfast before he left his room and expected it to be on the table as he arrived. He struck up a special relationship with the staff and they made marmalade for him to his particular recipe. It was all part of a rather friendly routine by which one could start what sometimes did not end up as a friendly day. I will miss Glen and his fine and wise counsel. I think many others in this place will probably miss his medical skills as well. But he has made his contribution. Glen, we wish you well in your retirement from this place.

Julian McGauran has been mentioned. It is hardly worth mentioning Julian as there is no doubt he will be back because we have given him a guarantee. Chris Puplick might say that some get special advantages. If it is not unkind to say so, I can tell the whole chamber that Julian is in fact learning because he is here tonight, and that is without the bells ringing! So, Julian, we look forward to your return and to your making a contribution to your party and our side of the chamber.

Tony Messner, of course, left a little while ago. I came after Tony into the Senate from my State. Tony possessed fine political skills. I guess he was a little unlucky in some ways in that the time in which he was high in the pecking order in our shadow ministries were the years in which we were losing elections. That is part of the luck of this business, it seems.

TALK.START.PARA: —That hasn't changed.

—It is changing, I think. If Senator Button sticks around a little while longer, he will find that out. But Tony Messner has left for a business career after giving many years of service to the Senate. We appreciate that and wish him well.

SPEECH.PARA: John Stone has been mentioned. He was not here long, but he certainly added to the intellectual rigour of the place and I guess his tussles with Peter Walsh were a highlight.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a mutual admiration society.
—We learnt that afterwards.
—We knew it all along.

—Yes. He is going to be down in Melbourne, I gather, and perhaps if Peter retires, as some suspect, he will go back to the tractor and they will engage in their intellectual economic tussles through the media with their respective columns. John Stone we similarly wish well in his future, whatever that might be.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Chaney was referred to and, of course, in succeeding him in this job I want to make particular mention of our appreciation of the leadership he gave on this side of the chamber. He showed a determination to get to the other place and he ultimately succeeded in that ambition. We trust that when he looks back in years to come he finds that the decision to move was a good one because in many ways his qualities seem to us to be the qualities of a senator. Certainly his contribution as a Minister and as leader of our side in opposition are appreciated and recognised.

On the Australian Labor Party side, Senator Morris is leaving. I have to agree with the Leader of the Government, I do not know Senator Morris well either, but I read in the papers that apparently he has other interests, so he will probably not be struggling in his retirement. I also read that he has been in ill health, so I hope that he recovers his health quickly.

Senator Devlin, again, I did not know well. It is interesting to learn upon his retirement the role which he played as shop steward for the staff in this place. You may have heard the interjection from someone on our side of the chamber that you might have played the same role for senators. I suspect later tonight they might be calling for some assistance to help them in their remuneration packages and other benefits. We wish you well in your retirement.
Senator Black, I understand, is another one who has some sort of understanding that guarantees his return.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the Labor Party.

—Not in the Labor Party? We recognise his contribution. As someone else said, the drugs in sport inquiry, for better or for worse, will probably be his contribution that is remembered most in years to come.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin, I guess, is someone to whom I was really quite close because of the similar sort of work we have done here over the last seven, eight or nine years. I will miss his dedication to the task and, I think, his intellectual contribution as well. I hope he takes this in good spirit. Like all Australian Democrats, he has taken himself very seriously, I might say. Nevertheless, I think he can look back on his contribution to the Senate with pride also. He is interesting in that he is one of those rare occurrences of a senator who seems to be retiring in his prime. It is probably a good lesson to all of us to remember that there is another life out there that is worth while, with new challenges, and not to become fixed in this place or to believe that it cannot exist without us, as seems to be the belief of so many.

I suppose my closest contact with Senator Jenkins was when I was shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory. We locked horns on such issues as the casino and self-government. If I have to make a concession at the moment I will. I now agree that the d'Hondt system has not worked particularly well, not that I think her proportional representation would have worked any better. We wish the honourable senator well in her retirement from the Senate.

Senator Haines, of course, being a South Australian, I knew well. She brought a certain flair to this chamber. I still find it difficult to believe that she is not going to seek political office again. Nevertheless, that will be interesting to follow. She took the plunge to take the Australian Democrats into the big league and was unsuccessful in doing that. But, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate said, she will certainly be remembered, particularly for the fact that she was the first female leader of a major political party. We send to her our best wishes.

Senator Sanders was one of those characters, I guess, who one moment was an American fighter pilot, I understand, the next moment was selling wood stoves in Tasmania, and the next moment was in the Senate. Goodness only knows what Norm is doing now.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not in Tassie.
—They reckon he is not welcome in Tassie. I would speak more fondly of him if he had not stood against my friend, Margaret Reid. Apart from that slippage, we wish him well.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Irina Dunn we did not know for long but we knew her for her quite long, some evenings, adjournment speeches. Nevertheless, she believed that she had a message that was important to put down. The Parliament is a forum that gives all honourable senators the opportunity to do that.

In conclusion, I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate and with Mr President in wishing all those who are leaving us at the end of this session our best wishes for the future. We thank them for their companionship and for their efforts in helping make this place a better environment in which to work. As I have said, we wish them well.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the National Party of Australia with the remarks given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill). There have been a lot of comparisons made about the Parliament. Senator Button compared it with a boarding school. Other people compared it with different things. I always think of it as a bit of a battlefield; some lose, some win, some fall, but within that environment of a battlefield we all share a common interest, and some of the most unlikely friendships are struck up.

SPEECH.PARA: As we leave the Thirty-fifth Parliament, I would like to make a few remarks about some of the honourable senators here whose company I have enjoyed, particularly the senators of the National Party. Senator Glen Sheil leaves the Parliament after a second go. He was elected in 1974 and then returned in 1984. He has been the family physician around the Parliament, and he has been a great doctor. I know that some of the things he has prescribed for me have had instant success, and not only that, but his costs and charges are very reasonable. He does not bulk bill. He has given his services free and gratis to all. He has been a great member of the tennis team. He struck up various friendships around the Parliament. But he is now leaving the Parliament. I understand that he is going into research. It has not been a good year for Glen. He has lost his wife. I know how fond of and dedicated to each other they both were. That is terribly sad for him. He is a strong man when you need some support and he has given me support in the short time that I have been Leader of the National Party. I wish him very well in his retirement. I hope that in his research he comes up with some answers that will benefit the whole of mankind.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone is not with us any longer. I suppose a lot of people would say that there would not be two more unlikely people in this Parliament. I must admit that when Senator Stone got his scholarship to Canberra and to the National Party I stood back and said, `What is happening?' Then I found that we did share a lot in common. We shared a great friendship. I can honestly say that as people from two most diverse backgrounds we gradually came to respect each other. I certainly look upon him now not only as a colleague but as a very dear friend. I am sad that he has left. I am sad that he left in the circumstances that he did. I did warn him. I said, `Don't go down to that other place. You will be looking after potholes and little old ladies' lost dogs. That is not your game'. He did not take any notice of me. He has left and I think he will be a great loss to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I think his shoes will be well filled by Senator O'Chee, who has also got a great depth of knowledge. I know Senator Stone welcomed his own replacement by Senator O'Chee who is also going to be a great asset to this Parliament. I know that he also appreciates the help that Senator Stone has given him.

I now come to my good friend Senator Julian McGauran. He will be known for his passionate defence of the wheat industry and the wool industry. He fought like a Kilkenny cat. He never let go. He has been here only a short time but he has left his mark on the Parliament. He will be back in three years. I can hardly wait for him to come back because he is a fighter, he knows what he stands for, he goes out and attacks and says what he believes. His loss will be felt not only in this Parliament but also throughout the rural industries of Australia. They all know Julian and how he stands up for them. When he comes back, he will have learnt a lot. One of the things will have been not to muffle the bells with a couple of pieces of foam rubber. Those things have passed now and he has not missed a division in two years.

There are a lot of other people I wish to say goodbye to-for example, Senator Puplick. I do not know how I am going to explain the coalition's position on the environment if I do not have Senator Puplick to blame. He was very handy to have for branch meetings. We are two people that one would never think would have a lot in common. I have grown to respect Chris's judgment. In fact, he has been one of my advisers. In those great debates we had with Senator Richardson on the Ravenshoe issue, Chris and I had to `tic, tac, and, delicately, toe' the party line on the environment issue. He was a great help to me. Chris, I will miss you. You have been a good friend to me and I hope you come back because you give a great depth to this Parliament.

Senator Messner has gone to better fields. I know that he has now gone into business. I wish him all the best. Senator Hamer has given great service to this Parliament as Chairman of Committees. We will miss him also. Senator Chaney has gone, but not very far. He will be around. He is only across the corridor and we still have his friendship in this Parliament. Senator Black, one of my Queensland colleagues, entered Parliament with me. We ran for the Senate together in 1984. He has served Parliament well with his committee work on drugs in sport. I think that has opened up the debate and made a very worthwhile contribution to sport in Australia.

Senator Devlin and I shared a lot of committee work as we belted around all over Queensland and the northern part of Australia on our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission committee work. He is a great guy too. In my speeches I often said that Senator Devlin was the only worker in Parliament, the only one on the Government side who had ever picked up a tool in anger. He is a good representative of the working people. He, too, will be missed because he is so friendly with the people that work around this place.

Senator Macklin and I have pulled off a few coups in our time on the fishing and sugar industries. If he would just lift his game on the environment a bit and not go over the top, we would have a lot more in common. I have enjoyed sitting next to Senator Macklin, not only this time around but also in a previous Parliament. We have also become very good friends. Senator Sanders has gone. That is a relief in some ways because he used to scream down my microphone. Senator Jenkins is also leaving us. Senator Haines has gone. I do not know that she will stay out of Parliament. She will probably have only a short sabbatical and come back again, too.

We wish these people all the best as they go into a new era of their lives. Some will go into business and some will come back into politics, but in whichever direction they head we wish them the best on their retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking for the Australian Democrats tonight to associate myself with these valedictory remarks because, in fact, our present Leader is also a leaver tonight. No doubt Senator Macklin will have his time a little later tonight, but it falls to me to associate myself with these remarks on behalf of the Party. It seems interesting that the number of senators who are leaving or who have left in the course of this Parliament is not considered a particularly large number. I will go home tonight and reflect on the fact that we seem to have a high turnover of people in this chamber during the life of the Parliament. Those people are all people that we get to know in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention Senator Hamer initially because I was for a time a member of the panel which helped keep your seat warm, Mr President, when you were off on matters of importance which keep this place running. As Chairman of Committees, Senator Hamer looked after the panel of Acting Deputy Presidents and Temporary Chairmen of Committees. I just want to say that Senator Hamer has great Christmas parties, and I thank him for inviting me to the one which occurred after I had retired from that position. Having a long and distinguished career in politics, he will be missed in this place.

When I first came into this place I remember being absolutely fascinated with wondering what colour Senator Puplick's matching tie and rosebud would be. I think that, in moving up here from down there, one of the greatest losses we have all suffered is that Senator Puplick has not been able to carry on that fine and very colourful tradition. If I were Senator Puplick, I would not come back until they get up here a rose garden like the one at the old Parliament House.

Senator Stone was quite a sparring partner for many of us in this particular spot in the chamber, but I recall with some pleasure a dinner at Mr President's table at which Senator Stone and I swapped some really interesting stories and quotations from A. A. Milne, of whom we both appear to be aficionados. I also remember Senator Stone particularly for the long hours of detailed work poring over the language in committee reports. I served on a number of committees with Senator Stone. Of course, he was one of the many leaders in this place who went during this Parliament.

I have to mention Senator McGauran because-this is official-he and I, according to his words, marched arm in arm to Warracknabeal to defend the wheat growers of this country. Senator McGauran has a chance to prove something to all of us-that there is such a thing as an iron-clad guarantee in politics. Good luck, Julian. I perhaps knew Senator Messner best as shadow Minister for communications, a position he held for a very brief period. I would like to thank him because during that period, for some reason or other, the Democrats were able to achieve some fairly significant amendments to communications legislation.

Senator Chaney was a distinguished leader in this chamber. I must say that I was always fascinated by the story about where Senator Chaney finally would end up. He has made a slight move and, I must say, I was quite taken with Senator Boswell's interpretation of that move. As I said, in this chamber it is interesting how many of our leaders seem to have moved on during the life of this Parliament. One of the things that is really odd is to hear Senator Chaney referred to so often in the media as Mr Chaney. I always get the feeling that somebody has got it wrong. Then I say to myself, `No, that's right. He is across the other side now'.

Senator Black, as others have said, has made his mark recently with his committee work. In fact, I first met Senator Black before I was a senator on a briefing for a political exchange program when both of us were intending to go the United States. I did not go on that trip. The two-day briefing was fun; I am sure that the trip would have been also. It was not that I did not want to go on a delegation that Senator Black was on. It was simply that there was a by-election in my State which caused me to stay home.

When I first came here, for many weeks I actually thought that Senator Devlin was a member of the transport office operation. It is clear that he has a great rapport with the genuine workers around this place. I have worked out that he is not a member of the transport office. My stint in the chair helped me to learn who everybody was around here. I must say that, even then, I always had to look Senator Morris up on the little list that they put inside the President's seat.

The Australian Democrats are farewelling tonight more than our fair share of senators and very many more than our fair share of leaders. Norm Sanders is gone, but not to be forgotten. I have mentioned Senator Puplick's colourful contribution. Norm Sanders's contribution was colourful in both a physical and verbal sense. I am sure that he will never be forgotten in this place. He will certainly not be forgotten by the Australian Democrats. He made a major contribution to bringing grassroots politics into a chamber that has found that very difficult to cope with. He never made an apology for that. I think he earns our respect for that.

We have also already farewelled our first female parliamentary leader in this country, Janine Haines. It was difficult at the end of the last year for us, and also for others who were known to be planning to move into the House of Representatives. We were never sure whether we would come back here, and the end of the last Budget session was difficult for that reason. We did not want to say goodbye from the Senate, we did not want to say that there was a danger that we might be saying goodbye from the Parliament.

Janine has made a major contribution to the Senate, and many people in this place have indicated their view on that score to me. She was engaged in significant negotiations and discussions on a regular basis with people from both sides. That is not an easy task for anybody, and Janine handled the task with distinction. Whether Janine chooses to make her future mark in our community through politics or through some other method, I am quite sure that she will continue to be what she has been in the past-a major contributor and a significant role model for young women.

We are farewelling another leader tonight in Senator Jenkins, who has been our Deputy Leader in this session of Parliament. Jean has already been acknowledged as a great grassroots politician, as a person who has battled for her constituency and the people in it who can find no-one else to fight their battles for them. She will be sadly missed as a Western Australian parliamentarian for that reason. In the short time that she served us as Deputy Leader, her skills as a human, kind, fair and just person have shone through. I was very pleased when Jean came into the Senate. It brought to this place three women, all of us whose names begin with the letter J. In the Party, it began to seep in that if you wanted to win preselection, you almost had to be a woman whose name began with J.

Jean and I have shared a friendship. I respect Jean as much as I have respected anyone in my life. She served as ombudsman for our Party in Western Australia for a time before she came to this place. In the Western Australian Democrats at that time, that was not an easy task. She has a great sense of justice and finely tuned antennae for injustice where it occurs in the community. Jean has been a strong parliamentary performer. We will miss her, but we are entirely persuaded that this is merely a temporary absence and that Jean will be back here sitting with us in this chamber again in the not too distant future.

We are also losing our leader. It is very careless of us to lose three leaders in one parliamentary session, but never mind. It has already been said that Michael Macklin is one of those rare creatures who leaves politics and Parliament on a voluntary basis. And he is so young, too! He is younger than I am, which is fairly disgusting. He has contributed in a substantive way to the work of this Parliament. When Michael began in this chamber, he said he would serve only two terms of office. Mind you, he has faced four elections. It is rough trying to get two Senate terms without going backwards and forwards to the electorate. Michael has been successful against all odds in Queensland at those elections that he has contested. Michael is showing us that there is a life beyond politics, and we wish him extraordinarily well.

Michael is one of those people-there are one or two others around here, too-who actually believe that the Senate is the centre of the universe and that the whole universe should be run from here. That is why he has made so many significant contributions. We should all realise that he has also laid a fair number of landmines around the place during his term here. Those of us who remain in this place will either have to dodge those landmines or get in and disarm them. We will all be pondering about some of those contributions which Michael and his colleagues from both sides of the chamber have made out of their belief that this is an important place. I have no doubt that his contributions will long be remembered.

Michael has done a great deal of committee work. Because some of that committee work, particularly in regard to the committees dealing with the National Crime Authority and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, Michael has become our resident expert on crims and spooks, and he has a nice line in colloquialisms. The other day I heard him talking about people `grassing' and getting `iced on the pavement'. Senators are used to Michael Macklin's erudite contributions in this place, but it can get fairly rough in the Party room.

Michael has a couple of other humorous characteristics as well. One is his legendary monetary meanness and the fact that he is a one-and-a-quarter pot screamer. The Queensland division of our Party understands the former very well. At a fundraising party in the then president's house some years ago, entry donations were listed at the door; members $5, guests $10 and Senator Macklin $325. His latter difficulty with handling too much alcoholic beverage has been familiar to his senatorial colleagues, especially if they have been in this place after dinner on occasions. It has always been accepted that he has never been allowed to move amendments after dinner; that has been a Party room decision. Unfortunately, he has sometimes been tempted to do that of his own volition. Sometimes the two characteristics have been defined. His ability to suss out freebie meals is quite extraordinary. On most nights in the dinner break he has been off to one embassy or another to be fed and watered. Likewise, even Senator Hill as shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has not been able to clock up as many overseas trips in such a short time. I counted the number of trips in the curriculum vitae supplied to me by Senator Macklin's office, and found that he had 16 trips in 10 years. I think that is quite good!

Our Michael is also inclined to a little sexism. One might think that that is not possible in a party like ours, but he had a habit of walking into the staff room of our former leader's office, seeing all the women sitting at their desks and saying, `Oh, there's no-one here'. We forgive him. He is a living example of the fact that you can be a tiny bit sexist and still survive in the Australian Democrats, and indeed move to the great heights of parliamentary leadership of our Party. Michael was a foundation member of our Party in 1977, president in Queensland in those first few years; then deputy national president; and he served on the National Executive of our Party even after his election to the Senate. No other senator who has been elected has been able to match that. He was an able and very loyal deputy to Janine Haines. He was our Party Whip, at the same time, until Senator McLean came in; and he is now our leader, and leaves us as our leader. Indeed, I would remind everybody that he is our leader until 1 July.

We will all miss him in this chamber-not just the Australian Democrats and our colleagues to come on 1 July, who deeply regret the fact that they will not be able to serve here with Michael. We certainly wish Michael, Jenny and their family well. We thank the family for lending Michael to us for all those years. I am sure that my sentiments are shared by many people in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall take just 30 seconds to remind the Senate, particularly those who are leaving us, that 15 years ago when I first came into this place the Senate contained a number of people of fairly advanced age. I was told that the existence of the Senate was proof that there was life after death. My only statement to those who are leaving is that there is certainly life after the Senate. I take the opportunity of joining with those who have already spoken to offer to those leaving this place my best wishes for the future. I count you all as friends and I hope that that is reciprocated. I wish you and your families the best.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always very interesting, Mr President, and perhaps a little sad to hear your own obituary, but I must warn those who are giving me an obituary that there is still the rest of tonight and tomorrow in which I can make a couple more speeches and ask a couple more questions. I also warn you of another thing: although my term expires on 30 June, I will remain here as Deputy President until you get around to electing another one. During that time as Deputy President, as far as I can gather, I will be responsible to no-one! That might be quite interesting.

SPEECH.PARA: On these occasions it is important to give thanks to everyone who has made it possible for me to perform as a politician. I want very quickly to go through the list of those who have helped me so much. First of all, there is my staff-as Deputy President and as a senator. What you are as a politician is very much dependent on your staff, and I thank them. My colleagues have already said farewell, but they know how I feel about them and how much I will miss them. The parliamentary staff are an enormous support to all of us. I particularly wish to mention the transport staff. I live about 12 miles from here and in order to get to my home I have to cross one river, the Murrumbidgee, and a creek. The Commonwealth car drivers nobly battle there. This morning-I think I was the only member of parliament to experience this-I arrived after crossing the Murrumbidgee, which is in flood, hanging on to the side of a front end loader to be met on the far side by a rather surprised Commonwealth car driver. I do not think many other members of parliament could duplicate that experience! The parliamentary staff have been wonderful to all of us.

I would like to pay a particular tribute to you, Mr President. Our system of having a President and Deputy President from opposite parties is not any easy one. I like to think that we worked well together. I can recall no occasion on which we differed on matters of handling the Senate. I think that has been due very largely to your support and understanding, for which I am very grateful.

I should also like to point out that you, Mr President, are presiding over what is potentially the most important chamber in the Westminster system. We often talk about the Westminster system as if it were the same as it was in the 1850s, forgetting what has happened and what party discipline has done to the system. Whatever its admirable qualities, the House of Representatives is no longer and cannot be a legislature. It is an electoral college for the Government-a place where the Executive and the alternative Executive fight it out. It cannot be a legislature. If you do not want to have what Lord Hailsham described as `an elective dictatorship', you have to realise that this chamber is the only legislature. That is why I attach so much importance to it. If it is to be a responsible legislature, not controlled by the Government-as it will not be-we cannot do deals on the floor of the chamber. That is no way to legislate. We must use extensively the public hearings of our committee system. That is why I have been so insistent on them and why I have attached such great importance to them. The future of this great chamber lies there.

People are constantly asking me what I feel about leaving the Senate. That is difficult to answer. I feel a bit like the man who was injured in a road crash and who made claims for very extensive damages. At the inquiry the lawyer put to him that his claims were either grossly exaggerated or totally fraudulent. He said: `I have evidence from the policeman who interviewed you after the accident and you told him that you had never felt better in your life. That is quite incompatible with these very extensive injuries for which you are claiming'. The man replied: `Well, yes, I did tell the policeman that I had never felt better in my life, but you must understand the circumstances. I was in this road accident, my car was a write-off, I was injured and an injured dog and an injured horse were also there. This policeman of yours arrived and examined the dog. He shook his head, took out his revolver and shot it. Then he went over to the horse, examined it, shook his head, pulled out his revolver and shot it. He then came over to me and asked me how I felt. I said, ``I never felt better in my life!''.' So when people ask me how I feel about leaving the Senate and I reply that I have never felt better in my life, they will know that I will really miss you all and this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devlin Sen A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was first elected to the Senate in December 1984. I came from working class people in Tasmania, and in my 5 3/4 years in the Senate I have never dissociated myself from them. My lifestyle has not changed. I pay tribute to the Burnie Trades and Labour Council, which has always given me its undivided support and encouragement.

SPEECH.PARA: Working with my colleagues in the Senate has been a great experience for me and I have made many friends on both sides of politics; some of them are close friends.

Mr President, I thank you for your assistance and advice. I also thank your staff, who have been so helpful during my time in this place. I also express my appreciation of the work done by the Whip and Deputy Whip in the day-to-day running of the Parliament. I extend a special thank you to Joan Harvey, the Whip's Clerk, for her assistance.

For the past 12 months or so I have chaired the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I thank Monica McMahon, who has been acting Secretary during that time, and her staff for their dedication to the task under sometimes difficult circumstances. I leave the Senate with some regrets because of the many friends my wife and I have made since we have been in this place.

I sincerely thank the staff of the Parliament-the Clerks, the Hansard staff, the committee staff, the catering staff, the Senate Printing Unit, the Senate transport staff, the attendants and security staff and in particular the Comcar drivers and finance officers. They have always been helpful and courteous and they do not always get the recognition they deserve. I thank them for their cooperation and friendship over the years.

My staff, Vurlie, Cheryl, Juliet and Vicki, have been with me since my election in 1984 and have given me tremendous support. I offer my heartfelt thanks for their loyalty and cooperation. I also thank Marcia for her thoughtfulness and all the help she has given me during my time in Canberra.

On a personal note I must pay tribute to the tireless and unselfish support given to me by my wife, Vurlie. Her companionship and advice have been invaluable and I look forward to their continuing for many years to come. I use this occasion also to express my gratitude for all the support given to me by members of my family in Tasmania.

I also wish to thank George Georges for providing my accommodation in Canberra over the years. George earned many tributes during his time in the Senate and to me he still stands for values that many of us share. George is presently undergoing medical treatment for a heart condition and I send him my very best wishes for a speedy recovery.

Mr President, I take this opportunity of wishing the Ainslie Football Club a successful season and look forward to seeing it win the 1990 premiership. I greatly appreciate the warmth and friendship that members at Ainslie have shown me and I will certainly miss them. I will have very warm memories to take away of the people I have met in this place. I take this opportunity to wish all the retiring members the best in the future, whether they retire or return to this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Federation, in a nation which has seen many millions of Australians make their individual contributions to our nationhood, a mere 420 men and women have been chosen by their fellows to be senators. I have been honoured to be one of these. When I was first elected in 1978 I was aged 30, the second youngest senator in history. That was a matter of some curiosity. Since then, numerous younger colleagues have come in to this chamber, all of them I think on this side of the Senate. I wish them in particular long, distinguished and, above all, useful careers.

SPEECH.PARA: In making this, my last speech in the Senate, I am minded to do three things briefly.
