First, to pay my thanks; secondly, to say something of my own score sheet of public life, like a good professional historian, to write my own version of history before someone else does it; and, thirdly, to look to the future.

In terms of paying thanks I should not dwell for too long upon these personal tributes and personal thanks, for fear that the heartfelt may become maudlin and that the inability to express my thanks adequately may be all too apparent. First and foremost to my family: to my mother, Barbara; my sister, Deirdre, and her family. I say no more for they know all that there is to be known. Secondly, to my colleagues in this chamber: my friendship spans the entire range of my colleagues, from Peter Baume to Noel Crichton-Browne. And that says something about the meaning of friendship.

To the ladies among the Liberal senators, in particular, to Margaret, who has whipped me in the nicest possible way, and to Jocelyn and Shirley, who have challenged me on many occasions and then stood shoulder to shoulder with me in all of the fights that we have had for the common cause on our side of the chamber. To Amanda, Kay and Sue whose friendship, hospitality and, in the best sense of the term, familiarity have meant so much.

I make special mention of two of my colleagues. To Robert Hill, my friend, my parliamentary Leader, and I believe, a person who will be one of the great Foreign Ministers of Australia. To Peter Baume, a friend, a friend and then again a friend.

I extend particular thanks to my friends and colleagues in the Liberal Party in the House of Representatives. To Andrew Peacock, Don Dobie, Peter Shack, Philip Ruddock and, in particular, Warwick Smith. To both Warwick and his wife, Kathryn, his daughter, Sabrina, whose little picture I treasure very greatly-she drew it for me when I was a guest at their home in Launceston-and to Isaac, his son, whom I had occasion to remark to Warwick bears a very distinguished historical name. Isaac Smith was the name of the first person from the First Fleet to set foot on Australia. He was the able seaman who carried Captain Phillip ashore.

To my closest personal friend, Greg Hamilton, who in the last couple of weeks has been a great rock and supporter. Finally, and inexpressibly to my staff over the years, Jose Garcia, Jim Malins, Andrew Kirk, Rosemary Yeo, Paul Vieira and Hazel Elliott. Above all, to Hazel, my electorate secretary, who has served with me in the rough times and the smooth, the good times and the bad, the days of celebrations and despair, of sorrow and anger, of triumph and more latterly of defeat. I say to all of them, in the words of the twenty-fifth chapter of St Matthews Gospel, `Well done good and faithful servants'.

In terms of the political scoresheet, I came into the Parliament, frankly, because I do give a damn. I care about Australian democracy and the system which allows a pommie migrant, such as I-whose father was thrown out of school at the age of 11, whose mother was never allowed to complete the education which she would have been able to complete, given her talents and abilities-from that migrant background to be able to represent my State, my people and my philosophy in the Parliament of Australia. I care about Australian society, to see it fairer, to see it freer, to see it more just, to see the rights of individuals respected and enhanced.

I care about the Australian nation. It is a nation of unique and wonderful character. I think that we, in general, and in particular members of the Liberal Party of Australia, tend to devalue Australia a little by looking too much overseas for our models when the best models are in fact here at home in terms of our art, our intellectual culture and our democratic political ethos. Australia led the world in fair and free elections, the extension of the franchise, and the establishment of a good system of government. Ours is the model for others to follow. We do not need overseas models. We have the best home grown ones.

I say that I am here because I regard myself as a classical Liberal with liberal ideals to identify, to write about, to preach, to provide and to put into practice. I will give a brief statement, not my own words but the words of Jose Ortega y Gasset, a Spanish philosopher, about liberalism and what it is I have tried to represent. He writes:

Liberalism is that principle of political rights, according to which the public authority, in spite of being all-powerful, limits itself and attempts, even at its own expense, to leave room in the State over which it rules for those to live who neither think nor feel as it does, that is to say as do the stronger majority. Liberalism-it is well to recall this today-is the supreme form of generosity; it is the right which the majority concedes to minorities and hence it is the noblest cry that has ever resounded on this planet. It announces the determination to share existence with the enemy; more than that, with an enemy which is weak. It was incredible that the human species should have arrived at so noble an attitude, so paradoxical, so refined, so anti-natural. Hence it is not to be wondered at that this same humanity should soon appear anxious to get rid of it. It is a discipline too difficult and complex to take firm root on earth.

Despite the fact that my personal support of causes in favour of human rights, the legitimate role of gay people and their life styles in our community, the welfare of the Muslim community, my hostility to the regulators, the censors, the philistines and the corporatists have been used against me throughout the whole of my parliamentary life, I have never waivered, never retreated, never resiled and never regretted standing for them. As Martin Luther said, `Here I stand, I can do no other'.

I believe that my achievements have not been as great as those of many other senators in the terms of their parliamentary careers. I do look to a few things. I look to the enactment of the Whale Protection Act in 1980. I look to the improvement of the Freedom of Information Act which my friend Peter Durack pioneered and brought into the Parliament. I look to the role that I played and enjoyed playing in defeating the Australia Card and I look very much to the establishment and fostering of the Amnesty International group within the Parliament. I look with pleasure on the steps in which I have been involved in helping to make the Senate work better, to pay attention to some of the technical sides of how legislation is treated and having been kept up to the mark by Harry and Anne whenever it appeared that somebody had to get in there and do it. I look in particular to the bipartisan development of our policy on the acquired immune deficiency syndrome and on the parliamentary liaison committee which we established to try to make sure that our system worked. There have been notable failures, and I regret, in many cases, the things that I was unable to achieve. I was unable to achieve justice for individuals, and justice for people like Alex Watson in his campaign to have his name cleared. I regret not having had the opportunity to do more in that respect.

Internationally, I make one comment. I hope that in my life time I will see the creation of an independent state of Palestine, living in peace, harmony and security alongside the free and secure state of Israel, so that, in the words of the holy Koran, `kit-e-kitab'-all the people of the book can live together. This is not an impossible dream. In my life time so many of the impossible have become commonplace. So much has moved from science fiction to empirical fact that this too can be achieved. I would like to be able to work to achieve some progress in that area.

Tomorrow, the last day that I will be here during a Senate sitting, is the anniversary of the death 379 years ago of the Elizabethan poet, Christopher Marlowe. In his wonderful play, Tamburlaine the Great, he wrote:
Is it not passing brave to be a King,
And ride in triumph through Persepolis.
I have had the opportunity to ride through Persepolis and, indeed, the travel which I have undertaken as a member of the Senate has been one of the really great experiences of my life.

I have travelled to broaden the mind, to deepen the understanding, not as an alleged delegate to some conference or to be photographed in all the right places in all the right company, but essentially in order to expand and to develop that sense of what it is that I can do, that I can understand, and that I can contribute.

Obviously, I had hoped to achieve more but this has been denied by our failure in New South Wales to win three Senate seats. Unfortunately, we were the only State to fail to elect three coalition senators. Our vote was substantially below the votes in all other States. We in the Liberal Party will have to do something about that.

I turn in conclusion, as I often do in times when I am looking for reference points, to works of poetry. Poetry means a great deal to me, whether it is the poetry of Shakespeare or the King James version of The Bible, or the poetry of Emily Bronte or Pablo Neruda or the Persian greats, like Sa'di, Hafiz, Rumi, Sana'i, and Khayyam. I express what I hope to do in the next few years by turning to Tennyson's poem, Ulysses. Tennyson writes:
I cannot rest from travel: I will drink
Life to the lees. All times I have enjoyed
Greatly, have suffered greatly, both with those
That loved me, and alone; on shore, and when
Through scudding drifts the rainy Hyades
Vexed the dim sea. I am become a name;
For always roaming with a hungry heart;
Much have I seen and known-cities of men
And manners, climates, councils, governments,
Myself not least, but honoured of them all;
And drunk delight of battle with my peers,
Far on the ringing plains of windy Troy.
I am part of all that I have met;
Yet all experience is an arch wherethrough
Gleams that untravelled world, whose margin fades
For ever and for ever when I move
How dull it is to pause, to make an end,
To rust unburnished, not to shine in use!

Mr President, I do not intend to rust. I intend to pursue other interests. When Margaret Mitchell first submitted her famous novel to a publisher they had reservations and, like all good editors, they eventually made changes for the better. One thing they changed was the book's title. Mitchell had originally given it the title of its own equally famous last line-`Tomorrow is another day'. Perhaps it is fitting that I could refer to that novel, one of the world's most loved, published as Gone with the Wind, for, as one of the great talkers of my beloved Senate, so am I.

Tomorrow is indeed another day and I know not where the wind will blow me, but I do know that I will set my sails to seek advantage. That wind blows in the way which my Tennyson poem describes so that I can say, ` `Tis not too late to seek a newer world', and to do it with the heart of Ulysses-proudly, defiantly and confidently asserting:
We are not now that strength which in old days,
Moved earth and heaven; that which we are, we are;
One equal temper of heroic hearts,
Made weak by time and fact, but strong in will
To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank honourable senators and others who have over the last few weeks spoken to me about my departure from this place, and wished me well. I suppose I was an accidental parliamentarian. It was very much an accidental exercise that I became involved in politics. I was driving to a school to observe some trainee teachers when I turned on the parliamentary broadcast. I and one other person in Australia at the time undoubtedly were listening. I heard Don Chipp's speech on his resignation from the Liberal Party broadcast from the House of Representatives. I found it very moving.

SPEECH.PARA: Being rather silly, I went home and wrote a letter in which I said, `Good on you' and many other things. Because one always finds it difficult to finish these things, I signed it by saying that if I could help at any time I would. That was the fatal error. About two days later I got a phone call from Don Chipp, who was slightly like Gough Whitlam-one of those mythical figures whom one hears about out in the provinces but whom one does not think are real.

He was real enough because he landed on my doorstep shortly afterwards and asked me to organise a meeting in Brisbane. Having never been involved in politics, I thought, `Well, I will have a run at this' and so I booked the Brisbane City Hall. I arrived at 6.30, found the keys, stood around and got all the lights on. It was a very large and empty hall with me holding these keys. I thought, `This is a pretty stupid exercise to get involved in', but by half past seven, as some people in here know, the City Hall was filled to overflowing and, in fact, a system had to be set up to broadcast outside into the King George Square.

I found myself on the stage having to chair the meeting and they said, `You have done such a good job at chairing the meeting you can chair the next one' and get the party going. I did that, and then they said, `You have done such a good job at that you might as well be the first president. Here is all the material we have'. And they all left.

Within 12 weeks we were fighting both a State and the Federal campaign. We were not successful that time around and so they said, `We are never going to win a seat in Queensland. You can run next time as our Senate leader', at which I said, `Thank you very much'. They said, `You have got some time on your hands. Away you go'. In 1980, after 6 weeks of counting, I was elected to this place. So I came to this place by way of a series of errors which undoubtedly a lot of people have regretted ever since.

In the time that I have spent here I have tried to follow through the values that were given to me as a result of my Irish Catholic upbringing. Those honourable senators who have had one of those know what I mean. Two of those values are, firstly, a very strong regard for friends and, secondly, an integrity in making sure that what one does one actually believes in. I have tried to follow through both of those principles in this place and I have made some very good friends. I remember Senator Tate interjecting on what must have been my second speech here, saying, `Don't be so pompous'. It was very good advice and I have tried to take it. One of my colleagues showed me a piece of paper the other day which talked about a Chinese herbal medicine which was a cure for importance. I thought it might be a useful thing to give to a lot of new senators. At that stage we probably do think we are pretty important.

In a way it is a very privileged existence, as honourable senators know. It is a privilege as a migrant to this country to be selected by the people of my State to represent them, not only at one but at two, three and four elections. I will always treasure the memory that the people of my adopted country were willing to place their trust in me to represent them. In the coming years we need to think very carefully about where we are going in that debate. It is something very close to my heart.

I have made some very good friends in all parties and I shall miss them. I had the unique experience of being able to serve here with Don Chipp. When I got to know him I realised that he was what he actually appears to be. I got used every morning to 20 minutes in the party room hearing Don's latest problem. It was described to us with great verve. There were only five of us sitting around a small table and we were preached at for 20 minutes each morning. It was a rare experience. Don really felt it. He has become a great friend of mine and a person whom I hold very dear.

Janine Haines, who took over from Don, was a totally different type of person. She was also a person to whom I grew very close, a person whom I count as a very close friend. Norm Sanders, also. It goes on. There are so many people whom one would want to refer to, but there is no time for that.

I thank those people here who have assisted me. I have tried to put in. When I was teaching at the university I would say to my students who were going into teaching that there were two things that they had to do: their first task was to be good teachers, they had to do their job properly as professionals; their second task was to be professional people who would contribute to the profession of teaching. They had a task outside the classroom as well as in the classroom.

I have tried to follow that through here. I have tried to put into the task that we have in this chamber, which I believe is legislation. That is the central role of this chamber, and a role that this chamber does excellently. Certainly, there are not too many other chambers that can lay a finger on what is done in this chamber during its committee stage.

I have also tried to look at the institution that I was in and contribute to that. Quite a number of motions that I have moved are now embedded in the Standing Orders. I hope that they will be seen as improvements. I have attempted to do other things in politics. Somebody knowing my previous existence said that as I had been a preacher all my life, I probably would not stop. Indeed, after this I will carry on preaching about those things that I hold very dear in this great country.

In my experience there are unfortunately too few people who put in and an awful lot of people who take out. I must admit to having changed my view of politicians entirely. Having been an academic, which was a pretty low form of life, I suddenly got elected as a politician, which was even lower! I have changed my view of politicians; I was wrong. I have met people here who have had the utmost dedication to their country. Although I have not always shared their views I never doubted that they were attempting to put into the country. It is a pity that people outside of politics do not stop and think about that once in a while.

Some people make sacrifices for us to be able to do this task, a tax necessitated by democracy. As my wife said in an exasperated way to somebody who was probably the 112th person who rang on the day of the last election, politicians are the price of democracy. We cannot have an operating democracy without having people elected to a parliament. When we do that, other people make sacrifices.

I refer to my family, which I do not think is any different from the families that most people here have. My family is still young. My eldest daughter was six when I came here. She is now sixteen. Because of the pressures of work here and the pressures of work in the electorate, being the only Australian Democrat elected in the entire State, I spent an enormous amount of time away from home. Many honourable senators in this place relate to that. Only the other day I was looking at my daughter, who is now sixteen, and wondering what happened to those ten years.

I hope that the media and others will pause possibly for a moment or two and think about that; think about the spouses. Last year my daughter had appendicitis. I was here and my wife was at home with the other two children. This attack began in the middle of the night. What happens? They are forced to live as single parent families, and we are able to contribute. We do not really appreciate enough what other people put in.

Unfortunately the denigration of political life is such that it hurts not only the individual-most of us who work in this place have fairly tough skins-but also others. My children have come home from school crying because of some thoughtless remark of the teacher. They have read things in the paper about all politicians being better dead. This may be funny; I suppose there is always a good joke to be had. One should not get too serious about it. But somebody does suffer from those types of comments. It would be nice if people once in a while took pause to consider the damage and the hurt that they were causing to the families of members of both the Senate and the House of Representatives.

Last, I would like to thank all those who have assisted me. I hope I have been able to contribute. I ask forgiveness from any of those people whom I may have hurt during the time that I have been here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, thank you very much for your kind valedictory words. I can remember a time when you were fearful that you would be the shortest serving President of the Senate. Circumstances treated you a lot more gently than they did me. I thank the leaders of all the political parties for their kind words tonight. It is nice to hear them but when you gotta go, you gotta go.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill mentioned the members' services staff, who provide the breakfasts and other things. I thank them for the marvellous time they have given me since I have been in the Parliament. They have always looked after me like a prince. I am the world's champion at being looked after. I can take any amount of it. They have done a wonderful job with me. I also thank them for the champagne breakfast they gave me. They have appreciated the coaching I have given them over the years. They finally got breakfast right. I thank them for the lovely present they gave me.

The Commonwealth car drivers were also mentioned tonight. They have provided marvellous service over years and years. I thank them for the present they gave me. Although it is perishable I can assure them that I will appreciate it as long as it lasts.

I will be forever grateful to the Office of the Clerk of the Senate, particularly Harry and Anne, going right back to the orientation course for honourable senators where we had to learn how to operate in this place. I thank them for all the advice they have given us on procedures, Bills and other things over the years. I thank them for their sentiments and their invitations for the future. I assure them that I will take them up on that.
I notice that the attendants are on strike today but a few are helping here. I thank them for their servility and the help that they have given us over the years. I have always appreciated them.

I thank the Whips. I seem to have been whipping around here for years and years. I go right back to Georgie Georges. Margaret Reid and Sue Knowles are a most congenial pair to work with. Gerry Jones, Jim McKiernan and Dom Foreman have made up a very easy group to work with. When we think about it, it is actually the Whips that run the Senate. We should have more trouble than anybody, but we do not.

As far as I can recall, my coalition colleagues and I have had nothing but fun since I have been here. I appreciate them. I have learnt a lot. I have had so many different sorts of colleagues. As mentioned earlier tonight, when I first got here we had some elderly-type senators. The numbers were equal on both sides then. But I had the rattiest group-not mentally, just physically. Quite often it was an effort to get us all in for divisions. Lionel Murphy once threatened that if sometime I could not get them in here he would bang through all the Bills he wanted. So I became an expert at getting into the Senate elderly senators suffering all sorts of illnesses.

I thank Government senators for all they have done over the years. Early in my life I was advised not to have all of my friends on one side of the House, and so it has turned out. I have some very good friends on the other side. I visit them and enjoy their company. That was a thing which I would never have expected because I thought socialism was akin to some dreadful disease that was catching, and I did not want it to get near me-and it certainly has not done that! But I did learn that not all the good politicians are on one side of this House and not all good policies are on one side either. If you try to consider everything you will probably never decide anything. It has been a rewarding experience to learn those few facts or have them confirmed to me.

As far as I know I have not got any enemies here, except perhaps in the media, but it is not I who is the enemy. If they are my enemy, it is all on their side. They seem to have taken the freedom of the press to the extent of licence without any responsibility. That might make them an enemy but, as far as I know, there may be a lot of people in this place who will be quite pleased never to see me again but I would not classify them as enemies.

It is a very sobering moment when you come to consider any achievements you have made since you have been here. Some people come and achieve greatness or have it thrust upon them. Others make a much more modest contribution. I remember talking to the late Bob Katter once and I asked what he felt was the best thing he had done. He said, `It is not easy to get anything done down there but I noticed they could not handle iced water; they never had any iced water in the dining room. So I had to get on the House Committee. After two years I got a resolution through and now you can thank me for all the jugs of iced water on the dining room tables'.

Georgie Georges, who was mentioned here, was a politician of a little greater stature than he was ever given credit for, I think, but at the end of his career his political fortunes went into decline and he ended up getting expelled from his party and ostracised by them. Somebody said to him one day, `Georgie, you must be terribly disappointed to be leaving the Parliament with such disillusionment after all this trouble'. He said, `Oh, no, not at all; I have had two great achievements'. `What are they?' He said, `Well I was walking across King's Hall one day and I slipped and fell and broke a rib. They thought I had had a heart attack, and they jumped on me and massaged my chest. It nearly killed me; I could not breathe'. He said, `I passed out; they thought I had had another heart attack. I had a dreadful time. So I had to get on the House Committee'. And after quite a while he got a resolution through and there was a notice placed in King's Hall that said, `Watch out-Slippery floor'.

We can thank Georgie Georges for another thing. One time he was taken short and he was in the senators' toilet and the bells went. Of course, Georgie was at a stage where he could not be really interrupted so he took a punt that it was the House of Representatives bells ringing-and it was not. So he had to come in, and he made an impassioned speech afterwards, apologising, and asked whether House lights could be put in the toilets. Now when you look at the House lights in the toilet you can thank Georgie Georges for that.

They were the great achievements of Bob Katter and Georgie Georges. When it came to thinking of my great achievements I really could not think of much at all except that the first vote I ever got in the place was to vote against a salary increase, and that is an act--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're going to get another chance tonight.
—It is an act that is assuming a more acute significance as I get toward retirement and I would not recommend it to anybody again. Either you believe in arbitration or you do not, and I do.

SPEECH.PARA: I did start the inter-House tennis competition, and I hope that continues up here. It is a little bit more difficult to get to the courts, but if you can have a tournament every session I think it will do the Parliament good. We have seen some funny times during that tournament. In one we got down to needing a decision in the final rubber. It was Bob Hawke and Ian Viner, like a panther and a cobra playing together. It all depended on that. They had to knuckle down and get to work, and they did, and they won, and the Senate lost. I would love that to continue.

It has been mentioned that I was the shortest-serving Minister. That is quite right. When that happened I was rather pleased that beheading had got out of style! I was the only guy who had been to Africa to have a look at it and I got back here and I said, `Look, we had better have another look at this South African bit; they seem to be changing, however slowly. It would be better to encourage them and not obstruct them'. This was not received very well at all and it was not the general view, but I notice it is coming around that way now.

Also I am relieved that the wool Bill has not got very far at this stage because I did not want to be leaving this Senate with a smoking gun in my hand and a wounded corpse of a coalition behind me. We will see how it goes.

I have enjoyed the committee work. I have done and seen a lot of things and many places that I would not have seen otherwise, and I have enjoyed that sort of thing. I thank all the committee staff. Rob Alison was actually the Secretary of the first committee I was ever chairman of, trade and commerce. We knew how to give ourselves references in those days. I remember the wine inquiry. Now there is an inquiry! Every Senator should do a wine inquiry. And, I must say, while the Government implemented the recommendations of that committee the wine industry prospered. It was the same with forestry. We actually built up the forests to such an extent that now they are trying to conserve them all. Through the Public Works Committee I have seen places that I would never have seen-and I hope in the meantime been instrumental in saving the country some millions of dollars. I found it was a very rewarding experience and I hope the country did too.

I have also been on many health and community relations type committees. Health was the reason I got into Parliament. I wanted to see if I could help with the administration of health. But health is in a bigger mess now than it ever was. Perhaps it is time I went out! You cannot even get insurance for your medical expenses now, which staggers me. Anyway, I can leave that to the new ones.

I had some committee experience in the very early days when Gough Whitlam was the Prime Minister of the country and Lionel Murphy was running the Senate. Of course, Lionel Murphy was putting through, from my point of view, a whole deluge of revolutionary legislation on things like trade practices, family law and particularly anti-discrimination type legislation. I was on an Opposition Attorney-General's committee with a whole lot of luminaries like the late Sir Reg Wright, the late Ivor Greenwood and the late Allan Missen. I seem to be talking on too many condolence motions too these days so perhaps it is time to go! Fred Chaney was on the committee, and I think I must have been the nearest thing that the Country Party of those days had to a lawyer so it put me on it.

The big issue of the day was clubs. Apparently there was a lot of discrimination going on in clubs. They would not let these people into that club and those people into that club, and women did not seem to be able to get into any club. These lawyers discussed this on a high level for about an hour and a half. I had to listen to all that. Then they suddenly looked around and said, `Glen, you have not said anything yet. Have you got a contribution to make?'. I said, `Well, as far as I can see, the only reason you have a club is to discriminate'. They did not seem to think I really understood the issue at all.

So on we went, and that was all good fun. I just concentrated on keeping them all healthy to get them into the divisions. I was here in perhaps the most dramatic days of this Parliament, and that was when we had to block Supply in the Gough Whitlam days in 1975. I did not ever see that as the rape of democracy. I know that millions of words have been written about it, and it created consternation here and anger there. But I can remember at the time the Senate, I felt, was just reacting to the feelings in the electorate. We had a Prime Minister who was trying to run the country on borrowed money, we were trying to run the country on borrowed money, we were trying to force an election and we were quite prepared to go to the people so we kept blocking Supply. I do not see how it can be said that it is the rape of democracy when an election is called. Anyway, it is in the past now. It is part of history. There are very few of us left here in the Senate who were here in those days.

I congratulate the new senators on their election and on their maiden speeches. I think we are turning the Senate over to a new lot of safe hands. I wish it well because, as Senator Hamer said, the Senate is approaching a new era. It is the only legislative chamber, but the committee work has developed and expanded to such an extent now that I think the Senate is making a major contribution to Australian legislation such as no other chamber in the world does.

I would like to mention at this stage our newest committee, the Senate Standing Committee on the Selection of Bills for their referral to committees. That could be the best or the worst thing we have ever done. If we like to work at it, I think we can make it the best thing we have ever done. I wish the Committee and the Senate well. When the founding fathers gave us this Senate they gave us a robust institution. I see it as our responsibility, and now your responsibility, to see that it grows and develops and serves the nation well.

It has been a delight to sit next to Senator Flo for so long. She is a lady with great perspicacity and a wealth of political knowledge and nous, married to an Australian legend. She has a big family and I know all about the grandchildren. I am very pleased to know about those sorts of things; it has been a pleasure to sit beside her. For myself, as was mentioned, I think I will have a holiday for a couple of weeks. Then I want to go on a veterans' tour of tennis. When I get back I will get stuck into medical research. Thank you very much for mentioning Dr Marjorie tonight. The medical research unit is going to be named after her. I wish you all well and thank you very much for a very pleasant valedictory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would very briefly like to make some remarks by way of farewell to this chamber. I depart with some regret, but it is a regret tempered by an appreciation of the heavy toll that parliamentary representation imposes on its practitioners, an observation that I can confirm by merely looking around this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As an independent senator I have enjoyed the luxury of voting according to my conscience and judgment, something which it could be argued should be the duty of all senators. But I will admit that at times I would have appreciated the support of a well-oiled and well-funded party machine and the support of colleagues with whom I could have divided the labour involved in following complex legislation in its passage through the Senate.

Discerning the likely effect of legislation, as opposed to the honourable intent, has sometimes proved too difficult for governments, with all their resources. I would like to thank senators of all three parties in this chamber for their assistance in clarifying for me issues relating to many of the Bills brought before the Senate.

At this point I would like to congratulate Senator Jo Vallentine on her re-election and express my hope that three successive elections have demonstrated to even the most obtuse senator her legitimacy as a representative of strong community views in her home State.

I would also like to congratulate the Australian Democrats on their election success. Honourable senators will remember that several commentators had written them off as a party in decline a few months before the election. I am not sure that I should refer to them as a party, unless as a Clayton's party-I mean this in the nicest possible way-the party you have when you do not have a party, as in this Parliament they seem to have achieved the best of both worlds with a large degree of individual freedom as well as mutual support. I should like to commiserate with the Democrats over the near miss in Kingston, which entailed the retirement of their leader, Senator Janine Haines.

I would like to congratulate Ted Mack on his election. I do not envy him his difficult role as groundbreaker in the relatively nasty and brutal other place. The primary vote against the major parties in the last election was about 17 per cent, which is roughly reflected in the Senate result but which resulted in 0.7 per cent representation in the other place. That 0.7 per cent is, of course, Mr Ted Mack. This anomaly could be rectified by adopting the amendment to the Electoral Act that I put before this chamber recently.

I make the distinction between the chambers of this Parliament because quite often I have been gratified by the spirit in which honourable senators with different political allegiances have worked together in this chamber and in committees on matters of genuine importance. The fact that there are more women here may have something to do with this relative civility. The role of the House of review and the lack of a single party majority may also be relevant. Whatever the case, I am grateful for the fellowship and even friendship I have enjoyed with honourable senators from all sides of this chamber.

The adversarial format of our Parliament is designed to ensure that all points of view are represented. It is not only a mechanism for sucking the maximum electoral advantage out of every issue. At times I have resented the amount of time spent repetitiously hammering away at particular issues, like the umpteenth matter of public importance on the pilots dispute, while other important issues were ignored.

I know that opinions differ on what is important and I am well aware of the pressure of business in the Senate, but I would like to thank you, Mr President, and your deputies for your patience and forbearance during my first frequent use of the adjournment debate to raise matters that I believed were important.

It only remains to thank the many people who have assisted and supported me during my time here-far too many to list in anything but the most cursory manner. Firstly, I would like to thank my running mates in the uphill race during the last election-Peter Prineas and Dr Harry Recher; my staff, past and present; the volunteers who gave selflessly of their time for the often boring tasks they had to perform; and all the supporters of our ticket. I should especially like to thank the staff of the Senate. First among them, the prodigiously informative Mr Harry Evans, the Clerk of the Senate. Also, the legislative drafting staff, the library staff, the printers, the attendants, the drivers and all the support staff without whom this institution could not operate.

I should mention here and comment on the professionalism of Mr Munro, the parliamentary draftsman, who, when I asked him to draft the amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Act nearly had apoplexy when he thought that, with the introduction of the Hare-Clark system at a federal level, there would be the possibility of many more Independents and Australian Democrats getting into the lower house and anarchy would be loosed upon Australia, yet he still carried out his task with great professionalism, and for that I am very appreciative.

It may be that I have missed something. Perhaps there are deep currents of dissatisfaction or disaffection simmering in the bowels of this vast building. Perhaps at this moment the mob approaches the door of this sacrosanct chamber with sweaty nightcaps and meat cleavers, but if this is the case I have not noticed. My experience has been of unfailing courtesy, efficiency and good humour with a distinctively Australian flavour.

Having barely recovered from my surprise at being here and having, if not greatness some notoriety, thrust upon me, I am now about to leave. Finally, through you, Mr President, I would like to convey my thanks to all the honourable senators for their various contributions to making the last month a hectic but very rewarding time for me in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with very mixed feelings that I rise to make these remarks in my valedictory speech. I feel in one respect like a condemned prisoner offered one last meal to savour and enjoy with an unexpected choice of menu. I feel also like a person at prayer asking for mercy for deeds done that ought not to have been done and for deeds not done that should have been done. I suppose for `deeds' I could substitute speeches, press releases, press conferences, amendments, notices of motion and questions with and without notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel privileged to have sat in the Senate for these last nearly three years. This experience must be one of the most fast track learning experiences possible. As an Australian Democrat there can be no other way. Today, one makes one's first speech and tomorrow it is one's responsibility to see through a piece of legislation which falls within one's own portfolio area.

A number of backbenchers in the bigger parties here have said how much they envy our constant and real activity. Apart from the fact that we are obliged, as Australian Democrat parliamentarians, to have a conscience vote every time, we all are members of our own shadow cabinet and involved in all decision making. I feel especially privileged to have sat in the Senate for the last three years and to have played a part in the historical move from the provisional Parliament House to this present one.

It was expected when I was elected in 1987 that I would work miracles-and on some occasions I may have come close. My main portfolio for the Democrats has been that of immigration and multicultural affairs. In this, I have made what seems like herculean efforts to get both the Government and the Opposition to subscribe to simpler, more understandable legislation than the present mess of pottage. I have sought to argue for humanitarian values appropriate to the area of law that deals with people.

For some of the time, I also held the territories portfolio, as Senator Hill recently reminded us. Like immigration, this brought me into contact with a passing parade of fascinating Ministers and shadow Ministers-and some, I must say, were more shadowy than others. None more so than the Labor and Liberal spokespersons to whom I spoke about the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) system of self-government. My efforts to help the people of Canberra achieve democracy were not only frustrated by the desire of the big parties to take voting power away from individual voters by party lists but I was even lumbered with the blame for the mess which was created because my amendments were defeated. But then, as they say, that is politics and it is not compulsory to enter the heat of the kitchen.

As it happened, the people of the ACT showed themselves to be the most alert and cynical in Australia. They were the first to go to the polls and reject the bigger parties. However, the rest of Australia is now catching up. We are already in a situation where there is virtually no such thing as a safe Federal seat and no party which can achieve an absolute majority of the primary vote.

In respect of environmental and animal welfare issues, which I have raised during my three years in the Senate, I must express my disappointment at the lack of progress in several areas. These include: the cruelty involved in the export of live sheep to the Middle East and the failure of this Government to act to protect areas on the register of the National Estate. But on a more positive note, I feel some satisfaction that at last the Hawke Government has agreed to nominate Shark Bay in Western Australia for the World Heritage List. Like Shark Bay, the wetlands of Western Australia are also under threat. Nevertheless, the agreement in September 1989 to nominate 11 Western Australian wetlands in the inclusion on the list of wetlands of international importance under the Ramsar Convention is an important step in this particular direction.

The members of the House of Representatives who fail to be re-elected simply do not return to sit in the Parliament. Senators who fail to be re-elected are more fortunate with their fixed terms. Thus, I and the others mentioned here this evening who are retiring on an involuntary basis have at least had the advantage of a few weeks in which to attempt to complete our work and to tie up a few ends. I must say that when reviewing the workload that I have undertaken I am truly amazed at how great a workload every Australian Democrat senator carries. We have our own heavy portfolio areas of responsibility. In my case, as in Senator Macklin's, I have also had the responsibility of being the sole Australian Democrat parliamentary representative in my State. I have, therefore, taken on a number of State environmental and social justice issues. I could go through a long shopping list but I think it will probably take too long, so I will not do that. But I note that I have issued some 400 media statements on a wide variety of subjects ranging from Australian Rules Football to the ethics and standards of the football they play in the Western Australian Parliament.

I am sorry that Michael Macklin stole my thunder here because I was also going to talk about the incredible notice that came out from Australian Associated Press headed, `Chinese Herbal Medicine Cures Importance'. I must admit that when I saw that on the screen in my office I immediately asked one of my staff members to push all the relevant buttons and have a look at what it actually said. We found that it was not `importance' at all, but something that I do not know whether it would be useful to people in this place. It was disappointing because I thought medicine for `importance' could be quite useful.

There are senators here who have seen senators come and go, and indeed there are some senators who have already had the experience of going and making a comeback. In my going I find myself in very good company. We have heard a lot about the others who are leaving at the same time, and all the parties are well represented. It is multi-partisan company-Labor, Liberal and National parties, as well as independent representation. So I leave this Senate chamber in very good company indeed.

I also leave the ranks of the Australian Democrats in very good company. Two of my senator colleagues did not return to sit in this new Parliament; that is, former Senator Janine Haines, the first woman to lead a political party in Australia-she dazzled this place and left in a blaze of courage-and former Senator Norm Sanders, one of the most committed conservationists I have ever met, and certainly one of the most colourful ones, too.

Last, but not least, I am proud to be in the company as I leave of Senator Michael Macklin, our present leader. Michael is one of the most respected members of this chamber. I know so because I have been told so by people from all sides of the chamber. Michael's intellectual and oratory skills are an inspiration, as is his wit, although, as has already been signalled to the Senate tonight, we have seen perhaps more of that in our party room that we have seen in this chamber.

In the Budget session people here can look forward to having not seven Democrat senators, as they presently have, but eight. Three senators-elect from New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria will join their colleagues on the cross-benches, and 50 per cent of that number will be women. I confess to a feeling of disappointment that I shall not have the privilege and experience of sitting with those eight people.

Although I have been surprised by some of the bitter, offensive and very personal abuse that has been hurled across this chamber, nonetheless I have found helpfulness, courtesy and good company not only from my Australian Democrats colleagues, but also from members of the Labor, Liberal and National parties and all the four independents.

I wish also publicly to state my respect and gratitude to you, Mr President, for your courtesy and consideration at all times, to all the Clerks that sit in the Senate, and especially to Mr Harry Evans. I found all of you ever ready with knowledgeable advice, as I have all the Senate staff.
I would like to express my thanks, too, to the Hansard staff, who work miracles.

The Parliament could not function without our support systems and so I also wish to express my gratitude for all the courteous assistance I have received from the researchers in the Parliamentary Library, the attendants, the transport officers and the Commonwealth car drivers.

I also publicly express my gratitude to the hardworking, long-suffering and totally brilliant staff members that I have had over the past three years, some full time, some part time. So to Madeleine, Richard, Nick, Barbara and Janine, I say, `Thank you'-and that is inadequate.
I also wish to thank members of the Western Australian division of the Australian Democrats and the many volunteer workers who also work the most incredible hours in my office in Perth.

In this respect, I must also publicly express my thanks to my husband Brian, who, when my chief researcher requested not to leave Perth for a year while he nursed a family member through a terminal illness, came here and performed that task as a researcher.

Everyone here has to make sacrifices, but so do all of our families, as Michael said. I actually look forward to being able to spend more time with my children and my grandchildren, and I know that they look forward to having a mother and a grandmother who is not dashing off all the time.

I would not like to depart this place without urging senators, especially those with an interest in the land, to acquaint themselves with the writings of my family forebear, Joseph Jenkins, who arrived at Port Melbourne on 22 March 1869 as a free man at the age of 51.

Painstakingly, Joseph kept a daily diary for 58 years, including 25 years in Australia. A small part of his work was published by Macmillan in 1975 under the title Diary of a Welsh Swagman. The historian Professor Geoffrey Blainey, in an article in the Melbourne Age in 1984, said that this ranks as one of the 10 greatest books written by an Australian. I commend to honourable senators the pleasure of learning about the adventures of the Welsh swagman and his comments on everything from soil degradation to the Kelly gang to the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team led by W. G. Grace.

Joseph Jenkins, who made his way as a labourer in this country, was the best farmer of his generation in his native Cardiganshire in Wales. Those modern Australians who take an interest in the natural environment will be quite stunned when they read Joseph's prophetic words about the destructive nature of early Australian clearing and farming practices in the last century. He designed the first combined dung cart and distributor at least 60 years before such an implement appeared on the market.

He was a famous bard, or poet, in his native Welsh language. At Ballarat, which had a large Welsh mining and farming population, an eisteddfod was held each St David's Day on 1 March. While in the neighbourhood he competed at these meetings on 13 consecutive occasions, capturing the premier prize for poetry in the highly disciplined englyn form on each occasion. While hewing Australian timber, he composed the englyn which has become a motto for the Jenkins family. In translation in the newer language of English, it reads:
Tear not crosswise nor hack in twain--
Glide smoothly along the given grain.
In its true form in poetic Welsh it reads:
Dellto nid hollti allan
Dal yn groes, nid dilyn gran
I commend the spirit of these lines to honourable senators who look for harmony in the affairs of their respective parties and to those who now will embark on a new life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that we are all taking such a long time to retire. I also wish to add some parting comments thanking you, Mr President, and colleagues from both sides of the chamber for their friendship and tolerance throughout my term. There is no doubt that I am fortunate in that, due to the Liberal Party and National Party Victorian joint Senate ticket arrangement, I will be returning. In the ebbs and flows of politics, that is very fortunate. I also particularly thank Glen Sheil for his comradeship over my three years as a senator. He is a very good bloke. The Senate knows that he is also a very humorous man. No-one should underestimate the task he is now taking on-the establishment of a research centre named after his good wife, Marjorie. I think it is a very challenging task and I wish him well.

SPEECH.PARA: I never like to single out people, but I will single out one more, and that is Chris Puplick. I suppose Chris would not remember, but in the first weeks of my term in Parliament he was very friendly and obliging to me. In the ebbs and flows of politics, I have not forgotten that.

I am also very thankful to have served in the old House. I treasure that very closely. As anyone knows, there have been subtle changes in politics through the change from the old House to the new House, some of them good and some of them bad. I hope to return in 1993. To that end, I should put it on record that my Party some 12 months ago preselected me for that position. So I was no mug, Senator Powell. As far as that goes, I am as close as can be to a stitched up position. But, still, I am not holding my breath. Who knows what the spell will do. I suspect that it is a blessing in disguise.

I have been quite surprised at what and how much I have learned in my three years. I can hardly believe how much I have learned. Politics gives one great access to knowledge, opens one to experiences and really draws on every human emotion. I have felt that over the past three years. All terms of parliament present challenges to one's ideals. There would not be a senator come through here who has not thought that he has gone through the most important period of the nation's history. Those challenges to ideals usually come under the guise of raw political advantage.

I am not a believer in the adage that you come in with ideals which are eventually knocked out of you by the time you have served a term or two. I think you ultimately hold onto those ideals. If it is good enough for Senator Jenkins to quote some Welsh and, goodness knows, Senator Puplick to quote Tennyson, I would like to draw on my little quote for the evening as a guide to a politician holding his ideals. It is simply a letter published in Time magazine by a citizen, Arthur Goward, which caught my attention. It said:

We elect a parliament to balance wisdom with the budget and a politician without wisdom is as useless as the language he uses. Fortunately, there is no substitute for spiritual leadership. I wonder if Lech Walesa considers an understanding of fiscal holes and micro-economic reforms of greater value than courage, caring and commitment.

To that end I would like to name two particular Bills that affected my core beliefs. They were the war crimes Bill, relating to the holocaust of World War II and my own private member's Bill relating to the establishment of the end of war list. Those speeches are in Hansard and they capture my feelings at the time. In those times, advice from both sides of the House as a new senator is quite valuable, as Bill O'Chee should find out.

Sometimes honourable senators might think that we do not listen as new senators, but it is true that we do. I have had advice from both sides of the House. I particularly highlighted those two Bills because I remember getting advice from both sides of the House on them. I have learnt in this chamber what many honourable senators will already know in the fullness of politics, and that is that a week is a long time in politics. So when you have your own great personal victories they are soon superseded. When you have your great personal failures or mistakes, the fullness of time places them in perspective. Believe me, I have learnt that lesson. It seems to be a very small lesson, but it really is a big step in perfecting the art of politics. I suspect there is no-one today who has perfected that art. Mr President, to state the obvious, I shall return-a little older, but a great deal wiser.
I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the matters of public interest debate earlier today, I quoted from a document which I now seek leave to table. It was prepared in my office, and if any honourable senators want copies of it I shall be happy to provide them.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief. Like others, I wish all those who are leaving well. I hope that indeed their pastures are greener. I thank them all for their understanding and friendship. My departing Australian Democrats colleagues will be deeply missed by those of us who remain.

SPEECH.PARA: To arrive in this place as a Democrats Senator is a unique experience, particularly under the leadership of Janine Haines and Michael Macklin. They are both former educators. I know that my other colleagues will miss Michael Macklin very much indeed. I have watched him with awe and unbounded respect. I know that that respect is shared by honourable senators on all sides of the chamber.

Being a Democrats Whip is different from being a Whip of the other parties. When one goes to count a division, one has a few spare minutes. During that spare time, it has been my custom to talk with the President and Chairman. Honourable senators might have noticed that David Hamer and I often exchange jokes; that is how we fill in the spare time. I was pleased and honoured that David used one of my favourite jokes here this evening. He just borrowed it from me. It was one I was going to use myself.

However, it did bring to mind another story. It is the story of the lady who overheard a conversation between a rabbi and a priest in a coffee shop. They were discussing at what point life begins. The rabbi insisted that life begins at the moment of birth. The priest rejected that proposition and said that life begins at the moment of conception. They had been engaged in this dialogue for quite some time, and the lady got up to leave the coffee shop and to pay her account. As she walked by the table where the rabbi and the priest had been having this dialogue, she said, `Excuse me, gentlemen. I could not help overhearing your conversation. I can assure you that you are both wrong. Life begins when the children leave home and the dog dies'. It is significant that Michael Macklin has always rejected that proposition. Jean Jenkins has been a gentle and tenacious colleague, for whom I have very genuine affection. Those who know Jean know her to be a person of extraordinary persistence. There is no doubt that she will return to this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to be as brutally honest as Senator McKiernan was in suggesting that I am rising to my feet in order to spend some time waiting for a Bill to arrive from the House of Representatives.
—Even if it is true?

—It is not. I must say that it has been an interesting evening and I think that most honourable senators would agree with me. A great many people for whom we have some affection and respect are leaving the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: In listening to some of the speeches and looking around the room, it really came home to me what an interesting and curious place the Senate is. It is a far more interesting place than the A grade, as members call the House of Representatives. If one looks along the conservative and Australian Labor Party ranks of this place, one will see retired farmers that have planted their last seed, retired lawyers who have seen their last briefs, and retired academics-such as Senator Macklin-who have been on extended sabbaticals for the last 10 years. On our side of the Parliament there is an entire raft of union and Labor Party officials for whom the party is now over, defeated House of Representatives members, failed House of Representatives candidates and assassinated party leaders. It is the flotsam and jetsam of Australian politics, lapping gently like a thick red tide on the welcoming shores of the Senate and disturbed-I must say only rarely-by an intrusive swell from the deep green depths of the House of Representatives. It is a very interesting chamber.

I guess one of the most interesting things about the chamber-and it was mentioned by a number of people here tonight-is that there is a collegiate atmosphere. I say this in a most positive sense about the Senate, despite our political differences. I think this is emphasised by the attidues that honourable senators have towards the people that are leaving the chamber.
