I go back a long way with Chris and knew him before I came to this place. In fact, we were reminiscing about that just the other day. I will not dwell too long on it but Chris Puplick is, I believe, a liberal and, without dwelling too long on it, I think he has paid a very high price for that. Michael Macklin is a fellow `Apple Macophile'-it is not the only thing we share in common-and a person who, like Chris Puplick, has made a lot of meaningful and useful contribution to the debates of this chamber, the committee stage of Bills, and the many Senate committees.
I must say-this is a reasonable reflection-that I came to the Senate with a very negative view of Senate Committees, which has not been realised in my experience of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you have had a lot of experience.

—Indeed, I have had a lot of experience. I had the impression that Senate committees were largely a waste of time, their recommendations were largely ignored, and they did not accomplish very much. But that has not been my experience in the committees that I have had the privilege to work on. There will be some indelible memories taken out of this chamber by those who are leaving us. Senator Jean Jenkins will no doubt take with her the indelible memory of serving on the Senate X-rated video committee-which is one of the more indelible memories I will take with me from this place, no matter how long I serve here. John Stone was a most conscientious and assiduous committee member who always did his homework and made a very strong contribution to the committee work of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: David Hamer has done a job that all of us have appreciated in the scrupulous way he has conducted the affairs of the chamber while he has been in the chair. I greatly appreciate the many conversations I have had with David about the Senate and the procedures of the Senate in which I know he has had such a deep interest and to which he has made such a lasting contribution.

Glen Sheil is a real gentleman and one of the really nice people in this Parliament that I am very sorry to see leave. Norm Sanders is an amiable eccentric. One of the nice things about the Senate is that we do in fact have people like Norm in here. Again, despite being an amiable eccentric, he was a person who made a real contribution to the Senate committees on which I had the privilege to serve with him.
Then there is young Jules who is leaving us-temporarily, he hopes-and will be back with us before too long. I know that Julian McGauran has found his time in the Senate to be a rewarding experience.

I join other honourable senators in wishing all the Senators who are leaving us all the best in whatever careers they pursue. I know that there are a number of us here who, hopefully, will be around long enough to see at least some of them come back to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill makes provision for payment of increased salaries for Parliamentarians and Parliamentary Office-holders, Judges, Secretaries to Departments and senior statutory office-holders, following the disallowance of various determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal contained in its report of 23 May 1990 and its Determination No. 17 in respect of offices in the Industry Commission. The effect of the Bill, by comparison with the provisions of the disallowed determinations, is to alter the commencement of several of the increases from 1 January 1990 to 1 July 1990 (in other words, there will be no retrospectivity as the Tribunal proposes), to decrease some of the recommended rises, and phase in most increases in two or three stages six months apart.
The Bill also provides for linking the basic salary for Parliamentarians to a salary level in the Senior Executive Service of the Public Service-the top of SES Band 1.

Mr President, at present there is a linkage between the salaries of Judges of the Federal Court and members of the Industrial Relations Commission. It is proposed that this link be broken and that members of the Industrial Relations Commission have their salaries fixed in their own right.
Salaries for Judges of the High Court, the Federal Court, the Family Court and ACT Supreme Court, are increased 6% from 1 July 1990 and 6% from 1 January 1991.
Salaries of the President, Deputy Presidents and Commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission are increased by 6% from 1 July 1990.
Those for other judicial related offices are also adjusted. Salaries for Secretaries of Departments and Senior Statutory Holders are increased by 19% from 1 July 1990.

Mr President, as I have indicated, basic salaries for Members of Parliament are linked by this legislation to the top of the SES Band 1. These consequent increases are phased in three instalments-6% from 1 July 1990 and 1 January 1991, and with the balance of approximately 5% from 1 July 1991.

The Government accepts the Remuneration Tribunal's determination of entitlements for Members of Parliament. This includes the option of a private plated car offset by a $6,000 per annum contribution from salary or electorate allowance.
For Parliamentary Office-holders, Expenses of Office Allowances are incorporated in additional salaries and this total amount adjusted in the same way as salaries of other Members and Senators.

The Bill also provides for the necessary appropriations. Mr President, the Government recognises that over the past few years there have been substantial changes in the nature and extent of the responsibilities of Judges, senior officials and Members of Parliament, including Ministers. The Government considers, however, that some greater measure of restraint is necessary, reflecting the restraint shown by other groups in the community.

It is for these reasons that the Government has decided not to adopt the full range of increases determined by the Tribunal in order that the clearest possible consistency be maintained with wage and salary movements in the community at large.
In this context, it is emphasised that the National Wage guidelines are completely met by the provisions now included in this Bill.

Mr President, the Remuneration Tribunal reported to Government on increases for Ministers. As with other Parliamentary Office-holders, the Government will incorporate Expenses of Office Allowances for Ministers into their additional salaries and has decided that an ongoing link be established on the same basis as for Parliamentary Office-holders. That is, Ministers are to receive the same percentage increase in additional salaries as Members of Parliament, and phased in the same way.
Financial Impact Statement

The direct costs of the adjustments proposed (excluding indirect effects on costs of superannuation, etc) are estimated to be approximately $7 million in a full year. These costs are significantly less than would have been incurred had the Tribunal's determination been implemented in full.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Opposition has had only a brief opportunity to read the Remuneration and Allowances Bill 1990 and, indeed, a copy of the second reading speech was kindly made available to me by Senator Cook only a few moments ago, I think it would be the desire of all senators to dispose of this legislation as expeditiously as possible. Therefore, I do not propose to move the adjournment of this matter as we would normally do.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been advised by the Government about its proposals to change the determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal which has been tabled during the course of this afternoon's proceedings. Although the details of that determination were also made available to the Opposition yesterday, we would normally like to have a little more time to consider these matters than the Government has permitted. However, in view of the imminent rising of Parliament for the winter recess, there is no time to consider this matter any further. Despite this, I would like to register our protest that this matter is being dealt with in this rushed way. This is particularly so as the Government has yet again seen fit to alter the determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal. These determinations are being altered not only in relation to members of parliament but also in relation to judges, Secretaries to departments, a large number of senior statutory office-holders and parliamentary office-holders.

This legislation extensively changes the Remuneration Tribunal's own determination. It is being changed by the Government for the reason that is referred to in the second reading speech. The reason is that the Government has been consulting its masters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions and it wishes to emphasise, as set out in the second reading speech, that it will not adopt the full range of increases determined by the Tribunal in order that the clearest possible consistency be maintained with the wage and salary movements in the community at large. It is emphasised that the national wage guidelines are completely met by the provisions now included in the Bill.

That proposal may be well in conformity with the attitudes of the Government and in accordance with its accord. But it is totally contrary to the principles under which the Remuneration Tribunal was set up to determine the salaries of a whole range of public servants, judges and members of parliament. The changes in the case of some of its recommendations are perhaps not all that great. In fact, the differences in the case of the High Court of Australia judges, for instance, are minimal. There have been some fairly substantial cutbacks in the proposed salaries for Secretaries to departments, perhaps even more so than in the case of members of parliament. However, the Opposition is clearly of the view that the determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal should not be tampered with in this way by the Government.

We have had a recent experience in this Parliament where decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to postage allowances for members of parliament was grossly interfered with in the other direction, vastly increased for naked political election purposes by the Government a few months ago. The ultimate result, as a result of High Court decisions and subsequent debates in this parliament, has been to restore the authority of the Remuneration Tribunal on that matter. The Opposition takes the view that the same approach should be taken in relation to these determinations that we have before us today, namely, that they should be left with the decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal. That is a principle upon which the Opposition feels very strongly.

For many reasons the Opposition has decided that it will not oppose this legislation. It simply wishes to reiterate the firm view that it takes in relation to the proper course of action for governments to take. When all is said and done the ultimate decision in matters of this sort has to be made by the Government. It has to take the ultimate responsibility and it is not for oppositions to seek by some means or other to change that. Therefore, we are going to accept, albeit reluctantly, the decisions that have been made by the Government.

There are one or two other matters that I think I should mention. The Opposition does not agree with the linking of a parliamentarian's salary with a public service salary, namely, Senior Executive Service band 1. We believe that the Tribunal gave very convincing reasons why the salaries of members of parliament should not be determined in that way. Certainly some people believe that that is a suitable way of dealing with the salaries of members of parliament.

The Bill certainly seeks to put parliamentary salaries on a permanent linkage. I presume that the Government hopes thereby to avoid further debate about these matters. However, the Tribunal has clearly indicated its opposition to that view. It seems unlikely that this question will be resolved finally by this legislation this evening. Situations may well arise in the future where further recommendations of the Tribunal will not be in accordance with the Government's preferred solution to the question of parliamentary salaries implemented by this legislation.

There is one other matter which I would like to have clarified by the Minister and which I have mentioned to him. There is a reduction of several thousand dollars in the salaries of all parliamentary office holders, led by the salary of the Leader of the Opposition, from that recommended by the Tribunal. We appreciate that the recommended salaries for Ministers under the Remuneration Tribunal do not take effect under this legislation but by an adjustment to the Ministers of State Act. That has not been brought in contemporaneously with this legislation.

I have taken this up with the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, who is at the table, and I hope that he will confirm that there will be a similarly proportioned reduction in the salaries of Ministers of State, that is, that Ministers' salaries will increase in the same way that parliamentary salaries and the salaries of parliamentary office holders increase-namely, by 6 per cent from 1 January until 1 July 1991, when they then become equal to Senator Executive Service salaries. I would like to make sure that that is the intention of the Government, even though it is not included in this package.

As I said, I do not want to detain the Senate any longer than necessary this evening. It is a matter of regret that this matter is being dealt with at this hour and in this way. It is particularly regrettable that the Government has seen fit to alter this determination, but the Opposition will not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation we have before us has come about in a most unfortunate manner. The Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 was a brave attempt to get an independent outside body to deliberate on and to make recommendations and finally determinations on salaries not only of members of parliament but also of senior office holders in the Commonwealth. I say `a brave attempt' because from the very start it was sabotaged by various people, mainly Prime Ministers, seeking political kudos for themselves-not only the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) but also previous Prime Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: The exercise we are now going through is just another one of those long, sorry sagas. I share Senator Durack's belief that this will not be the end. It will not end until the Prime Minister and the Cabinet take note of the spirit of the Act and finally allow to operate what everybody believes should be operating, that is, an independent outside body making a deliberation and bringing down a determination.

In this particular case there is an extremely long and well-argued introduction by the Tribunal, which earlier this evening suffered an historic rebuff from the Government when its report was disallowed by the House of Representatives. It is a pity that honourable senators and honourable members probably have not had a chance to read through the 32 pages of introduction.

I am quite sure that honourable senators have probably turned to page 32, where the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who is sitting at the table, starts his submission to the Tribunal. It was a submission that was well argued, a submission which has the support of all parties in this place. It was a submission upon which the Tribunal felt it was entitled to rely. The Tribunal thought that this submission was the Government's submission. It had the Minister's signature attached. The Tribunal thought, in terms of talking to other parties in this place, that the Government supported this submission. It thought then that, for the first time in many a long year, it would be able to get this right-it would bring in a determination that was acceptable to the Parliament. So it went ahead. The Tribunal must now be feeling extraordinarily bruised because the Government has again reneged on its submission and because a government yet again has spurned its determination.

The Bill we have before us has a number of changes. It is a pity that these have occurred. The exercise is not necessarily whether a particular level is one that one would want to argue for. It is the principle that the determination should not be made by this Parliament. The determination that was made is not the one contained in this Bill.

We are now back into a situation that the Bill in 1972 was passed to avoid: that is, we are now determining our own remuneration yet again. I think that the principle that applies to all other members of the community whereby they do not determine their own remuneration is one that the community wishes to see espoused. Members of the community do not want us to say that this is what we will get. They want it done by somebody else. They want it done as we have here, by a judge sitting with a group of other people, eminent citizens, making a clear and deliberative determination based on the presentation of facts before them that have been argued. The Democrats do not resile from the position we have taken for a very long time, that is, that this Parliament should agree to the determinations made independently of this and the other chamber.

There are some substantive changes outside the changes to the amounts. I do not intend to debate those amounts. As I say, they are amounts which have gone down. We are not upset by the fact the they have gone down. The exercise over time is such that one gives up on that particular worry.

There is a significant change with regard to the linkage. The Democrats have argued strongly in support of this linkage over many years. There are problems with it. The problems were set out quite comprehensively by the Remuneration Tribunal in this report tabled earlier today. Nevertheless, on balance, it would seem that, unless we are willing to go down the track of a fresh determination from scratch which tries to work out precisely what a member of parliament is worth by relating each and every part of his or her operations to the market outside-I think quite frankly, if one did that one would probably arrive at a figure which no-one in the community would wear-the second best option is this one: we seek an appropriate level within the Public Service, which has been the rate of the SES band 1 annual salary, to be the rate that is appropriate for members of parliament. I hope that this is the start of a stable regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, Ha!

—I said that I hope it will be the start of a stable regime. I agree with Senator Durack; I doubt very much that it will. This brawl will go on until there is agreement by everyone, which I thought there was.

SPEECH.PARA: As the person who represented my Party in various discussions in this place, I thought that finally there was an agreement that we would refrain from one-upmanship and getting a bit of kudos for ourselves-whether it be the celebrated exercise when Mr Fraser and Mr Anthony fell out or whether it be with Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. Whatever it is, it is not an edifying exercise; but the worst thing about it is that it is an unprincipled exercise. It is in opposition to what the community is seeking, which is an independent, non-pressured estimation of what these various people are worth and a determination brought down in an independent way.
I know that the Minister for Industrial Relations, who is at the table, has sought that. I am certainly not blaming him for what we are facing here tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are you blaming? Who is responsible for it?

—The exercise is relatively clear. Most of the Government members whom I have spoken to do not relish what is going on here tonight. They have been forced into it, as we all have. Senator Durack, who spoke on behalf of the Opposition, and I on behalf of the Australian Democrats wish that we were not talking about this. We have been forced into this situation because there is nothing else before us. The determination was disallowed and this is all we now have. We have not had the opportunity of being able to support the determination of the Tribunal, which we should have been able to do.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sorry and unfortunate situation and one which will probably mean that come 1 July parliamentarians will seek to flagellate themselves in public, come 1 January they will do it again, and come 1 July next year they will do it again. We seemingly enjoy this exercise. It is an absurd proposition. It is not a proposition in anybody's interest or of the making of anybody here. That in itself is unfortunate.

It is worth noting at least one point about the various levels that have been indicated here. If one turns to the Remuneration Tribunal's report one sees that the lowest salaries are for members of parliament. The market dictates every other salary. I take honourable senators back to the time when parliamentarians were not paid and the place was for the rich and the privileged. At the moment it is not like that. Obviously with these salaries, it will not be like that for a number of years. I believe we cannot allow to continue indefinitely an exercise where the elected members of parliament, the people who have to make the decisions and wear the brunt of it, are paid the least. All their advisers and all their staff are paid way above that. Ultimately, it is absurd.

There are some very interesting statistics on the movement of the salaries of members of parliament over time. From June 1974 to May 1990, average male weekly earnings in Australia rose by 350 per cent; the consumer price index rose by 315.7 per cent; the standard surgery visit rose by 346.8 per cent; the age pension rose by 443 per cent; and the salary for a senator and members rose by 175 per cent. If everybody else in the community had been linked to us we would have had the best wage restraint policy that Australia could ever have hoped for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I get terribly annoyed about this whole process. Earlier in the day we had to go through the ignominy of having the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who is in the chamber, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Mr Kelty in a telephone hook-up to decide what will happen to our salaries. That is no way to determine parliamentarians' salaries. It would not even happen in Venezuela, Colombia and those sorts of places, but here we have to grovel on the telephone seeking the permission of some total stranger as to what is a reasonable remuneration for members of parliament and how they should get it.

SPEECH.PARA: This farce has been going on for 15 years now, to my certain knowledge, and I do not appreciate it one little bit. I support the Remuneration Tribunal. It was set up to do a job. There is not one body in Australia that is likely to do that job as well. Why do we not use it? If we are going to keep the Tribunal, for goodness sake, let us support it.

Today we have had this procession of Government members either ringing us up or beating tracks to our doors complaining about their problems with their own people. Why do we have to fight the battles of Government members? Why can they not look after themselves? They are the ones in government.

I agree with Senator Macklin-I suppose this is one of the things that happens at a time when someone will not be with us for long-to a point. When he said, `I would like to think', I think that was a fond hope more than a genuine expectation.

The whole method of approach on this occasion has been totally unprincipled. We have already been judged by the media. The 9 o'clock news tonight made it clear that parliamentarians had achieved a $65,000 pay level. Are they likely to come out on the 1 o'clock news and say, `We are sorry, we made a little mistake. They didn't get the $65,000 we said they did'? This was only done for publicity and now, as usual, we cop the acrimony and do not achieve the sort of remuneration that the system lays down is reasonable under the circumstances.

I do not know one member here who is seeking anything more than the Tribunal believes is reasonable. That is all we are asking. That is all we believe it should be. The whole thing has got to the farcical stage. I call on the Government to have another think about this matter and do something sensible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say to Senator Macklin that he does not always make speeches in this place that I agree with, but tonight I heard him make a speech in which I agreed with everything he said until the very death-knock when he made a comment about Doug Anthony and Malcolm Fraser and what they did when they were Deputy Prime Minister and Prime Minister. Senator Macklin was wrong in relation to Doug Anthony. Doug Anthony had the courage to do what Senator Macklin wanted him to do. He arranged with Bill Hayden to accept the determination of the Remuneration Tribunal while Malcolm Fraser was overseas. A week after they had arrange it and we had suffered the barbs of the journalists, Malcolm came back from overseas and rolled the whole Cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at what has happened here today. I do not think any member of parliament except the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is opposed to this determination. I do not think there would be one. I think that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), also probably supports the determination. The Prime Minister has spoken to Mr Kelty, Mr Kelty has pointed out to him the difficulties of the accord and the Prime Minister has rolled the Executive of Cabinet. Then it rolled Cabinet. Then Cabinet rolled the Caucus this morning. Now it has rolled us and the Australian Democrats.

This decision tonight is absolutely shameful. I do not believe that anyone will call for a vote on it because I do not think anyone wants to be actually counted in relation to the Remuneration and Allowances Bill 1990. This Bill undermines the Remuneration Tribunal totally, and that is the crucial thing. What we are doing here tonight is shameful because we are undermining this independent body. We have asked it to do a job. We have given it the responsibility of doing a job. It has done the job. As Senator Macklin said, it even had a Government submission where it thought, `At last we have got a Government that has got the guts to accept that politicians are entitled to a reasonable salary'. No-one is asking for politicians to be highly paid but they are entitled at least to a reasonable salary. At last the Tribunal thought it had a Government that had the guts to pay a reasonable salary.

I say to the Government and the Government backbenchers: `I think you had the Opposition that had the guts to accept it too. Do not listen to your leaders because I have known, both in government and opposition, my leaders saying to me, ``You cannot trust the other side; at the last moment they will let you down'' '. Believe me, we would have stood by those on the Government side. What has happened? One member of Parliament, the Prime Minister, has rolled it. He has undermined this determination by reasonable people given a job to do. Frankly, I have not even looked at the determination. I have not had a chance to do so and I do not care whether it is good, bad or indifferent. I wanted to accept it. I say to the Government: `I would rather not have your filthy money in this Bill. I would rather go for another year with my current salary than have something changed by an Act of Parliament'.

This was the time, 1990. We have just had an election. This was the time to stand up for the Remuneration Tribunal, let it have its say and then implement it and say, `Right, that is it in 1990. Now, whatever you do in 1991 we are going to accept it again. For 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995-for the rest of this decade and beyond-we will accept whatever you say'. Here we are down the drain less than a couple of months after the last election. Next year, 1991, members of parliament will be starting to look at their marginal electorates and what people will be thinking there, whether they will vote against them. The politics of the matter will come into play. Why are we confronted with this Bill? I say again I would rather go without whatever salary rises are set out in this Bill than do what we are doing here tonight. I think it is an absolutely shameful situation.

Why are we doing what we are doing tonight? The public out there believe already that we have been given a salary rise up to $65,000-and, I gather, it is not true. The news tonight is that we have been given a 17 3/4 per cent rise. It is not true, but that is what everyone believes, and there is no way that belief can be turned around. I cannot find anyone who has yet said to me that we should not be supporting the Tribunal's finding, and yet what has happened today is that, because of the Prime Minister and Mr Kelty getting together for some crazy political reason to do with salaries being paid under the accord, the House of Representatives has disallowed the determination and we are stuck with this Bill, which I believe to be a quite shameful Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never spoken on any of these remuneration Bills in the time I have been in the Parliament, but I am making a breach from practice on the Remuneration and Allowances Bill tonight because I am very annoyed about at least three elements in this Bill. The first one is, as the previous speakers have said, the breach of a principle. We set up an independent tribunal, and in all the time I have been here, Senator Archer advises me, in only one year has the Remuneration Tribunal's findings with respect to parliamentary salaries been accepted. We set up the Remuneration Tribunal, as all the speakers on this side have said, to come to an independent determination. I believe that the Tribunals over the years have done that conscientiously and well, and yet in every case we have spurned their determination. The breach of that principle is my first objection.

SPEECH.PARA: My second objection to the legislation is that my salary is set by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Last year we had precisely the same situation. We had some union thugs in the ACTU deciding what we, the members of the Parliament of this country, should be paid. I object to that very much, particularly when we are asked to support a failed accord, a failed economic policy.

My third objection to this is that we are linked with the lowest grade of the Public Service Senior Executive Service. I do not want to be linked with anyone. I want to be valued as a parliamentarian and paid whatever some independent tribunal thinks. I do not want parity with anyone in the Public Service at all. I say that for a very important reason. I believe that we are here in the position of governing this country. It is for us to make decisions and to accept the reponsibility for those decisions. That is what we are paid for. We are not paper shufflers in any branch of the Public Service. Having made those points clear, I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not intending to speak on the Remuneration and Allowances Bill, but I wish to ask the Minister for Industrial Relation (Senator Cook) a question. I will give him some time so that he may respond in his second reading reply. I refer to the Remuneration Tribunal determination which is before us and point out, in prefacing what I want to know from the Minister, that in framing its recommendations the Tribunal was itself basing that determination on a submission from the Government. The Tribunal's own words in relation to the accord and the various considerations which it had to take into account were:

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, it is the firm conclusion of the Tribunal that a salary of-
so much-

. . . would be within the Wage Guidelines as applicable to Members and would be within the spirit and intent of them. In addition, experience since 1983 has shown that when Government or the Members have, in an endeavour to achieve worthy collateral purposes, reduced the salaries which Members otherwise would receive, the result has been confusion and injustice to ordinary Members.
Those are the words of the Tribunal itself. At page 23, speaking specifically of the salary, it goes on:
In relation to salary, the Government submissions suggested three things-

and it goes on and actually outlines those things. The rest of the Tribunal's report indicates quite clearly that the Tribunal was not only acting at arm's length but was basing its determination, its consideration, and its final recommendations, substantially on information which had been put before it by the Government, and yet the Government then turns around at the end of that whole process and rejects that determination.

In relation to the linking, this report points out that the Tribunal even considered the situation in the American Senate where linkage has been tried and found not to work; in other words, involving the Tribunal in considerable expense in undergoing this investigation and coming down with this determination. I ask the Minister: What has it cost the Remuneration Tribunal to go through this lengthy process of coming to a determination simply to have that determination rejected and thrown out completely? I would like to know that in the Minister's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in this debate, having just read part of the Remuneration Tribunal's report. I would just like to refer to the linkage system. We are told by the Government that it would like us to be linked to the Senior Executive Service (SES) Band 1 of the Australian Public Service. That was the submission that the Government put to the Tribunal. I think it is important that we understand what the Government is doing. The Tribunal made the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: That form of linkage would not be appropriate, for several reasons:
it would be wrong in principle;
it would attract, and properly attract, the kind of public controversy which a linkage procedure seeks to avoid;
it would be unfair to Members;
it would be unfair to the SES officers concerned;
it would not work in practice.

A simple linkage is wrong in principle. The salary of Members, like the salary of other employees whose wages are fixed by tribunals, should be fixed accordingly to the proper assessment of what Members have to do. To fix a member's salary, or to award an increase of it, because the work assessment of someone else has warranted an increase in salary for that person, would be wrong. And so would a rise in Members' salary.

It is very clear that the Tribunal has told the Government that it believes its submission is wrong in principle. The Government has set up a tribunal and asked this independent tribunal to give a decision on the wages and benefits of members of the Parliament. The Government has put forward a submission to the Tribunal and the Tribunal has said that its suggestion of linkage is wrong in principle. It said very clearly that it is not only wrong in principle, but it would be unfair to members and it would be unfair to the Senior Executive Service officers concerned. Yet the Government has said, `Blast the Tribunal'. The independent Tribunal has been appointed for a particular job and the Government does not care what the Tribunal has said and is going to insist upon setting its own standard for the salaries of those in government and in opposition.

I think that is the basic problem that the Government is now facing. It has put forward a submission which the Remuneration Tribunal says is wrong in principle and unfair to all concerned. Yet the Government has made a decision, in its usual way, to override all that. In the past Prime Ministers have not accepted the full benefit to be awarded by the Tribunal to members, senators and Ministers in this place. Many Prime Ministers of all persuasions have changed the award. But on this occasion it has nothing to do with not accepting the recommended salary. It has to do with the Prime Minister of this country saying that the Government will override the Tribunal, which is a totally different kettle of fish.

I have just been told that we now have to adjourn this debate after the second reading speeches because of mistakes in this document made by the Government at a quarter to one in the morning. The Government is trying to push through legislation which is wrong and which the Tribunal says is wrong in principle, is wrong to the public servants and is wrong to members of parliament.

Why is the Government trying to push the Bill through in the small hours of the morning? As usual, when the Government tries this shoddy sort of stuff, it falls flat on its face because it tries to do little deals which do not come off. The Government's big act of hanging around and filling in time while Government members wait for a Bill to come from another place has not worked. The Government will not get its Bill tonight after all. We shall have to sit tomorrow because of the Government's bumbling and fumbling. The Government's rotten little deals have not come off. So we will be going home later after this debate, when all of my colleagues have finished speaking. We will have to come back to debate this matter in the morning because the Government could not organise itself sufficiently to get the matter right.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are trying to fix it.
—Then perhaps I can go on speaking for a while while the Government gets around to fixing it.
—We had a bit of filling earlier.

—We had a little filling, as Senator Hill says, from the Deputy Whip. Maybe I can fill in a little more. Perhaps the Minister would like to hear a bit more of what the Tribunal said, because I could certainly go on. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: At present, any rise for an SES officer would ordinarily be justified for one of two reasons: because of National Wage increases; and because a change in the duties of office and the assessment of its work value make it appropriate.
It is the latter kind of rise which is in question. National wage increases are readily passed on. But to pass increases of the latter kind in SES salaries on to members would be wrong in principle.
A ``simple'' linkage would attract criticism: criticism of a rise given for the wrong reason would properly be raised.
The Tribunal then says:
A `simple' linkage would be unfair to Members: it would result in their receiving less-and perhaps increasingly less, than they should receive. There are two reasons for this:

First, on the present work assessment of Members and the SES at band 1, Members should receive more than such officers. In 1975, the Tribunal assessed the work then carried out by members. The assessment placed their salary at a level which happened to be between Level 1 and Level 2 of the Second Division of the APS (now the SES). But the nature of the work of Members, and their workload, has increased since 1975.

And it is likely to increase. This became evident in the 1987-88 work assessment of Members: they were put significantly above Level 1/Level 2 in the APS. Members were then assessed at $67,000. Level 1 and Level 2 officers were then $52,720 and $57,775. Members' salary and the increase of them, should not be reduced because of the position of SES officers.

I come back to the fact that this Government put in a submission to the Tribunal. The Tribunal said it was wrong in principle, it was wrong to public servants and it was wrong to the members. But despite it all, the Government has gone along and introduced a system that is wrong in principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only in the last few minutes had an opportunity to read the Remuneration Tribunal findings and contrast them with the Government's decision. As Senator Walters says, the truth of the matter is that the Government has in no part made any determinations in this matter on merit, but rather it simply has done so on a political consideration, as it has always done in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot recall the last time a salary increase was granted to members of parliament on the determination of their merit. For the last period since 1983, and certainly prior to that, it has been based on political expediency. I get no pleasure in recalling what happened in 1980 when Doug Anthony accepted the Tribunal's determination, only to have Malcolm Fraser come back, fly into Perth, go to the Liberal Party conference at the Sheraton Hotel and be accosted by two of our colleagues who were in marginal seats and be convinced that there was a political vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask honourable senators to sit down as there is too much movement in the chamber.

—I am not unused to standing room only when I am speaking and I am personally not offended. But if it is disorderly, then those honourable senators should stand outside and watch the monitors. It gives me no comfort to recall that for cheap political points in 1980, after Doug Anthony, the Acting Prime Minister, had entered into an arrangement with the then Leader of the Opposition and the now Governor-General, Mr Hayden, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, flew back to Perth and was accosted by two of my colleagues from Western Australia who were convinced that their seats were in peril and that a salary cut could be a salvation. Both of them lost their seats at the next election, notwithstanding the fact that we took a salary cut of 10 per cent as a result of it.
—On our first day here we actually got a 20 per cent rise.
—In my first visit to the party room, I got a cut of 10 per cent. The tragedy is that the Tribunal was set up--
—I have never seen more incompetent Ministers than this bunch.

—Frankly, I am not here as an advocate for paying Ministers of this Government on value. I am here to argue the intrinsic merits of appropriate salary ranges for members and senators, based on appropriate criteria, not some grotty telephone link-up between some faceless man in the Australian Council of Trade Unions, some powerless man in the Prime Minister's suite and whoever else hangs on these telephone calls and makes these sorts of arrangements which in no way are relevant to merit, justice or integrity.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the decision of 1980 to suspend the integrity of the Tribunal, the process has degenerated and deteriorated. As we all remember, the purpose of setting up the Tribunal in the first place was to take from the hands of government and Parliament the decision to pay ourselves what we judged ourselves to be worth because it was seen to be politically tainted and inappropriate for us so to do. The Tribunal was set up to ensure that decisions and judgments were made on value, virtue and merit and not on self-interest. The tragedy is that since that day we have had nothing but self-interest. We have had no value, virtue or merit and no consideration of the relevant factors.

On this occasion we have again seen the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) struggling to cope with political expediency at a time-as someone else said earlier-when the Tribunal for once thought that it could bring down a resolution or a finding that would receive support from all political parties. If I were a member of that Tribunal I would resign in disgust; I would resign on the basis that I had not yet brought down a determination that was judged by the Government to be competent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have won me. You are on it if they do resign!

—If I went on the Tribunal I would double my salary, Senator Ray. What was the expression of the present and temporary Treasurer about self-interest? It was: `Back it every time because you know it is trying'. The tragedy is that no longer does anyone believe that any determinations are made on the basis of worth. Not one single member of the Federal Parliament any longer believes that the decisions are being made on the basis of merit. Everyone of use knows that every time this matter comes up it is subject to political expediency.
—Take a cut!

—Senator Cooney says, `Take a cut'. Personally, in my moments of depression and weakness I see merit in paying nothing. Then we would see who stays in the Lodge for how long. The days of living on litigation are well past. Everybody in this Parliament knows that the decisions are grotty little deals done behind closed doors to see what is in the best interests of the government of the day.
—Your Government as well.
—Our Government did it in 1980.
—You started the whole damn thing.

—Our Government did start it, but like all things we start we did it with some modesty. Perhaps there was a taint of incompetence. This Government has turned it into an art form. That is what it has done on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall read this document ever so briefly. The arguments now being put to us in the second reading speech are dismissed as irrelevant. The speech states:
The Bill also provides for linking the basic salary for Parliamentarians to a salary level in the Senior Executive Service of the Public Service-the top of SES Band 1.
That is a total abrogation of the responsibility for making discrete decisions about the worth and merit of members of parliament. Somewhere in the Tribunal's contemplations it says:

A simple linkage is wrong in principle. The salary of Members, like the salary of other employees whose wages are fixed by tribunals, should be fixed according to the proper assessment of what Members have to do.

In other words, the Tribunal is pleading for once for members of parliament to be paid what they are worth. Perhaps in many respects that is subjective, depending on where one stands, but at the end of the day somebody has to make that assessment. The reason we have a Tribunal is to allow it to attempt in an objective form to draw a conclusion.

As I look at the salaries of members of parliament-$58,000 or something ever so modest-and I compare that with every other salary range in this document, I see that almost without exception it is half the salary. Is there one person in this chamber who will put up his or her hand and say that he or she is not worth at least in terms of contribution, ability, time, endurance vaguely more than half anybody else whose salary is determined by the Tribunal?

For far too long the salaries of members of parliament have been political footballs. The Government knows that it can get away with it because, like shrinking violets, we modestly blush and step back from standing up and being counted and saying, `We believe we are worth more'. I think on this occasion the Tribunal thought it had common approval. I suspect that from now on the Tribunal will throw up its hands and give it away.

I was interested to hear it reported that the great advocate in the caucus for this piece of legislation was one Simon Crean. He has not spent one miserable day in his life on a back bench salary. He comes cruising in-

TALK.START.PARA: —Eat your heart out.
—Senator Ray knows how to hurt.
—Order!

—I am sorry, Mr President, I did not realise that I had attracted you in to the chamber. The ex-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) wanders benignly into this place, cruises as a result of some sort of factional deal on to the front bench, and two or three members with competence and capacity are shuffled off the front bench to allow for another grotty little deal by this Prime Minister. He has the audacity to stand up in the caucus room and lecture the back benchers on what they are worth, for goodness sake! He has not spent one day on their salary. If he had any integrity he would donate the difference between his salary and their salary to a fighting fund to help them improve their conditions.
—Appoint Ray Devlin.

—I knew that we had to get on to this matter with a great deal of haste but I was very much tempted to stand up and speak tonight in respect of Senator Devlin. It is a pity that he is not on our Tribunal, instead of helping others.
—As well as.
—Yes, as well as. It is interesting in not a cynical but an objective way to read what the Tribunal said:

SPEECH.PARA: A `simple' linkage would be unfair to the SES officers
This is the irony of it.

Experience has shown that when the salaries of Members of a legislative body are linked to those of civil servants the result is apt to be not to lift the Members' salary but to keep down the civil servants'.

In other words, the poor old civil servant gets linked to us. We think that by being linked to them we might float like flotsam and jetsam to the top. What happens is that we pull them down. They get sucked into the political process.

TALK.START.PARA: —On performance pay they will get around it.
—Perhaps that is the case. I notice that the Government has rejected a dislocation allowance.
—It has not rejected a dislocation allowance. The Tribunal never determined one.
—Order! This subject may be discussed in Committee; not across the chamber.

—The reason that the Tribunal ultimately gave up on this question of a dislocation allowance is that it was pretty clear to it that the Government was not going to have a part of it. It has already made that clear.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that nothing is to be gained by arguing this issue. That is the tragedy of it and that is the basis on which the Government makes these decisions. But if it were in any other forum being argued by the ACTU or any of its body parts, dislocation would be an intrinsic part of the determination.

I do not complain. It is always said to parliamentarians, and I guess it is so easy to say it, `If you don't like the job there are always a lot lining up behind you who will do it for you'. That, I understood, was not an argument that the Government or the ACTU have ever accepted about minimum wages. I thought that they determined and demanded that people be paid not on who wants their job but what the job is worth. I do not complain. During the pilots dispute last yeat I spent 12 full weeks without going through the front door of my own home. I do not complain that in the last month I have slept in my own home twice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was she surprised?
—Order!

—I suppose it is the sort of thing one can make witty cracks about, and that adds to the colour of the debate, but it is not a lot of fun spending a lot of time in Meekatharra. Which reminds me. What did Tamie Fraser say?
—Don't.
—I was born in Wiluna, so I have some very close emotional attachments to Meekatharra. I am just saying that it is not the place I go for my holidays every year.
—Crean gets an additional $46,000.

—He gets $46,000 extra, plus his base salary? Senator Lewis is not going to tell me next by way of interjection that Minister Crean is on some sort of superannuation scheme from the ACTU? He is not going to suggest for a moment that Minister Crean is double dipping or that he is getting any fringe benefits from being the President of the ACTU, and at the same time has the pomposity to stand up in the Caucus room today and harangue the poor, hungry, mean, lean back benchers and tell them that they are overpaid? He is not going to imply that the advocate of the working man will suggest that as he gets out of his Commonwealth car, goes into his plush office and writes himself out a cheque for his penthouse, the proletariat is only worth $55,000 and he is worth double that? I have heard of upwardly mobile. That is what one would call astronomical. It is amazing. What did Gough Whitlam say when he became Prime Minister? He said that God deserves the best. So he bought himself a Mercedes and the previous Prime Minister had been driving a broken-down Holden. They sure know how to live high on the hog.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me conclude on a serious note by saying that it is a pity for those who have difficulty living on the salaries that they do, that they have to suffer continuously because of political expediency. There are those of my colleagues-I consider I have colleagues on both sides of the Parliament-that come into this Parliament with certain obligations, certain responsibilities, certain encumbrances, a certain standard of living and a certain lifestyle. They find as they remain in political life that that is eaten away or eroded to the point where continuously, in the pursuit of serving their electorate and their State, they have to accept a lower standard of living.

There are very few of us that much mind that; but for many of us being in Parliament can be considered in some ways a hobby-a full-time hobby and a full-time commitment. But it is an awful price that we cast upon our families and our children to allow us to pursue that which is of interest to us in areas where we believe we can make a contribution. It is the wives and the children who have to suffer the reduced standard of living simply because this Government has not the guts, has not the courage, has not the fortitude and, least of all, has not the integrity to pay parliamentarians what they are worth. Yet, with respect, I have to say that I do not think there is a damn vote in it.

I remember reading two lines in the Courier-Mail when the fringe benefits tax was introduced. Joh just slipped up the salaries of the members of parliament to include that tax and there was barely a blip. But of course Joh did not have to do deals with the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know who he did deals with.
—He did not have the ACTU as his master.
—If I had Thiess looking after me I wouldn't have to do any deals.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—As I noticed in a cursory way some of the police court charges in Queensland I thought a few of Bob's mates-people he had given written references for-seemed to be having a bit of trouble from time to time.
—There are not too many interjections from that side this time.

—No. The difference is that this Prime Minister has to get on the telephone to someone outside of Parliament every time he wants anything. I seem to remember Coronation Hill when the Prime Minister of this Government for all people, for all time, had to ring up the Australian Conservation Foundation to decide whether he would give away billions of dollars worth of exports to save himself and to save his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that it is no credit to this Government, nor to those on that side, that we find ourselves subject to this grotty deal. It is very interesting, and perhaps a bit unkind of me to say, that it was not without significance to note that those who stood up in the Caucus today and argued for this arrangement were the Gerry Hands, the Nick Bolkuses and all the beneficiaries of the Prime Minister's indulgence after the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my adjournment speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
STATEMENT TO THE SENATE
The portion incorporated deals with the financial circumstances of Mr Donald Brownlie Fleming and his bankruptcy proceedings.

The portion of the segment I have not incorporated deals with the involvement of Fleming and several partners in running business and motivational courses. That portion is not relevant to the matter I raise tonight, nor in fact do I have any knowledge of the matters raised in that portion of the program which concerns the courses.

The matter I wish to raise relates to the portion of the segment presented as a re-enactment of Fleming's bankruptcy hearing. Reference to the transcript will show that two assertions made by the actor playing Don Fleming in bankruptcy hearings re-enacted may be summarised as:
Grant Chapman was one of the friends who approached Fleming about setting up a discretionary trust for his family
Grant Chapman was one of those who established the trust
The inferences are made by the program that I assisted Fleming, through this trust, to avoid meeting his obligations to creditors-and did this while a Federal Liberal member of parliament.
Both the assertions and the inferences are false.

My association with Donald Fleming was as part of a Christian fellowship group of about 6 people of which he was also part, which was initiated by an ordained Baptist pastor, Milt Richards. The fellowship met approximately weekly between mid-1983 and early 1988. My own involvement tapered off from early 1987, due to absences overseas on business and then, after election to the Senate, absences in Canberra. A particular purpose of this group was to encourage each other to practise christianity day-by-day in our personal, family and business lives.

In line with that, this group raised with Fleming on a number of occasions his apparent continuing failure to properly manage his personal finances and therefore his failure to provide financially for the day-to-day needs of his wife and children.

Subsequently, several members of the group proposed to Fleming that his financial affairs be operated by a trust, so that he would not have control of his business chequebook to indulge his spendthrift ways at the expense of his wife and children.
But I was not one of those who put this proposal to him.
Fleming acquiesced, but reluctantly.

Irrespective of Fleming's personal motives in accepting this proposal and his final acceptance of the proposition put by the interrogator in his bankruptcy proceedings that a purpose of the trust was: (in the interrogator's words) ``That if you did go bankrupt, any assets you may have acquired in your own name would be in the name of the trust and thus prevent the official receiver or trustees from obtaining these assets for the benefit of the creditors'', I believe that purpose was not in the minds of those who proposed the trust. It was certainly not a purpose of the trust during any of the time that I was subsequently a director of the trustee company.

The purpose of the trust was simply to remove from Fleming the capacity to spend willy nilly, and to ensure any income or assets earnt by his new business activities were primarily spent on his wife and children, not frittered away. Indeed, to ensure that he did not amass debts beyond his capacity to pay.
I did not establish the trust, as asserted.
A solicitor, who was a member of the fellowship group, was the settlor who established the trust, known as the Hamilton settlement, on 25th August 1986.

Earlier in the year, on 26th February 1986, the fellowship group had acquired a shelf company, Clearnew Pty Ltd, which it had planned to use for possible commercial activities with a charitable intent.
Three members of the fellowship group, including me, took directorships of this company, while another became company secretary. Don Fleming had no position in it.
The commercial/charitable plans for the company did not develop and it lay dormant.
When the trust was settled, the directors of Clearnew Pty Ltd therefore agreed for this company to be given over for the purpose of being the trustee company for the Hamilton settlement.
At this time, I resigned as a director of Clearnew. To be more precise, I did so, 1 3/4 hours before it accepted responsibility as the trustee company for the trust.
The company secretary also resigned. The other two directors remained in office, with one of them also becoming company secretary and public officer.
So, I played no role in the establishment or the early activities of the trust.
Subsequently, there was a proposal for the trust to acquire an interest in a second board listed company, of which two of the directors, were the directors of the trustee company, Clearnew Pty Ltd.
To avoid any possible conflict of interest, they resigned as directors of the trustee company, Clearnew Pty Ltd., on 26th November 1986.

Because of the purpose which the fellowship group had for the trust at the outset-to assist Fleming to be responsible in his financial affairs to the benefit of his wife and children-it was regarded as appropriate that the directors of the trustee company continue to be drawn from the group.
Pastor Milt Richards and I, as two members of the group with no vested interest in the transaction, accepted the directorships, driven by a christian compassion for Mrs Fleming and her children.
I also became company secretary, public officer and, with Richards, a bank account signatory for the trustee company.
The motivation and subsequent behaviour of us both in relation to the trust was entirely altruistic and directed towards the welfare of Mrs Fleming and her children.

The only activity of the trustee company during the period that I was a director was to authorise it being a guarantor for a loan relating to the transaction for which a memorandum of heads of agreement had been approved on 3rd October 1986, before I was a director. The loan guarantee was approved on 27 February 1987.

I resigned as a director on 26th June 1987, following pre-selection for a position on the S.A. Liberal Senate Team, as I regarded it as inappropriate to retain a directorship not relevant to my direct commercial interests once becoming a senator.
During my time as a director, the trust did not receive income or assets, nor incur any liabilities.
Neither the proposed transaction or the loan proceeded during my time as a director.

This reinforces that the purpose asserted by the interrogator in the Fleming bankruptcy case was not a purpose, either by intent or practice, during the time that I was a director of the trustee company.
I am not aware of the activities or purpose of the trust after my involvement ceased.
But my concern for Mrs Fleming and her children was maintained.

She was a competent secretary, so I employed her as my full-time electorate secretary when first elected as a senator, giving her and the children an income independent of Don Fleming. She subsequently worked for me on a relieving and part-time basis and again full-time from July 1989 until March 1990, when she moved from Adelaide to Sydney, having separated from her husband some months earlier.

To summarize: my involvement with the hamilton settlement as a director, for a short period, of its trustee company, Clearview Pty Ltd., was neither intended, nor did it allow, Don Fleming to avoid responsibilities to creditors, as has been inferred in the 7.30 Report. It was at all times conducted in the interests of his wife and children.

Apart from the fellowship group activities, my only other involvement with Don Fleming was, firstly to undertake in the latter part of 1983, as a consultant, a market research project relating to export opportunities for a company with which he was associated.

Secondly, a company in which I had a beneficial interest bought shares in a caravan and tourist accommodation complex and also provided a shareholders' loan to the project. He and several other people also held shares in this complex. These shares were sold at their purchase price and the loan repaid to my company more than a year later.

Thirdly, in 1987, I introduced Don Fleming to a potential investor from Asia. I understand this investor subsequently purchased land south of Adelaide from one of the company associated with Don Fleming, and that investor is successfully proceeding with a subdivision and development project on that land.
I have only had discussions with Don Fleming once in the past 18 months and that was in relation to his family and marital situation.
As can be seen my association with Don Fleming has been overwhelmingly for altruistic reasons rather than commercial.
My limited commercial association occurred when I was not a member or senator in Parliament.
I repeat that the assertions and the inferences presented in relation to me in the 7:30 Report are false and without foundation.

And lest the reference in the program to Kevin Mackey also having influential friends be inferred as relating to me, may I say that I have never met Kevin Mackey and indeed the only knowledge I have of him is what was presented on the 7.30 Report.
I have instructed my solicitor to write to the A.B.C. enclosing a copy of the statement I have made tonight.

I can only say in conclusion, that the ethics of the 7.30 report disappoint me, in their failure to approach me with assertions and inferences before going to air, especially when they claimed in the segment that they had approached a number of people to comment on the issues raised.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
